headline: Australia Revokes Medical Evacuations for Offshore Detainees
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Asylum, Right of', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: The government called the policy, enacted just 10 months ago, a “back door” to let refugees into the country. Human rights advocates denounced the repeal as shameful.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — The Australian Parliament on Wednesday repealed a law that had allowed refugees and asylum seekers being held offshore to seek emergency medical care in Australia, a reversal that human rights advocates denounced as cruel and shameful.

headline: Prominent Political Donors Charged in Campaign Finance Scheme

lead_paragraph: An influential political power broker who was a witness named in the Mueller report was among eight people charged with conspiring to conceal the source of excessive contributions to groups supporting Hillary Clinton’s 2016 presidential campaign, the Justice Department announced on Tuesday.

headline: Secrets of the Oldest Comedy Club Barker on Macdougal Street
abstract: There’s an art to comedy, and an art to selling tickets to comedy. This is a story about selling the tickets.
lead_paragraph: Six nights a week, Pete Burdette arrives on Macdougal Street wearing a Hawaiian shirt and wielding a clipboard. Out of respect for vaudeville tradition, he keeps a rubber chicken in his pocket.

headline: When Your Makeup Is the Party
keywords: ['Cosmetics and Toiletries', 'Women and Girls', 'Holidays and Special Occasions', 'your-feed-selfcare']
abstract: For all of the festive spirit of the season, you may still need a boost to get out the door. This makeup can help.
lead_paragraph: Rachel Goodwin, a makeup artist in Los Angeles, thinks we’re living through a rare makeup moment. “It hasn’t been this experimental since the 1980s,” she said.

headline: 25 Again? How Exercise May Fight Aging
abstract: The muscles of those who worked out looked like those of 25-year-olds and showed less of the inflammation that is tied to health problems as we age.
lead_paragraph: Regular exercise throughout adulthood may protect our muscles against age-related loss and damage later, according to an interesting new study of lifelong athletes and their thighs. The study finds that active older men’s muscles resemble, at a cellular level, those of 25-year-olds and weather inflammatory damage much better than the muscles of sedentary older people.

headline: This Woman Wants to Help Regulate Your Period With Food
abstract: Can dietary and lifestyle changes help women dealing with complex and confounding hormonal issues? Alisa Vitti thinks so.
lead_paragraph: A few months ago, in a conference room at the Yard, a co-working space in Manhattan, a group of female employees were updating their boss, Alisa Vitti, on their latest projects and the state of their hormones.

headline: T’s Holiday Issue: Past Perfect
abstract: One of art’s great privileges and responsibilities is to imagine lives that may not be written about in our textbooks.
lead_paragraph: “History is almost always written by the victors,” Jawaharlal Nehru famously wrote, and like most highly reductive, irresistibly catchy phrases, it’s not completely wrong. Of course, considering the arc of human existence as a series of scrimmages won or lost is problematic in a number of ways, chief among them the implication that life itself is something that can be measured quantifiably. Yet for centuries, we have been taught that there was a single, unified narrative: To the victor went the spoils, and the spoils were stories, annals of their feats and adventures.

headline: Men Say They Want Paid Leave but Then Don’t Use All of It. What Stops Them?
keywords: ['Paid Time Off', 'Family Leaves', 'Work-Life Balance', 'Men and Boys', 'Women and Girls', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: When balancing work and family becomes difficult, women tend to resort to caregiving and men to earning money.
lead_paragraph: Men today are as likely as women to say they need to have time off work to care for babies, aging parents or sick family members, new data show. Yet men are much less likely than women to actually take leave if it’s not paid — and even if it is paid, they take much shorter leaves than women do.

headline: How to Travel Car-Free With a Family
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Bicycles and Bicycling', 'Transit Systems', 'Buses', 'Children and Childhood', 'Sustainable Living']
abstract: In one writer’s experience, letting go of the wheel leads to happier travels, especially with children.
lead_paragraph: When I moved to New York and started a car-free travel blog in 2007, I was a recovering Los Angeles transplant, keen to ditch driving and atone for my environmental sins. I hiked the Appalachian Trail off the Metro-North train, surfed via the Queens-bound A subway and biked into the Hudson Valley from the Bronx’s South County Trailway. No car? No problem!

headline: Yes, Luis Scola Is Still Playing (Now in Milan)
abstract: This week’s newsletter catches up with Luis Scola, 39, to talk about how the N.B.A. has changed since he left two years ago and about his surprising World Cup silver medal as part of Argentina’s team.
lead_paragraph: Want more basketball in your inbox? Sign up for Marc Stein’s weekly N.B.A. newsletter here.

headline: These Cluster Bombs Started Killing Civilians Before They Left U.S. Soil
keywords: ['Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Cluster Munitions', 'Factories and Manufacturing']
abstract: In 1989, a BLU-97 cluster-munition bomblet exploded in a Kansas factory, killing two workers. Their fates were soon shared by American service members in the Persian Gulf War.
lead_paragraph: Inside the government-owned Kansas Army Ammunition Plant, hundreds of civilians worked in close quarters on the assembly lines. The plant, spread among a series of huge block buildings on a secure 14,000-acre site in Parsons, Kan., was one of the centers of production for America’s cluster munitions. It was 1989, and the Pentagon was still keeping arsenals filled for a potential war against the Soviet Union. Factories in other parts of the country made parts and pieces of the weapons, but in Parsons they all came together, a lethal product assuming final form.

headline: America’s Dark History of Killing Its Own Troops With Cluster Munitions
keywords: ['Cluster Munitions', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Iraq War (2003-11)', 'Civilian Casualties']
abstract: The weapons are notorious for their effects on civilians. But five years of reporting and hundreds of interviews have revealed they’ve also killed and wounded scores of Americans.
lead_paragraph: Staff Sgt. Michael S. Crick huddled in the howling wind and wrote in his diary. It was just past noon on Feb. 26, 1991, the third day of the American-led invasion of Iraq during the Persian Gulf war. The day before, a French and American force had seized As Salman airfield, an Iraqi military installation about 70 miles from the Saudi Arabian border.

headline: Pony Show Jumpers Deliver Big Thrills

lead_paragraph: Ponies may be small, but they deliver big thrills in the show-jumping ring. A highlight of the European winter equestrian shows, the Longines Masters of Paris, which starts on Thursday, will host a new class this year featuring pony jumpers.

headline: A Sleeper Agent Wanted to Cooperate. He Just Got 40 Years in Prison.
abstract: A man from Lebanon believed he would get leniency for providing information to the F.B.I. Instead, he was arrested on terrorism charges.
lead_paragraph: He was a Lebanese immigrant named Ali Kourani, and he told the F.B.I. that he was a sleeper agent for a terrorist organization. He said he was scouting targets in New York City for possible attacks, including airports and government offices, while leading a second life as a telephone salesman and family man.

headline: How Today’s Queer Artists Are Revising History
keywords: ['Art', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Books and Literature', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Writing and Writers', 'Photography']
abstract: By revisiting and refuting the cultural history of the West, this group is using time as its primary medium, looking backward to inform a different kind of gay future.
lead_paragraph: Two women and their baby stare straight at us from the American past. Jessie Evans-Whinery, as she is identified in the caption, looks a lot like Elvis, with the tousled pompadour and watchful eyes of a rebel in repose. Her dowdier wife, Edith Evans-Whinery, leans toward her in affection and probably exhaustion; she’s clearly the homemaker in this homesteading family in Pie Town, N.M., circa 1940. It’s she who holds the dirty baby with the quizzical expression and a finger in his ear. Is he confused?

headline: Kim Jong-un Visits Sacred Mountain on Horseback. Analysts Watch His Next Move.
keywords: ['Embargoes and Sanctions', 'ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The North Korean leader has often visited Mount Paektu, near the border with China, before making major policy shifts.

headline: What’s the Point of the Turner Prize, Anyway?
abstract: The prize’s winner-takes-all model, borrowed from book and film awards, sits uneasily with contemporary art.
lead_paragraph: It was a conclusion as sappy-sweet as the climax of “Mean Girls,” when Lindsay Lohan’s character breaks apart her homecoming queen tiara and divides the pieces among her classmates. Assembled in Margate, England, to discover the winner of the 2019 Turner Prize, members of the British art world discovered that the long-in-the-tooth award would go to … all four nominated artists.

headline: Is the Country Ready for a Gay President? Don’t Trust the Polls
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: Polls have a poor record on predicting behavior around social issues and disfavored groups.
lead_paragraph: As Pete Buttigieg, the openly gay mayor of South Bend, Ind., has surged to a top position in Iowa polls in the Democratic presidential primary, media reports have emerged warning that his sexuality may yet derail his White House bid. A recent national Politico/Morning Consult poll found that a plurality of voters, 45 percent, think the country is not ready for an openly gay president, with only 40 percent saying it’s ready. Consultants have chimed in to say the mayor may be less electable than coastal elites realize because he’s gay.

headline: Do Democrats Really Know Who Their Friends Are?
keywords: ['Organized Labor', 'Labor and Jobs', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Collective Bargaining', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Starting with Nancy Pelosi, many party leaders have failed to make labor enough of a priority, which hurts their coalition.
lead_paragraph: Organized labor is the lifeblood of liberal politics in the United States. Unions backed Franklin D. Roosevelt’s New Deal reforms, gave critical support to the fight for the Great Society and powered Democratic political victories throughout the 20th century. Even now, the Democratic Party is generally strongest in states where organized labor has the most influence.

headline: Democrats, Don’t Overreach on Impeachment
abstract: Like Nixon, Trump is accused of many things. But only one matters.
lead_paragraph: The summer of 1998 was not an auspicious time for me to start work as a young White House lawyer. I was in the Office of Legislative Affairs — but all legislative work had ground to a halt with President Bill Clinton facing impeachment in the House. Instead, we compiled a daily catalog of statements by members of Congress about Mr. Clinton’s actions and their possible consequences.

headline: The Best N.F.L. Trade of the Season? Look to Pittsburgh
abstract: After forcing his way out of Miami, Minkah Fitzpatrick has powered the Steelers’ surprising surge into contention.
lead_paragraph: PITTSBURGH — Minkah Fitzpatrick has always known that playing well gives him options. When he received dozens of scholarship offers in high school, he elected to play at Alabama because it was where he would develop most quickly. Then after his junior season, when the Crimson Tide won the second national title of his tenure and he was honored as college football’s best defensive player, Fitzpatrick entered the N.F.L. draft because he didn’t think he had anything more to prove.

headline: Germany Says Russia Is Suspected in Berlin Assassination
abstract: Germany’s federal prosecutor took over an inquiry into the murder of a former commander of Chechen separatists, and the authorities expelled two Russian diplomats.

abstract: Researchers wanted to improve the fruit yields for small farmers in Indonesia, and hope their findings will encourage protections for bats.

Although repulsive to many Western noses — some compare the smell to rotting trash — durians command the highest unit price of any fruit in Indonesia, with an export value of more than $250 million in 2013.

headline: Here Are the Key Members to Watch on the House Judiciary Committee
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Trump-Ukraine Whistle-blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry', 'Impeachment']
abstract: The panel has been involved with impeachment proceedings against three presidents. On Wednesday, Donald Trump will be the fourth.

It has either held or recommended impeachment proceedings against three presidents: Andrew Johnson, Richard M. Nixon and Bill Clinton.

headline: In Syria, Health Workers Risk Becoming ‘Enemies of the State’
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Detainees', 'Geneva Conventions', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'your-feed-visual-investigations']
abstract: Physicians for Human Rights corroborates claims that Bashar al-Assad’s government has criminalized giving care to its enemies, a violation of international law.
lead_paragraph: The nearly 9-year-old conflict in Syria has been punctuated by repeated violations of what is considered acceptable in war, including the military’s use of chemical weapons, torture of prisoners and recurrent bombings of hospitals in rebel-held areas. Less attention has been paid to another outcome: the government’s criminalization of medical care.

headline: James Harden Dunked It. Ruling: No Basket.

lead_paragraph: James Harden rose for an uncontested dunk. It went into the basket with great downward force, as so many of his others have before. Then came an apparent violation of some of the fundamental laws of physics.

headline: The Year’s Best Pastry Cookbooks
abstract: Melissa Clark has rounded up 2019’s finest, and naturally brought back four fine recipes for you to make this week.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. My friend Kurt makes the cornbread dressing we eat every year on Thanksgiving, has done so for 20 years, and for each and every one of them he’s made enough to feed an army. Leftover dressing is a highlight of my post-Thanksgiving nights, well into this week.

headline: Hundreds of Thousands Are Losing Access to Food Stamps

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration, brushing aside tens of thousands of protest letters, gave final approval on Wednesday to a rule that will remove nearly 700,000 people from the federal food-stamp program by strictly enforcing federal work requirements.

headline: Kelly Loeffler Will Fill Georgia Senate Seat, Setting Up a Clash With Trump
abstract: The appointment of Ms. Loeffler, a politically untested businesswoman, pits Gov. Brian Kemp against President Trump and his allies, who had lobbied for a different candidate.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Brian Kemp of Georgia on Wednesday appointed Kelly Loeffler, a politically untested business executive, to fill a soon-to-be-vacated United States Senate seat in the state. The move put the governor at odds with President Trump, who had lobbied for a different candidate.

headline: A New Hotel Embraces Kyoto’s Old Soul
abstract: The Park Hyatt Kyoto is perfectly at home amid the city’s teahouses, centuries-old dwellings and Edo-era temples.
lead_paragraph: Though Kyoto hasn’t been Japan’s imperial seat for over 150 years, it remains one of the best places to glimpse the country’s ancient soul. By day, visitors and pilgrims flock to the Higashiyama district, which sits just beneath the mountains on the eastern side of the city, for its temples and teahouses. Particularly charming is Ninenzaka Street, a sloping lane lined with machiya — centuries-old dwellings with clay roof tiles and latticed wood doors — and the new 70-room Park Hyatt Kyoto, which is situated between the street and an Edo-era temple. The hotel group might be famous for the three-towered skyscraper housing its Tokyo location, but here you’ll find a low-ceilinged, tile-roofed arrival house, as well as airy guest rooms with tamo wood floors and windows for walls. “It was important for us not to compete with the rich history of Kyoto but to bring some of it indoors,” says the general manager, Mark De Leeuwerk. Throughout the property are artworks and design elements by local craftspeople, including gold-leaf trim done by a 106-year-old artisan and, in the hotel bistro, earthenware by a 16th-generation potter. Another restaurant, Yasaka, offers heartier fare, from grilled shrimp to savory pancakes, prepared on the traditional steel hot plates known as teppan.

headline: I Oversaw Executions. We Cannot Resume the Federal Death Penalty.
keywords: ['Capital Punishment', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Federal-State Relations (US)']
abstract: The system has too many flaws for the Trump administration to carry out the executions it has scheduled for Monday.
lead_paragraph: I have seen the death penalty up close. During my years as Ohio’s Republican attorney general, I oversaw 18 executions. Before that, I helped write the state’s death penalty law as a legislator. I’ve heard all the justifications — deterrence, support for victims, cost savings. And I know now they are all wrong, and those misguided arguments act as a smoke screen for the profound flaws that mark capital punishment.

headline: French Strikes Are a Fresh Test for Macron
keywords: ['Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Yellow Vests Movement', 'Politics and Government', 'Strikes', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: The walkout by a broad range of workers threatens to paralyze France for several days, calling into question the president’s apparent quelling of the “Yellow Vest” movement.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — President Emmanuel Macron is facing his biggest test since the “Yellow Vest” uprising shook his presidency a year ago, as unions representing railway and transportation workers and many others in the public sector called for a mass walkout on Thursday to protest changes to France’s uniquely generous pension system.

headline: $2.3 Million Homes in Pennsylvania, New Mexico and Illinois

The nearest SEPTA station is a two-minute walk, and the train trip south to downtown Philadelphia takes less than 30 minutes.

abstract: The average American and Australian generates nearly 3½ times the global average of carbon dioxide pollution.
lead_paragraph: The Trump administration recently began the formal process of withdrawing from the Paris climate agreement, citing “the unfair economic burden imposed on American workers, businesses and taxpayers” by the United States’ pledge to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. Australia’s prime minister, Scott Morrison, expressed similar sentiments: “Australia won’t write a blank check with its economy” to fight climate change, “which requires action from around the globe.”

Giuliani’s role in the pressure campaign against the Ukrainian government that is at the heart of the impeachment inquiry, Mr. Giuliani has been in Europe continuing his efforts to shift the focus to purported wrongdoing by President Trump’s political rivals.

headline: How Watching ‘Jeopardy!’ Together Helped Me Say Goodbye to My Father
abstract: Every night, as my father was dying, we made the show a ritual. Then Alex Trebek announced that he was sick, too.
lead_paragraph: When my father was dying — when the reality of his decline seemed to be pressing us into the center of the earth, and every day felt suddenly crucial — we started a new ritual: watching “Jeopardy!” together. We watched in person when we could, but we lived 3,000 miles apart, so more often it was over FaceTime. I would call at 7 p.m. My father had lost much of his motor control by then, but he could still answer his phone and wave a weak hello. Out of his TV would come the “Jeopardy!” theme song — a bright, compulsively hummable tone poem designed to make you feel as if you were reading an encyclopedia while bouncing on a trampoline.

headline: Why the Great Auk Is Gone for Good
keywords: ['Birds', 'Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Conservation of Resources', 'Genetics and Heredity', 'Research', 'your-feed-science']
abstract: New research finds that the extinction of this flightless bird was completely our fault.
lead_paragraph: Not so long ago, the northern seas were full of great auks. Every summer, millions of the two-toned, goose-sized birds would gather at different breeding grounds across the North Atlantic. The flightless birds were easy to capture, and passing sailors loved how they tasted.

headline: A Design Dealer Who Lives Among His Wares
abstract: Rhett Baruch has transformed his compact Los Angeles apartment into a showroom for the colorful, unconventional items that he sells.
lead_paragraph: A humdrum exterior belies the artfully wacky world behind the doors of Rhett Baruch’s home in Los Angeles. While the building — a stuccoed two-story structure set on the border of Koreatown and Westlake — is fairly unremarkable, Baruch has transformed his 1,200-square-foot second-floor apartment into an ever-evolving series of colorful vignettes; a burl-wood console in the style of the Dutch de Stijl designer Gerrit Rietveld might be paired with a lumpy ceramic étagère by the Los Angeles-based artist Emilie Carroll, or the sensual curves of a Flemming Lassen chair could be offset by an amoeba-like neon sculpture (called “Blooops”) from Alina Hayes. A collector and dealer of contemporary art and design, Baruch uses the space as a de facto showroom, a place to display beguiling curios and whimsical home décor for the benefit of clients, though of course he also takes personal pleasure in living among eccentric and beautiful things.

headline: Review: ‘Barber Shop Chronicles’ Offers an Exhilarating Sanctuary

lead_paragraph: The earth is a planet built for speed in “Barber Shop Chronicles,” which burst open at the Brooklyn Academy of Music’s Harvey Theater on Tuesday in an intoxicating cloud of adrenaline and talcum powder. Watching Inua Ellams’s globe-girdling, London-born play, you feel the world spinning so fast that you half expect its far-flung inhabitants to slide across continents and fall into one another’s laps.

headline: ‘The Crying Book’ Follows the Many Tracks of Our Tears
abstract: Heather Christle’s peculiar and indelible book bounces between observations about the causes and uses of the tears we shed.
lead_paragraph: The lachrymatory, a vaselike receptacle used to collect mourners’ tears and purportedly found in Roman tombs, has made a strange resurgence in the second decade of the 21st century, albeit in a form better suited to late capitalism: the coffee mug. Whether you’re looking to consume “MALE TEARS” or “LIBERAL TEARS” or “BILLIONAIRE TEARS,” chances are you can find an appropriate vessel.

headline: New York Art Galleries: What to See Right Now
abstract: Alina Szapocznikow’s bits of body; Nathalie Djurberg and Hans Berg’s triggering Claymation; Sonya Kelliher-Combs’s poignant picturing of abuse; and Amy Brener’s urethane goddesses.
lead_paragraph: The piece that opens the exhibition “To Exalt the Ephemeral: Alina Szapocznikow, 1962-1972,” Hauser & Wirth’s thorough and enthralling first show of the artist’s work since beginning to represent her estate last year, is an untitled plaster cast of her mouth. Rough edges frame the philtrum, chin and bits of cheek around her lips, and the piece rests on a spindly plaster stem that descends a couple of inches to a broader foot.

headline: Review: The Tap Dancer Dormeshia Finds Her Groove, and Then Some
abstract: In the stellar “And Still You Must Swing” at the Joyce Theater, she is joined by Jason Samuels Smith, Derick K. Grant and Camille A. Brown.
lead_paragraph: Dance relies on technique, but if that’s all there is, a performance loses its dimension; its energy fizzles out. There are many points to be made about an excellent show like “And Still You Must Swing,” led by Dormeshia, a tap dancer of exceptional elegance, dazzling speed and, yes, an abundance of technique. But above all, at its foundation, there is heart and conviction. And, mission accomplished: It swings.

And many more political ones — even if those who have been running one of the world’s most powerful companies continued to think of themselves as benign, long after it was clear to everyone else that they were many things but that.

headline: A Graffiti Museum Where the Writers Are in Charge
abstract: The Museum of Graffiti, the first of its kind, opens in Miami with a ticktock history of the art form’s early development
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — When Alan Ket was a teenager growing up in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn in the 1980s, he fell hard for the graffiti that still decorated New York City trains. Sometimes he was the one painting, but more often, he was a detective, figuring out the best locations to snap pictures of the art. On weekends, he’d meet up with friends at a one-hour photo shop on Canal St. to trade negatives and prints of the graffiti photos they’d taken that week.

headline: The American Health Care Industry Is Killing People
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Opioids and Opiates', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)']
abstract: Yes, transitioning to a more equitable system might eliminate some jobs. But the status quo is morally untenable.
lead_paragraph: Won’t you spare a thought for America’s medical debt collectors? And while you’re at it, will you say a prayer for the nation’s health care billing managers? Let’s also consider the kindly, economically productive citizens in swing states whose job it is to jail pregnant women and the parents of cancer patients for failing to pay their radiology bills. Put yourself in the entrepreneurial shoes of the friendly hospital administrator who has found a lucrative new revenue stream: filing thousands of lawsuits to garnish sick people’s wages.

headline: Do Voters Even Care About the Articles of Impeachment?
abstract: Everyone knows what Trump did. The Democrats shouldn’t draw out the process any longer than necessary.
lead_paragraph: Day 1 of the House Judiciary Committee phase of the impeachment hearings is just about over, and we’ve been reminded that however historic such hearings are, they’re not always riveting. Republican histrionics aside, legal scholars expounding on constitutional jurisprudence don’t pack quite the punch that Fiona Hill did.

headline: Sara Mearns and Caleb Teicher to Debut Shows at the Joyce
abstract: The theater’s coming season will also include the second installment of its Pride Festival and its first presentation of the Paul Taylor Dance Company.
lead_paragraph: Sara Mearns and Caleb Teicher, two of the most important young figures in New York dance, will stage productions at the Joyce Theater next summer. Ms. Mearns, a principal New York City Ballet dancer, will perform a collaborative and eclectic program that charts her explorations outside of ballet. Mr. Teicher, a choreographer, will debut a new swing dance piece called “Swing 2020.”

headline: Adam Sandler Is Betting the N.B.A. (and Knicks) Can Take a Joke
abstract: A new movie uses an N.B.A. playoff as the backdrop for Sandler’s gambling character, a mix the league once would have run from.
lead_paragraph: Adam Sandler is a devoted Knicks fan, which seems improbable for someone who moved to New England from Brooklyn at age 5 and so grew up deep in Boston Celtics country during the genesis of the Larry Bird era. He offers no reasonable explanation for this paradox beyond the retrospective admission that he foolishly chose the wrong partisan path.

headline: Inside The World of Interiors, Condé Nast’s Secret Weapon
abstract: The gold-standard shelter magazine runs on a brass-tacks budget and refuses to kowtow to the internet.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — To be a magazine reader these days is to lament — unless you are reading The World of Interiors, published since 1982 by Condé Nast Britain but widely available on American newsstands, where it sells for $9.99 per issue.

headline: Steve Cohen in Talks to Buy Majority of Mets From Wilpons
abstract: The deal with Mr. Cohen, a billionaire hedge fund manager, would represent a significant change in the New York sports landscape.
lead_paragraph: Steven A. Cohen, a minority investor in the Mets, is negotiating with the Wilpon family to purchase a controlling stake in the team, according to two people close to the negotiations.

headline: Impeachment Hearing Highlights
keywords: ['Trump-Ukraine Whistle-blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry', 'Impeachment', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Three law experts called by Democrats on the House Judiciary Committee and one called by Republicans provided contrasting judgments of the case for impeachment against President Trump.
lead_paragraph: Three law experts called by Democrats on the House Judiciary Committee and one called by Republicans provided contrasting judgments of the case for impeachment against President Trump.

headline: Carolyn Konheim, Foe of All That Befouled a City, Dies at 81
abstract: Finding her sons’ clothes speckled with soot, a history teacher was transformed into an influential New York environmentalist with pollution in her sights.
lead_paragraph: Carolyn Konheim, whose sons’ soot-specked white snow suits transformed her from a high school history teacher into a crusading New York environmentalist who targeted water and air pollutants, congested streets and other scourges of modern urban life, died on Nov. 25 at her home in Brooklyn. She was 81.

headline: Key Excerpts From Legal Scholars’ Arguments on Impeachment
abstract: The House Judiciary Committee kicked off its first hearing with testimony from four experts on constitutional law. We examined their opening statements.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The four law professors who testified before a House panel on Wednesday, three invited by Democrats and one by Republicans, gave an overview of the history of impeachment, the practical justifications for it and their views on whether President Trump’s conduct in the Ukraine affair warranted it.

headline: ‘Knives and Skin’ Review: ‘Twin Peaks’ Redux? Not Quite
abstract: While it has some genuine eeriness, the similarities to David Lynch’s work give the impression of a secondhand sensibility.
lead_paragraph: It is manifestly unfair to compare the work of a near-universally admired auteur to an odd, ambitious independent film, but “Knives and Skin” owes so much to David Lynch, particularly “Twin Peaks,” that it feels wrong to pretend it exists in a vacuum.

headline: Modern Love Podcast: Ruth Wilson Reads ‘Never Tell Our Business to Strangers’
abstract: The star of “The Affair” reads an essay about familial loyalty, love and identity.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: Via Apple Podcasts | Via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher

headline: Eight Highlights From Miami Art Week
abstract: A tribute to Miami’s queer culture, meditations on climate change — and more not to be missed at this year’s constellation of art and design fairs.
lead_paragraph: Miami Art Week is the most densely packed event on the art world calendar. At the center of the week’s festivities each year is Art Basel Miami Beach, which celebrates its 18th edition this month with a roster of 269 international galleries. Satellite fairs include NADA, Untitled, Design Miami, Pinta and Pulse, and, of course, there are the city’s private and public museums, such as Rubell Family Collection, the Bass and Pérez Art Museum Miami (PAMM), which will open their most anticipated shows of the year. With so much to see, there’s always a risk of missing something. Here are eight highlights to put on your list.

headline: With Internal Squabbling on Vivid Display, What’s Next for NATO?
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT']
abstract: The alliance might not be suffering “brain death” but it faces new technologies, new rivals, new weapons and a changing America.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — When President Trump left the NATO gathering early and in a huff on Wednesday, it only reinforced the fear that with America distracted and retreating, the West’s celebrated alliance has lost focus.

headline: Biden Proposes Smaller Tax Increases Than Rivals Do
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Corporate Taxes', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Capital Gains Tax', 'Taxation', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Tax Cuts and Jobs Act (2017)', 'Corporations', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'Income Inequality']
abstract: His set of tax plans would ask the highest earners to pay more to fund a smaller-scale expansion of government than those proposed by other leading Democrats.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Democratic presidential candidate Joseph R. Biden Jr. would raise taxes on high earners and corporations by at least $3.4 trillion over the course of a decade if elected, his campaign said Wednesday, releasing a set of plans that are far less aggressive than his more liberal rivals’.

headline: Trump Fired Him. Now California Has Made Him a Homelessness Adviser.
abstract: Matthew Doherty had clashed with the president’s team over potential interventions in the state, which has half of the country’s unsheltered homeless people.
lead_paragraph: A homelessness official fired by the Trump administration last month amid a dispute over White House proposals to address California’s homeless population was hired on Wednesday to advise the state’s governor, who has repeatedly clashed with the president.

headline: Joe Smith, Career-Making Record Executive, Is Dead at 91
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Pop and Rock Music', 'Audio Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: He spanned musical eras in presiding, all told, over three major labels, nurturing acts from Peter, Paul and Mary to the Grateful Dead to Queen.
lead_paragraph: Joe Smith, who presided over three major record companies in a career that stretched from the early days of rock ’n’ roll to the CD boom of the 1990s, died on Monday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 91.

headline: Howard Cruse Dies at 75; His Cartoons Explored Gay Life
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Comic Books and Strips', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Cartoons and Cartoonists', 'Graphic Novels']
abstract: He described his experiences as a gay man in a comic strip and an acclaimed semi-autobiographical graphic novel, influencing many other cartoonists.
lead_paragraph: Howard Cruse, a gay underground cartoonist who mined his life in “Wendel,” a comic strip that ran for several years in The Advocate, and “Stuck Rubber Baby,” a poignant graphic novel set in the South in the 1960s, died on Nov. 26 in Pittsfield, Mass. He was 75.

headline: Josie Rubio, 42, Dies; Wrote of Dating While Terminally Ill
keywords: ['Writing and Writers', 'Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Dating and Relationships', 'Blogs and Blogging (Internet)']
abstract: Her essay in The New York Times drew a wide readership; she also chronicled her life with terminal cancer in a blog, finding humor amid despair.
lead_paragraph: Josie Rubio, an editor and writer who chronicled her life with cancer in a long-running blog and whose Op-Ed essay in The New York Times in August about dating while terminally ill drew a wide readership, died on Tuesday at a hospice facility in Brooklyn. She was 42.

headline: How the Devils’ Season Went Wrong
abstract: Blown leads, low scoring, goaltending woes and unmet expectations led to the firing of Coach John Hynes.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — Ray Shero had been the Devils’ general manager for less than a month when he announced in June 2015 that John Hynes would be his head coach. Hynes was 40 and had no N.H.L. head-coaching experience, but he’d worked for Shero in Pittsburgh.

headline: China’s Genetic Research on Ethnic Minorities Sets Off Science Backlash
keywords: ['Minorities', 'Uighurs (Chinese Ethnic Group)', 'Genetics and Heredity', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Facial Recognition Software', 'Forensic Science', 'DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid)', 'Research', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Biometrics', 'Academic and Scientific Journals']
abstract: Scientists are raising questions about the ethics of studies backed by Chinese surveillance agencies. Prestigious journals are taking action.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — China’s efforts to study the DNA of the country’s ethnic minorities have incited a growing backlash from the global scientific community, as a number of scientists warn that Beijing could use its growing knowledge to spy on and oppress its people.

headline: How the ‘Babe Ruth of Cookies’ Brought Us a Dozen Dazzling Holiday Recipes
abstract: Susan Spungen, multihyphenate cookie whiz, spent months conceiving and developing unique recipes for a special section.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: Impeachment, NATO, Cookies: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: NASA’s Parker Solar Probe Is Unlocking the Sun’s Mysteries
abstract: Scientists working with the solar diving mission have released the spacecraft’s first batch of findings.
lead_paragraph: Since it launched last year, NASA’s Parker Solar Probe has made three dives toward the sun as it reached the fastest speed ever clocked by a human-built vehicle. Scientists released the mission’s first batch of findings on Wednesday, revealing that the dynamics of our star are even weirder than once imagined.

headline: Why There Won’t Be a Black Woman Running for President
abstract: Kamala Harris’s campaign had its flaws, but we can’t let liberal biases go unchecked.
lead_paragraph: When Senator Kamala Harris of California entered the race for the Democratic presidential nomination in January, many believed she would be hard to beat. Telegenic, highly educated and from a multiethnic background, she would have been an ideal candidate in the pre-Obama era. We expected her to create an All-American narrative that is relatable to a wide cross-section of the country; that’s how President Barack Obama ascended in 2004. But Ms. Harris failed to do that.

headline: Netanyahu and Pompeo Seek Heightened Pressure on Iran in Wake of Violent Protests
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Palestinians']
abstract: A meeting between Secretary of State Mike Pompeo and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu was also expected to gauge American support for Israeli annexation in the Jordan Valley.
lead_paragraph: LISBON, Portugal — Protests in Iran and elsewhere in the Middle East prompted Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and Secretary of State Mike Pompeo to hold hastily planned talks on Wednesday, aimed at ramping up pressure on Tehran and reducing its sprawling influence in the region.

headline: Baseball Free Agency: Power Starts Shifting Back to Players
abstract: Two big deals were reached on Wednesday, part of a pattern that suggested a substantial change from the quiet market of recent winters.
lead_paragraph: Baseball free agency will never unfold as it does in the N.B.A., where the players largely fit into predetermined salary slots. In baseball, the players’ union has fought to preserve a market that develops organically, with real competition for free agents and no hard caps on salaries.

headline: Billy Dee Williams Says Pronoun Use Did Not Mean ‘Gender-Fluid’
abstract: In a recent interview with Esquire, the actor said he used “himself” and “herself,” widely taken to mean that he had embraced gender-fluid pronouns.
lead_paragraph: Billy Dee Williams recently told Esquire magazine that he uses both male and female pronouns to refer to himself. “I say ‘himself’ and ‘herself,’ because I also see myself as feminine as well as masculine,” said Williams, who is known for playing Lando Calrissian in the “Star Wars” universe. “I think of myself as a relatively colorful character who doesn’t take himself or herself too seriously.”

headline: Diabetes in Mothers Raises Heart Risks in Children
abstract: Risks were especially high for heart failure, high blood pressure and blood clots among children born to mothers with diabetes.
lead_paragraph: The children of mothers with diabetes may be at increased risk for early heart disease.

headline: Would You Consider Living on Roosevelt Island? Two Newcomers Look There for the ‘Flow of Life’
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)']
abstract: A California couple, bored with life in Palo Alto, search for a new home across the country. Here’s where they wound up.
lead_paragraph: A California couple, bored with life in Palo Alto, search for a new home across the country. Here’s where they wound up.

headline: Iran Is Secretly Moving Missiles Into Iraq, U.S. Officials Say
keywords: ['Missiles and Missile Defense Systems', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services']
abstract: The buildup of a hidden arsenal of short-range missiles is the latest sign that American efforts to deter Iran have largely failed.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Iran has used the continuing chaos in Iraq to build up a hidden arsenal of short-range ballistic missiles in Iraq, part of a widening effort to try to intimidate the Middle East and assert its power, according to American intelligence and military officials.

headline: For Democrats, #DebatesSoWhite
abstract: The 2020 Democratic field was historically diverse. But the next debate won’t look like it.
lead_paragraph: We’ve talked a lot in this newsletter about the historic diversity of the Democratic primary campaign. At its peak, the field boasted six women, two black senators, a Latino former cabinet secretary, an American Samoan member of Congress and an Asian-American businessman.

headline: Pantone Declares Another Year of Blue
abstract: Can the latest color of the year help people feel better? Or just help sell a lot of stuff?
lead_paragraph: The people at Pantone know that times are hard.

headline: Trump Administration Moves to Upgrade Diplomatic Ties With Sudan
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Terrorism', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates']
abstract: The two nations agreed to exchange ambassadors for the first time in 23 years. But the State Department is keeping Sudan on a list of state sponsors of terrorism.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States said on Wednesday that it would begin exchanging ambassadors with Sudan after a 23-year gap, a sign the countries intend to strengthen diplomatic ties.

headline: Venezuelans’ Struggle to Survive, Told in Pictures
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Photography', 'Malnutrition', 'Famine', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Birth Control and Family Planning']
abstract: Residents in the nation’s slums suffer with the economy’s collapse.
lead_paragraph: To visit Venezuela today is to see how misrule can shatter a country. Years of corrupt, incompetent and autocratic rule have left Venezuelans hungry and children dying for want of basic medical care. Daniela Serrano, above, lost a child this year to malnutrition and now watches apprehensively as her daughter, Daryelis, 3, undergoes a health exam at a clinic affiliated with an aid group, Proyecto Nodriza. Some Venezuelans fear that famine lies ahead, and it seems easier to find supporters of President Nicolás Maduro on an American university campus than in Venezuela itself. Words can’t capture the misery, so I’m giving my column space over to photos of people I met on a recent visit. People were willing to be photographed and share their stories so that the world could understand what their country is enduring.

headline: He Waited 6 Hours for Help at Rikers. Then He Tried to Hang Himself.
abstract: Nicholas Feliciano, 18, had a history of suicide attempts, but Rikers jail guards failed to act for seven minutes when he tried to kill himself.
lead_paragraph: The guards brought the 18-year-old detainee with a gashed lip into a special holding cell the night before Thanksgiving. He had been injured after a fight with seven other inmates and was being transferred to an urgent care facility on Rikers Island.

headline: Iran’s Leaders Soften Stance on Protesters
abstract: In an apparent attempt to ease anger over the killing and arrest of protesters, senior leaders urged leniency and promised compensation for peaceful demonstrators who died.
lead_paragraph: Faced with a simmering fury in the country, Iran’s leaders on Wednesday abruptly softened their stance toward street protests that are believed to have left hundreds of civilians dead last month, the most lethal crackdown since the 1979 revolution.

headline: Hair Dyes and Straighteners May Raise Breast Cancer Risk for Black Women
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Breast Cancer', 'Hair', 'Dyes and Dyestuffs', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'your-feed-healthcare']
abstract: A new study finds a weak link between coloring and straightening treatments and breast cancer. But experts caution the results are far from certain.
lead_paragraph: For decades, scientists have debated whether hair dyes frequently used by women might contribute to cancer. The research has been mixed and inconclusive, but now government investigators have turned up a disturbing new possibility.

headline: The Impeachment Show Fleshes Out Its Back Story
keywords: ['Trump-Ukraine Whistle-blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry', 'Television', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The congressional saga returned to TV, shifting modes from foreign-intrigue thriller to constitutional documentary.
lead_paragraph: More and more often, absorbing TV serials don’t just stand on their own. There are ancillary shows, explainers, deep dives for the superfans. The HBO mini-series “Chernobyl” inspired a successful podcast exploring the history behind the dramatized events. “The Walking Dead,” “Game of Thrones” and Bravo’s reality series  have inspired talk shows devoted to analyzing and theorizing about them.

headline: What Kamala Harris’s Campaign Teaches Us
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Debates (Political)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: It is worth exploring the election system in this country and who benefits from it.
lead_paragraph: Kamala Harris entered the presidential race with a bang.

headline: How Google’s Founders Slowly Stepped Away From Their Company
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Search Engines', 'Driverless and Semiautonomous Vehicles', 'Android (Operating System)', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: Larry Page and Sergey Brin became billionaires thanks to the success of Google. But toward the end, they appeared happy to let someone else run it.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — About a month after Donald J. Trump was elected president in 2016, Larry Page, the Google co-founder, was summoned along with other prominent tech executives to a meeting at Trump Tower.

headline: ‘Midnight Family’ Review: The Night Stalkers of Mexico City
abstract: In this outstanding documentary, a family of emergency medical workers struggles both to save lives and to make a living.
lead_paragraph: Periodically while watching “Midnight Family” you feel as if you can’t look at the screen for another second. But you can’t look away either. That tension encapsulates the push-pull of this documentary, a haunting portrait of a family of emergency medical workers in Mexico City. Because as you tag along on another wild nighttime ride, and yet one more life-or-death race, the family’s careening ambulance seems like an emblem both of their reality and of your own whiplashing position as a viewer.

keywords: ['Military Bases and Installations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']

lead_paragraph: HONOLULU — A United States sailor opened fire at the Pearl Harbor Naval Shipyard on Wednesday, fatally shooting two shipyard workers and injuring another before killing himself, the authorities said.

headline: Kamala Decamps, Iowa’s Still Crowded, Trump’s Still Trump
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: For Democrats, it’s Des Moines for the holidays.
lead_paragraph: Kamala Harris is out! This is big news. The Democratic presidential field is shrinking. We’ve got only 15 people left. Twenty-six fewer than the House Judiciary Committee. Smaller than the cast of “Saturday Night Live.” Although sometimes more entertaining.

headline: Corrections: Dec. 5, 2019
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, Dec. 5, 2019.
lead_paragraph: An article on Wednesday about Rudolph W. Giuliani’s call records, because of an error in the Democrats’ impeachment report, gave an incorrect date for a conversation between Secretary of State Mike Pompeo and Mr. Giuliani. The call was on March 29, not March 28.

headline: Mocked Abroad and Assailed at Home, Trump Returns to Face Impeachment
abstract: Two days in London on the world stage provided him no respite.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When times turn tough, presidents can hop on Air Force One to escape the country for a while and stride purposefully across the world stage. But the world stage was not so friendly this week for President Trump, who landed back in Washington on Wednesday night to confront a grim couple of weeks ahead.

headline: Huawei Sues the F.C.C., Ramping Up Fight With Critics and Foes
abstract: The commission took aim last month at the Chinese tech giant’s sales to telecom carriers in rural America.
lead_paragraph: SHENZHEN, China — Huawei, the Chinese technology powerhouse, is suing the Federal Communications Commission for choking off its sales in the United States, the latest in the besieged company’s widening efforts to hit back at regulators and critics across the globe.

headline: Review: Facing Life’s Final Stretch in ‘Harry Townsend’s Last Stand’
abstract: George Eastman’s Off Broadway play is lifted by its direction and performances, but often feels like a cornball sitcom.
lead_paragraph: The reception of any play, film or song can vary greatly depending on the audience’s age. But this difference could peak at the new show “Harry Townsend’s Last Stand.”

headline: Treat With the Identical Color Scheme As This Puzzle
abstract: Neville Fogarty returns my childhood to me.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY PUZZLE — Rebus puzzles can come in all shapes and sizes. In crossword puzzle solving, we tend to think of them as elements that requires us to squeeze more than one letter into a single square, (For those of you just joining us: Yes, that’s a thing, and you can even do it on your devices) or perhaps insert a symbol.

headline: Anti-Semitic Imagery Could Cost Belgian Carnival Its UNESCO Status
abstract: As the United Nations agency considers whether to rescind the cultural heritage designation, a city’s mayor has tried to renounce the honor.
lead_paragraph: The city of Aalst, Belgium, faces the prospect of an unheard-of demotion: A decade after declaring its Carnival celebrations a valued cultural expression, UNESCO could revoke that designation over anti-Semitic imagery that has been part of the revelry.

abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, December 5, 2019.
lead_paragraph: “This isn’t improvisational jazz — close enough is not good enough.”

headline: NATO, France, Global Heat: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: President Trump left NATO’s anniversary celebrations in London early and on the defensive after lashing out over a video that caught Canada’s prime minister and other world leaders apparently venting about him at a reception.

headline: Tekashi69 Is Praised by Prosecutors, Who Urge a Lenient Sentence
abstract: His cooperation with the government led hip-hop fans and other rappers to call him a snitch and a fraud.
lead_paragraph: The rapper Tekashi69 was a star government witness at the trial of two men who were accused of being members of his former crew, the Nine Trey Gangsta Bloods, and who were ultimately convicted on racketeering conspiracy charges.

headline: Threats and Abuse on Campaign Trail: A Grim Reality for U.K. Female Candidates
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Elections', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'Threats and Threatening Messages', 'Cyberharassment']
abstract: This is politics in a climate of fear and intimidation: Inconspicuous offices with no campaign posters and multiple security cameras. No canvassing after dark. Death threats.
lead_paragraph: LEEDS, England — The campaign office is deliberately inconspicuous — tucked above a salon through an unmarked doorway in a 1970s-era shopping center. There are no campaign posters in the windows. Two cameras are trained on the entrance. The door frame was recently reinforced.

headline: How to Pluck a Feather
abstract: Hold the bird in your sterilized, nondominant hand. Gently pull out two feathers, six in from each side of the tail’s underside.
lead_paragraph: “It’s easier than pulling out a hair from your chin,” says Kristen Ruegg, an assistant professor of biology at Colorado State University. Ruegg is a director at the Bird Genoscape Project, which oversees a collection of more than 200,000 bird feathers used by scientists to extract genetic material and better understand where birds go, what makes them vulnerable and how they might survive a changing climate. Nearly a third of all North American birds, some three billion, have vanished since 1970, and biologists are calling for urgent action to avoid “future avifaunal collapse.”

headline: Palettes Are What Every Teen Wants for the Holidays
keywords: ['Cosmetics and Toiletries', 'Teenagers and Adolescence', 'Social Media', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: How did eye shadow become the most sought-after item on high schoolers’ wish lists?
lead_paragraph: In early November, teenagers across America were sent into a frenzy over makeup.

headline: Texas Judge Blocks Construction of Private Border Wall, for Now
abstract: A Hidalgo County judge ruled that the privately built wall on the banks of the Rio Grande would pose “irreparable harm” to a nearby butterfly conservancy.
lead_paragraph: A Texas judge granted a temporary restraining order this week to the opponents of a crowdfunded project to build part of President Trump’s border wall, siding with a butterfly conservancy that sued over its projected environmental impact.

headline: What’s on TV Thursday: ‘Gone Girl’ and a New Holiday Favorite
abstract: David Fincher’s eerie drama is on FXM. And the third part of a Christmastime trilogy premieres on Netflix.
lead_paragraph: GONE GIRL (2014) 7:40 p.m. on FXM. Ben Affleck stars in this drama as Nick Dunne, a small-town Midwestern man who comes home one day to find his wife, Amy (Rosamund Pike), missing. Nick becomes a suspect in her disappearance, with the only evidence as to Amy’s whereabouts coming from her diary entries. These detail the deterioration of her marriage and her fear of her husband. And while Nick maintains his innocence, it becomes clear that Amy may not be a reliable narrator. Based on the 2012 novel by Gillian Flynn, who also wrote the screenplay, “Gone Girl” is “a ghastly vision,” Manohla Dargis wrote in her New York Times review. Dargis added that the director, David Fincher, “fashions an ever more haunted, haunting world that wavers so violently between ordinariness and aberration that, as in his other movies, the two soon blur.”

headline: Word + Quiz: turgid
abstract: This word has appeared in 12 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year.

headline: A New Evita Rises in Argentina
abstract: Cristina Fernández de Kirchner’s brand of feminism isn’t actually designed to empower other women — only herself.
lead_paragraph: Turning Point: In October, voters in Argentina returned the Peronist party to power.

headline: Did FIFA Accidentally Confirm a World Cup Bribery Scandal?
abstract: Qatar has for years been dogged by accusations that a corrupt vote delivered the 2022 World Cup. Now, world soccer’s governing body may have inadvertently supported those claims.
lead_paragraph: Confirmation of one of the worst scandals in soccer history appears to be sitting in plain sight, published last week on the website of FIFA, the sport’s global governing body.

headline: Working at Equinox: ‘It’s Very Hunger Games’
keywords: ['Health Clubs', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Work-Life Balance', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Exercise']
abstract: Working for the high-end gym chain seems glamorous, but for many trainers the schedule is unforgiving, the pay low and the turnover high.
lead_paragraph: Equinox, the high-end gym chain, calls its five-story facility on Greenwich Avenue in Manhattan a “fitness mecca.” It features a juice bar and a boxing studio, a eucalyptus steam room and a saltwater lap pool.

headline: The Epic Rise and Hard Fall of New York’s Taxi King
keywords: ['Taxicabs and Taxicab Drivers', 'Politics and Government', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Tax Evasion']
abstract: Ferraris. Villas on the French Riviera. Tax fraud. No one embodies the  spectacular collapse of New York’s taxi industry more than Gene Freidman.
lead_paragraph: The man known as the Taxi King arrived at his 2014 holiday party in a $384,000 Ferrari, wearing a custom Italian suit. He told the guests whom he had invited to an upscale  Manhattan club — including executives, politicians and celebrities — that he had flown in from Saint-Jean-Cap-Ferrat, a town in the French Riviera where he owned two villas.

headline: Late Night Can’t Get Enough of World Leaders Laughing at Trump
abstract: President Trump’s leaving NATO early after the release of a video in which leaders mock him was like a child calling his mother to come get him from a sleepover, Trevor Noah said.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. If you’re interested in hearing from The Times regularly about great TV, sign up for our Watching newsletter and get recommendations straight to your inbox.

headline: Strikes Against Macron’s Pension Plans Shut Down Much of France
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Yellow Vests Movement']
abstract: Workers across the country were staging walkouts and joining demonstrations to register their opposition to President Emmanuel Macron’s efforts to overhaul the pension system.
lead_paragraph: A protest against changes to France’s pension system brought parts of the country to a grinding halt on Thursday, with nationwide strikes shutting down transportation and leaving schools and hospitals unstaffed and basic government services unmet.

headline: Afghanistan Needs Billions in Aid Even After a Peace Deal, World Bank Says
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'Foreign Aid', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Humanitarian Aid']
abstract: Analysts say that American hopes for a quick deal and then slashed spending could lead to a collapse after 18 years of international aid created an unsustainable economy.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — As the United States urgently pushes a peace deal with the Taliban to end its costly military presence in Afghanistan, the World Bank  has warned that the war-stricken country will still require billions of dollars in international aid over many years after a peace deal to deliver basic services and sustain any potential peace.

headline: Japan Plans to Spend $120 Billion to Stimulate Slowing Economy
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Typhoon Hagibis (2019)', 'Infrastructure (Public Works)', 'Government Bonds', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe announced the spending as the country’s economy has slowed because of reduced demand from China and tensions with South Korea.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Japan will spend nearly $120 billion to stimulate its slowing economy and to help some of the areas worst affected by Typhoon Hagibis, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe announced on Thursday.

headline: Lesson of the Day: ‘Studying Sea Snakes? Time to Call the “Fantastic Grandmothers”’
abstract: In this lesson, students will learn about the women who contributed to scientific research through their own data collection and then be given an opportunity to become citizen scientists.
lead_paragraph: Featured Article: “Studying Sea Snakes? Time to Call the ‘Fantastic Grandmothers’”

headline: The T List: A New Kyoto Hotel, Comfortable Party Shoes and More
abstract: What to visit, wear and covet this week, from the editors of T Magazine.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the T List, a newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Each week, we’re sharing things we’re eating, wearing, listening to or coveting now. We hope you’ll join us for the ride. (Sign up here, if you haven’t already, and you can reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.)

headline: For Entertaining Musicals, Look No Further Than … Paris
abstract: The genre has long been seen as minor in the French capital, but a string of English-language productions is creating a pleasingly upbeat dynamic.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The opening line in Christopher Wheeldon’s 2014 musical, “An American in Paris,” currently playing here at the Théâtre du Châtelet, is directed at the audience: “When you think of Paris, what comes to mind?”

headline: I Worked for Alex Jones. I Regret It.
keywords: ['Fringe Groups and Movements', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Radio', 'Muslim Americans']
abstract: I dropped out of film school to edit video for the conspiracy theorist because I believed in his worldview. Then I saw what it did to people.
lead_paragraph: On Election Day 2016, I sat in the passenger seat of Alex Jones’s Dodge Hellcat as we swerved through traffic, making our way to a nearby polling place. As Jones punched the gas pedal to the floor, the smell of vodka, like paint thinner, wafted up from the white Dixie cup anchored in the console. My stomach churned as the phone I held streamed live video to Facebook: Jones rambling about voter fraud and rigged elections while I stared at the screen, holding the camera at an angle to hide his double chin. It rarely worked, but I didn’t want to be blamed when he watched the video later.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on Where Midtown Ends
abstract: Is Midtown a place? Or a state of mind?
lead_paragraph: Steve writes: Most would agree that Midtown Manhattan ends at 59th Street, but where does it start? I just moved to the city a year ago, but to me, it seems that Midtown begins at 14th Street. My partner claims it’s 34th Street. Who is right?

headline: Times Critics Discuss Their Year in Books, From New Talents to Old Favorites
abstract: The Times’s staff critics talk with each other about the reading they did in 2019, on and off the job.
lead_paragraph: Each year around now, The Times’s staff critics — Dwight Garner, Parul Sehgal and Jennifer Szalai — choose their favorite books from among those they reviewed over the previous 12 months. But they also read far more than can fit on such lists, and so they’ve come together to discuss the rest of their thoughts about 2019. Below, they talk about authors who inspired and disappointed them, favorite books they reread this year, how (and if) fiction should be addressing our political times and more. — John Williams, Daily Books Editor and Staff Writer

headline: Dealing With Grown-Up ‘Mean Girls’
abstract: Just as in the destructive patterns in adolescence, women can be both the victims and the villains in their adult relationships.
lead_paragraph: I was packing up my things after a teacher training in a K-8 school when a woman stopped me. Her pained expression was as familiar as what she confessed; “I’m a pushover. I hate conflict. I avoid other teachers and parents. It happens in my other relationships. I feel like we don’t grow past ‘Mean Girls.’ We just get older.”

headline: ‘The Man Without Qualities’ Acquires a New Volume
abstract: Combining material from Robert Musil’s great unfinished novel and from his archives, “Agathe, or the Forgotten Sister” focuses on the twinlike siblings at the book’s heart.
lead_paragraph: First there was Robert Musil the mechanical engineer, who invented a chroma meter, a device for evaluating color. Then there was Musil the philosophical scientist, interested in probability theory and logical positivism, as well as in the workings of the mind and the soul. Neither Musil seems a likely candidate for the role of novelist, even in that hotbed of modernism that was the Austro-Hungarian Empire during its dying liberal decades. Yet Musil went on to write “The Man Without Qualities,” an achievement that ranked him with Proust and Joyce.

headline: Edelweiss, Edelweiss? Julie Andrews Loves Reading About 18th-Century Plant Hunters
abstract: “I’m fascinated by stories of how the various plant specimens we take for granted today were originally discovered,” says the actor, whose latest book is “Home Work: A Memoir of My Hollywood Years.”
lead_paragraph: “I’m fascinated by stories of how the various plant specimens we take for granted today were originally discovered,” says the actor, whose latest book is “Home Work: A Memoir of My Hollywood Years.”

headline: The Best Crime Novels of the Year
abstract: Marilyn Stasio’s 2019 top 10 list includes a gruesome Danish serial-killer thriller, a missing-persons caper and a murder mystery set in the video-gaming world.
lead_paragraph: Lisa Sandlin’s irresistible mystery THE BIRD BOYS (Cinco Puntos, paper, $16.95) is set in 1973 in Beaumont, a bustling city on the Texas Gulf Coast where a freshly minted private eye has just hung out his shingle. His first job, a classic missing persons case, is enhanced by a particularly memorable cast of characters — including his receptionist, a paroled murderer, and the local cops, who invite a visitor to “set your behind in a chair, you.” Thanks, don’t mind if I do.

headline: What Is Voters’ Highest Priority? There’s a Way to Find Out
keywords: ['Trump-Ukraine Whistle-blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Impeachment', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: Peeling away preferences, a study shows impeachment is at the top of the list for Republicans, and is the second choice for Democrats.
lead_paragraph: Republicans in Congress have tried to discredit the Democratic-led impeachment inquiry by arguing that it distracts Congress from its real duties. One Republican-aligned group recently released a poll of 1,600 voters in four congressional districts that suggested Americans “prioritize issues over impeachment.”

headline: The Lost Jewish Brands of Berlin
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Trademarks and Trade Names', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Luxury Goods and Services', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'your-feed-fashion']
abstract: Once upon a time the German capital had a thriving fashion industry run by Jews. The Nazis destroyed it. Now one company is trying to bring it back.
lead_paragraph: Last month, Andreas Valentin, a 66-year-old professor at the State University of Rio de Janeiro, traveled more than 6,000 miles from Brazil to Berlin to participate in a restitution ceremony, of sorts.

headline: For William Nader, a Lifetime With Horse Racing
abstract: He got his start at his hometown track and now is an executive with the Hong Kong Jockey Club.
lead_paragraph: William Nader’s passion for the horse racing industry has taken him from the old Rockingham Park in his New Hampshire hometown to the New York Racing Association and then to Hong Kong, where he has had a profound impact as director of racing business and operations at the Hong Kong Jockey Club. Nader, who turns 62 on  Monday, reflected on his career during an interview. The following conversation has been edited and condensed.

abstract: And why are birthrates dropping?
