lead_paragraph: Can a person have too many popcorn epiphanies?

headline: Denmark Raises Antibiotic-Free Pigs. Why Can’t the U.S.?
abstract: American pigs are raised on a liberal diet of antibiotics, fueling the rise of resistant germs. Danish pork producers are proving there’s a better way.
lead_paragraph: BILLUND, Denmark — How many rounds of antibiotics does it take to raise a Danish pig?

headline: Michelle Pfeiffer’s Perfume Bottles, Illustrated
abstract: The actor began her collection of antique vessels three years ago, while developing her fragrance line, Henry Rose.
lead_paragraph: Michelle Pfeiffer began collecting antique perfume bottles three years ago, while developing Henry Rose, the fragrance line she launched last spring. “As I learned more about the history of perfume, I became fascinated with the design of old bottles,” says the actor, whose new brand includes five scents — among them, Fog, a blend of musk and vetiver, and Jake’s House, a mix of honey and neroli — all of which are free of endocrine-disrupting phthalates and other harmful synthetics often found in eaux de parfum. Some of Pfeiffer’s collection of mostly early- and mid-20th-century vials have intricate etchings, while others are gilded like an Art Deco skyscraper. “Fragrance bottles aren’t really designed that way anymore,” says the 61-year-old, who finds them online or at antique shops in her hometown, Los Angeles. “They live on my vanity in my dressing room. I imagine who owned them before and what kind of scents they contained,” she says. Pfeiffer’s latest film, “French Exit,” directed by Azazel Jacobs and co-starring Lucas Hedges, is due in theaters in 2020.

headline: The $120,000 Banana Wins Art Basel
abstract: Stampeding billionaires took over Miami Beach for the annual art fair where everybody is V.I.P.

headline: The Topanga Tea Ceremony
abstract: Why does Los Angeles sit in the quiet?
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — A reasonable question one who has never attended a tea ceremony might have in advance of attending their very first tea ceremony is: What happens at a tea ceremony? But when I spoke on the phone with Baelyn Elspeth a week before she hosted a carefully planned “tea sit” in Topanga Canyon, she was cagey, and would only tell me that it would “feel formal.”

headline: Saying No to Trump’s Troops
keywords: ['Mormon Family Massacre (Mexico, 2019)', 'Drug Cartels', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic']
abstract: The U.S. government had better forget about any kind of intervention in Mexico.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Mexico should not agree, under any circumstances, to host United States troops — or those from any other country — in its territory. It’s a matter of principle, sovereignty and history.

headline: Cold Stopped a Woman’s Heart for 6 Hours, Then Helped Save Her Life
abstract: Audrey Mash got caught in a snowstorm while hiking in the Pyrenees. Doctors say she experienced the longest period of cardiac arrest that a patient has survived in Spain.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Audrey Mash arrived at a Spanish hospital cold to the touch and all but dead: Her heart had stopped beating hours earlier, as she clung to her husband in a mountain snowstorm and her body temperature collapsed.

headline: 3 Suicides in 2 Months Jolt a College Campus

headline: ‘Black Friday’ Headline Is Condemned by Stars of Italian Soccer

headline: No One Should Have to Breathe These Chemicals
keywords: ['Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Explosions (Accidental)', 'Chemicals', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Respiratory Diseases', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: In Texas and across the country, the E.P.A.’s gutting of the Chemical Disaster Rule is a matter of life or death.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — While families across the country celebrated Thanksgiving with their loved ones, more than 50,000 people in Port Neches, Tex., were forced to evacuate from their homes and spend the holiday in makeshift shelters. The reason? Two explosions at the Texas Petroleum Chemical plant sent flames into the sky, injured eight people, and released plumes of butadiene, a carcinogen, into the air.

headline: ‘A Christmas Prince: The Royal Baby’ Review: The Title Says It All
abstract: This holiday film on Netflix, the third in a series, is both flimsy and flat, but if royal romance is what you crave, you’ve found it.

headline: The Playlist: The Weeknd’s Cold Heart, and 8 More New Songs

Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

headline: Hugh, Actually: In U.K. Campaign, Voters Find an Actor at the Door
abstract: Celebrities have long thrown the weight of their public personas behind political candidates. But Hugh Grant has been one of the most active ahead of Britain’s general election.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Londoners responding to a knock on their front doors in recent days may have been surprised to see a familiar face grinning back at them: Hugh Grant, one of the country’s most recognizable actors, who made his mark as the floppy-haired, bumbling leading man in romantic comedies.

headline: Holiday Magic: Fooled and Fooled and Fooled Again
abstract: In its sixth year on Broadway, “The Illusionists” serves up familiar routines, but two smaller shows deliver egghead charm and brainy sleight-of-hand.
lead_paragraph: When you consider the Twitter bots, the Facebook ads, the phishing expeditions, the password hacks, the phone scams and the deepfakes, we are a nation of dupes. At least, at a magic show, we can possibly enjoy it. We can even abet it.

abstract: The Premier League club is in crisis again. But it is more serious than just one manager’s failings: It is part of a fundamental reordering of the soccer world.

lead_paragraph: Apple has struggled to find its footing as it tries to go Hollywood. Critics were lukewarm at best about “The Morning Show,” the star-studded, big-budget flagship series on Apple TV Plus, the streaming platform that went live Nov. 1. And now one of Apple’s first films, “The Banker,” starring Samuel L. Jackson and Anthony Mackie, is in limbo after the company pulled it from a theatrical run that was scheduled to start Friday.

headline: Review: Dancing the ‘Twisted Beauty’ of the Black Experience
abstract: At the Next Wave Festival, the choreographer Kyle Marshall unveils a new work along with his ravishing “Colored” from 2017.
lead_paragraph: Until seeing his program at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, I knew Kyle Marshall as a compelling, sensitive dancer with the Trisha Brown Dance Company and someone whose work trusted colleagues had been urging me to see. Now I understand the buzz. In a double bill at BAM Fisher (and as the only local dance maker in this year’s Next Wave Festival), Mr. Marshall demonstrated that rare and hard-to-define thing: a choreographic voice like no one else’s.

headline: A Political Party Aligns Itself With Ocasio-Cortez
abstract: The new leader of the Working Families Party in New York hopes to remake the progressive group to attract the energized left.
lead_paragraph: The Working Families Party, an influential, labor-backed organization that has helped push Democrats to the left, is moving toward a new identity: It wants to align itself with the movement that spawned Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez.

headline: ‘Reprisal’ Review: A Femme Fatale on the Midnight Train to Revenge
abstract: In Hulu’s “Reprisal,” Abigail Spencer plays a woman on an implacable mission in a Southern gothic tale of brawling gangs and tender male pride.
lead_paragraph: The term “noir” gets slapped on a lot of things these days that don’t deserve it, as an all-purpose identifier for productions that are grim and violent and impressed with themselves. It’s there in the news release for Hulu’s new series “Reprisal” (10 episodes premiering Friday): “a hyper-noir story that follows a relentless femme fatale.”

headline: Gender-Based Violence Harms Us All
keywords: ['Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Gender']
abstract: The murders of transgender or gender nonconforming people in 2019 are frightening attacks on our collective humanity.
lead_paragraph: Death is the ultimate destination. The Shavasana position in yoga prepares you for it, lying flat on your back, arms resting slightly away from your body. I’ve made many drawings of bodies stretched out on their backs, including some afloat in water. They point to the deep suffering that engulfs the lives of those who exist in the margins and intersections of society, beyond the interests of the powers that be. I have also worked for years with images of women’s bodies, demonstrating the damage done to them by the social, cultural and environmental crises we frequently face around the world.

headline: A Billion Pixels and the Search for India’s Crashed Moon Lander
abstract: The Indian space agency has been tight-lipped about the fate of Vikram, but crowdsourcing and NASA’s openness led to its discovery.

headline: ‘I’m a Business, Man’
abstract: Michael Eric Dyson’s book, “Jay-Z: Made in America” is new on the nonfiction list this week.
lead_paragraph: Hustling is, as the sociologist Michael Eric Dyson puts it, “the central motif of American history, the dominant measure of the American character,” and he thinks the rapper and entrepreneur Jay-Z embodies every element, good and bad, of hustling culture.

headline: Gerrit Cole, the Yankees and the Value of the Long Game
abstract: Brian Cashman drafted Cole, and lost him. Tried to trade for him, and lost out again. Now, in free agency, is he finally in a position to get his man?
lead_paragraph: The Yankees tried to spin their latest playoff knockout. After losing in six games in the American League Championship Series — the third time in five seasons that the Houston Astros had ushered them off the stage — they insisted they had been strong enough to win.

headline: Christian Doomsayers Have Lost It
keywords: ['Christians and Christianity', 'Conservatism (US Politics)', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'ABORTION', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Birth Control and Family Planning']
abstract: Leading social indicators are trending their way, but somehow it is only Trump who stands between us and the apocalypse.
lead_paragraph: We are facing an existential moral crisis.

headline: That Banana on the Wall? At Art Basel Miami It’ll Cost You $120,000.
abstract: Maurizio Cattelan’s latest provocative work is buzzy and fun. But is it art?
lead_paragraph: Remember when Morley Safer famously — controversially — asked on “60 Minutes” whether Marcel Duchamp’s urinal and Jeff Koons’s vacuum cleaners were really art? Now, in the spirit of such questions, comes Maurizio Cattelan’s (somewhat overripe) banana pinned to the wall with gray duct tape.

headline: Our 50 Best Recipes of 2019
abstract: The recipes our readers viewed most on NYT Cooking this year.
lead_paragraph: Assembling cassoulet, proofing sourdough bread or constructing a Harry Potter Sorting Hat croquembouche are all worthwhile pursuits, but, for many people, the word “cooking” means weeknight cooking: recipes that are fast and easy without sacrificing a little excitement. Those are exactly the kind of recipes NYT Cooking readers loved most this year.

headline: Interviewing Bernie Sanders
abstract: A look into the making of our candidate profile on the Vermont senator.
lead_paragraph: For part two of our series on Democratic presidential candidates, we told the story of how Bernie Sanders learned to wield political power — not in the Senate or on the national stage, but in the town of Burlington, Vermont, all the way back in 1981.

headline: West Virginia Fires 3 Employees After Photo Shows Trainees Giving Nazi Salute
keywords: ['Prison Guards and Corrections Officers', 'Neo Nazi Groups', 'ANTI-SEMITISM']

headline: Winston Lawson, 91, Secret Service Agent With Kennedy in Dallas, Dies
abstract: The advance man for the Texas trip, he rode ahead of Kennedy’s limo, helped lift the president onto a stretcher and then lived a half-century with regrets.
lead_paragraph: Winston Lawson had been a Secret Service agent for four years when, on Nov. 22, 1963, he was in an unmarked police car in Dallas just ahead of President John F. Kennedy’s open limousine.

headline: Teenager Pleads Guilty to Throwing Boy Off Balcony at Tate Modern in London
abstract: Jonty Bravery, who faced one count of attempted murder, intended to kill the boy so he could be on the news, the authorities said.

headline: Knicks Fire Coach David Fizdale

headline: White House Signals Trump Won’t Mount House Impeachment Defense

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The White House signaled on Friday that it did not intend to mount a defense of President Trump or otherwise participate in the House impeachment proceedings, sending Democrats a sharply worded letter that condemned the process as “completely baseless” and urged them to get it over with quickly.

headline: Win-a-Trip in 2020!
abstract: I invite university students to enter a contest for a reporting trip next year.

My aim is to generate interest in neglected topics and get more people writing about them.

headline: Dressing ‘The Irishman’: Polyester Pantsuits and Capo Collars
abstract: The costume designers Sandy Powell and Christopher Peterson explain why they turned to Pucci-style looks for the women and how they waded through a sea of ties for the men.
lead_paragraph: The women of “The Irishman,” Martin Scorsese’s somewhat true story of the mob hit man and Teamster, initially look sparkly and refreshing, an oasis in a desert of suit jackets. But their bloom and innocence are a mirage, these aging Barbie dolls in polyester pantsuits, dutifully getting rid of their husbands’ bloodstained shirts.

headline: G.O.P. Tactic on Impeachment: Turn Ukraine Allegations Against Biden
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Trump-Ukraine Whistle-blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry']
abstract: President Trump and his allies are pushing debunked claims of corruption by Mr. Biden as a counternarrative to impeachment.
lead_paragraph: President Trump’s re-election campaign has run menacing and misleading ads this fall accusing Joseph R. Biden Jr. of corrupt dealings with Ukraine. Republicans in Congress are scrutinizing Mr. Biden’s son, pressing the State and Treasury Departments for information about his work for a Ukrainian energy company. The president himself has unleashed a stream of unfounded accusations against the Bidens and pushed for them to appear at a potential impeachment trial in the Senate.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court agreed on Friday to decide whether states can take account of a judge’s political affiliation in trying to achieve ideological balance on their courts.

The all-new, postelection Parliament is only sitting for just over a week before cooling off with a six-week break.

headline: I Tested 13 Bidets. I’m a Convert.

But after installing and using 13 bidets for Wirecutter (priced between $30 and $1,000) over the past 90 days, I now — like nearly everyone who can get past the uncontrollable giggles of those first few uses — count myself among the converted.

keywords: ['Tests and Examinations', 'Education (K-12)', 'Reading and Writing Skills (Education)', 'National Assessment of Educational Progress']

headline: Elon Musk Is Cleared in Lawsuit Over His ‘Pedo Guy’ Tweet
abstract: A jury found that the Tesla billionaire did not defame a cave explorer in a dispute over a rescue effort in Thailand last year.

The verdict ended a short trial based on an acrid dispute between the men over the high-profile rescue of a group of children trapped in Thailand in the summer of 2018.

abstract: The rare operation has implications for wounded soldiers, accident victims, cancer patients and those undergoing sex reassignment.

headline: Fans Didn’t Like the Way Jeff Wilpon Ran the Mets. Neither Did Some of His Relatives.

lead_paragraph: The Wilpon family, a wealthy and well-connected New York clan, should have been everything sports fans would want in the owner of a team. They were local, passionate about their game and desperately wanted to win.

headline: Supreme Court Won’t Allow Federal Executions to Resume
keywords: ['Capital Punishment', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: The Trump administration had asked the justices to overturn a trial judge’s ruling that blocked the first four federal executions scheduled in nearly two decades.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court said on Friday that it would not allow the Trump administration to resume executions in federal death penalty cases after a 16-year hiatus. The move, which left in place a preliminary injunction from a federal judge in Washington, effectively stayed the executions of four men scheduled to be put to death in the coming weeks. The court’s brief, unsigned order said it expected an appeals court to decide the inmates’ challenges “with appropriate dispatch.”

headline: Ron Leibman, Tony Winner for ‘Angels,’ Is Dead at 82
abstract: In addition to his acclaimed turn as Roy Cohn on Broadway, he was known for his work in “Norma Rae,” “Slaughterhouse-Five” and other films.
lead_paragraph: Ron Leibman, an actor whose career of more than six decades in film, television and the theater was highlighted by a Tony Award in 1993 for his electrifying performance as Roy Cohn in the first part of “Angels in America,” died on Friday in Manhattan. He was 82.

headline: Eli Manning Is Ready for Another Chance
abstract: Manning, the longtime Giants quarterback, is in line for his first start in three months with Daniel Jones injured.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — For the past 11 weeks, as rookie Daniel Jones has taken over the spotlight as the starting quarterback of the Giants, Eli Manning has been running the scout team at practice. As the backup quarterback, Manning played in the style of opposing quarterbacks to prepare the Giants defense for what they will face on game day.

headline: French Strike Aims to Save an Envied, but Convoluted, Approach to Pensions
keywords: ['Strikes', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Politics and Government', 'Government Employees', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Railroads']
abstract: In France, train drivers can retire at 52, public utility workers at 57 and ballet dancers at 42. President Macron calls the tangle outdated and unsustainable. A million French protesters disagree.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Stéphane Vardon has worked as a conductor on France’s high-speed and suburban rail network for 20 years. It is hard work, he says, and he’d like to retire before he turns 58, a privilege he now fears President Emmanuel Macron is going to strip away.

headline: Editors’ Note: Dec. 7, 2019
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Dec. 7, 2019.
lead_paragraph: An article on Oct. 8 about voters in a swing county in western Pennsylvania who supported Donald Trump in 2016 featured comments from Mark Graham, who said he no longer supported Mr. Trump. Local news media reported this week that Mr. Graham did not vote in the 2016 election; The Times has confirmed those reports. While Mr. Graham acknowledged misspeaking about his voting record, he said the article accurately reflects his feelings about the 2016 race and President Trump’s performance in office.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday: ‘Marriage Story’ and ‘The SpongeBob Musical’
abstract: Catch Noah Baumbach’s story of a marriage’s collapse, and a televised performance of the colorful Broadway musical.
lead_paragraph: MARRIAGE STORY (2019) Stream on Netflix. The director Noah Baumbach told The New York Times’s Reggie Ugwu that during the process of writing his latest film about a crumbling marriage, he leaned on his friends and his actors for their perspectives on relationships to get inside the minds of the uncoupling couple Charlie (Adam Driver) and Nicole (Scarlett Johansson). The result, as A.O. Scott writes in his New York Times review, is a film that is “funny and sad, sometimes within a single scene, and it weaves a plot out of the messy collapse of a shared reality, trying to make music out of disharmony.”

headline: Utah Had a Shot at the College Football Playoff. Oregon Spoiled It.

headline: A Catastrophic Accident, Then the Gift of Learning How to Live

lead_paragraph: Late in the afternoon on Dec. 10, 1956, when I was an 18-year-old freshman at Williams College, my roommate locked me in my fourth-floor room as a prank. I went out on the ledge outside my dorm window to escape, fell off and broke my back. I was paralyzed, and my life was never the same.

headline: Getting Back on Track After Tragedy
abstract: A surgeon and a pilot from Russia had planned a future for themselves and their children in New York. His death in a helicopter crash threw their lives into disarray.

headline: Virginia Is the National Champion. But It Can’t Seem to Make a Shot

Out of ground-floor kitchens that opened directly onto the street, they came out singing old songs, sweeping the stone floor and scattering their homemade orecchiette, the city’s renowned ear-shaped pasta, on the mesh screens of wooden trays.

headline: Are Live Christmas Trees Really Fire Hazards?
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Christmas', 'Christmas Trees', 'Fires and Firefighters']
abstract: Here’s what the statistics say.
lead_paragraph: Q: My girlfriend and I live together in an Upper West Side co-op. I want to buy a live Christmas tree, but she wants an artificial one because she thinks the real ones are inconvenient and pose a fire hazard. To that, I say: A fake tree??? Our building wouldn’t decorate the lobby with a real tree if it were a fire hazard, right? Please settle this for us: Is there a safe and convenient way to have a real Christmas tree?

headline: Hall of Fame Takes Another Swing at an Underappreciated Era
abstract: Ted Simmons and Dale Murphy are among 10 candidates for election by the Veterans Committee, whose choices will be announced on Sunday. The former pitcher Ron Darling offered his thoughts on the seven he faced.
lead_paragraph: Baseball’s winter meetings are all about the future — players changing teams, leagues changing rules — except for the first order of business. On Sunday night in San Diego, a committee of executives, historians and former players will announce its verdict on the 10 candidates it is considering for the Hall of Fame.

keywords: ['Strikes', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Organized Labor', 'Yellow Vests Movement', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']

headline: Is It Possible Trump Is on the Right Track With China?
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: Paul Krugman responds to reader questions about the lasting effects of Trump’s trade wars.
lead_paragraph: “Trump’s trade war is losing, not gaining, support,” Paul Krugman wrote this week in his column “Why Is Trump a Tariff Man?” So why does the president avoid making the deals that might end this perpetual state of economic uncertainty? In a word, freedom.

headline: Violence Drives a Swell in Mexican Migration
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Asylum, Right of', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: Many are asylum seekers but are being forced to wait in Mexico, where their lives may be at risk.
lead_paragraph: CIUDAD JUÁREZ, Mexico — A crackdown on illegal immigration has sharply curbed the number of Central Americans and others trying to enter the United States. But Mexicans, who have not been bound by some of the same restrictions, have been showing up at the border in greater numbers, in many cases fleeing the escalating violence in their country.

headline: Variety: Acrostic
abstract: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon, sing, heavenly muses!
lead_paragraph: ACROSTIC — There’s no correlation between hard-to-solve acrostics and esoteric themes, is there? I’m sure we all have strong and weak subjects, and I’m also pretty sure that the chances of any passage being familiar (as in, already read) by the average solver are pretty slim. Today, I think the subject matter of the passage is quite heady and thought-provoking, and I also think that a lot of the clues, many of which related to the theme as per usual, are really hard.

headline: Judiciary Committee Report Offers Legal Rationale for Impeaching Trump
abstract: The report, which echoes one released in 1974 as the House debated impeaching President Richard M. Nixon, comes two days before the committee will formally receive the evidence against President Trump.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — House Democrats released a report on Saturday intended to lay out the legal and historical underpinnings of their case for impeaching President Trump while also countering Republican accusations that the investigation of the president’s conduct in office has been unfair and illegitimate.

headline: These Baby Names Defined the 2010s
abstract: Also: The rise of “momfluencing” and more new stories from NYT Parenting.
lead_paragraph: The 2010s gave us new trends in baby naming, which Pamela Redmond of Nameberry has analyzed for a new piece on our site. Apparently, “Freya and Theo seem destined to fill nurseries for years to come,” Pamela wrote. In another look at the past decade, Kathryn Jezer-Morton asked, “Did moms exist before social media?” The literal answer is yes, of course, but the rise of social media has changed how we parent and how we talk about parenting.

abstract: I overcame the desperation I felt after stepping down from Congress, and I’m still in the fight.

One year later, I was sitting on a train to New York to meet with my lawyers about suing The Daily Mail for cyber exploitation — and I was no longer a member of Congress.

headline: Jim Brown: Football Has Forgotten the Men Who Made It Great
abstract: While the league makes billions, many retired players are living on shockingly low pensions.
lead_paragraph: Turn on any N.F.L. game on Sunday, and you’ll see the league celebrating its 100th season. Thunderous video montages and “Top 10 Tight Ends” specials will exalt football’s history with one clear, though unspoken, message: The appeal and profitability of today’s N.F.L. derives as much from its past as its present.

headline: The World Solved the Ozone Problem. It Can Solve Climate Change.

abstract: The same tools that fixed the ozone hole — science, innovation and international action — can address it.
lead_paragraph: Nearly 50 years ago, three chemists named Mario Molina, Sherwood Rowland and Paul Crutzen found evidence that chlorofluorocarbons, chemicals known as CFCs and released from aerosol sprays, were weakening the ozone layer that functions as the earth’s natural sunscreen protecting humans, animals and plants from harmful radiation.

She was our first, and much wanted. We were United States citizens and our future as a family should have seemed bright. But we felt deeply insecure and anxious.

headline: ‘Lookin’ Good!’
abstract: Emily Carroll reveals the beauty in the braininess of all of us.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — If Emily Carroll was a novelist, I’m sure I’d be recommending her books to all my friends. Her constructions keep improving, she often incorporates references to things that exist somewhere in my experience (and even sometimes jog pleasant memories), and when we get a theme from her it is, without fail, clever and subtle. Today’s is a delight when you get it, a play on a classic compliment. It’s a good time of year to note that a correctly-paid compliment isn’t difficult — this puzzle, though, was a good challenge!

One was to demand the College Football Playoff’s top ranking. The other was for the Tigers’ quarterback, Joe Burrow, to win the Heisman Trophy.

headline: For Trump, Instinct After Florida Killings Is Simple: Protect Saudis
keywords: ['Naval Air Station Pensacola Shooting (2019)', 'United States International Relations', 'Mass Shootings']

lead_paragraph: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. — When a Saudi Air Force officer opened fire on his classmates at a naval base in Pensacola, Fla., on Friday, he killed three, wounded eight and exposed anew the strange dynamic between President Trump and the Saudi leadership: The president’s first instinct was to tamp down any suggestion that the Saudi government needed to be held to account.

headline: What’s on TV Sunday: ‘Hala’ and ‘The L Word: Generation Q’
abstract: Catch Minhal Baig’s coming-of-age story about a Muslim teenager, and the revival of Showtime’s pioneering L.G.B.T.Q. series.
lead_paragraph: HALA (2019) Stream on Apple TV Plus. Although it’s not autobiographical, the filmmaker Minhal Baig plumbed aspects of her own childhood in Chicago to tell the story of her title character in “Hala.” The feature follows the high school senior as she comes to terms with her identity as an American teenager and the daughter of Muslim Pakistani immigrants. “As Hala tests the boundaries of faith and sexual desire (her name means ‘halo’ in Arabic, and it feels like a burden), the movie is unsparing about gender roles and the awkwardness of first-time fumblings,” Jeannette Catsoulis wrote in her New York Times review, designating the film a Critic’s Pick.

headline: Corrections: Dec. 8, 2019
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Dec. 8, 2019.
lead_paragraph: An article last Sunday about the slow rise of lesbianism on TV misstated which season of “Buffy the Vampire Slayer” featured a scene in which the characters Willow and Tara are shown in bed together. The scene occurred in the show’s sixth season, not its final season. The article also referred incorrectly to the scene. It was not the first lesbian sex scene shown on broadcast television; it showed the characters in bed together, but not engaged in sex. A later scene in that episode with the characters Willow and Kennedy was the first lesbian sex scene on broadcast television.

headline: Homes That Sold for $420,000 or Less
abstract: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
lead_paragraph: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.

headline: At Japan’s Most Elite University, Just 1 in 5 Students Is a Woman
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Tests and Examinations', 'Women and Girls', 'Discrimination', 'ADMISSIONS STANDARDS', 'Education (Secondary)']
abstract: Enrollment of women at the University of Tokyo has remained about 20 percent for years, an imbalance that extends across many top Japanese colleges.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — From a young age, Satomi Hayashi studied hard and excelled academically. It seemed only natural that she would follow in her father’s footsteps and attend the University of Tokyo, Japan’s most prestigious institution.

headline: Hundreds of Thousands March in Hong Kong
abstract: Pro-democracy protesters in Hong Kong turned out on Sunday for the largest march in weeks.
lead_paragraph: Pro-democracy protesters in Hong Kong turned out on Sunday for the largest march in weeks.

headline: Impeachment, Pensacola, Interstellar Comet: Your Weekend Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.

headline: Young Voters Helped Upend Last U.K. Election. Can It Happen Again?
abstract: The left-wing opposition Labour Party outperformed most polls in 2017 thanks in part to its strength among young people, who appear to have registered in larger numbers this time around.
lead_paragraph: SOUTHAMPTON, England — As students from the University of Southampton zigzagged across campus on a recent cold afternoon, youthful activists with Britain’s main opposition Labour Party intercepted them with cups of tea and a leaflet with detailed instructions on how to register to vote in December’s election.

headline: The Week in Business: Uber’s Sexual Assault Problem
keywords: ['Car Services and Livery Cabs', 'Driverless and Semiautonomous Vehicles', 'Sex Crimes', 'International Trade and World Market', 'United States Economy', 'Customs (Tariff)', 'Food Stamps']
abstract: It’s that stressful time in the holiday shopping season when we’re all playing chicken with sales — wait a little longer, and the price could go down; wait too long, and things will sell out. Some gift options that probably won’t get cheaper? French wine, cheese, perfume and handbags, which are the latest victims of President Trump’s tariff wars. Here’s what to know about that, plus other top stories in the business and tech worlds.
lead_paragraph: It’s that stressful time in the holiday shopping season when we’re all playing chicken with sales — wait a little longer, and the price could go down; wait too long, and things will sell out. Some gift options that probably won’t get cheaper? French wine, cheese, perfume and handbags, which are the latest victims of President Trump’s tariff wars. Here’s what to know about that, plus other top stories in the business and tech worlds.

headline: Brexit Will Bring a Baby Boom, Boris Johnson Promises
keywords: ['Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'Birth Rates', 'Elections', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: Another dubious claim has drawn attention on the campaign trail in the lead-up to British elections on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Add this head-scratching prediction to the list of campaign-trail utterances made by Prime Minister Boris Johnson: Brexit is sure to inspire a baby boom if he remains in office.

headline: I.M.F., Endorsing Zelensky, Approves Loan for Ukraine
abstract: The International Monetary Fund, in conditionally agreeing to lend the country $5.5 billion over three years, cited “impressive progress” under President Volodymyr Zelensky.
lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — The International Monetary Fund has agreed to lend $5.5 billion to Ukraine, a move viewed as a stamp of approval for President Volodymyr Zelensky’s anticorruption and economic policies.

headline: Reconnecting With His Son, and Picking Himself Back Up
abstract: When Derrick Manigault became a full-time caregiver, he found tools in a fatherhood program.
lead_paragraph: For almost a decade, Derrick Manigault saw his son, Jeramiah, two days a week.

headline: Songs, Poems and Parodies: Readers Compose ‘Variations’
abstract: We invited readers to stretch the traditional boundaries of a letter to the editor, in verse, song or some other form. Many couldn’t resist the urge to aim their wit at the president.
lead_paragraph: (To the tune of “My Favorite Things” from “The Sound of Music”)

headline: Do You Know Where to Find This New York Architectural Gem?
abstract: The Guastavinos were a father-son design team that turned unassuming spaces into art. This week we introduce “Local Treasure,” a new bi-weekly quiz that focuses on the architectural delights scattered around the streets of New York City.
lead_paragraph: The Guastavinos were a father-son design team that turned unassuming spaces into art. This week we introduce “Local Treasure,” a new bi-weekly quiz that focuses on the architectural delights scattered around the streets of New York City.

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: Pan-roasted chicken in cream sauce, Indian-spiced tomato and egg casserole, a swordfish piccata: Make foods to comfort against the cold.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. No one I know loves winter more than Angie Mar, the chef and an owner of the Beatrice Inn in Manhattan. You could find some ski bum kid living the dream life in Durango, Colo., or Whitefish, Mont., or waking up each morning to praise the snow lords of Killington, Vt., a huge smile on his face, ready to shred. But he’s a depressive compared to Mar this time of year, when she’s cooking dinners of fats on fats, flavors on flavors, beautiful richness to reel the mind.

headline: Banana Splits: Spoiled by Its Own Success, the $120,000 Fruit Is Gone
abstract: The artist Maurizio Cattelan’s taped banana at Art Basel Miami prompted so much buzz and commotion that it was removed on Sunday before the end of the fair.
lead_paragraph: The banana that consumed the art world has taken early retirement.

headline: What Does This Country Demand of Black Women in Politics?
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Elections, Mayors', 'Women and Girls', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: After Kamala Harris’s departure from the presidential race, the people who saw their own paths reflected in hers are thinking about what comes next.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The first black woman to be elected mayor of San Francisco, London Breed, considers Senator Kamala Harris something of a political soul mate. When Ms. Harris announced her White House bid in Oakland, Calif., in January, Ms. Breed was one of the 20,000 supporters there loudly celebrating, and she endorsed the campaign from the beginning.

headline: Pensacola Shooting Updates: F.B.I. Presumes It Was Terrorism
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Military Bases and Installations', 'Terrorism', 'Naval Air Station Pensacola Shooting (2019)']
abstract: Officials said on Sunday that federal investigators were working on the presumption that the attack in Pensacola on Friday was an act of terrorism. Sailors from Alabama, Florida and Georgia were killed, and eight others were injured.
lead_paragraph: Rachel Rojas, the special agent in charge of the Federal Bureau of Investigation’s Jacksonville field office, said on Sunday that the presumption of terrorism allows law enforcement agencies to more quickly identify and eliminate any potential threats to the community. None have been identified so far, she said.

headline: Juice WRLD Dies at 21; Chicago Rapper Whose Star Was on the Rise
abstract: He began posting songs online while in high school. On hits like “Lucid Dreams,” he combined melodic hip-hop instincts with heavy-hearted angst.
lead_paragraph: Juice WRLD, one of a crop of sweet-voiced singing rappers who emerged from the streaming platform SoundCloud in recent years, died on Sunday in a hospital in Oak Lawn, Ill. He was 21.

headline: How the Constitution Defines Impeachable, Word by Word
abstract: What “treason, bribery, or other high crimes and misdemeanors” really means.
lead_paragraph: What “treason, bribery, or other high crimes and misdemeanors” really means.

headline: Ban on Surprise Medical Bills May Pass After All
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Emergency Medical Treatment', 'Law and Legislation', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'AMBULANCES', 'Doctors']
abstract: Congress is close to a deal that would help patients by resolving billing disputes between doctors and insurance companies.
lead_paragraph: Turns out, even as the impeachment debate blazes, Democrats and Republicans can agree on one thing: They don’t like surprise medical bills.

headline: The Internet Swallowed INXS. Can a Movie Rescue Its Legacy?
keywords: ['Pop and Rock Music', 'Movies', 'Nineteen Hundred Eighties', 'Documentary Films and Programs']
abstract: A remastered concert film and a new documentary reposition the Australian band for the digital age.
lead_paragraph: In the opening scenes of the concert film “Live Baby Live,” INXS bangs out “Guns in the Sky,” an anti-nukes anthem from its six-times-platinum 1987 album “Kick.” As beats reverberate across London’s old Wembley Stadium, the Australian rock band’s appeal leaps to life: funky guitar rhythms, saxophones, tight trousers and the soulful flow of the singer Michael Hutchence’s voice.

headline: Would Prince Have Wanted His Rough Drafts Made Public?
abstract: A memoir and a deluxe edition of “1999” offer a new perspective on the meticulous artist.
lead_paragraph: Prince was a perfectionist. He was a relentlessly creative musician and a refined aesthete, careful about the music he put out in the world, always presenting a seamless package — image and sound.

headline: The College Football Playoff Is Set, and L.S.U. Is No. 1
keywords: ['Football (College)', 'Playoff Games', 'Fiesta Bowl', 'College Football Playoff National Championship']
abstract: The 2019 season delivered remarkable consensus about which teams should reach the semifinal games. The last mysteries were about seedings and pairings.
lead_paragraph: The potential for chaos gave way to consensus: Louisiana State, Ohio State, Clemson and Oklahoma will compete for a national title after their selections on Sunday for the College Football Playoff.

headline: Caroll Spinney, Big Bird’s Alter Ego on ‘Sesame Street,’ Is Dead at 85
abstract: Besides the sweet-natured giant yellow bird, he also played the misanthropic bellyacher Oscar the Grouch.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes he stood 8 feet 2 inches tall. Sometimes he lived in a garbage can. He often cited numbers and letters of the alphabet, and for nearly a half century on “Sesame Street” he was Big Bird and Oscar the Grouch, opening magic doors for children on the secrets of growing up and the gentle arts of friendship.

headline: Will Russia Be Thrown Out of the Olympics on Monday? A Primer
abstract: Failed drug tests, altered samples and full-throated denials. Here’s what you need to know as the World Anti-Doping Agency considers barring Russia from sports.
lead_paragraph: There is a little more than seven months left before the opening of the 2020 Olympics, and, once again, Russia is bracing for yet another potentially severe punishment after yet another accusation of state-sponsored, performance-enhancing, sports-tainting doping malfeasance.

headline: West Point Strips Racist Motto From Its Football Team Flag
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Football', 'Slogans and Mottoes', 'Fringe Groups and Movements']
abstract: The military academy used a flag with a skull and crossbones and “G.F.B.D.”, which stands for “God Forgives, Brothers Don’t.” The slogan has been associated with white supremacists.
lead_paragraph: The United States Military Academy has stripped a motto from its football team spirit flag because of its connection to hate groups, the academy said on Sunday.

headline: Review: At Alvin Ailey, Tragic Themes Overwhelm a Dance
abstract: Donald Byrd’s “Greenwood,” about the 1921 massacre of black citizens of Tulsa, struggles to translate traumatic history into movement.
lead_paragraph: No one knows exactly what happened in 1921 when a young black man stepped into an elevator operated by a white woman in the Greenwood district of Tulsa, Okla., but the aftermath was horrific. The man was arrested, and a white mob descended on the area, an affluent black enclave, and destroyed it. Hundreds were killed, injured or left homeless by the destruction.

headline: With White House Absent, Impeachment Devolves Into Partisan Brawl
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Impeachment', 'Trump-Ukraine Whistle-blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry', 'Constitution (US)']
abstract: President Trump is refusing to engage and Democrats have concluded they will press ahead anyway, rendering a historic undertaking little more than a foregone conclusion.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Almost from the moment that Speaker Nancy Pelosi and her lieutenants decided this fall to pursue the impeachment of President Trump, they made a fateful judgment: If the president intended to do nothing but stonewall and subvert their inquiry, they were not going to be the ones politely sticking to lofty traditions.

headline: Podcasts About Beyoncé, Arias and Health Care: Worth a Listen
abstract: These returning shows, tailor-made for bingeing, deserve to be revisited (or newly discovered).
lead_paragraph: At the end of a year filled with more podcast debuts than ever, it’s sometimes easy to overlook returning shows just as worthy of your time. If you haven’t given them a try yet, there are plenty of past episodes for your ears to indulge during holiday travels. Below are some recent podcasts that came back for new seasons, followed by a few newcomers to check out.

headline: As Water Runs Low, Can Life in the Outback Go On?
abstract: In Australia’s vast interior, rivers and lakes are disappearing. “We’re starting to glimpse what the future is going to be like,” one scientist said.
lead_paragraph: EUCHAREENA, Australia — Fleur Magick Dennis has stopped showering every day, allowed her vegetable patch to die and told her four sons to let the dishes pile up. Sometimes, all her family has is bottled water, and they have to preserve every drop.

headline: A Farewell to Feministing and the Heyday of Feminist Blogging
abstract: Another site is about to close, joining other publications like The Hairpin and The Toast that are dead or dying, as their “rowdy” voices go mainstream.
lead_paragraph: Soon after Anna Holmes took on the job of building the website Jezebel, in 2007, she set it apart from established publications like Vogue and Elle with a post offering $10,000 to anyone who would send in the best unretouched version of a women’s magazine cover photo. And with that, Jezebel had marked its territory: feminist cultural criticism, with an edge.

headline: Marvin Goodfriend, Trump Nominee to the Federal Reserve, Dies at 69
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Inflation (Economics)', 'Deaths (Obituaries)']
abstract: He was a conservative monetary economist and a Carnegie Mellon professor who took on policy roles. His nomination lapsed after he failed to win Senate support.
lead_paragraph: Marvin Goodfriend, a leading conservative monetary economist and former nominee to the Federal Reserve Board, died on Thursday at his home in Pittsburgh. He was 69.

abstract: Here’s what you need to know.

headline: Bump Elliott, College Football Star and Coach, Dies at 94
abstract: An All-American halfback at the University of Michigan, he later coached the team and then became athletic director at the University of Iowa.
lead_paragraph: Bump Elliott, the All-American halfback on an unbeaten University of Michigan football team who later coached the Wolverines for a decade, then rebuilt the sports program at the University of Iowa as its longtime athletic director, died on Saturday in Iowa City.  He was 94.

headline: ‘Frozen 2’ Continues to Outdo Its Predecessor at the Box Office
abstract: With the biggest December releases yet to arrive, “Frozen 2” has kept its box-office lead for a third weekend.
lead_paragraph: The Disney animated musical “Frozen 2” again dominated domestic theaters this weekend, leading the box office for the third weekend in a row.

headline: This Man May Be Big Tech’s Biggest Threat
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: Representative David Cicilline doesn’t just want to enforce the laws governing the tech industry. He wants to change them.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — At a hearing this summer about the rising power of the country’s biggest tech companies, Representative David Cicilline zeroed in on Amazon. Unhappy with a response from one of the company’s top lawyers, he delivered a biting retort.

headline: Does Trump Think Our Constitutional Processes Are Beneath Him?
keywords: ['Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Trump-Ukraine Whistle-blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry', 'Presidential Election of 2020']
abstract: The best course for the House is to present a case for impeachment focused on Ukraine and the danger to the 2020 elections.
lead_paragraph: President Trump has now made obvious his contempt for the notion that Congress has any authority to hold him accountable. He has signaled that he won’t mount any defense to impeachment charges in the House over his scheming in Ukraine, insisting it is somehow beneath him to participate in a constitutional process.

headline: ‘Sleeping Car Porters’ Review: Billy the Kid Meets the Zodiac Killer
abstract: This cryptic play at the Brick Theater examining a certain kind of mythological American noir is wonderfully flabbergasting, and often genuinely creepy.
lead_paragraph: The warning comes early in Ryan William Downey’s “Sleeping Car Porters” as a voice-over welcomes us to the story — “and when I say ‘story’ I really mean a patchwork of moments.”

headline: Donald B. Marron, Financier, Art Collector and Philanthropist, Dies at 85
abstract: Mr. Marron began his Wall Street career as a teenager before leading some of its most powerful firms and becoming a force at the Museum of Modern Art.
lead_paragraph: Donald B. Marron, a prominent Wall Street financier and philanthropist and a major figure in the New York art world, died on Friday in Manhattan. He was 85.

headline: 5-Year-Old Carries Baby in Subzero Cold After They Are Abandoned, Police Say
abstract: A power outage scared the older child, who, wearing socks and light clothing, carried the baby about half a mile to another house in Alaska.
lead_paragraph: A 5-year-old, wearing just socks and light clothing, carried an 18-month-old through subzero temperatures in the Yukon Flats of Alaska after the power went out at the home where they had been left alone, according to the authorities.

headline: Trump Cripples W.T.O. as Trade War Rages
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A U.S. offensive against the World Trade Organization will effectively shutter the group’s system for settling disputes, at a time it’s most needed.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States has spent two years chipping away at the World Trade Organization, criticizing it as unfair, starving it of personnel and disregarding its authority, as President Trump seeks to upend the global trade system.

headline: A (Grudging) Defense of the $120,000 Banana
abstract: Maurizio Cattelan is more than a prankster, and “Comedian,” his potassium-rich latest work, is more than an overpriced piece of fruit.
lead_paragraph: Art may be long, and life short, but the existence of a hand fruit is most ephemeral of all. This week at Art Basel Miami Beach, the art world’s premier Champagne-steeped swap meet, no work drew more grins, guffaws and selfies than a new sculpture by the semiretired Italian trickster Maurizio Cattelan: a banana duct-taped to the wall, its peel already speckled with brown spots.

headline: Release the Influencers! Quibi’s Plan for Streaming Success
keywords: ['Social Media', 'Millennial Generation', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Web-Original Programming']
abstract: Are you an online star with more than 500,000 followers? Jeffrey Katzenberg may want to have a word with you.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Jeffrey Katzenberg and Meg Whitman, the founders of Quibi, a short-form video app scheduled for an April 6 debut, are trying to create a platform for the smartphone age. To entice subscribers, they have ordered big-budget shows from known quantities like Kevin Hart and Steven Spielberg — but they have turned to social media stars for the kind of casual, low-commitment programming that could make Quibi a daily habit.

headline: First ‘Wonder Woman 1984’ Trailer: Steve Trevor Is Somehow Back
abstract: The superheroine, played by Gal Gadot, has a new look but apparently the same love interest (Chris Pine) in the sequel, directed by Patty Jenkins.
lead_paragraph: “We wanted to bring Wonder Woman into the modern world,” the director Patty Jenkins said before introducing the first trailer for “Wonder Woman 1984” at CCXP, the Comic Con Experience convention in São Paulo, Brazil, on Sunday.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Dec. 9, 2019
abstract: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
lead_paragraph: Students

headline: Rosario Dawson Hits the Trail in Iowa. (Her Boyfriend Is Running for President.)
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Dating and Relationships', 'ACTORS AND ACTRESSES']
abstract: The actress went shopping for vegan snacks — and votes — in Iowa with her boyfriend, the presidential candidate Cory Booker.
lead_paragraph: IOWA CITY — Senator Cory Booker was in a frantic sprint for a little extra zest in Iowa.

headline: Margaret Lawrence, 105, Dies; Pioneering Black Female Psychoanalyst
keywords: ['Psychology and Psychologists', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Women and Girls', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Deaths (Obituaries)']
abstract: She overcame many hurdles, including rejection by Cornell’s medical school, which told her a black man before her “didn’t work out.” (He had died.)
lead_paragraph: As a senior at Cornell in the 1930s, Margaret Lawrence had a nearly perfect academic record and expected to attend the university’s medical school. But Ms. Lawrence (she was Margaret Morgan at the time), the only black student in her class, was denied admission.

headline: Barr Dives Into the Culture Wars, and Social Conservatives Rejoice
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Conservatism (US Politics)', 'Legal Profession', 'Freedom of Religion', 'Attorneys General', 'Christians and Christianity']
abstract: The attorney general embodies the combative culture and conservative ideology that animate the president and the Republican Party. Is he what the party looks like post-Trump?
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When President Trump nominated William P. Barr as attorney general a year ago, establishment Republicans who had chafed at Mr. Trump’s takeover of their party were relieved. Between Mr. Barr’s work in the Reagan White House and his fast-track career under George Bush, he could be a bridge to the Republican Party they knew — and preferred.

headline: Completely Enchanted
abstract: Ellis Hay is back with his second New York Times Crossword.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — When we met the constructor Ellis Hay in March, there were B’s buzzing all over the place. He is back with a nice, straightforward Monday puzzle that would make a great point of entry for any new solver.

headline: Air Force Aims to Deploy a New Battlefield Weapon: Faster Communications
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Military Aircraft', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Drones (Pilotless Planes)']
abstract: Military officials are trying to develop systems that instantly push intelligence to front-line forces, a development strategists say could help deter aggression by Russia and China.
lead_paragraph: SIMI VALLEY, Calif. — The Air Force will propose spending $9 billion over the next five years to build a system to automatically send intelligence to front-line forces, new technology that strategists say will change how the military fights and will help deter aggression by Russia and China.

headline: Protesters Are Fleeing Hong Kong. A Secret Network Is Helping Them.
keywords: ['Hong Kong Protests (2019)', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Politics and Government', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: Risk years of imprisonment or flee? We traced the journey along a covert pipeline helping Hong Kong protesters escape to Taiwan.
lead_paragraph: Risk years of imprisonment or flee? We traced the journey along a covert pipeline helping Hong Kong protesters escape to Taiwan.

headline: The Eight Counts of Impeachment That Trump Deserves
keywords: ['Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Trump-Ukraine Whistle-blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry', 'Impeachment', 'Constitution (US)', 'Amnesties, Commutations and Pardons', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Campaign Finance']
abstract: The lessons from Nixon and Clinton.
lead_paragraph: During Watergate, the House Judiciary Committee considered five articles of impeachment against Richard Nixon — and voted down two of them. During the impeachment of Bill Clinton, the House voted on four articles — and rejected two.

headline: René Auberjonois, a ‘Deep Space Nine’ Star, Dies at 79
abstract: The busy character actor was also known for “Benson,” “Boston Legal” and several Broadway roles.
lead_paragraph: René Auberjonois, a sought-after character actor whose hundreds of roles included a governor’s officious assistant in “Benson,” an alien security officer on “Star Trek: Deep Space Nine,” a managing partner in “Boston Legal” and a con man who gets Huck Finn into hot water in the Broadway musical “Big River,” died on Sunday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 79.

headline: The Gig Economy’s Sexual Misconduct Problem, and How to Fix It
abstract: In my research I’ve heard countless tales of assault, harassment and abuse.
lead_paragraph: Uber has released its long-awaited safety report, detailing sexual assaults, fatal physical assaults and motor vehicle fatalities in the United States. The results on sexual assault are disturbing: nearly 6,000 incidents in 2017 and 2018 combined, ranging from “nonconsensual touching” to rape.

headline: Trump Brings 2 Officers He Cleared of War Crimes Onstage at Fund-Raiser
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: The president had pardoned Army First Lt. Clint Lorance and Maj. Mathew Golsteyn last month, in a move that strained his relationship with Pentagon leaders.
lead_paragraph: President Trump brought two soldiers he had pardoned in cases involving war crimes onstage at a fund-raiser this weekend in Florida, tightening his embrace of an episode that roiled his relationship with military leaders and prompted a public outcry.

headline: The N.F.C.’s Best Team? San Francisco Makes a High-Scoring Case
abstract: The 49ers’ win over New Orleans gave them the conference’s best record. They will have to defend their case as the N.F.C.’s best team while playing a brutal end-of-season schedule.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — Across the last month, the best team in the N.F.C. has been more of an abstract concept than an unassailable certainty. The contenders relish cannibalizing one another. The distinction shifts week to week.

headline: Pensacola Victims: Three Hopeful Men at the Dawn of Naval Careers
keywords: ['Mass Shootings', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The sailors who were fatally shot on Friday at Naval Air Station Pensacola had only recently arrived to train in naval aviation, grieving relatives said.
lead_paragraph: Three young men, one of them not yet 20, recently arrived in the Florida Panhandle, fresh-faced and eager to pursue their dreams at the cradle of American naval aviation.

headline: Oh, Nikki. You’re So Wrong.
keywords: ['Race and Ethnicity', 'Flags, Emblems and Insignia', 'Whites', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Discrimination', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: There is much Nikki Haley could learn from a true heroine of the South Carolina Confederate flag removal: Bree Newsome Bass.
lead_paragraph: There was a moment in which people thought — and many liberals feared — that Nikki Haley, former South Carolina governor and former United States ambassador to the United Nations, would be the post-Donald Trump face of the Republican Party as a political candidate.

headline: The Indispensable Man: How Giuliani Led Trump to the Brink of Impeachment
keywords: ['Trump-Ukraine Whistle-blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Rudy Giuliani didn’t get the job he expected. But as unpaid personal counsel to the president and for-profit peddler of access and advice, he got the spotlight.
lead_paragraph: Not so long ago, it seemed to Rudolph W. Giuliani that he would be presiding over a hefty part of the world.

headline: NATO Conference Is Canceled After U.S. Ambassador Barred a Trump Critic
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: An expert was scheduled to speak at the Copenhagen event but was told the ambassador, Carla Sands, had vetoed his participation.
lead_paragraph: The United States ambassador to Denmark barred an American NATO expert critical of President Trump from speaking at an international conference hosted by the American embassy and a Danish think tank, prompting the event’s cancellation, organizers said.

headline: Pensacola Attack Probed for Terrorism Link. Saudi Suspect Clashed With Instructor.
keywords: ['Foreign Students (in US)', 'Mass Shootings', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Military Bases and Installations', 'International Study and Teaching', 'Terrorism', 'Naval Air Station Pensacola Shooting (2019)']
abstract: The F.B.I. said it was conducting a terrorism investigation into the shooting at Naval Air Station Pensacola, as new information emerged about the gunman’s training at the facility.
lead_paragraph: The investigation into the fatal shooting last week at a Navy training center in Florida was officially characterized as a terrorism inquiry on Sunday, as new details emerged about the Saudi Air Force trainee who killed three sailors on the base where he was a visiting student.

headline: Patriots Run Out of Comebacks in Testy Rematch Against Chiefs
abstract: Tom Brady and his offense’s continued struggles drew boos from New England fans as Kansas City avenged its A.F.C. championship loss.
lead_paragraph: FOXBOROUGH, Mass. — Trailing at home by 16 points in the third quarter on Sunday evening, the New England Patriots had already been booed off the field three times. Tom Brady, the epitome of cool, had snapped in the first half, furiously charging at a mammoth Kansas City defensive lineman after a jarring tackle. The Patriots’ beleaguered young wide receivers, blamed for everything that has troubled New Englanders this month except for last week’s snowstorm, had dropped two pivotal passes.

headline: ‘Keep’ Review: Daniel Kitson Takes Inventory
abstract: An excursion into the Theater of Lists at St. Ann’s Warehouse proves to be both original and exasperating.
lead_paragraph: You’ve been warned. At the beginning of Daniel Kitson’s “Keep” at St. Ann’s Warehouse, a frustrating show in ways that Kitson does and doesn’t intend, Kitson tells you that what you’re about to see “is not a stand-up comedy show, but neither is it one of the powerful pieces of storytelling theater I have made my own.”

headline: ‘Watchmen’ Season 1, Episode 8 Recap: Chicken or Egg?
abstract: This week’s episode asked: If you knew when and how a relationship would end, would you take the plunge?
lead_paragraph: “By definition, don’t all relationships end in tragedy?”

headline: ‘Mr. Robot’ Season 4, Episode 10 Recap: Run Away With Me
abstract: This week’s episode took a bit of a breather to focus on the star-crossed fates of Darlene and Dom.
lead_paragraph: And now, a breather.

headline: After Eruption in New Zealand, 5 Dead, 8 Missing and ‘No Signs of Life’
abstract: Rescuers were struggling to reach White Island, where conditions remained dangerous. The authorities said a criminal investigation had been opened in the eruption’s aftermath.
lead_paragraph: WHAKATANE, New Zealand — They had taken boats to a desolate island to get a glimpse of a natural wonder, but when the White Island volcano erupted on Monday,  a scene of stunning beauty suddenly turned into a deadly trap.

headline: Elizabeth Warren Earned $1.9 Million Over 3 Decades for Corporate and Legal Work
abstract: While demanding that an opponent, Pete Buttigieg, disclose his McKinsey clients, Ms. Warren provided a fuller explanation of her compensation as a legal consultant.
lead_paragraph: Senator Elizabeth Warren disclosed a detailed list of compensation she received during 30 years of moonlighting as a legal consultant — about $1.9 million in all — as she and Mayor Pete Buttigieg continued a back-and-forth demanding transparency in the race for the Democratic presidential nomination.

headline: ‘Madam Secretary’ Proved TV Didn’t Have to Be Hip to Be Great
abstract: The CBS drama, which ended its six-season run on Sunday, was a one of the squarest shows on television. That was a big part of its charm.
lead_paragraph: Here’s to loving one of the least-hip shows on TV. To its earnest parenting, its destabilizing cast changes, its long seasons. Get excited for a cameo from Colin Powell, as himself! Marvel at the variety of accents being attempted! Can we interest you in some passionate descriptions of diplomacy and an occasional mention of Thomas Aquinas?

headline: Even a Little Alcohol May Raise Cancer Risk
abstract: Associations between drinking and cancer were particularly strong for cancers of the mouth, throat, stomach and colon.
lead_paragraph: Even moderate alcohol consumption may increase the risk for cancer.

headline: N.F.L. Week 14: What We Learned
abstract: George Kittle dragged the 49ers to a win over the Saints, Patrick Mahomes finally beat the Patriots and the Ravens topped the Bills in a week that did not disappoint.
lead_paragraph: A week ago, San Francisco lost a defensive thriller in Baltimore. This week, they won a shootout in New Orleans against Drew Brees and the Saints. Doubt the 49ers all you want, but you can’t accuse them of not having range. In what may prove to be the biggest week of the season in terms of strong head-to-head matchups, the 49ers cemented themselves as Super Bowl contenders, the Baltimore Ravens held on for a tough win over the Buffalo Bills and the Kansas City Chiefs, with some help from the officials, upset the New England Patriots in Foxborough.

headline: A Few Cities Have Cornered Innovation Jobs. Can That Be Changed?
abstract: A new report documents the concentration of cutting-edge industries in a few coastal areas and why lawmakers ought to be alarmed.
lead_paragraph: There are about a dozen industries at the frontier of innovation. They include software and pharmaceuticals, semiconductors and data processing. Most of their workers have science or tech degrees. They invest heavily in research and development. While they account for only 3 percent of all jobs, they account for 6 percent of the country’s economic output.

headline: You Live Your Life Online. Don’t Forget Your Manners
abstract: Etiquette helps you get on in life, but having a range of etiquette makes all the difference.
lead_paragraph: I have made many a digital etiquette faux pas in my time. I used to be that person in the office who always replied to a group email first to show how keen I was, but really I was just coming across as annoying and needy. I spammed my social media with MySpace-angle selfies — camera held aloft, lips pouting like a fish — in my formative online years. I have even ghosted someone.

headline: What’s on TV Monday: ‘Bridesmaids’ and ‘It Comes at Night’
abstract: The extended cut of the wedding comedy arrives on HBO. And Trey Edward Shults’s horror movie jumps from Amazon to Netflix.
lead_paragraph: BRIDESMAIDS (EXTENDED VERSION) (2011) Stream on HBO. Rent on Amazon, Google Play, iTunes, Vudu and YouTube. Paul Feig directs as Kristen Wiig stars as Annie, the disastrous maid of honor for the wedding of her lifelong friend Lillian (Maya Rudolph). The movie, written by Wiig and Annie Mumolo, follows the chaotic gaggle of bridesmaids through the ups and downs of matrimonial rites of passage — dress fittings, bachelorette parties, bridal showers — and twists each ritual into a new catastrophe. As Manohla Dargis wrote of “Bridesmaids” in her Times review, “Ms. Wiig and Ms. Mumolo want to make you giggle and snort — but they get at the layers of insanity in weddings as well as the joys.”

lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — The uncertainty for unbeaten Ohio State going into the Big Ten championship game wasn’t about whether the Buckeyes needed to beat Wisconsin to make the College Football Playoff. It was about what they could showcase for the Playoff’s committee as they made a final push for the top seed.

headline: Despite Warnings, Trump Moves to Expand Migrant Family Detention
keywords: ['Immigration Detention', 'Families and Family Life', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Tiny prison uniforms were replaced with T-shirts. Health care and schooling improved. Experts say there is still no safe way to incarcerate families.
lead_paragraph: DILLEY, Texas — On a burning hot day last summer at the South Texas Family Residential Center, a federal detention facility for immigrant families, Kenia and her son, Michael, 11, were hunched over a foosball table in an air-conditioned recreation room when Michael dropped to the floor and started sobbing. He curled his body into a ball and writhed as if he were in pain.

headline: What Are Your Experiences With Meditation?
abstract: What strategies do you use to calm your mind, diminish stress or get through a crisis?
lead_paragraph: Do you have any effective ways to protect yourself from the distractions and stressors of daily life? Or to quiet your mind? Have you ever tried meditating or practicing mindfulness?

keywords: ['APNEA (SLEEP DISORDER)', 'Sleep', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Snoring']

lead_paragraph: Both of us have sleep apnea, and both of us receive treatment that makes a world of difference.

headline: Are Sugar Substitutes Good for Kids?
abstract: Information is limited about the long-term safety of consuming nonnutritive sweeteners.
lead_paragraph: Even the name, “nonnutritive sweeteners,” sounds like it was invented to avoid, well, sugarcoating the issue. We used to call them artificial sweeteners; this new term is intended to emphasize that they have no nutritional content — no vitamins, no minerals, no calories, or very few (that’s the whole point).

headline: When Drug Side Effects Pose Real Dangers
abstract: The rule of thumb in medicine — first, do no harm — has as its corollary that the expected benefits of treatment should outweigh its potential risks.
lead_paragraph: About a month ago, I took myself off a medication without first contacting the doctor who prescribed it, a step I have often cautioned others never to do. A neurologist had put me on the anticonvulsant drug Keppra as a preventive in case a seizure had caused an otherwise unexplained fall on my head and brief memory loss.

headline: Michelle Wolf Doesn’t Want to Be Your Folk Hero

lead_paragraph: It seems like every comic has a routine that deals with outrage culture. But when Michelle Wolf addresses it, you can be sure she is speaking from experience.

But for Madhuri Parson, a sixth-generation jeweler whose Hudson Yards studio has doubled as her company’s base of operations since she moved there in the summer of 2016, it was an absolute must.

headline: ‘The Ferrante Effect’: In Italy, Women Writers Are Ascendant
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Books and Literature', 'Writing and Writers', 'Book Trade and Publishing']
abstract: “My Brilliant Friend” and Elena Ferrante’s other best-selling books are inspiring female novelists and shaking up the country’s male-dominated literary establishment.
lead_paragraph: ROME — In Italy, literary fiction has long been considered a man’s game. Publishers, critics and prize committees have dismissed books by women as chick lit and beach reads. They scoffed at Elena Ferrante, the author of “My Brilliant Friend,” as the writer of mere page-turners.

headline: Violent Protests and Free Speech: Who’s to Blame for an Officer’s Injuries?
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'First Amendment (US Constitution)', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: The A.C.L.U. asked the Supreme Court to hear an appeal from DeRay Mckesson, a Black Lives Matter activist sued by a Louisiana police officer.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The lawsuit, a federal judge found, bordered on the delusional. A Louisiana police officer injured in a protest tried to sue the hashtag #BlackLivesMatter, which amounted, wrote Judge Brian A. Jackson of the Federal District Court in Baton Rouge, to picking a fight with an idea. “A hashtag,” Judge Jackson wrote, “is patently incapable of being sued.”

headline: ‘Marriage Story’ and ‘The Irishman’ Propel Netflix to Most Golden Globe Nominations
abstract: Streaming services had a big day with Netflix leading the TV and film categories. Apple’s centerpiece series, “The Morning Show,” and its two stars all received nominations.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — It is Netflix’s world. Hollywood just lives in it.

headline: Jacqueline Woodson on Africa, America and Slavery’s Fierce Undertow
abstract: The African-American novelist journeys to Ghana, once a hub of the trans-Atlantic slave trade, as the nation invites descendants of enslaved Africans to call it their “home.” But can you go home again?
lead_paragraph: IN THE COASTAL TOWN of Elmina, Ghana, the Atlantic Ocean crashes against the rocks with such a ferocity, I make our kids move back away from the gray-blue water. Four hundred years have passed since captured Africans were forced across these waves on their way to bondage in the New World and now, standing at the edge of this violent water, startled by my own anxiety, I feel something deep and old and terrifying. Call it hydrophobia. Call it genetic memory. I’ve always had a fear of the ocean, the fierce pull of its undercurrent, the crest of its powerful waves and most of all, its seeming infinity — the way it moves to a place where the skyline caresses it. Then drops off into nothing at all.

headline: Highlights From the Horowitz Report on the Russia Investigation
keywords: ['Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Special Prosecutors (Independent Counsel)', 'Informers', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Inspectors General']
abstract: The inquiry by the Justice Department’s inspector general found no evidence of the political conspiracy alleged by President Trump but uncovered flaws in how the case was handled.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A much-anticipated report on the early stages of the F.B.I.’s investigation into possible ties between the Trump campaign and Russia heavily criticized how the F.B.I. obtained court orders to eavesdrop on a former Trump campaign aide but found no evidence of political bias or improper motivation by the F.B.I.

headline: The 25 Rooms That Influence the Way We Design
keywords: ['ARCHITECTURE', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Furniture', 'Restoration and Renovation', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Stonehenge (England)', 'PANTHEON (ROME)']
abstract: Three designers, two journalists and an interiors photographer gathered at The New York Times to make a list of history’s most enduring and significant spaces. Here are the results.
lead_paragraph: On an October afternoon, our six-person jury — Tom Delavan, the design and interiors director of T Magazine; Gabriel Hendifar, the creative director of the Manhattan-based lighting and design studio Apparatus; the architect Toshiko Mori; the architect and designer Daniel Romualdez; the veteran design journalist Suzanne Slesin; and the interiors photographer Simon Watson — assembled in a featureless conference room at The New York Times to discuss the most influential rooms of all time. By that, we meant “influential” in its truest sense. We wanted the jury to identify the spaces that not only changed the way we live but also changed the way we see, places — whether pleasing, provocative or completely novel for their eras — that not only informed our panelists’ individual practices as designers and documenters but also challenged how we all, as humans, think about beauty, strangeness, originality, décor, proportion, furnishings, art and the multivalent connections therein that define memorable rooms: ones that, above all, offer a new kind of visual lexicon. These are rooms, in other words, that have influenced and inspired interior design throughout the decades, shaping how our mind identifies and assesses a space, any space.

headline: Russia Banned From Olympics and Global Sports for 4 Years Over Doping

headline: The Children of ISIS Don’t Belong in Cages, Either
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Children and Childhood', 'Detainees', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: The world is failing innocent victims of the war on terrorism.
lead_paragraph: Children peer out from behind the bars into the light, scarred by intense trauma and uncertain of their future, terrified both of their prison and the outside world. The images and stories of these youngsters, robbed of their childhood by the extreme violence of life under the Islamic State, are harrowing. Many are unaccompanied, the large majority are under 12. They now find themselves abandoned in appalling conditions in rudimentary camps in Syria. Governments have to do better: This is not the way to treat children who are also victims of terrorism. Nor is it effective counterterrorism policy.

headline: An Art History Mystery with No Shortage of Sleuths

lead_paragraph: Paul A. Volcker, who helped shape American economic policy for more than six decades, most notably by leading the Federal Reserve’s brute-force campaign to subdue inflation in the late 1970s and early ’80s, died on Sunday in New York. He was 92.

headline: Don’t Let China Win the Green Race
keywords: ['Wind Power', 'Solar Energy', 'Electric and Hybrid Vehicles', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Automobiles', 'United States Politics and Government', 'High-Speed Rail Projects']
abstract: America should be leading the way on clean energy, not falling behind.
lead_paragraph: Washington is consumed with discussion about the consequences of a rising China, from trade disputes, to their authoritarian surveillance and oppression of Uighurs, to their aggression in the South China Sea. There’s comparably little debate about how the United States can shape the environment into which China is rising, let alone the actions we can take at home to ensure our values prevail. We see more focus on tariffs than building wind turbines and solar farms. We should not be spectators in shaping our own future, or the world’s. We should pledge that by the end of the next decade, America will surpass China and win the clean energy race.
