headline: $1.4 Million Homes in California
abstract: A hilltop house in Mendocino County, a midcentury-modern home in Berkeley with Golden Gate Bridge views and a four-building complex in Joshua Tree.
lead_paragraph: After buying this house with impressive ocean views in 2000, the owners added a second floor with a master suite and an artist’s studio, and landscaped the property to create multiple seating areas. The home is in Mendocino County, about eight miles north of Gualala, where there are shops, supermarkets, gas stations, galleries and restaurants. It is a little more than a three-hour drive south to San Francisco.

headline: How Do You Combat Compassion Fatigue?
abstract: Monday: An expert talks about the effects of seeing people living on the streets. Also: A major PG&E settlement, and Katie Hill speaks out.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Documents Reveal U.S. Officials Misled Public on War in Afghanistan
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )']
abstract: The documents, obtained by The Washington Post, paint a stark picture of missteps and failures in the American effort to pacify and rebuild the country.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Prominent American officials concealed pessimistic assessments about the long-running military campaign in Afghanistan, according to thousands of pages of documents published by The Washington Post on Monday. Taken together, the documents paint a stark picture of missteps and failures.

headline: Scenes of New Zealand’s Volcanic Eruption
abstract: A volcano erupted on White Island off New Zealand on Monday. At least 16 people are known to have been killed.
lead_paragraph: A volcano erupted on White Island off New Zealand on Monday. At least 16 people are known to have been killed.

headline: Golden Globes Movies Snubs: ‘Little Women’ and Robert De Niro
abstract: The surprises included nods for the director of “Joker” and Annette Bening (“The Report”).
lead_paragraph: The 2020 Golden Globe nominations were announced Monday in Los Angeles, and while the Hollywood Foreign Press Association, which hands out the prizes, had plenty of love for awards-season contenders like “Parasite,” “Once Upon a Time … in Hollywood” and the field-leading “Marriage Story,” the group also went its own way with a set of eyebrow-raising snubs. Here are some of the unexpected omissions and big surprises from the nominations.

headline: Report on F.B.I. Russia Inquiry Finds Serious Errors but Debunks Anti-Trump Plot
keywords: ['Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Special Prosecutors (Independent Counsel)', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Informers', 'Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Inspectors General', 'Search and Seizure', 'Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA)']
abstract: A long-awaited report by the Justice Department’s inspector general delivers a scathing critique of the F.B.I.’s handling of a wiretap application but also punctures many conspiracy theories.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — F.B.I. officials had sufficient reason to open the investigation into links between Russia and Trump campaign aides in 2016 and acted without political bias, a long-awaited report said on Monday, but it concluded that the inquiry was a rushed and dysfunctional process marked by serious errors in documents related to a wiretap.

headline: The First ‘Ghostbusters: Afterlife’ Trailer Emphasizes the Eerie
abstract: The clip, featuring Finn Wolfhard, is short on jokes and plays more like a horror film. Jason Reitman directed.
lead_paragraph: “I ain’t afraid of no ghosts,” Ray Parker Jr. said in the title song for the original 1984 “Ghostbusters.” Judging by the first full trailer for the forthcoming sequel “Ghostbusters: Afterlife,” viewers might have good reason to be afraid.

headline: At Alvin Ailey, a Quiet Disrupter With No Time for Tears
abstract: Jamar Roberts, the company’s first resident choreographer, wants to bring the world into his dances.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes riding the subway has its upside. It affords time to think — and, in the case of Jamar Roberts, to choreograph. Recently, as he headed to the final working rehearsal for “Ode,” his new dance at Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, he had to think about what it was missing: an ending.

headline: ‘Game of Thrones,’ ‘Russian Doll’ Get Snubbed by Golden Globes
abstract: The television nominations included only one truly quirky choice (“Catch-22”?) but there were a few unexpected choices and omissions.
lead_paragraph: The television nominations for next year’s Golden Globes went largely according to form, with just one truly quirky choice among the shows (see “Catch-22” below) and a paucity of the usual get-a-celebrity-to-come-to-our-party picks (though Reese Witherspoon’s acting nod for “Big Little Lies” might fit into that category). Here are a few of the less expected nominations.

headline: You’ll Never Buy Caramel Corn Again
abstract: Melissa Clark’s new recipe is light, super-crisp, very caramel-y — in short, bonkers delicious.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. There’s a potluck holiday party coming up at the school, at the church or the shul, at the office, the gym, the bait shop, at the yoga studio, the grange hall, the library, wherever communities gather to ask anodyne questions about family and travel this time of year, about the weather, about work. What are you going to bring this year? Not the three bags of Tate’s cookies you picked up at the market last year because you forgot to bake the night before!

headline: What Did the U.S. Get for $2 Trillion in Afghanistan?
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: An assessment of spending on the war in Afghanistan finds there is little to show for it.
lead_paragraph: An assessment of spending on the war in Afghanistan finds there is little to show for it.

headline: Julia Fox, Diamond in the Rough of ‘Uncut Gems’
abstract: The role of a young lifetime: oneself.
lead_paragraph: Julia Fox’s progression from downtown Manhattan persona to actress in the new Adam Sandler movie “Uncut Gems” might sound like an impressive run of luck. Ms. Fox, 29, says she manifested the entire thing.

headline: The Parable of the Sick Pig and the Lonely Rooster
keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'Global Warming', 'Documentary Films and Programs']
abstract: I still believe that living gently on the land will produce an ecological paradise. I also fear the global collapse of agriculture.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — John Chester’s lovely new documentary film, “The Biggest Little Farm,” opens with a tragedy in the making: Wildfires are moving toward the farm from three different directions. A horse whinnies in alarm as workers rush to shepherd a storybook cast of farm animals — chickens, pigs, sheep, cows — toward what they hope will be safer pastures. Sirens wail in the distance. Smoke and ash fill the air.

headline: Whom Does President Trump Remind You Of?
keywords: ['Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Uncouth he may be, but he’s not unfamiliar.
lead_paragraph: Like more than a few Americans, I used to read President Donald Trump’s tweets with trepidation. No modern president had ever expressed himself publicly in this manner, and the universal reaction seemed to be a mixture of horror and consternation.

headline: The Season’s Most Vibrant Jewels
abstract: Dazzling compositions of color — rosy rubies, yellow beryls, azure sapphires — set these kaleidoscopic pieces apart.

headline: It’s 2071, and We Have Bioengineered Our Own Extinction
keywords: ['Biotechnology and Bioengineering', 'Microbiology', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Tardigrades', 'Science Fiction']
abstract: The micro- and macro-organisms that saved humanity from our climate crisis are now changing us — and might destroy us.
lead_paragraph: Editors’ note: This is part of the Op-Eds From the Future series, in which science fiction authors, futurists, philosophers and scientists write Op-Eds that they imagine we might read 10, 50 or even 200 years from now. The challenges they predict are imaginary — for now — but their arguments illuminate the urgent questions of today and prepare us for tomorrow. The Opinion piece below is a work of fiction.

headline: Amazon Accuses Trump of ‘Improper Pressure’ on JEDI Contract
keywords: ['Cloud Computing', 'Enterprise Computing', 'Defense Contracts', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Government Contracts and Procurement', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: In a legal complaint, Amazon said the president had attacked it behind the scenes to harm its C.E.O., Jeff Bezos, “his perceived political enemy.”
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Amazon said in a legal complaint unsealed on Monday that it had lost a $10 billion cloud computing contract with the Pentagon because President Trump used “improper pressure” to divert the contract from the company to harm its chief executive, Jeff Bezos.

headline: Marie Claire Editor Departing for Health Start-Up
abstract: Anne Fulenwider joins a handful of magazine women who have left their posts for new ventures.
lead_paragraph: Hearst Magazines announced today that Anne Fulenwider, the editor in chief of Marie Claire, would leave her post at the end of the year. Aya Kanai, the chief fashion director of Hearst, has been named the new editor of the women’s magazine, and will start in January.

headline: The 10 Best Los Angeles Dishes of 2019
abstract: As she finishes her first year as our California restaurant critic, Tejal Rao names the flavors she can’t forget from in and around the city.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Throughout my first year as a restaurant critic living in Los Angeles, zigzagging across the city in my car, I kept a running list of delicious things I wanted to tell you about.

headline: How an Icy Moon of Saturn Got Its Stripes
abstract: Scientists have developed an explanation for one of the most striking features of Enceladus, an ocean world that has the right ingredients for life.
lead_paragraph: Of the strange and unexplained terrains in our solar system, the south pole of Saturn’s moon Enceladus is among the most perplexing.

headline: Supreme Court Lets Kentucky Abortion Ultrasound Law Take Effect
abstract: The law requires doctors to show and describe ultrasounds to women seeking abortions. Challengers said it violated the First Amendment.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday said it would not hear a challenge to a Kentucky law that requires doctors performing abortions to display fetal ultrasounds and to describe the images to women seeking the procedure. The court’s action means the law will go into effect.

headline: Juice WRLD and the Tragic End of the SoundCloud Rap Era
abstract: The death of the 21-year-old rapper, which comes after those of Lil Peep and XXXTentacion, marks the unsatisfying, rapid conclusion of the decade’s most promising musical movement.
lead_paragraph: Last year, Juice WRLD emerged as SoundCloud rap’s best hope, and also its eulogist.

headline: Seawater Is Filled With a Sugary Feast. Here’s How Sponges Eat It.
keywords: ['Coral', 'Reefs', 'Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Oceans and Seas', 'Bacteria', 'Sugar', 'Microbiology', 'your-feed-science']
abstract: The new research helps explain how sponges, and coral reef ecosystems, survive with limited nutrients.
lead_paragraph: For centuries scientists, even Darwin, couldn’t make sense of it: Tropical water contains so few nutrients, you can see right through it. And yet coral reefs are oases that support about a quarter of all known species on Earth.

headline: Review: An ‘Orlando’ Opera Is a Milestone, but No More, in Vienna
abstract: Olga Neuwirth’s adaptation of Virginia Woolf is the first work by a woman to be performed by the Vienna State Opera.
lead_paragraph: VIENNA — Olga Neuwirth’s “Orlando” had made history even before its world premiere at the Vienna State Opera here on Sunday: It would be the first work by a female composer to be performed by this storied company.

headline: Democrats Close to Agreement With White House on New NAFTA
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations', 'International Trade and World Market', 'North American Free Trade Agreement', 'Law and Legislation', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Organized Labor']

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Democratic lawmakers are nearing an agreement to bring the revised North American free trade deal to a vote after securing additional labor, enforcement and other provisions and winning the support of top labor leaders.

headline: Boy, 3, in Stroller Is Killed at Intersection in East Harlem
abstract: The toddler’s death was the sixth of a child pedestrian who was struck by a vehicle in New York City this year, according to city data.
lead_paragraph: It was a dreary morning, but the mother still put her 3-year-old son in a stroller draped with a teal rain cover and headed out for a coffee and bagel in their East Harlem neighborhood.

keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Local Government', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'States (US)']

headline: Pete Buttigieg’s Stint at McKinsey: So What?
abstract: A reader who is also a McKinsey alum explains that the young Pete Buttigieg would have had little choice in what he worked on. Also: Ending a life full of pain; the art of managing one’s time.

headline: Peloton’s Cringe-y Ad Got Everyone Talking. Its C.E.O. Is Silent.
abstract: But the “Deadpool” star Ryan Reynolds describes how he found a way into the conversation.
lead_paragraph: During a talk in New York on Monday, John Foley, the chief executive of Peloton, did not laugh off the negative reaction to the fitness company’s holiday commercial, a 30-second spot that drew intense criticism and caused Peloton stock to drop 9 percent in one day. Neither did he apologize or defend it. In fact, Mr. Foley did not mention it at all.

headline: ‘Frozen 2’ Soundtrack Debuts at No. 1, Without a ‘Let It Go’ (So Far)
abstract: The Disney movie’s sequel lacks a monster hit like the Idina Menzel smash, but still moved the equivalent of 80,000 copies its first week out.
lead_paragraph: In early 2014, the soundtrack to Disney’s “Frozen” topped the Billboard album chart. At the time, it seemed like a fluke — no LP from an animated film had gone to No. 1 in almost a decade — but “Frozen” wound up dominating the chart for 13 weeks.

headline: Louisville and Ohio State Start to Rise Above Other Teams
abstract: The men’s college basketball season started without any truly dominant teams. But the Cardinals’ defense and the Buckeyes’ impressive wins have them among an emerging top tier.

headline: Italian Cookies for the Holidays
abstract: Find 11 colorful sweets at the retail counter of a new Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, cafe, Ciao, Gloria.
lead_paragraph: Ciao, Gloria in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, is a new source for abundant platters of classic Italian cookies like rainbow squares, craggy brutti ma buoni and white chocolate-dipped cantucci. The cafe is owned by Renato Poliafito, who was a founder of Baked. The pastry chef, Ginger Fisher Baldwin, also from Baked, is creating the cookies with his expert tutelage. There are 11 varieties.

headline: Democrats Signal Abuse of Power and Obstruction of Congress Charges Against Trump
keywords: ['Trump-Ukraine Whistle-blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry', 'Impeachment', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2020']
abstract: Democrats have narrowed their focus to two articles of impeachment against President Trump, expected to be unveiled on Tuesday, after lawyers labeled his conduct a “clear and present danger” to fair elections and national security.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — House Democrats signaled that they would unveil articles of impeachment on Tuesday morning that charge President Trump with abuse of power and obstruction of Congress for conduct they called a “clear and present danger” to the 2020 election and national security.

headline: The Digital Faux Pas We’re All Making
abstract: Mind your manners.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Smarter Living newsletter! Every Monday, S.L. editor Tim Herrera emails readers with tips and advice for living a better, more fulfilling life. Sign up here to get it in your inbox.

headline: Barr and Durham Publicly Disagree With Horowitz Report on Russia Inquiry
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Inspectors General']
abstract: The attorney general reprised his role as a vocal defender of President Trump.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When the Mueller report was made public this spring, Attorney General William P. Barr seemed to try to blunt its findings, playing them down in an early summary and defending President Trump at a news conference just before its release.

headline: In New Memoirs, Food Writers Serve Up Stories About Their Beat
abstract: Adam Platt’s “The Book of Eating” and Ed Levine’s “Serious Eater” are about the passions of professional foodies.
lead_paragraph: If critics’ faces are ever put on postage stamps, Adam Platt’s will be a collectible. The longtime food critic for New York magazine, Platt is tall, bald, large and pale — he resembles a cherubic, sensitive-souled butcher from an imaginary Hitchcock film. (His brother is the actor Oliver Platt.)

headline: ViacomCBS Weighs Putting Black Rock Skyscraper Up for Sale
abstract: ViacomCBS looks to unload the famous "Black Rock" skyscraper in Midtown.
lead_paragraph: Black Rock, the modernist skyscraper designed by Eero Saarinen that has been CBS headquarters for more than half a century and symbolized the network’s invincibility, is being considered for a sale.

headline: Vanna White Takes a Spin as ‘Wheel of Fortune’ Host After 37 Years
abstract: After Pat Sajak had emergency surgery, the show’s famous letter-turner took her first turn leading the show, for three weeks of episodes that start airing on Monday.

headline: 9 Times Big Bird Helped Us Be Better People
abstract: Caroll Spinney, who portrayed Big Bird for decades, died on Sunday. But the lessons he shared on “Sesame Street” live on.
lead_paragraph: Who among us didn’t learn something from Caroll Spinney’s Big Bird over the years? Spinney, who for decades brought the Gentle Giant to life (and also Oscar the Grouch), died on Sunday, but the lessons he shared live on with the millions of people who grew up watching “Sesame Street.”

headline: Pete Frates, Who Promoted the Ice Bucket Challenge, Dies at 34
abstract: The former college baseball player’s involvement in the viral trend helped raise more than $100 million toward fighting A.L.S.
lead_paragraph: Pete Frates, a former college baseball player whose participation in the social media phenomenon known as the Ice Bucket Challenge helped raise more than $100 million toward fighting amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, commonly known as A.L.S. or Lou Gehrig’s disease, died on Monday at his home in Beverly, Mass. He was 34.

headline: ‘Portrait of a Lady on Fire’ Understands Queer Desire
abstract: Céline Sciamma’s lush period piece is one of several movies this year that get intimacy between women right.
lead_paragraph: In the film “Portrait of a Lady on Fire,” set in 18th-century France, a glance, a stare is everything. The artist Marianne (Noémie Merlant) is commissioned to paint the noblewoman Héloïse (Adèle Haenel) so that the man Héloïse’s mother has arranged for her to marry can approve or disapprove of her before the wedding. Héloïse — opposed to the impending nuptials — has refused to sit for portraits before, and at first Marianne must do her job surreptitiously, studying her subject carefully during outings under the guise of having been hired as her companion.

headline: Fox News Picks Bill Hemmer to Take Shepard Smith’s Old Slot
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Television', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: The morning co-anchor, a Fox News veteran, will host a daily newscast at 3 p.m. But don’t expect Smith-style fireworks.
lead_paragraph: Fox News on Monday named Bill Hemmer, one of the network’s longest-serving news anchors, to replace Shepard Smith as host of the channel’s 3 p.m. weekday newscast.

headline: Church’s Nativity Scene Puts Jesus, Mary and Joseph in Cages
keywords: ['Christmas', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Border Barriers', 'Methodist Church', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Asylum, Right of', 'Immigration Detention', 'Family Separation Policy (US Immigration)']
abstract: A California congregation’s display is meant to highlight the plight of refugees and asylum seekers.
lead_paragraph: CLAREMONT, Calif. — The Mylar blanket glitters like tinsel, but wrapped around the figure of the baby Jesus, it looks hostile and stark. His parents, Mary and Joseph, look on from their own chain-link cages. Barbed wire hovers overhead.

headline: This Hanukkah, Let Michael Solomonov Make Dinner
abstract: For a Whole Foods holiday meal, the Zahav chef serves chicken schnitzel and other fried delights.
lead_paragraph: “For me Hanukkah is about frying in olive oil,” said Michael Solomonov, the chef of Zahav, who has created a dinner menu for the holiday that’s being sold to go at Whole Foods Market. Meaty and crisp chicken schnitzels topped with amba, a condiment he makes with apples instead of the usual mangoes, are the main dish. Alongside are crisp-tender green beans and mushrooms swirled with a tahini sauce, a sweet-sour eggplant and red bell pepper mixture, and plump, lightly fried leek and potato cakes. “It’s less iconic than usual, but I think it’s in the spirit of the holiday,” Mr. Solomonov said.

headline: In Collecting Nobel Prize, Ethiopia’s Leader Plans to Sidestep Media
abstract: Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed is too busy and too humble for news conferences, his spokeswoman says, but observers say he’s avoiding scrutiny over trouble at home.

headline: Who Is John Durham, the Prosecutor Investigating the Russia Inquiry
keywords: ['Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Special Prosecutors (Independent Counsel)']
abstract: Mr. Durham, the top federal prosecutor in Connecticut, has investigated potential wrongdoing by the F.B.I. and C.I.A. for the Clinton, Bush, Obama and Trump administrations.
lead_paragraph: John H. Durham, a federal prosecutor conducting a criminal investigation into the origins of the F.B.I.’s Russia probe, said Monday that he disagreed with a report released by the Justice Department’s inspector general, which said there was no basis for President Trump’s accusation that the bureau conspired against him during the 2016 presidential election.

headline: McKinsey Gives Pete Buttigieg Permission to Disclose Clients
abstract: Mr. Buttigieg will also open his fund-raisers to the press and identify people raising money for his campaign, in a significant concession from a candidate facing pressure over transparency.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Mayor Pete Buttigieg will disclose his management consulting clients, open his fund-raisers to reporters and reveal the names of people raising money for his presidential campaign, his campaign announced Monday, a series of significant concessions toward transparency for a candidate under increasing pressure to release more details about his personal employment history and campaign finances.

headline: Getting Help, and Giving Back
abstract: DeAdra Lee and her son, Dacian, fled Chicago for Florida with virtually nothing. Though they are still struggling, they are now volunteering at the community dinner that saved them.
lead_paragraph: BRADENTON, Fla. — Three years ago, DeAdra Lee sold nearly everything she owned and packed what remained into a cargo van. Then she and her infant son, Dacian, left Chicago for Florida’s Gulf Coast.

headline: Rare Whiskey Collection Expected to Fetch $10 Million at Auction
abstract: Richard Gooding, a Colorado businessman who died in 2014, collected more than 3,900 bottles over two decades.
lead_paragraph: For more than two decades, Richard Gooding traveled the world in search of his favorite whiskeys. Next year, the more than 3,900 bottles he collected will be sold in two auctions, including rare offerings from storied distilleries such as Macallan, Bowmore and Stromness.

headline: A Guide to Watching Scorsese Movies Like an Insider
abstract: The director sprinkles his work with references to the films he loves. That’s probably why the barbershop sequence in “The Irishman” ends with a shot of flowers reminiscent of “Vertigo.”
lead_paragraph: This article contains spoilers for “The Irishman” and other Martin Scorsese films.

headline: Before Death, Juice WRLD Flew on Jet Loaded With Drugs, Police Say
abstract: The up-and-coming artist, whose cause of death remains unknown, went into convulsions while officers in Chicago searched the private plane he arrived in.

lead_paragraph: “Beetlejuice,” which overcame a sluggish start to become a fan favorite on Broadway, is being evicted from its theater to make room for another musical that promises to be more lucrative.

headline: What the Russia Global Sports Ban Means, and What It Doesn’t
abstract: Investigations concluded Russia cheated, then tried to cover up the cheating after it had been caught. Now it will pay a price for the cover-up. Or will it?
lead_paragraph: Like many such rulings, the decision to bar Russia from international sports for four years raises more questions than it answers. For instance, Russia has been barred before, but its athletes have continued competing. Why is that? Let’s try to clear away the fog.

headline: Boeing 737 Max Factory Was Plagued With Problems, Whistle-Blower Says

That manager, Ed Pierson, plans to tell his story to Congress on Wednesday.

headline: Who the Heck Is That?
abstract: A look at one of the entries from last week’s puzzles that stumped our solvers.
lead_paragraph: The entry AMOS has appeared in the New York Times Crossword more than 500 times, and can be clued many different ways. Solvers have seen AMOS clued as the maker of the “Famous AMOS” cookies, as the singer Tori, as the biblical prophet and others. The Saturday, Dec. 7 puzzle by Kevin G. Der and Erik Agard introduced the Crossword to the Nigerian author AMOS Tutuola (1920-1997).

headline: Restore Bolivian Democracy and Break Its History of Coups
keywords: ['Politics and Government', "Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat"]
abstract: Evo Morales is out after corruption at the polls, but his right-wing temporary successor must ensure free elections.

lead_paragraph: Hundreds of Nike employees, angered both by the company’s steadfast support of the disgraced running coach Alberto Salazar and by its treatment of female employees and sponsored athletes, protested their employer Monday at its headquarters in Beaverton, Ore.

headline: Marvin Miller Adds a Missing Piece of Baseball’s Story to the Hall of Fame
abstract: Though he wanted no part of the Hall, Miller has finally been recognized for showing players what they were truly worth.
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — The big story on the first full day of baseball’s winter meetings on Monday was Stephen Strasburg becoming the richest pitcher in major league history. Strasburg reached an agreement to stay with the Washington Nationals for seven years and $245 million. If he had wanted to sign elsewhere, perhaps with his hometown San Diego Padres, he could have done that. But now he is back with the team he just led to a title, and he probably will never pitch for anyone else.

headline: Over Shouts and Bangs of the Gavel, Democrats Make Their Impeachment Case Against Trump
abstract: Protests and parliamentary bickering reigned as the House Judiciary Committee formally heard arguments for and against President Trump’s impeachment.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Two minutes into Monday’s historic House Judiciary Committee hearing into the impeachment of President Trump — even before Representative Jerrold Nadler, the chairman, issued the customary call for decorum — a protester, screaming that Mr. Nadler was committing treason, was dragged out of the grand columned hearing room by the Capitol Police.

In addition to the hearing, the Justice Department’s inspector general released a much-anticipated report on the  investigation into links between Russia and the Trump campaign, which found the F.B.I. had sufficient reason to open the inquiry.

headline: Twin 4-Year-Olds Climb Steep Ravine to Safety After Fatal Car Crash
abstract: Aurora and Rosaline Crider, twin toddlers in Washington State, managed to get out of their booster seats and crawl up to a roadway after a car accident that killed their father.
lead_paragraph: A silver 2017 Nissan Sentra veered off a road in rural Washington State on Friday evening, barreled down a steep embankment, struck several trees, and came to a stop. The driver, Corey Simmons, 47, was unresponsive, the police said.

headline: Atlanta Newspaper and Warner Bros. Battle Over ‘Richard Jewell’
abstract: The Journal-Constitution threatened legal action over the Clint Eastwood movie’s depiction of its 1996 Olympic bomb reporting.
lead_paragraph: A war of words erupted on Monday between The Atlanta Journal-Constitution and Warner Bros. over “Richard Jewell,” a new Clint Eastwood-directed film that depicts the newspaper’s reporting after a bomb exploded at the 1996 Summer Olympics.

headline: Review: In ‘Greater Clements,’ the Tragedy of a Town that Closed
abstract: Samuel D. Hunter’s creaky play about the downsizing of the American West features terrific performances by Judith Ivey and Edmund Donovan.
lead_paragraph: As other journalists are said to cover the police beat or subway beat, I used to say in my pre-critic days that I covered the tear beat. For whatever reason, editors felt compelled to send me wherever people were crying. The job was to capture the sadness of, say, a mother mourning her murdered gay son, while also suggesting how that sadness said something about us all.

headline: ‘Halfway Bitches’ Review: A Play as Unruly as Life Itself
abstract: Stephen Adly Guirgis’s bumpy, vibrant and expansive comic drama about a women’s homeless shelter features a cast of 18 (or 19, counting the goat).
lead_paragraph: Prepare to be surrounded — and, ultimately, to surrender.

headline: Say ‘Seasons Greetings’ With Chocolate
abstract: Sweeter Cards offer a thoughtful card with a little something extra — a full-size chocolate bar.
lead_paragraph: With Sweeter Cards, a greeting-card-meets-chocolate-bar, a stocking stuffer can be sweet in both taste and sentiment. Founded in January, the St. Louis-based company includes Hanukkah and Christmas greetings among its offerings. Each card comes with the same type of Fair Trade-certified chocolate: dark, sprinkled with sea salt and a ribbon of caramel. The company will handwrite a message inside for online orders and ship the 3.5-ounce bar in a small white box.

headline: At the Big Brawl

lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — It has been more than a year since we tried to escape from Eric Berlin’s last puzzle in The New York Times, and he is back to stir up more trouble.

headline: What Your Email Signature Says About You
keywords: ['E-Mail', 'Social Media', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Customs, Etiquette and Manners']
abstract: Sent from my iPhone.
lead_paragraph: There’s nothing like doing a story about email to make you feel really, really insecure about your own digital correspondence.

headline: Museum of Ice Cream Returns With a Bigger Space
abstract: The eye-catching experiential museum now has three stories of Instagram-able ice cream moments.
lead_paragraph: Enter through the gift shop. The bright pink fun house called the Museum of Ice Cream opens in SoHo on Saturday. The entrance features a dipping counter where signature flavors like honey-swirled Queen Bee, crunchy Churro Churro and Malt Shake, with nubbins of malt balls, are scooped. Beyond, ticket holders will find three stories of ice cream installations, including a gallery of ice cream history and a speakeasy-style lounge where sundaes and shakes are served. Upstairs, there’s a room of bananas on strings, a space with secret doors, a pretend subway car and a stand for elastic Turkish ice cream. The lower level has the colorful sprinkles pool that the museum is known for and a big playroom with a tub full of cones. There are guides throughout to help.

headline: Lady M Adds Champagne to Its Signature Creation
abstract: A seasonal Mille Crêpes cake is topped with a glittering gelée made with bubbly.
lead_paragraph: Pop the cork alongside a dessert like no other, from the kitchens of Lady M, the bakery founded in New York in 2001. It has infused its famous nine-inch multilayered Mille Crêpes cake with Champagne for the holidays. A whiff of strawberry enhances the pastry cream between the delicate layers and a shimmering Champagne gelée paves the top. The cake can be ordered whole for a party, or by the slice to eat on the spot.

headline: A New Turkey for the Season
abstract: D’Artagnan now sells a free-range turkey raised on scrap vegetables.
lead_paragraph: This year, for the first time, D’Artagnan is selling turkeys, raised free range in Pennsylvania the same way as its Green Circle chickens, on scrap vegetables from food markets. The birds are grown to market weight more slowly than usual and air-chilled. I tried one for Thanksgiving without brining or heavy seasonings, roasted at 375 degrees for about 12 minutes per pound with a 30-minute resting period. The consensus was that it was very tasty, and the meaty breast was also quite moist. The turkeys are available throughout the holiday season.

headline: A Bush Grandson and Trump’s Former V.A. Pick Vie for Congressional Seats in Texas

lead_paragraph: One comes from a political dynasty that has had its differences with President Trump, and the other is intertwined with the president. Now, both are seeking to fill a Republican power vacuum in open-seat congressional races in Texas.

lead_paragraph: SANTIAGO, Chile — A fleet of military aircraft and navy and merchant ships continue searching the gelid waters north of Antarctica for a Chilean Air Force cargo plane that went missing on Monday evening with 38 people on board.

She represents an area in Queens near where the campus was to be built. She does not represent the area where the campus was to be built.

headline: The Fury in France
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Yellow Vests Movement', 'Strikes', 'Organized Labor', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: Could the latest round of strikes spell the beginning of the end for Emmanuel Macron?
lead_paragraph: France is paralyzed. Since a general strike began on Thursday, planes have been grounded, mail delivery stopped and schools closed, and trains remain in their depots. Even lawyers are staying home. Some 800,000 people took to the street across the country last Thursday, and another major demonstration is planned for today as the strike continues. As one participant put it to the French newspaper Mediapart, the mass mobilizations are meant as a rebuke to “Macron and his world.”

headline: What’s on TV Tuesday: Ellen DeGeneres and ‘Astronomy Club: The Sketch Show’
abstract: The talk show host gives back to families in need in her holiday special, and a new sketch comedy series starring an all-black troupe hits Netflix.
lead_paragraph: ELLEN’S GREATEST NIGHT OF GIVEAWAYS 8 p.m. on NBC. Tuning into Ellen DeGeneres’s talk show on any day of the year is almost guaranteed to be a feel-good exercise. But this week, the host is dialing up the positivity with a special holiday series that focuses on giving back to families in need (as well as showering her live audience with goodies, à la Oprah Winfrey). Jennifer Aniston joins the comedian on the first of her three-night gifting spree, which will also welcome other celebrity guests like Chrissy Teigen, Justin Timberlake and Michelle Obama throughout the week. Get the tissues ready!

keywords: ['Elections', 'Politics and Government', 'Social Media', 'Political Advertising', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: Foreign meddling was once the most feared source of online deception before critical elections. Now, some candidates themselves are turning to such manipulative tactics.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Manipulated Twitter accounts, doctored videos, dodgy websites and questions of foreign meddling. In just six weeks, the campaign leading up to Britain’s general election this Thursday, one of its most important votes in a generation, has had a taste of what the dark arts of online campaigning have to offer.

headline: SoftBank Takes Loss in Sale of Wag, Dog-Walking Start-Up
abstract: The technology investment powerhouse sold its shares as its pushes the companies it bets on to seek profits and long-term stability.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The SoftBank Vision Fund has sold its stake in Wag, the troubled dog-walking start-up, back to the company at a loss, according to two people briefed on the deal, in a further sign of turmoil for the Japanese investment powerhouse that has bet big and lost big on the technologies of the future.

headline: Duterte Says Martial Law in Southern Philippines Will End This Month
abstract: The president imposed military rule on the island of Mindanao two and a half years ago, after an Islamist rebellion in the city of Marawi.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — President Rodrigo Duterte announced on Tuesday that military rule in the southern Philippines would soon end, two and a half years after he imposed it in response to a rebellion by Islamic State militants in the city of Marawi.

lead_paragraph: On Dec. 7, thousands of people spent the night sleeping outside in cities across the world.

headline: Czech Hospital Shooting Leaves at Least 6 Dead
abstract: A man who was believed to be the attacker killed himself as officers closed in, the authorities said. The shooting was the deadliest in the country since 2015.
lead_paragraph: A gunman killed six people on Tuesday after opening fire at close range in a hospital waiting room in the eastern Czech city of Ostrava, and a man who was believed to be responsible for the relatively rare instance of gun violence in the country killed himself hours later as the police closed in, the authorities said.

headline: Why Were Tourists Allowed to Visit an Active New Zealand Volcano?
abstract: Visitors were allowed to tour the mouth of the White Island volcano despite recent warnings about bursts of gas and steam.
lead_paragraph: WHAKATANE, New Zealand — Above the noise of the boat engine, there was quiet, Geoff Hopkins remembered. There was no rumble, no roar to signal that the White Island volcano had awakened.

lead_paragraph: PAGAN VIRTUES: Poems, by Stephen Dunn. (Norton, $26.95.) Dunn’s sly, companionable collection, his 19th, is filled with an embrace of the everyday that reifies the epigraph from Emerson: “An actually existent fly is more important than a possibly existent angel.”

headline: C-Section Is Not Tied to Obesity in Children
abstract: A large new study found no link between the method of birth and obesity.
lead_paragraph: Some recent reports have suggested that women who give birth by cesarean section are more likely to have obese children. But a large new study found no link between the method of birth and obesity.

headline: Homestays: Finding Comfort in a Stranger’s Home
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'International Study and Teaching']
abstract: From a Peruvian mud-brick house to a wooden longhouse in Borneo, travelers are rediscovering the intimate thrill of a homestay.
lead_paragraph: While planning a trip to Peru last July, Brian Twite and his girlfriend, Constance Hansen, decided to skip hotels and stay with a host family. At $35 a night, the accommodation in the Santiago district of Cusco was a bargain. But the warmth of their host mother, a 65-year-old widow named Marie, won them over.

headline: What Happens When a Weddings Influencer Gets Divorced?
keywords: ['Weddings and Engagements', 'Divorce, Separations and Annulments', 'Social Media']
abstract: Stone Fox Bride made Molly Rosen Guy the face of bohemian weddings. Then her marriage ended.
lead_paragraph: A woman who bought her wedding dress at Stone Fox Bride was probably going to wear a flower crown along with it. She most likely idolized the Olsen twins and had an active Instagram presence. Her wedding was not going to be religious, but it was going to be spiritual, and her vows might even include curse words. She was going to buck tradition, and she was going to do it in a sunset-pink robe dress with silk chiffon bell sleeves that cost $6,800.

headline: The Yearbook That Victims of School Shootings Never Collected
keywords: ['School Shootings and Armed Attacks', 'Newtown, Conn, Shooting (2012)', 'Parkland, Fla, Shooting (2018)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Law and Legislation', 'Gun Control']

headline: Ruth Carter and Cynthia Erivo on Clothes, Culture and Self-Expression
abstract: Two creative people in two different fields in one wide-ranging conversation.
lead_paragraph: “This has been a long time coming!” said Ruth Carter, 59, in her Academy Award acceptance speech for best costume design for her work on the film “Black Panther” (2018). Carter, who was born in Springfield, Mass., and lives in Los Angeles, is the first African-American to win that Oscar, and her résumé reads like a tour through the past three decades of black cinema: After getting her start with the director Spike Lee on “School Daze” (1988) and “Do the Right Thing” (1989), she went on to costume films as varied as “How Stella Got Her Groove Back” (1998), “Love & Basketball” (2000) and “Selma” (2014). For “Black Panther,” Carter helped bring the futuristic African kingdom of Wakanda to life by fitting the stars Lupita Nyong’o and Angela Bassett in avant-garde outfits inspired in part by the traditional garb of the Surma and Zulu people.

headline: Don’t Think Sanders Can Win? You Don’t Understand His Campaign
abstract: There was a time in America when being called a socialist could end a political career. Not anymore.

headline: A Swiss Watch That Lets You in on Its Secrets
abstract: Through the back of Vacheron Constantin’s luxurious new timepiece, you can see what makes it tick.
lead_paragraph: History often treats the engineering marvels of the 21st century as exponentially more virtuosic than what came before, but consider the tourbillon. Created in 1795 by the Paris-based watchmaker Abraham-Louis Breguet, a favorite of Louis XVI and Marie Antoinette, the mechanism (French for “whirlwind”) is perhaps the most esoteric and elegant watch complication ever conceived. Born of horology’s obsession with maintaining accuracy to the millisecond, the tourbillon counteracts the effect of the earth’s gravity by constantly rotating the cage that holds the timepiece’s balance wheel, balance spring and escapement while the movement is running. The idea was to eliminate errors in rate — the loss or gain in time that would arise if the watch stayed too long in one position — by crafting an internal apparatus that continually turned on an axis. Such a marvel of intricacy must be witnessed to be fully understood: It is as transfixing as watching a heart beat. In this new incarnation by the Swiss company Vacheron Constantin, which has specialized in rarefied timepieces since its founding in 1755, you can stare at it all you want through the round porthole at the bottom of the blue lacquer dial or through its sapphire crystal back. Because the case is fashioned from stainless steel instead of the platinum or gold used for most tourbillon watches, this exemplar of late 18th-century ingenuity seems decidedly contemporary — and, perhaps, ever so slightly less beyond our grasp. Vacheron Constantin Overseas Tourbillon, $98,500, (877) 701-1755.

headline: New York’s Top 10 New Restaurants of 2019
abstract: Pete Wells names his favorites among the new food halls, tasting counters, pasta joints, dim sum parlors and taco trucks he visited this year.
lead_paragraph: It’s true, I couldn’t figure out how to allocate stars to the labyrinth of Spanish restaurants, bars, cafes, kiosks and shops that the chef José Andrés presides over in the Hudson Yards complex. But putting it in the No. 1 slot for the year isn’t a close call. Not that Mercado Little Spain is without flaws. It has its share, starting with a name that’s too long. But it has made the city’s Spanish food scene, what, five times better? Ten times? Mercado Little Spain gives us ingredients we’ve never tasted in New York before, like weeks-old Ibérico pigs slowly melted over fire, or imported rabbit — so flavorful that nobody will say it tastes like chicken — in the Valencian paella cooked over burning logs. It also sells high-fidelity transcriptions of dishes from the chefs Ferran Adrià, whose liquid olives are still blowing minds, and his brother, Albert, who fed recipes to the outstanding pastry department. Somehow, though, the most impressive foods are the most elementary: the gazpacho that shimmers with olive oil and sherry vinegar; the thick, dark hot chocolate that comes with churros just out of the fryer; the goblets of gin and tonics. These and other dishes are so much better than what we’re used to that Mercado Little Spain might as well be the only Spanish restaurant in New York.

lead_paragraph: If you’d like some comic book art, TV artifacts, or a little something from the movies, this may be your month as an array of pop culture memorabilia is coming to auction. The collectibles include original comics pages drawn by Steve Ditko and Will Eisner; television items like the frightening warrior doll from “Trilogy of Terror” and a jacket worn by the Fonz on “Happy Days”; and film props that include a motorcycle ridden by Tom Cruise in “Mission Impossible 2” and boxing trunks, stained with theatrical blood, worn by Sylvester Stallone in “Rocky III.”

headline: Baked Pastas Nodding to Florence Come to the West Village
abstract: A West Village spot from a Danny Meyer alumna, the return of Colors NYC and more restaurant news.
lead_paragraph: Emanuele Bugiani, an owner of the Fiaschetteria Pistoia restaurants in the East and West Village, has opened a tiny new spot focusing on baked pasta. He’s dipped into history for inspiration, basing the restaurant on Pasta al Forno, in Florence, Italy. That restaurant, open from 1964 to 2000, was owned by Marino Pollacci, a pasta maker from Bologna who, Mr. Bugiani says, traveled all over Italy to study baked pastas. In addition to a classic lasagna Bolognese, a crespelle casserole of spinach-filled crepes, a dome of tomato-swathed Neapolitan timpano and an elaborate Sicilian timballo, Mr. Bugiani’s brief menu offers a few vegetable dishes, like eggplant Parmigiana and potatoes with truffles. The place consists of a compact serving counter and several marble-topped tables with about a dozen seats. The dishes are sold by the portion or, for a special occasion — tree-trimming, ball drop, maybe — they can be ordered to serve eight to 10.

headline: ‘Crime in Progress’ Tells the Story Behind the Steele Dossier
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates']
abstract: Glenn Simpson and Peter Fritsch, founders of the private intelligence firm Fusion GPS, write about what turned up in their investigation into Donald Trump’s ties to Russia.
lead_paragraph: In the annals of political warfare, sober recitations of facts often pale next to lurid speculation. Before they founded the private intelligence firm Fusion GPS, Glenn Simpson and Peter Fritsch had long careers reporting and editing for The Wall Street Journal. As old journalism hands, they shouldn’t have been surprised when their diligent research into Donald Trump’s finances slipped into the media stream with barely a ripple, while the raw intelligence memos sent to Fusion by the former MI6 agent Christopher Steele landed like a breaching whale.

Two long-necked feathery ostrich puppets followed, with one laying an egg that cracked open to reveal a baby ostrich puppet. Then a bright orange cat puppet tap-danced to the old show tune “I’m Fascinating.”

headline: Tiny Love Stories: ‘How to Survive a Broken Heart (With Pictures)’
abstract: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
lead_paragraph: All I ever wanted was a dog, but Carlito was allergic and unmovable. I married him anyway, certain that love would prevail. One night while eating with friends in a Manhattan restaurant, a 50-pound chandelier broke out of the ceiling, partly striking my head. I bled; he wept. When the E.M.T. told everyone I would live, Carlito’s friend leaned over my stretcher and whispered, “Now’s the time to ask for anything …” We named the puppy Chandelier. Carlito sneezed every day of our dog’s life, but he didn’t care one bit. — Shari Simpson

headline: The Decorous Surfaces and Fraught Subtexts of Alice Adams’s Life and Work
abstract: “Alice Adams,” a new biography by Carol Sklenicka, recounts the career of the elegant novelist and short story writer who specialized in the disappointments of romance.
lead_paragraph: ALICE ADAMSPortrait of a WriterBy Carol Sklenicka

headline: Supreme Court May Back Insurers in $12 Billion Obamacare Case
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: The justices weighed whether the federal government may walk away from a commitment to shield insurance companies from losses.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court seemed inclined on Tuesday to require the federal government to live up to its promise to shield insurance companies from some of the risks they took in participating in the exchanges established by President Barack Obama’s health care law, the Affordable Care Act.

headline: Climate Change Is Ravaging the Arctic, Report Finds
abstract: It was another very warm year in the region, leading to low winter sea ice and growing concerns over sea level rise.
lead_paragraph: Temperatures in the Arctic region remained near record highs this year, according to a report issued on Tuesday, leading to low summer sea ice, cascading impacts on the regional food web and growing concerns over sea level rise.

headline: The Lesson of Afghanistan
abstract: A reader says the United States’ failure there is due to “muddled thinking.” Also: A lack of initiative on gun control; student activism at Beacon High School in New York City.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A top Interior Department official broke a federal ethics rule by improperly meeting with his former employer, a conservative research organization, to discuss the rollback of endangered species protections that the group had been pushing, the department’s internal watchdog said in a report published Tuesday.

headline: On Data Privacy, India Charts Its Own Path
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Privacy', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Law and Legislation']

lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India — India is poised to pass its first major data protection law, placing new restrictions on how corporations can collect and use information from the country’s 1.3 billion people.

headline: The Airline Industry’s Sexism Problem
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Discrimination', 'Women and Girls', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Breastfeeding', 'Flight Attendants', 'Pilots', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Workplace Environment']
abstract: For pilots and flight attendants, work and motherhood have long been treated as incompatible. We’re hoping to change that.
lead_paragraph: Like most expecting parents, Randi Freyer was saving every penny. A pilot at Frontier Airlines, she was ready and willing to work up until the end of her pregnancy. But two months before her due date, the airline grounded Ms. Freyer, even though her doctor still considered her fit to fly. Ms. Freyer knew that other employees had been offered interim ground positions when medical conditions rendered them temporarily unable to fly, but the company ignored her request when she asked whether she might be granted something similar. Suddenly, she found herself on forced unpaid leave, losing crucial income when she needed it most.

headline: Review: In ‘42 FT,’ a Circus Shrunk to Fit
abstract: At the new Cirque Mechanics show, the revolving ring, rotating ladders and spinning swings might not thrill, but the performers do.
lead_paragraph: The nice thing about a circus is that it wants you to be happy. Others shows challenge you, provoke you, make you think, make you feel. But a bigtop-style spectacle aims directly for your pleasure receptors, offering a dose of dopamine, cut with adrenaline and delivered straight to your seat. Or isn’t that what everyone experiences when Battulga Battogtokh, a strongman from Mongolia, hefts three women simultaneously?

headline: Yes, Killer Whales Benefit From Grandmotherly Love Too
keywords: ['Whales and Whaling', 'Menopause', 'Reproduction (Biological)', 'Research', 'Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Oceans and Seas', 'Fish and Other Marine Life']
abstract: Researchers hope the findings will improve conservation efforts, as some killer whale populations have dwindled and become endangered.
lead_paragraph: Parents, at least the human sort, know the benefits of having a grandmother close by: the extra help with child care, the reassuring advice borne from years of experience. In evolutionary biology, scientists call this the “grandmother effect,” and have hypothesized it’s one of the reasons humans live so long.

headline: ‘They’ Is the Word of the Year, Merriam-Webster Says, Noting Its Singular Rise
abstract: A surge in searches for the definition of an old-school pronoun signals a new, nonbinary meaning.
lead_paragraph: Merriam-Webster announced the pronoun “they” as its word of the year on Tuesday, marking the rise of the use of the venerable plural pronoun to refer to a single person whose gender identity is nonbinary.

headline: The Most-Read Food Stories of 2019
abstract: From articles on climate change to a review of a Brooklyn institution, the most popular stories this year were ones that prompted reader discussion.
lead_paragraph: The Impossible Burger bested the competition in a blind tasting of six national brands. The taste test replicated the experience of a home cook: Each burger was seared in canola oil and served in a potato bun.

headline: Trump and Pompeo Spoke to Russian Official About U.S. Elections. Did Only One Deliver a Warning?

But Mr. Lavrov denounced accusations of election interference and said the Trump administration still had not unveiled proof of nefarious Russian activity.

headline: Iran Banks Burned, Then Customer Accounts Were Exposed Online
abstract: The details of millions of Iranian bank cards were published online after antigovernment protests last month. Experts suspect a state-sponsored cyberattack.
lead_paragraph: After demonstrators in Iran set fire to hundreds of bank branches last month in antigovernment protests, the authorities dealt with another less visible banking threat that is only now coming to fuller light: a security breach that exposed the information of millions of Iranian customer accounts.

headline: How ‘Waves’ Got Kanye and Kendrick on Its Soundtrack
abstract: Some of the biggest names in music lent songs to this intimate family drama, but convincing them took time.
lead_paragraph: It can’t be easy for an indie movie to secure the rights to a Kendrick Lamar song. The Pulitzer Prize-winning rapper is in high demand, and a bid for his music is often going to require a lot more money and clout than a small film can afford.

headline: Will Congress Actually Pass a Privacy Bill?
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Privacy', 'Computers and the Internet']

lead_paragraph: The holiday season is upon us. The race for the White House is underway in anticipation of its first primaries. And, of course, there’s impeachment. So you could be forgiven for not quite paying attention to the other set of hearings in Washington that are near and dear to this newsletter’s heart: federal privacy legislation.

headline: University of Phoenix Cancels $141 Million in Debt for ‘Deceptive’ Ads

headline: Yuri M. Luzhkov, 83, Dies; Mayor at Dawn of Post-Soviet Moscow
abstract: An energetic leader, he steered the Russian capital out of its gloom, dominating Moscow’s political system while his wife became the richest woman in the country.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Yuri M. Luzhkov, who as the city’s longtime mayor led the transformation of Moscow from a gloomy, trash-strewn post-Soviet capital into a gleaming modern metropolis, but who was dogged by allegations that he had helped enrich his wife’s construction company, died on Tuesday in Munich. He was 83.

Representative Richard E. Neal, Democrat of Massachusetts and the chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, countered that there should only be two.

headline: China Displaces Turkey as Top Jailer of Journalists in 2019
keywords: ['Freedom of the Press', 'News and News Media', 'Censorship']
abstract: In its annual survey, the Committee to Protect Journalists found that at least 250 journalists are imprisoned around the world, largely by authoritarian leaders.
lead_paragraph: China nudged past Turkey as the leading jailer of journalists this year, a press advocacy group reported in its annual survey, partly because of severe repression in China’s Xinjiang region and Turkey’s eradication of “virtually all independent reporting,” which has left many reporters unemployed, driven into exile or intimidated into self-censorship.

headline: Gerrit Cole and Yankees Agree to Record Deal
abstract: The top free agent on the market will sign the richest contract ever for a pitcher: $324 million over nine years.
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — The Yankees have raised the stakes for their pursuit of another World Series title by acquiring Gerrit Cole, the top free-agent prize of this off-season, with the richest contract ever given to a pitcher: $324 million over nine years. The club had made Cole its overwhelming priority this off-season, ultimately beating the Los Angeles Angels and the Los Angeles Dodgers in the race for the right-hander.

headline: What’s on TV Wednesday: A Michelle Wolf Special and ‘Moonlight Sonata’
abstract: “Michelle Wolf: Joke Show” debuts on Netflix. And a documentary about deafness airs on HBO.
lead_paragraph: MICHELLE WOLF: JOKE SHOW Stream on Netflix. “We can’t wait to hate people,” Michelle Wolf says in this, her latest stand-up special. “We can’t wait to have them canceled. And because of that, we get mad before we get logical.” She’s talking about a snarky reply she got to a social media post she made about otters (of all things), but the observation also addresses the reason many people now know who Wolf is: Last year, she was catapulted to national prominence after delivering a piercing monologue at the White House Correspondents’ Association Dinner. Some celebrated the routine. Some denounced it. Looking back on the evening in a recent interview with The New York Times, Wolf mentioned just one regret: “I would maybe go harder.” She presumably had more freedom to push boundaries in her streaming “Joke Show,” in which she addresses subjects like manspreading, gender equality and the physical fitness (or lack thereof) of some past presidents. “I say this all the time: Don’t bring your baggage into my joke,” Wolf said in the interview with The Times. “A comic’s job isn’t to be right or wrong. They’re just supposed to be funny.”

headline: Who Keeps Europe’s Farm Billions Flowing? Often, Those Who Benefit
keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'Crop Controls and Subsidies', 'Politics and Government', 'Conflicts of Interest', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'Corruption (Institutional)']
abstract: Conflict-of-interest rules are uneven. Influence-peddling is murky.  The enormous E.U. subsidy program is built to keep the money moving.

headline: The Key to a Perfect Italian-American Sauce
abstract: Pickled peppers elevate a pan sauce that you can use on veal, on pork, on beef, on chicken.
lead_paragraph: Pimientos is what they’re called in dictionaries, in seed catalogs. But in Brooklyn, they’re known as cherry peppers, just as they are in most places where Italian-Americans gather and eat. Small and pumpkin-shaped, like miniature bell peppers, they can be found in deli cases stuffed with cubes of provolone and wisps of prosciutto, on antipasto platters at weddings and funerals or suspended in vinegar in big jars at the sub shop, hot and sweet at once, with a zing of sour acidity that makes them an ideal topping for a sandwich of cured meats and salty cheese. Sometimes I pair pickled hot cherry peppers with fried eggplant and mozzarella on a sesame hero with a swipe of mayonnaise. I like them with chunks of Parmesan, with raw clams, with coins of soppressata.

headline: How to Keep a Stranger on the Phone
abstract: Smile — the other person can hear it. Sit up straight. Don’t take it personally if people yell at you.
lead_paragraph: “Smile while you dial,” says Daniela Charter, director of the survey center and education services at the Marist Poll, whose public-opinion surveys are conducted by nearly 300 student interviewers at a call center at Marist College in Poughkeepsie, N.Y. Pollsters often have to dial hundreds of landline and cellphone numbers before someone answers. The first few seconds of contact are especially crucial. “Obviously that person can’t see your smile, but they can hear it,” Charter says. During training sessions, Charter makes each student turn to a partner and try to say something unkind with a big smile on his or her face. “It still sounds friendly,” Charter says. Then she makes each student say nice things while scowling. “It doesn’t work.”

For the most part, the less-than-desirable things about her are basically standard landlady grievances and petty annoyances. But over the years we have come to believe that she harbors significant racial and gender biases.

headline: Letter of Recommendation: 3D Without Glasses
abstract: You can teach yourself to see stereo photographs without a special viewer. This turns out to be good practice for making sense of a complex world.
lead_paragraph: When my dad decided to take up stereo photography in the late 1970s, he had already been taking regular pictures for years, and his approach to the transition was pretty straightforward. Instead of buying a new camera with two lenses, he kept using his old Pentax, quickly snapping two pictures in a row. He shifted a few inches between exposures to mimic the distance between a pair of eyes, and there he had it — a stereo pair.

headline: The Curious Case of the U.S. Government’s Influence on 20th-Century Design
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Design', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services']
abstract: Known for its intelligence-gathering operations during World War II, the O.S.S. also helped shape the look of modern life.
lead_paragraph: THE OFFICE OF STRATEGIC SERVICES was the first centralized foreign intelligence agency in the United States, the direct precursor to the Central Intelligence Agency. Founded during World War II by order of President Franklin D. Roosevelt, the O.S.S. (or the Coordinator of Information, as it was originally called) was established “to collect, analyze, and correlate information and data bearing on national security, to make such data available to the President and such other officials as determined by the President, and to perform related supplementary activities.” And yet its role soon became much larger and more influential. The head of the O.S.S., Colonel William “Wild Bill” Donovan, quickly realized that the information produced by the global war, fought on multiple fronts and territories, needed to be painstakingly abstracted, graphically depicted and efficiently presented. The O.S.S. mission expanded to include not only information gathering through research and counterintelligence but also packaging and interpreting that information for the president and other key decision makers. Propaganda played a crucial role during World War II, with the O.S.S. leading efforts to demoralize the enemy and encourage resistance in Axis-controlled countries. They created a stamp bearing the face of Hitler rendered as a skull, produced radio broadcasts in German, spread pamphlets announcing a German general’s resignation and made films for new military recruits, such as the Hollywood producer Darryl F. Zanuck’s circa 1943 “Organization of the Army,” which was commissioned by General George C. Marshall. Through its manipulation of the art of information, the agency helped shape the look and philosophy of American imperialism. In doing so, the O.S.S. assembled a concentration of acumen and talent that rivaled those of the iconic schools and institutes that propagated design in the 20th century. It was the Bauhaus, but for war.

headline: Indian Parliament Passes Divisive Citizenship Bill, Moving It Closer to Law
keywords: ['Citizenship and Naturalization', 'Law and Legislation', 'Politics and Government', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Discrimination', 'Hinduism', 'Freedom of Religion']
abstract: The government says it is trying to protect religious minorities from being persecuted in Muslim countries. Indian Muslims say the bill is discriminatory, and protests are spreading.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The upper house of the Indian Parliament passed a contentious citizenship bill on Wednesday, bringing a religiously polarizing measure one step closer to law as new protests erupted across the country.The measure, called the Citizenship Amendment Bill, uses religion as a criterion for determining whether illegal migrants in India can be fast-tracked for citizenship. The bill favors members of all South Asia’s major religions except Islam, and leaders of India’s 200-million-strong Muslim community have called it blatant discrimination. The Rajya Sabha, India’s version of a senate, approved the bill in a 125-to-105 vote. It next goes to the president’s desk, where it is expected to be signed into law in the coming days.

headline: $1.5 Million Homes in Indiana, Oregon and Colorado
abstract: An 1889 Victorian in Indianapolis, a triplex condo in Portland and a custom-built house on the Animas River in Durango.
lead_paragraph: This property is in the Old Northside neighborhood, a historic district with many elegant homes, less than two miles northwest of downtown. (Among them is an Italianate Victorian several blocks southwest, where President Benjamin Harrison lived.) The builder came from a lumber family, and this house displays a rich variety of woods, including cherry, mahogany and oak. At one point, it was the clubhouse for a fraternal order. A two-year renovation was completed last year.

headline: As a Disorienting Decade Closes, a Perilous One Begins
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: Western democracies have ceded ground to China and autocrats, while corruption and inequity have worsened. Can a generation of protesters turn the tide?
lead_paragraph: A world without American leadership and in search of a fairer, post-carbon economic model is finely balanced between ascendant authoritarianism and popular protest against injustice and repression. It does not take much to push people over the edge. A subway fare hike in Chile or a proposed tax on WhatsApp calls in Beirut is enough to ignite uprisings.

headline: Reeve Carney’s Week: Pedal Boards and Peloton Ads
abstract: The star of “Hadestown” shares what he watched, read and listened to last weekend.
lead_paragraph: Reeve Carney, the actor and musician, has been in and out of hell for nearly three years. In 2017, he joined a workshop of the Tony-winning musical “Hadestown,” following the show to Edmonton and London before arriving on Broadway. Carney, who previously starred in “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” and “Penny Dreadful,” plays Orpheus, a young man who believes he can change the world — and the underworld — with a song.

keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Discrimination', 'Sexual Harassment', 'Bullies', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct']
abstract: A report by the House Oversight Committee said the Coast Guard had failed to turn around a culture that coddles bullying and was hostile to women and minorities.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Coast Guard has fostered a poor environment for women and minority cadets and has failed to fairly investigate harassment by senior officers and to prevent retaliation against people who report bullying, a House committee said Wednesday.

abstract: One was in “Game of Thrones.” One is still in high school. They all act and play instruments. And in a new show they portray scrappy Dubliners creating a band.
lead_paragraph: “Is anyone not ready?”

headline: Why Women on the Pill Still ‘Need’ to Have Their Periods
keywords: ['Menstruation', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Hormones', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth']
abstract: It comes down to decisions made by two men half a century ago.
lead_paragraph: In the 1960s, manufacturers of the new birth-control pill imagined their ideal user as feminine, maternal and forgetful. She wanted discretion. She was married. And she wanted visible proof that her monthly cycle was normal and that she wasn’t pregnant.

headline: The Unexpected Freedom That Comes With Freezing Your Eggs
keywords: ['Egg Donation and Freezing', 'Women and Girls', 'Infertility', 'ARTIFICIAL INSEMINATION']
abstract: Most women never use their frozen eggs to become pregnant. But that’s not necessarily the point.
lead_paragraph: At first glance, egg-freezing seems like an ideal technological solution to a longstanding human conundrum: What if women could postpone having children to the exact time in their lives that made the most sense for them? And the rising popularity of egg-freezing and the easy-breezy marketing surrounding it — “egg-freezing for the price of a healthy snack,” according to one ad featuring açaí berries and a smiling cartoon egg — make it seem as if the prospects of having a child were essentially a given.

headline: When Dad Turns Out to Be the Fertility Doctor
abstract: It’s easier than ever to find out who your biological parents are. But when deception is uncovered, there aren’t many laws to help.
lead_paragraph: Scores of families, using commercial DNA testing kits, have learned in recent years that, decades ago, their doctors lied to them. The doctors told infertile couples seeking artificial insemination that they would use sperm from a medical student, from someone who resembled the husband or simply from an anonymous donor. Instead, the doctors used their own sperm — a disturbing and profound violation of medical ethics. It’s called fertility fraud. But is it unlawful?

headline: Lord & Taylor Returns to New York — Sort of!
keywords: ['Shopping and Retail', 'Pop-Up Stores and Restaurants', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'your-feed-fashion']
abstract: The iconic department store is a start-up now.
lead_paragraph: The new Lord & Taylor isn’t on Fifth Avenue. It doesn’t have towering ceilings, glossy beauty counters or zigzagging escalators; there are no racks of sensible shirts hung on plastic hangers, nor any other hallmarks of the American department store.

headline: Glenda Jackson Returns to the Screen for an Issue Close to Her Heart
abstract: In her first onscreen role in 27 years, the actor and former member of Parliament plays a woman with dementia in the new BBC film “Elizabeth Is Missing.”
lead_paragraph: LONDON — It’s rare to find either dementia or older women featuring prominently in mainstream dramas. But in the new BBC film “Elizabeth Is Missing,” Glenda Jackson, 83, takes on her first screen role in 27 years as a woman facing the rapid erosion of her faculties, even as she searches for answers to mysteries in both the present and the past.

headline: Questioning ‘the Newer the Better’ for Blood Transfusions
abstract: Fresh blood transfusions may be no better than blood that has been stored for several weeks, a new study found.
lead_paragraph: For critically ill children, fresh blood transfusions may be no better than blood that has been stored for several weeks.

This guild is comparable to the academy in terms of size and membership, and most of the five actors nominated in each individual category will go on to be nominated for Oscars, too.

headline: Kim Woo-choong, Who Strove to Be ‘Automotive Genghis Khan,’ Dies at 82
abstract: The Daewoo founder’s mad-rush corporate expansion symbolized South Korea’s rise as an Asian tiger. Daewoo’s collapse offered a bracing reality check.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — Kim Woo-choong, whose catchphrase of “To the world, to the future!” inspired legions of young South Korean entrepreneurs after the devastation of the Korean War but whose mad-rush corporate expansion ended in the biggest bankruptcy in the country’s history, died on Monday night in Suwon, south of Seoul. He was 82.

headline: How Professors Help Rip Off Students
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Books and Literature', 'Writing and Writers', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Textbooks']
abstract: Textbooks are too expensive.
lead_paragraph: As the semester ends, instructors at universities and community colleges around the country will begin placing their orders for next year’s textbooks. But not all professors will pay enough attention to something that students complain about: the outlandish prices of the books we assign. Having grown at many times the rate of inflation, the cost of a leading economics book can be over $250; a law school casebook plus supplement can cost $277. Adding to such prices is the dubious trend of requiring students to obtain digital access codes, averaging $100, to complete homework assignments.

headline: Could Politics Be Fairer? Two New Books Say Yes

Here, a selection of pastel handbags to add a little color (but not too much) to your holiday wardrobe.

headline: Boris Johnson Tries On a New Campaign Persona: Disciplined
abstract: The British prime minister is more grim tactician now than “the clownish, cuddly fellow” of the past. So far, it seems to be working.

The wall was labeled “Gridlock,” while the backhoe was emblazoned with a Union Jack and the slogan “Get Brexit Done.”

headline: Review: A Multimedia Excavation of Lispector’s ‘Wild Heart’
abstract: Video projections help set the mood for an admirable adaptation of the Brazilian writer’s fragmented novel about a woman chafing against society’s restrictions.
lead_paragraph: Reading the work of the Brazilian author Clarice Lispector often feels like diving into a pool of dark water, where the fear of drowning doesn’t deter the desire to bathe in mystery. For those willing to take the plunge, her writings come with many rewards: reminders that someone has shared your deepest fears, passions, even seemingly inhuman thoughts.

headline: Reinhard Bonnke, the ‘Billy Graham of Africa,’ Dies at 79
abstract: He was a German-born evangelist whose open-air Christian revivals drew millions of followers, many of them hoping to be healed of their afflictions.
lead_paragraph: The Rev. Reinhard Bonnke, a German-born Pentecostal faith healer whose open-air revivals in Africa attracted so many followers that in one case people were trampled to death hoping to be cured of their afflictions, died at his home in Florida on Dec. 7. He was 79.

headline: Philip McKeon, Actor on ‘Alice,’ Dies at 55

headline: One of India’s Most Original and Controversial Novelists Returns With a Powerful Parable
abstract: Perumal Murugan’s “The Story of a Goat” examines caste, surveillance and abuse — all cunningly folded into the biography of an unhappy little animal.
lead_paragraph: In her Nobel lecture, delivered in Stockholm earlier this month, the Polish writer Olga Tokarczuk surveyed the world of letters with dismay. What happened to its power and promise? she asked. What happened to its mandate to yank us out of our lives and into confrontation with the universal, to bind us to history and one another? Instead, we are deafened by a cacophony of memoirs and first-person narratives — “a choir made up of soloists.” Tokarczuk lamented the decline of the fable as a form, and the loss of literature as a site for radical tenderness that might militate against self-obsession and refresh our sensitivity to the world.

headline: Mythical Beings May Be Earliest Imaginative Cave Art by Humans
keywords: ['ARCHAEOLOGY AND ANTHROPOLOGY', 'Caves and Caverns', 'Art', 'Hunting and Trapping', 'Research', 'your-feed-science']
abstract: The paintings on an Indonesian island are at least 43,900 years old and depict humanoid figures with animal-like features in a hunting scene.
lead_paragraph: In December 2017, Hamrullah, an archaeologist on an Indonesian government survey, was exploring a cave system in Sulawesi, a large island in central Indonesia. He noticed a tantalizing opening in the ceiling above him. A skilled spelunker, Hamrullah (who only uses one name, like many Indonesians) climbed through the gap into an uncharted chamber. There, he laid eyes on a painting that is upending our understanding of prehistoric humans.

headline: We Just Got a Rare Look at National Security Surveillance. It Was Ugly.
keywords: ['Inspectors General', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA)', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Privacy']
abstract: A high-profile inspector general report has served as fodder for arguments about President Trump. But its findings about surveillance are important beyond partisan politics.

But the report was also important for reasons that had nothing to do with Mr. Trump.

headline: Investors Must Pay Back Sotheby’s Over Forged Frans Hals, Court Finds

lead_paragraph: A British court ruled on Wednesday that an art investment firm, Fairlight Art Ventures, was liable for its role selling a painting attributed to the Dutch old master Frans Hals that was later deemed a forgery. The company must reimburse about $6 million to Sotheby’s, the auction house that brokered the sale, the court said.
