lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Climate Fwd: newsletter. The New York Times climate team emails readers once a week with stories and insights about climate change. Sign up here to get it in your inbox. (And find the website version of this week’s letter here.)

headline: The Oscar Field Has Narrowed. Who’s on Top and Who’s in Danger?
abstract: Now that the Golden Globes, Screen Actors Guild and top critics’ groups have weighed in, our columnist assesses the contenders.
lead_paragraph: Forgive your Carpetbagger if he feels a bit dizzy: Over the last few weeks, a significant number of Oscar bellwethers has begun to ring, culminating in a special form of tinnitus with symptoms that include the persistent thought, “But do the Golden Globes really matter?”

headline: House Panel Debates Impeachment Articles in Bid to Complete Charges Against Trump
keywords: ['Impeachment', 'Trump-Ukraine Whistle-blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry', 'Constitution (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The House Judiciary Committee opened a two-day markup session to debate two articles before they are sent to the full House for a vote.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House Judiciary Committee opened debate Wednesday on two articles of impeachment against President Trump, starting a somber and deeply partisan confrontation over Democrats’ charges that the president abused his power and obstructed Congress.

headline: How to Get Americans to Love Capitalism Again
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Capitalism (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Income Inequality', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Income Tax', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: There are better solutions than wealth taxes, ‘Medicare for all’ or universal basic income.
lead_paragraph: American capitalism is at a serious inflection point. Many Americans, including the two of us, are alarmed by enormous levels of inequality and by declining economic mobility. We are concerned that in many cases American markets are no longer the most competitive in the world. And, we worry that our country’s long-term economic strength will slowly deteriorate because of an unsustainable fiscal trajectory that leaves future generations worse off.

headline: Weinstein’s Bail Is Doubled Over Handling of Ankle Monitor
abstract: The bail was set at $2 million after concerns that he had been disabling the device. His lawyers blamed “technical glitches.”
lead_paragraph: A state judge on Wednesday increased bail for Harvey Weinstein after prosecutors said he had mishandled his electronic ankle monitor, causing it to stop transmitting dozens of times and leaving prosecutors with no idea of where he was.

headline: British Election, Myanmar Leader, Saudi Aramco: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Leonard Goldberg, Producer of Hit TV Shows, Is Dead at 85
abstract: His partnership with Aaron Spelling gave the world “Charlie’s Angels,” “Fantasy Island” and many other series. On his own, he created “Blue Bloods.”
lead_paragraph: Leonard Goldberg, who produced the popular television series “Charlie’s Angels” and “Fantasy Island” with Aaron Spelling in the 1970s and late in life conceived the hit police drama “Blue Bloods,” died on Dec. 4 in a hospital in Los Angeles. He was 85.

headline: Would You Open Your Home to an Ex-Prisoner?
keywords: ['Group Homes and Supportive Housing', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Ex-Convicts']
abstract: A new effort in Oakland, Calif., matches hosts with people who were recently incarcerated to help them reintegrate after they’re released.
lead_paragraph: In the beginning, Sabina Crocette struggled with the best way to introduce London DeLora Croudy to her family and friends. “Should I introduce her as my roommate? My renter? A new family member?” Ms. Crocette was also questioning how much to get involved in her guest’s life: “I wanted to embrace her but not smother her.”

headline: Jared Kushner: President Trump Is Defending Jewish Students
keywords: ['ANTI-SEMITISM', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: With an executive order, he makes clear that anti-Semitism is not to be tolerated.
lead_paragraph: As the poison of anti-Semitism spreads with dangerous violence throughout Europe, the Middle East, and even here at home — most recently in a horrific attack on Tuesday in Jersey City — President Trump is taking meaningful action to crush this evil.

headline: 5 Charged in New Jersey in $722 Million Cryptocurrency Ponzi Scheme
abstract: Federal prosecutors said the defendants operated BitClub Network, a  bogus investment scheme that they promoted as “the most transparent company in the history of the world” and “too big to fail.”
lead_paragraph: Five people have been charged with defrauding investors of $722 million, using promises of huge returns if they joined a cryptocurrency investing club while privately deriding their clients as “sheep” and “idiots,” the United States attorney’s office in New Jersey said on Tuesday.

headline: Sleeping 9 Hours a Night May Raise Stroke Risk
abstract: Excessive sleeping or taking long naps was tied to an increased risk of having a stroke.
lead_paragraph: Sleeping a lot may increase the risk for stroke, a new study has found.

headline: Head Cones in Ancient Egyptian Graves Cap Archaeological Debate
keywords: ['Egyptian Civilization', 'ARCHAEOLOGY AND ANTHROPOLOGY', 'Hats and Caps', 'Skull (Body Part)', 'Smells and Odors', 'Tombs and Tombstones', 'Perfumes and Fragrances', 'Research', 'your-feed-science']
abstract: It took recent excavations to finally prove that the headgear depicted in hieroglyphic scenes was real and not iconographic.
lead_paragraph: Painted throughout ancient Egyptian hieroglyphics are scenes of people at boisterous banquets. On top of the dark, braided heads of some revelers sat peculiar white cones. Archaeologists have long puzzled over the purpose of the mysterious headgear, and whether they were real items worn by people, or just iconographic ornaments, like halos crowning saints in Christian artwork.

headline: Terry de Havilland, Cobbler to the Stars, Is Dead at 81
abstract: He made python boots for Nureyev, black leather thigh-high boots for Jacqueline Onassis and platforms for Kate Moss that spelled out a vulgarity in crystals.
lead_paragraph: If you wanted style and edge in your footwear in the 1970s, Terry de Havilland was your go-to designer. He offered gravity-defying wedges with metallic accents. Also bondage boots. Even winkle-pickers. They came in his favored psychedelic colors, inspired by his frequent trips on LSD.

headline: America’s Public Restrooms Are Kind of Great Now
abstract: Everywhere you look, there are cleaner, more private and more inclusive loos. Thank social justice warriors.
lead_paragraph: In the past few years, something amazing has been quietly happening across the land. Public restrooms in America — long a flash point of exclusion by race, gender, class and ability — have gotten much, much better. Thanks to an increasingly effective campaign by a range of activists, America’s public bathrooms are now cleaner, more plentiful, more private, and more accessible and inclusive than ever. In many places, they’re even great.

headline: Supreme Court Weighs Role of Jury in Death Penalty Case
abstract: An Arizona death row inmate was granted a new sentencing to consider evidence of childhood abuse. The justices examined whether that required a hearing in a trial court.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Wednesday struggled to decide what kind of new sentencing an Arizona death row inmate was entitled to after a federal appeals court ruled that the trial judge who had condemned him to death failed to take account of evidence of abuse the inmate had endured as a child.

headline: Modern Love Podcast: Renée Elise Goldsberry Reads ‘Are You My Husband?’
abstract: The Tony Award winning actress reads an essay about a traumatic brain injury and the stranger it left behind.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: Via Apple Podcasts | Via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher

headline: George Laurer, Who Developed the Bar Code, Is Dead at 94
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Bar Codes', 'Inventions and Patents', 'Supermarkets and Grocery Stores']
abstract: Every purchase evokes his design of the rectangular Universal Product Code. But although it became ubiquitous, he received no royalties.
lead_paragraph: George J. Laurer, whose design of the vertically striped bar code sped supermarket checkout lines, parcel deliveries and assembly lines and even transformed human beings, including airline passengers and hospital patients, into traceable inventory items, died on Dec. 5 at his home in Wendell, N.C., near Raleigh. He was 94.

headline: What to See Right Now in New York Art Galleries
abstract: Andra Ursuta’s glass sculptures, Brice Marden’s latest paintings, portraits from Henry Taylor; Baseera Khan’s photo-collage constructions; and Jill Mulleady’s Neo-Surrealist works.
lead_paragraph: As a few giant galleries absorb ever more market share, thank the muses of art and commerce for Ramiken. The young dealer Mike Egan has piloted this enigmatic, protean gallery through a choppy decade for both art and real estate, and presented its ambitious exhibitions in a crumbling basement, an Upper East Side penthouse, a cave in Puerto Rico — and, now, a 17,000-square-foot warehouse floor in industrial Bushwick, Brooklyn, with a view of both refulgent skyscrapers and an infernal scrap-metal recycling plant.

headline: A Student Who Makes African Emojis
abstract: O’Plérou Grebet, an artist from the Ivory Coast, learned to make emojis from (where else?) YouTube.
lead_paragraph: Name: O’Plérou Grebet

headline: More Americans Are Dying at Home Than in Hospitals
keywords: ['Hospice Care', 'Death and Dying', 'Home Health Care', 'Elder Care', 'Hospitals', 'Families and Family Life', 'Medicare', 'Nursing Homes', 'your-feed-science', 'your-feed-healthcare', 'your-feed-health']
abstract: In a historic reversal, fewer patients are dying in hospitals. But experts warn that many families are unprepared to care for seriously ill relatives at home.
lead_paragraph: For the first time over a half century, more people in the United States are dying at home than in hospitals, a remarkable turnabout in Americans’ view of a so-called “good death.”

headline: Natural Gas Boom Fizzles as a U.S. Glut Sinks Profits
keywords: ['Natural Gas', 'Shale', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Electric Light and Power', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: Chevron’s multibillion-dollar write-down of gas assets is the most recent sign that the gas supply has far outstripped demand.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — A decade ago, natural gas was heralded as the fuel of the future. In shale fields across the country, hydraulic fracturing uncorked a lucrative new source of supply. Energy giants like Exxon Mobil and Chevron snapped up smaller companies to get in on the action, and investors poured billions of dollars into export terminals to ship gas to China and Europe.

headline: Justice Dept. Official and Liaison to Special Counsel to Step Down
keywords: ['Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'United States Attorneys', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Attorneys General', 'Special Prosecutors (Independent Counsel)']
abstract: Edward O’Callaghan worked closely with Rod J. Rosenstein to oversee the Russia investigation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The primary liaison between the Justice Department and the special counsel’s office is set to step down at the end of the month, after helping oversee the department’s most consequential and controversial investigation in a generation.

headline: Promises Aside, Deportations Under Trump Dropped in Last Year
keywords: ['Illegal Immigration', 'Immigration Detention', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Deportation']
abstract: In June, President Trump promised that millions of undocumented immigrants already in the country would be deported. That didn’t happen.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Arrests and deportations of undocumented immigrants inside the United States dropped in the past year, according to government data released on Wednesday, a sharp contrast to the “millions” of deportations that President Trump promised this summer.

headline: With Many Dents to Its Image, Nobel Peace Prize Is Hit With a Few More
keywords: ['Nobel Prizes', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: Myanmar’s onetime champion of democracy and Ethiopia’s prime minister join a roster of figures who, one way or another, have given the Nobel Peace Prize a contentious image.
lead_paragraph: [View the latest updates to the 2020 Nobel Prize winners list.]

headline: House Passes $738 Billion Military Bill With Space Force and Parental Leave
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Government Employees', 'Paid Time Off', 'Family Leaves']
abstract: A bipartisan group of lawmakers agreed to give troops a pay raise and the president his Space Force, while jettisoning a slew of measures that would have reined in the president’s war powers.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House on Wednesday passed a $738 billion military policy bill that would authorize the creation of the Space Force championed by President Trump as the sixth branch of the military and secure paid parental leave for more than two million federal workers.

headline: Some N.B.A. Draft-Night Snubs Are Turning Into Stars
abstract: From Bryn Forbes of the Spurs to the cult hero Alex Caruso of the Lakers, many undrafted players are staking their claim in the league that shunned them.
lead_paragraph: SAN ANTONIO — Bryn Forbes spent his first year in the N.B.A. shuttling between San Antonio and Austin, Texas, in his 2010 Chevrolet Impala. He became very familiar with the 80-mile stretch of Interstate 35 that connects the two cities. Sometimes he played music. Sometimes he talked on the phone. Sometimes he drove in silence.

headline: In Champions League, the Rich Don’t Get Richer. They Get It All.
abstract: For the first time, all 16 teams in the Champions League knockout stages will come from Europe’s so-called Big Five leagues. The continent’s elite clubs like the sound of that.
lead_paragraph: For a while, it looked as if the closest thing this season’s Champions League would get to old-fashioned, soul-stirring romance would be the new-build team, plucked out of thin air and deployed as a rolling billboard for an energy drink manufacturer.

headline: Can Boris Johnson Lie His Way Back Into Office?
keywords: ['Elections', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'Politics and Government', 'Legislatures and Parliaments']
abstract: Britons face a miserable set of choices.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — This is the dejection election. Not in my lifetime has Britain faced such a miserable choice. Two vain, incompetent, mediocre charlatans are competing to become prime minister. For the Conservatives, we have the blustering, lying, oafish puffball Boris Johnson. In the Labour corner is the querulous, wooden, sanctimonious Jeremy Corbyn.

headline: Unions Skeptical Trump’s Trade Deal Will Bring Back Auto Jobs
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Organized Labor', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement', 'North American Free Trade Agreement', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The administration has said its North American trade pact would add 76,000 jobs in the sector. Experts are not so sure.
lead_paragraph: In his State of the Union address in February, President Trump said the North American trade agreement his administration had negotiated would reverse the flow of auto manufacturing jobs by ensuring “that more cars are proudly stamped with our four beautiful words: Made in the U.S.A.”

headline: JR’s Street Gallery Comes Indoors
abstract: At the Brooklyn Museum, his pictures skim the surface of social problems. It can be a frustratingly reductive vision of world peace. “I think being naïve is what has helped me the most,” he says.
lead_paragraph: On a fall day at the Brooklyn Museum, it was hard for JR, the most recognizable anonymous artist in the world, to go more than a few steps without a wave of double takes and a trail of enthusiastic fans.

headline: Withering Criticism of F.B.I. as Watchdog Presents Russia Inquiry Findings
keywords: ['Inspectors General', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods', 'Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA)', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: At a Senate Judiciary Committee hearing, the Justice Department’s inspector general recounted egregious problems with wiretap files.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department’s inspector general on Wednesday painted a bleak portrait of the F.B.I. as a dysfunctional agency that severely mishandled its surveillance powers in the Russia investigation, but told lawmakers he had no evidence that the mistakes were intentional or undertaken out of political bias rather than “gross incompetence and negligence.”

headline: Ending America’s Endless War in Afghanistan
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: We need to press for an agreement between the U.S. and the Taliban and cement the parallel support of the Afghan government.
lead_paragraph: I took command of the United States Army’s 75th Ranger Regiment two months before the Sept. 11 attacks. Not long after, the regiment deployed to Afghanistan as part of the American effort to destroy Al Qaeda and remove the Taliban from power.

headline: Arrest of Top Crime Fighter Stuns Mexico, Where Corruption Is All Too Routine
abstract: The news shocked even a country grown used to graft: The man who for years led Mexico’s war against drug traffickers was accused of taking millions in bribes from the Sinaloa Cartel.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Even in a nation almost inured to corruption, the news was astonishing.

headline: M.L.B. Sends Message: Pitchers, Not Baseballs, Must Adapt
abstract: Home runs are up and pitchers are grumbling but baseball said a study of its seemingly supercharged baseballs had led them to conclude they did not need to change a thing.
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — Chris Young played basketball at Princeton, pitched for 13 seasons in the major leagues and is the son-in-law of Dick Patrick, the president of the Washington Capitals. So Young knows plenty about athleticism and how elite athletes adapt to changes in their environment. Home run rates in baseball have spiked, he believes, because hitters recognize that the current generation of balls seem engineered to soar.

headline: Will Impeachment Change 2020?
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Trump-Ukraine Whistle-blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry', 'Impeachment']
abstract: Public opinion has shifted about impeachment, but not about the president. Here’s what that means.
lead_paragraph: Picture this: a president enjoying the lowest unemployment rate in decades and a booming stock market. He is about to notch a major legislative victory with the passage of a significant trade deal, has appointed two Supreme Court justices and has signed a major tax bill into law. Most voters say they’re better off financially than when he took office, according to polling this week.

headline: Let Trump Have a Miserable Little Christmas
keywords: ['Impeachment', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'Trump-Ukraine Whistle-blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct']
abstract: Deck the halls with tons of tweeting.
lead_paragraph: Hey, it looks like we’ll have impeachment before Christmas. Talk about the holiday spirit.

headline: Movie Nights, Camp David and Cable Messaging: A White House Impeachment Playbook
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Trump-Ukraine Whistle-blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry', 'Impeachment']
abstract: The all-hands-on-deck atmosphere is a change from just weeks ago, when President Trump’s aides dismissed the idea of a war room.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The White House impeachment battle begins every day shortly after sunrise, when President Trump’s press secretary, his acting chief of staff and a group of lawyers crowd into the wood-paneled second-floor office of Pat A. Cipollone, the White House counsel, to synthesize the latest Capitol Hill legalese.

headline: Trump’s Executive Order and the Rise of Anti-Semitism
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'ANTI-SEMITISM', 'Fringe Groups and Movements', 'Hate Crimes', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The president’s campus intervention ignores the bigger threat of anti-Semitism and threatens speech.
lead_paragraph: Last year, anti-Semitic attacks killed more Jews around the globe than in any year in decades. Worshipers were gunned down during Saturday services at Pittsburgh’s Tree of Life Synagogue. Attackers took the lives of a Jewish college student in California and a Holocaust survivor in France. German Jews were cautioned not to wear skullcaps or Stars of David on the street.

headline: How the Yankees Wooed Gerrit Cole
abstract: Gift boxes, visits from team legends and a record-breaking pile of money lured Cole, the top free-agent pitcher on the market, to the Bronx after a pursuit that began 11 years ago.
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — A courtship that began in 2008 was rekindled on Dec. 3 in a suite at the Fashion Island Hotel in Newport Beach, Calif. The Yankees arrived to the hotel bearing gifts for Gerrit Cole, whom they had drafted out of Orange Lutheran High over a decade earlier before failing to persuade him to forgo his commitment to U.C.L.A.

headline: They Came to Play Table Tennis. They Were Deported at Gunpoint in the Dark.
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Deportation']
abstract: Two Nigerian students, in Croatia for a sports tournament, were mistaken for undocumented migrants. They were robbed of their money and clothes and expelled to a country they had never heard of.
lead_paragraph: VELIKA KLADUSA, Bosnia and Herzegovina — For two Nigerian competitors at a recent table tennis tournament in Croatia, losing was just about the high point of their trip.

keywords: ['Jersey City, NJ, Shooting (December 10, 2019)', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Attacks on Police', 'ANTI-SEMITISM', 'Hate Crimes']
abstract: He was a follower of the fringe Black Hebrew Israelite movement, which has expressed hostility to Jews, officials said.
lead_paragraph: After first saying that a deadly rampage at a New Jersey kosher market was random, the authorities disclosed on Wednesday that one of the two attackers had published anti-Semitic posts online and had, in fact, targeted the site.

headline: From Nixon to Trump, Zoe Lofgren Is Democrats’ Memory on Impeachment
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Trump-Ukraine Whistle-blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry', 'Impeachment']
abstract: Ms. Lofgren, Democrat of California, is the lone Judiciary Committee member to have participated in all three modern impeachments.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the summer of 1974, a young law student named Zoe Lofgren, working for a member of the House Judiciary Committee, drafted what she thought was an ill-advised article of impeachment charging President Richard M. Nixon with usurping the power of Congress by concealing the bombing of Cambodia.

headline: Ukraine’s President Stands Alone Against Russia
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Trump-Ukraine Whistle-blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry']
abstract: The lack of American interest was clear as the two nations’ presidents met in Paris.
lead_paragraph: Throughout the impeachment hearings, American military aid for Ukraine was portrayed as a way for a friendly giant to help a David fend off a staggering Goliath who, if not stopped, would continue his rampage. That’s the big picture.

headline: After North Korea Hints at New Policy, U.S. Warns Against More Missile Tests
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'Nuclear Tests']
abstract: The American ambassador to the United Nations, responding to North Korean signals that it could resume long-range missile tests, said such a move would be “deeply counterproductive.”
lead_paragraph: The United States is prepared to take “simultaneous steps” with North Korea to achieve peace on the Korean Peninsula, the American ambassador to the United Nations said Wednesday, but she also warned the North Koreans against conducting further missile tests.

headline: Impeachment Briefing: A Late-Night Meeting
abstract: The Judiciary Committee met for a rare evening gathering, during which each member got a chance to argue for or against impeachment.
lead_paragraph: My colleague Michael Shear wrote a handy guide to the Judiciary Committee’s “markup” session. Here’s an abbreviated version.

headline: Michael Cohen, Broken and Humiliated, Asks for Leniency From Prison
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'ADULTERY', 'Campaign Finance', 'Tax Evasion', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct']
abstract: He told a judge that he “sold his soul” in working as President Trump’s lawyer.
lead_paragraph: Michael D. Cohen says he has been left disbarred, financially crushed and personally embarrassed and humiliated after being sentenced to three years in prison for federal crimes. He says he regrets that he thought “being Donald Trump’s lawyer made him a ‘big man.’”

headline: Corrections: Dec. 12, 2019
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, Dec. 12, 2019.
lead_paragraph: An article on Wednesday about incarcerated journalists in China misstated the time period in which the Committee to Protect Journalists helped win the early release of 80 imprisoned journalists worldwide. It was over the past year, not since the group’s founding in 1981.

headline: Frequently Asked Questions About Wordplay
abstract: How to get technical help with your crossword account, where to write if your streak gets struck and much more.
lead_paragraph: New to Wordplay and aren’t sure where to start? Here are answers to some of the questions that new readers frequently ask.

headline: Tennessee Sheriff’s Deputy Indicted on 44 Charges, Including Rape and Stalking
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', 'Sheriffs', 'Sex Crimes', 'Extortion and Blackmail', 'Assaults']
abstract: Daniel Wilkey, who was charged on Tuesday with rape, extortion, stalking and assault, has previously been accused in lawsuits of false imprisonment, child molestation and forced baptism.
lead_paragraph: A sheriff’s deputy in Tennessee was indicted on Tuesday on 44 criminal charges — 25 of them felonies — over actions alleged to have been taken in the course of his official duties, including rape, extortion, stalking and assault, according to the authorities.

headline: Boy, 2, Is Fatally Hit by Subway Train at Busy Manhattan Station
abstract: The child became separated from his mother at a financial district station during the evening rush hour.
lead_paragraph: A 2-year-old boy was fatally hit by a subway train in Lower Manhattan on Wednesday after he became separated from his mother at one of New York City’s busiest stations during the evening commute, officials said.

headline: Is It Bad That I Gchat My Friends While I’m at Work?
abstract: And other pressing matters.
lead_paragraph: Gone are the days when the etiquette rules for office communication needed to cover only memos, phone calls and in-person meetings. Today we have to figure out the right behavior for email, Slack, instant messages, texts, social media and more — as well as interact with people who definitely haven’t figured out the right manners for each medium yet.

headline: Stick-Up Artist
abstract: Alex Eaton-Salners makes a periodic appearance.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY PUZZLE — Wow. Did you have a tough time with this one? It took me a long time to crack the code, and I honestly thought the fact that I had very little in the grid (and was cursing at it) meant that this puzzle by Alex Eaton-Salners had a rebus element to it.

headline: Photos of the U.K. in the Shadow of Brexit
keywords: ['Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Agriculture and Farming']
abstract: Britain feels anxious, with traditional loyalties cracking. A fifth election in five years has cleaved the country into Leave and Remain, and raised questions about whether the United Kingdom can remain united.
lead_paragraph: Britain is dragging itself through its fifth major election in five years: a third general election, even though Parliaments are supposed to last for five years; and two referendums, one on Scottish independence, which lost, and the other on Brexit, which won.

abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, December 12, 2019.

keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Trump-Ukraine Whistle-blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry', 'Law and Legislation', 'Impeachment', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'Constitution (US)']
abstract: Donald Trump and his supporters need to know that you can be punished for your actions.
lead_paragraph: It is hard for me to be out in public or on social media without being peppered with questions by people with strained faces about whether there is any chance that the Senate will vote to convict Donald Trump if the House of Representatives impeaches him.

headline: Late Into the Night on Capitol Hill: A Debate of Impeachment Articles Begins at 7 P.M.

abstract: The hour lent a prime-time urgency to the spectacle, but both sides reverted to boilerplate.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — They might as well have been speaking different languages, from alternate realities. They spoke mostly past each other, late into the cable night and into history.

headline: Student, 18, Is Fatally Stabbed Near Barnard Campus
abstract: A first-year student was killed during an armed robbery in Morningside Park.
lead_paragraph: An 18-year-old Barnard freshman was fatally stabbed just after nightfall on Wednesday during a mugging in a park near the college’s Manhattan campus, the police and college officials said.

headline: Christine Lagarde Begins to Chart a Course at the E.C.B.
keywords: ['Interest Rates', 'Inflation (Economics)', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Credit and Debt']
abstract: The European Central Bank chief is internationally prominent, but her monetary views are less clear. That started to change at a news conference on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Christine Lagarde is one of the most recognizable people on the world stage, but as president of the European Central Bank, a job she began six weeks ago, she has been a cipher.

headline: A Bitter Election Dispute Sends Afghanistan Back to the Brink
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Elections', 'United States International Relations', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Abdullah Abdullah, a three-time contender for the presidency, is again at the center of an electoral crisis. This time, he insists he won’t compromise.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Three months after Afghanistan’s presidential vote, the entire electoral process is stalled in a dispute that Afghan and Western officials say could pose an even greater threat to stability than the last such crisis, five years ago.

headline: Dallas Man Gets 30 Years for Recruiting for ISIS Through App
abstract: Prosecutors said Said Azzam Mohamad Rahim used a social media app called Zello to recruit fighters and encourage others to kill enemies of the Islamic State.
lead_paragraph: A Dallas man who prosecutors said tried to recruit fighters for the Islamic State through social media, encouraged others to carry out terrorist attacks and lied to federal agents was sentenced on Wednesday to 30 years in prison.

lead_paragraph: The House Judiciary Committee will convene Thursday morning to debate two articles of impeachment against President Trump, the final step before Democrats bring them to the House floor for an expected vote next week to charge the president with high crimes and misdemeanors.

headline: Why Nothing Happened for Ukraine
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Elections', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: How Putin kept a meeting of the leaders of France, Germany, Russia and Ukraine from moving closer to an end of a calamitous five-year war.
lead_paragraph: The France-Germany-Russia-Ukraine summit meeting in Paris on Monday, seeking ways to end the war ravaging eastern Ukraine, ended with a few promising words but no progress in reality. Russia, the aggressor, continues to keep the Ukrainian territory it seized in 2014, and Ukraine’s new president, Volodymyr Zelensky, showed he can’t easily be pressured into surrender.

headline: What’s on TV Thursday: ‘Long Shot’ and ‘I Am Big Bird’
abstract: A romantic comedy with Charlize Theron and Seth Rogen airs on HBO. And a documentary about Caroll Spinney is streaming on Topic.
lead_paragraph: LONG SHOT (2019) 10:10 p.m. on HBO. Love blooms in the din of an underground bomb shelter in this romantic comedy, which stars Charlize Theron as a United States secretary of state running for president and Seth Rogen as a journalist who becomes her beau. The “long shot” in the title refers to both the presidential bid and the unlikely romance that the pair develops: Charlotte (Theron) used to babysit Fred (Rogen). Their meet-cute adult reunion happens at a lavish charity event, where Fred (the only neon windbreaker in a sea of suits) manages to trip down a staircase in front of an assembly of distinguished guests. The rest of the story involves Charlotte hiring Fred as a speechwriter and a journey abroad that lands the pair in that snug bomb shelter. “Much of what happens isn’t surprising,” Manohla Dargis wrote in her review for The New York Times, “but Dan Sterling and Liz Hannah’s script is consistently, genially funny, filled with patter and nonsense, and spiked with sincerity and a few gross-out flourishes.” The movie was directed by Jonathan Levine, who also directed Rogen in “50/50” and “The Night Before.”

headline: Before Pensacola Shooting, Foreign Military Programs Had Years of Troubles
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Terrorism', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Military Bases and Installations', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Foreign Students (in US)', 'Naval Air Station Pensacola Shooting (2019)']
abstract: The U.S. is training thousands of foreign service members. But some of them have disappeared. Others went on to commit human rights abuses at home.
lead_paragraph: The training programs that bring thousands of foreign military forces to the United States each year are meant to project American values around the world, but they have at times had troubling outcomes: soldiers accused of using their skills to overthrow governments, commit atrocities or crush democratic uprisings.

headline: Running While Introverted
abstract: For me, running is not a social activity. It is an extremely private affair.

headline: Who’s Better at Image Management: Colin Kaepernick or the N.F.L.?
keywords: ['Football', 'United States National Anthem Protests (2016- )', 'Social Media', 'Free Agents (Sports)']
abstract: If anyone understands the power of video, it is the N.F.L. But in a triumph of guerrilla filmmaking, Kaepernick keeps seizing their narrative control.
lead_paragraph: On Nov. 16, Colin Kaepernick, the free-agent quarterback at the center of sports’ most contentious labor dispute, held a workout on the football field at Charles R. Drew High School in Riverdale, Ga., a dozen miles south of Atlanta. In a livestream broadcast by a local NBC affiliate, Kaepernick could be seen doing the stuff athletes usually do when they arrive at workouts: chatting with onlookers, milling around, tapping at a phone, limbering up. Eventually he was joined by four other players, all unsigned wide receivers, and he began to throw some footballs. This was the main event: a chance for viewers — and, more to the point, a group of N.F.L. team scouts — to assess the skills and fitness of Kaepernick, who is 32 and hasn’t played a snap in a game since the 2016 season.

headline: Poem: The Still Life
abstract: To engage the concept of a “still life” painting, this tender poem pauses and holds.
lead_paragraph: To engage the concept of a “still life” painting, this tender poem by Mark Sanders pauses and holds. Memory permeates awareness again and again, illuminating the absent, suggesting not that we keep it alive but that it may keep us alive. Sometimes the plums or ceramic pitchers in a painting feel more vivid than the ones on our tables right in front of us. It may take, as the poet William Stafford used to say, a certain tilt of the head to perceive it. Here in this poem, no one is gone. Selected by Naomi Shihab Nye

headline: Many Renters Who Face Eviction Owe Less Than $600
keywords: ['Evictions', 'Legal Aid for the Poor (Civil)', 'Law and Legislation', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Landlords', 'Affordable Housing', 'Poverty']
abstract: Can Washington do something to help them? A growing number of politicians think so.
lead_paragraph: Among the millions of recent eviction cases researchers have begun to compile across the country, there are a startling number of modest sums. There are dozens of families in Texas evicted with money judgments — unpaid rent, late fees, court costs — totaling $516. There are multiple families in Cumberland County, N.C., who owed all of $301. There is a household in Providence, R.I., whose 2016 court record shows a debt of just $127.

headline: 36 Hours in King’s Cross, London
abstract: Among the postindustrial-chic buildings and stylish restaurants and shops: Victorian splendor, verdant hide-outs and the long-ago haunts of writers and musicians.
lead_paragraph: When I was young I liked to read about cities I never dreamed I’d visit. And that’s how I fell in love with the name of the London train station and neighborhood known as King’s Cross — or “King’s X,” as this most English of place-names was sometimes gracefully abbreviated. But when I first moved to England, in 1996, grace wasn’t so easy to find amid the widespread social and economic challenges that had come to define this corner of north London. Today, much (but by no means all) of the neighborhood has been transformed by swank restaurants and shops, expensively repurposed industrial structures, and the glittering glass offices in which the gears of a decent chunk of London’s booming knowledge economy turn ever faster. Welcome, in these Brexit-tossed times, to King’s Cross, and to one of London’s most fascinating stories of adversity and renewal.

headline: Where Housekeepers, Bartenders and Cooks Wield Vast Political Clout

headline: The 25 Best Classical Music Tracks of 2019
abstract: Hear our critics’ favorites, crossing six centuries, compiled over a year of listening.
lead_paragraph: I promised myself I would find a track on this solemnly glittering set to highlight other than the obvious: the mighty Chaconne from the Second Partita. But here we are. Mr. Zehetmair’s interpretation of this classic feels dancily suspended in air, understatedly intense. As throughout the album, his touch is mistily veiled one moment, glinting copper the next. ZACHARY WOOLFE

headline: After Russia Doping Ban, a South African Speaks Up for the Innocent

lead_paragraph: Even before global antidoping leaders confirmed this week that Russia would be banished from top-level international sport for four years, the athletes’ committee they consulted was expressing frustration that the punishment did not go far enough.

headline: Israel’s Democracy Is Broken
abstract: As the country heads for yet another divisive election, it’s time to address the roots of our crisis.
lead_paragraph: It’s official. Israel will hold another election in March, our third national vote in less than 12 months. With trust in Israeli political parties already at a historic low, this election will only reinforce how broken Israeli politics have become.

headline: López Obrador Is Cruising, Mexico Is Not
abstract: Crime, economic stagnation and erratic government decisions signal a long and bumpy ride for his presidency — and his country.
lead_paragraph: So the first year of Andrés Manuel López Obrador’s presidency of Mexico has come and gone, and there is both much and little to say about it. While no major catastrophe has come to pass, a bright new future seems more distant than ever. He is cruising, but his results are desultory.

headline: A Vote for Jeremy Corbyn’s Labour Party Is a Vote for Anti-Semitism
abstract: The only thing necessary for bigots to be normalized is for the unbigoted to shrug.
lead_paragraph: Back when Donald Trump was running for president — and Republicans were still capable of feeling politically ashamed — a conservative friend made what was, to my mind, the decisive case against voting for him.

headline: ‘Bombshell’ Review: Blind Ambition and Blond Sedition at Fox News
abstract: Charlize Theron, Nicole Kidman and Margot Robbie star in a story about the fall of Roger Ailes.
lead_paragraph: Bright and bouncy until it turns grim, “Bombshell” is a fictionalized account of the women who brought down Roger Ailes, the chairman and chief executive of Fox News. Helped bring him down is probably more accurate given that he was ousted by Rupert Murdoch, who founded Fox News in 1996 before handing the reins to Ailes. Since then, the network has become a ratings powerhouse and hothouse of right-wing talking points, a sea of white faces and dolled-up women in skirts and high heels. Ailes is now gone but the talking points, high ratings, skirts and heels remain.

headline: Out: M.P.G. In: Kilowatt-Hours. Classic Cars Get an Electric Jolt.
keywords: ['Electric and Hybrid Vehicles', 'Automobiles', 'Antique and Classic Cars', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Restoration and Renovation', 'Engines']
abstract: A California company has developed a “crate motor” to relatively simply (but not so cheaply) convert gasoline cars to modern electric engines.
lead_paragraph: CHATSWORTH, Calif. — A vintage Fiat 124 Spider — so pretty you could pinch its little orange cheeks — accelerates up a canyon road in the San Fernando Valley. But there’s something strange about this Pininfarina-designed Italian roadster. First, it feels downright peppy as it chugs uphill. And there’s actually no “chugging,” but rather a spacey, high-pitched whir.

lead_paragraph: There are few things as unsettling as sitting in an in vitro fertilization clinic hearing you need a team of experts — embryologists, lab techs and nurses along with a reproductive endocrinologist — to help you become pregnant.

headline: ‘Chinese Portrait’ Review: A Snapshot of a Country, Artfully Composed
abstract: A visual take on the vast expanse of a land and its people, compiled over 10 years by Wang Xiaoshuai.
lead_paragraph: In its title and its panoramic scope, “Chinese Portrait” promises a snapshot of modern China, with scenes that show life in settings urban and rural, industrial and agrarian, scenic and seedy. This documentary’s human subjects are young and old. But in intriguing, sometimes unsatisfying ways, it leaves the synthesis to the viewer. It is an experimental film more than it is a state-of-the-nation address, inviting consideration of how each of its successive tableaus — just about the entirety of the movie — came to be created.

headline: ‘The Death & Life of John F. Donovan’ Review: A Child Is Torn
abstract: Xavier Dolan’s muddled tale of a closeted celebrity and his much younger fan is shackled by an awkward structure and a fragmented vision.
lead_paragraph: Of all the criticisms one might level at the films of Xavier Dolan, dullness is unlikely to be among them. Until now, perhaps: “The Death & Life of John F. Donovan” isn’t just flat, it’s choppy and grandiose. From its contrived structure to its forced speechifying, this story about a yearslong correspondence between Donovan (Kit Harington), a closeted actor, and Rupert (Jacob Tremblay), a troubled prepubescent boy, never acquires the emotional potency or coherence its themes demand.

headline: Impeachment Highlights: Judiciary Committee Finished Debate and Recessed for Vote Friday Morning
abstract: Republicans on the House Judiciary Committee spent more than 14 hours trying to gut or water down the Democrats’ draft of the articles of impeachment. All their amendments failed.
lead_paragraph: Democrats in the House moved closer Thursday night to impeaching President Trump for abusing the power of his office and obstructing Congress, finishing more than 14 hours of debate before scheduling a final vote in the Judiciary Committee for Friday morning.

headline: ‘Jumanji: The Next Level’ Review: New Faces Join the Gang, Back in the Wild
abstract: Dwayne Johnson, Kevin Hart, Jack Black and Karen Gillan return for this sequel, and they’ve got Danny DeVito and Danny Glover in tow.
lead_paragraph: It’s only two weeks after Thanksgiving. A little early to have to contend with a new overstuffed turkey. And yet, here is “Jumanji: The Next Level.”

headline: 2 Dead in Protests Over India’s Religion-Based Citizenship Bill
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Citizenship and Naturalization', 'Religion and Belief', 'Curfews', 'Politics and Government', 'Discrimination', 'Censorship']
abstract: Demonstrators defied troops and a curfew after the bill, which would make it easier for some non-Muslim migrants to become citizens, was approved in Parliament.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Tens of thousands of protesters rioted in three states across India’s northeast, some defying a government curfew and military deployment to demonstrate against the passage of the contentious Citizenship Amendment Bill, which will grant citizenship to thousands of migrants on religious grounds.

headline: ‘The Great War’ Review: A Segregated Black Unit Fights in World War I
abstract: While the movie takes inspiration from real events, it doesn’t have the budget or craft it needs.
lead_paragraph: The centennial of the end of World War I prompted a flood of ambitious movies. Peter Jackson’s “They Shall Not Grow Old” touched up vintage footage; Sam Mendes’s forthcoming “1917” applies the illusion of continuous camera movement to a single mission. “The Great War,” written and directed by Steven Luke, stands to be a less remembered entry. It simply does not have the budget or craft for the scale it requires.

headline: ‘Seberg’ Review: Woman on Fire
abstract: Kristen Stewart is a picture of gorgeous disintegration in this speculative look at the F.B.I.’s persecution of the actress Jean Seberg.
lead_paragraph: “A man lit a fire and put me on it,” the actress Jean Seberg (Kristen Stewart) curtly tells her lover, the activist Hakim Jamal (Anthony Mackie), in “Seberg,” a flawed and fascinating film about fame and martyrdom. She’s explaining the burn scars she suffered while playing Joan of Arc in Otto Preminger’s “Saint Joan” (1957), but the comment could as easily serve as this movie’s tagline.

headline: Kentucky Gives Voting Rights to Some 140,000 Former Felons
abstract: The state’s new Democratic governor said he would ease one of the nation’s strictest policies. Iowa will be alone in barring voting by all felons.
lead_paragraph: Kentucky’s newly elected Democratic governor, Andy Beshear, signed an executive order on Thursday restoring the vote and the right to hold public office to more than 140,000 residents who have completed sentences for nonviolent felonies.

headline: What’s Ahead for PG&E?
abstract: Thursday: A look at the moving pieces in the utility’s bankruptcy. Also: Zoe Lofgren, and a historic marionette theater.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: ASAP Rocky Returns to Sweden in Triumph, Without Trump’s Help
abstract: The rapper’s show in Stockholm on Wednesday came just months after his trial for assault in the country drew international attention.
lead_paragraph: STOCKHOLM — When the rapper ASAP Rocky played an arena show in Stockholm on Wednesday night, it was the first time he had been to Sweden since August, when he was convicted over his part in a street brawl — a case that drew international attention when President Trump got involved.

headline: Where Are Homeowners Successfully Refinancing?
abstract: Home appreciation and credit scores weigh heavily when examining the success of refinance applications.
lead_paragraph: Thirty-year fixed mortgage rates are low right now — about 3.68 percent as of the week of Dec. 5, down from a seven-year high of 4.94 percent in November 2018. On a $300,000 loan, the difference represents savings of about $220 a month, or nearly $80,000 over 30 years. Naturally, many homeowners might be asking themselves: “Should I refinance my mortgage?” perhaps followed by, “Will I be approved?”

headline: Camila Cabello and Harry Styles, Teen-Pop Alumni, Think Bigger
abstract: Both emerged from groups created on “The X Factor.” And both are releasing their second solo albums, showing listeners they have the ambition to go their own way.
lead_paragraph: Teen-pop vocal acts — boy bands and girl groups — always have an alibi. The producer/manager/record company/Svengali made them do it. The other members outvoted them. It seemed smart or funny or commercial or harmless at the time. They were just kids. But a solo career demands more than big smiles, intertwined vocals, art-directed outfits and synchronized dance moves. It calls for something more personal, or at least more committed to a persona. The singer’s name is above the title; the buck stops there.

headline: The T List: What to Try, Read and Know About This Week
keywords: ['Restaurants', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Swimming Pools', 'Candles', 'Photography', 'Mediterranean Food (Cuisine)', 'Bars and Nightclubs']
abstract: Glittery eyes, a classic Nan Goldin book and more ideas from the editors of T Magazine.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the T List, a newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Each week, we’re sharing things we’re eating, wearing, listening to or coveting now. We hope you’ll join us for the ride. (Sign up here, if you haven’t already, and you can reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.)

abstract: This week’s properties include a five-bedroom in Bridgewater, N.J., and a three-bedroom in Pelham, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: This week’s properties include a five-bedroom in Bridgewater, N.J., and a three-bedroom in Pelham, N.Y.

lead_paragraph: This week’s properties are in East Harlem, on the Upper East Side, and in Williamsburg, Brooklyn.
