headline: A Big Change Comes to Billboard’s Album Chart: YouTube Streams
keywords: ['Audio Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Music', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: Starting Jan. 3, official video plays will count toward the tallies on the trade publication’s flagship weekly chart, the Billboard 200.
lead_paragraph: What are the most popular albums in any given week?

headline: The Week in Tech: Countdown to the California Consumer Privacy Act
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Privacy', 'Consumer Protection']
abstract: Companies are figuring out how to deal with a new law that gives individuals the right to see, delete and stop the sale of the personal information about them.
lead_paragraph: Each week, we review the week’s news, offering analysis about the most important developments in the tech industry.

headline: Check Out the New W-4 Tax Withholding Form. Really.
keywords: ['Income Tax', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Tax Cuts and Jobs Act (2017)']
abstract: The first major redesign since 1987 is simpler and reflects tax code changes, the I.R.S. said. Workers should make sure it also reflects what they owe.
lead_paragraph: If you are starting a new job next year or if you want to adjust the amount of income tax withheld from your paycheck, the form that you’ll have to complete and give to your employer will look much different.

headline: Battle Over a $9 Million Will Rests on Just One Clause
abstract: Three charities say they’re the heirs to a woman’s estate. But the daughter of the woman’s partner argues that she’s the victim of bias against common-law gay marriage.
lead_paragraph: Jill Morris and Joan Anderson met decades ago in New York City and were romantically involved for close to 20 years. Ms. Morris, a psychologist, died in 2016 at age 84 after suffering for years from cancer. Twelve days later, Ms. Anderson, 76, died of a stroke.

headline: Even Hermit Crabs Have Wealth Inequality
abstract: The distribution of shells in one population of hermit crabs matched how wealth is shared in some human societies.
lead_paragraph: Hermit crabs face a uniquely competitive real estate market. They need bigger and bigger shells throughout their lives, but can’t grow these homes themselves. So they rely on castoff snail shells, and are constantly on the lookout for better properties entering the market.

headline: N.F.L. Week 15 Predictions: Our Picks Against the Spread
abstract: The Titans try to grab the A.F.C. South, the Bills and the Steelers get set for a defensive battle and Broncos quarterback Drew Lock tries to improve to 3-0 with a start against the Chiefs.
lead_paragraph: It is hard to match the standard set by last week’s action, but with the Titans and the Texans battling it out for A.F.C. South superiority, and the Bills and the Steelers facing off in a defensive grudge match, there should be plenty of fun ahead.

headline: What Exactly Is a Modern Farmhouse?
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Interior Design and Furnishings']
abstract: Chip and Joanna Gaines may not be done with this nostalgic home aesthetic, but maybe it has finally run its course.
lead_paragraph: We are living in the age of the Modern Farmhouse. This is why so many of our kitchens have apron sinks, Shaker cabinets and industrial lighting, whether the home is a prewar apartment in Manhattan or a split-level in Mamaroneck. A dining room wouldn’t be complete without a table made of reclaimed wood, perhaps from a barn. Not our barn, of course, because who in Westchester or Manhattan has a barn?

headline: Brexit Is Going to Get Done. But on Whose Terms?
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Elections', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)']
abstract: Boris Johnson’s victory has drawn in millions of former Labour voters whose vision of Brexit is far different from the Conservative establishment’s.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Prime Minister Boris Johnson’s landslide election victory Thursday clarifies British politics in one important respect: Efforts to reverse the Brexit referendum are now dead. Britain will leave the European Union next month. But on what terms it will do so remains unclear, perhaps even more so in the wake of the election.

headline: Need a New Crime Drama? Visit This Colorful Nail Salon
abstract: Our TV critic helps readers find the shows they seek.
lead_paragraph: I’ve always needed an ensemble family drama in my life. Starting with “Thirtysomething” years ago, then “Once and Again,” then “Parenthood” and now “This Is Us.”  “Succession” sort of doesn’t count because it’s more of a comedy.  Do you have other suggestions along these lines? — Mark

headline: ‘Marriage Story’: Noah Baumbach’s First Feel-Good Movie
abstract: Yes, it’s about an excruciating divorce. But it is also Baumbach’s most hopeful treatment of the subject, in a long history of films that make it a central theme.
lead_paragraph: This article contains spoilers for “Marriage Story” and other Noah Baumbach movies.

headline: On the Frontier, the Lubumbashi Biennial Makes Art From Obstacles
abstract: The global mushrooming of fairs has reached Congo’s remote but resilient mining hub, where politics find its way into artists’ work.
lead_paragraph: LUBUMBASHI, Democratic Republic of Congo — This hot, dry metropolis may seem an unlikely art center. It is a thousand miles from the capital, Kinshasa, on the southern edge of an enormous, unwieldy country typically associated with wars and other crises.

headline: A Townhouse in Greenwich Village Lists for $50 Million
abstract: At nearly 55 feet wide, the mansion is one of the widest townhouses in New York City, and could set a downtown price record.
lead_paragraph: At nearly 55 feet wide, the mansion is one of the widest townhouses in New York City, and could set a downtown price record.

headline: One of New York’s Widest Townhouses Narrows Its Aim to $50 Million
abstract: The Greenwich Village townhouse of Warren J. Spector, a former Bear Stearns executive, is back on the market, reduced from last year’s price tag of $59.5 million.
lead_paragraph: A nearly 55-foot-wide mansion in Greenwich Village owned by Warren J. Spector,  the former co-president of the investment firm Bear Stearns, has returned to the market for $50 million, down from an asking price of $59.5 million last year.

headline: Juice WRLD and the Crisis of SoundCloud Rap-Era Fame
abstract: Success is coming faster than ever for a new generation of musicians. But at what price?
lead_paragraph: Thanks to the internet, young performers can get attention faster than ever and become famous long before any systems are in place to support and sustain their fame. This dynamic gives up-and-coming talent unusual leverage: When you get big on your own terms, it’s less likely that you’ll consider taking on someone else’s guidelines along the way.

headline: Boris’s Big Win
keywords: ['Elections', 'Voting and Voters', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: ‘I get it, and I’m on your side.’
lead_paragraph: This article is part of David Leonhardt’s newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it each weekday.

headline: Initial China Trade Deal Defuses Tensions, but U.S. Still Has Concerns
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Customs (Tariff)', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Economy', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: The agreement includes a commitment by China to buy more agriculture products and to strengthen laws protecting foreign companies operating there.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When President Trump and China confirmed on Friday that they had reached an initial trade deal, it helped defuse tensions in a 19-month trade war and avoided another round of punishing tariffs scheduled for this weekend.

headline: What to Cook This Weekend
abstract: Make like the chef Mario Carbone, and cook with pickled hot cherry peppers.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. I took the subway down to the Village recently, the middle of a bright, late-autumn day, to hang out with Mario Carbone in the kitchen of his red-sauce emporium Carbone. I’d forgotten the place is open at lunch, and it was startling to see people leaning into nighttime excess at noon: frosty martinis on tables through the restaurant’s front, glistening Dover sole on one waiter’s arm, the restaurant’s pillowy veal Parm on another’s. “People make a day of it,” Carbone said. “They got a reservation. They’re going to use it.”

headline: 361 Days of Christmas
abstract: Bronner’s Christmas Wonderland, outside of Detroit, bills itself as the largest Christmas store in the world.
lead_paragraph: Deep in the huge stockroom of Bronner’s Christmas Wonderland, a holiday supercenter about 80 miles north of Detroit, a man named Jason was assembling a 17-foot Santa. Each body part, painted bright red and black, hung from a hook in the ceiling like a cow carcass in a meat locker.

headline: Danny Aiello, Actor in ‘Do the Right Thing,’ Dies at 86
abstract: A memorable character actor on both stage and screen, Mr. Aiello won an Academy Award nomination for his role in Spike Lee’s 1989 film.
lead_paragraph: Danny Aiello, the burly New York-born film and stage actor who was 40 when he made his movie debut and 16 years later earned an Academy Award nomination for his role as a pizzeria owner in Spike Lee’s “Do the Right Thing,” died on Thursday. He was 86.

headline: ‘Bombshell’ | Anatomy of a Scene
abstract: The director Jay Roach narrates a sequence featuring Charlize Theron, Nicole Kidman and Margot Robbie.
lead_paragraph: The director Jay Roach narrates a sequence featuring Charlize Theron, Nicole Kidman and Margot Robbie.

headline: How ‘Bombshell’ Takes an Uncomfortable Elevator Ride
abstract: The director Jay Roach narrates a scene from his film about harassment at Fox News, featuring Margot Robbie, Charlize Theron and Nicole Kidman.
lead_paragraph: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series each Friday. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.

headline: He Wanted to Be Pope. He Settled for Conducting the Metropolitan Opera.
abstract: The Quebec-born music director Yannick Nézet-Séguin has soared to the peak of his profession thanks to his precocious talent and a belief in “smiles and optimism.”
lead_paragraph: MONTREAL — When the conductor ​​Yannick Nézet-Séguin was 10, he went to the basement of the family house, put on one of his parents’ vinyl records, held a yellow pencil aloft and began to conduct the first movement of Mozart’s Symphony No. 40, over and over again.

headline: Theaters in Hungary Feel the Chill of Viktor Orban’s Culture War
abstract: With new rules on funding, the government has taken a further step in controlling arts in the country, prompting an outcry in Budapest.
lead_paragraph: BUDAPEST — The applause was still going strong after an evening performance at Jozsef Katona Theater in Budapest this week when one of the actors, his shirt and face covered in stage blood, turned to the audience with a request. He asked the theatergoers to gather and pose for a photograph with the cast, hands held up in protest.

headline: A Festive Cake With a Big Reveal
abstract: Beautiful and bright, Yotam Ottolenghi’s warm upside-down lemon cake gives you that ta-da moment for the holidays.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — There’s a lot of wrapping up going on at this time of the year. Presents get wrapped up as we prepare for the holidays. The year gets wrapped up in advance of a new one just around the corner. (Even our bodies get wrapped up as the temperature drops.)

headline: U.K. Election Result Starts Clock on Brexit Talks With E.U.
keywords: ['Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: Few expect the negotiations on the country’s future trade and security relationship with the bloc to be quick or easy.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — European leaders on Friday welcomed the clarity of the British election result, since they, too, want to “get Brexit done.” But Boris Johnson’s substantial majority will only start the clock on new negotiations about Britain’s future trading and security relationship with the European Union.

headline: How the Investigation Into Richard Jewell Unfolded
abstract: He was a suspect in the 1996 Atlanta Olympics bombing, and is now the subject of Clint Eastwood’s new film. A look back on our reporting to understand the story.
lead_paragraph: A special edition of The Atlanta Journal hit newsstands on July 30, 1996, a pivotal headline splashed across the front page: “F.B.I. Suspects ‘Hero’ Guard May Have Planted Bomb.”

headline: The Playlist: Kesha Simmers, and 9 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by Usher, Kaytranada, Martha Wash and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

headline: We Have Climate Leaders. Now We Need Followers.
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Global Warming', 'United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change']
abstract: To win over more nations, we need fixes with tangible benefits, like reducing local air pollution and cutting energy costs.
lead_paragraph: As the United Nations’ annual climate conference in Madrid winds to a close, it has become clear that climate summits are stuck in a rut. The job of cutting global emissions is actually getting harder, and not just because the planet keeps warming.

headline: ‘The Straights’ Review: On the Road With No Sense of Direction
abstract: Amusing monologues and oddball encounters enliven T. Adamson’s overstuffed play that follows two friends on a very long car ride.
lead_paragraph: Among the ingredients for a successful road trip — the food, the music, the car — the most crucial is the company. That feeling of being trapped in a small space with someone who gets on your every nerve? It does not bode well for an enjoyable journey.

headline: Review: Five Pieces From ‘Nine,’ and Plenty More From Its Composer
abstract: “Anything Can Happen in the Theater: The Musical World of Maury Yeston” is an old-fashioned revue that ably showcases the Tony-winning songwriter.
lead_paragraph: Tired of hearing your favorite songs shoehorned into a random story (looking at you, “Mamma Mia!”) or used to illustrate a biographical yarn (“The Cher Show,” “Ain’t Too Proud”)? Fret no more: “Anything Can Happen in the Theater” is not a jukebox musical but an old-fashioned revue that just strings numbers together, and to heck with plot and character motivation. For that matter, to heck with characters altogether.

headline: What Would Jesus Do About Inequality?
keywords: ['Christians and Christianity', 'Evangelical Movement', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Income Inequality', 'United States Economy', 'Entrepreneurship', 'Capitalism (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Bible']
abstract: The faith and work movement wants to bend the gospel back toward economic justice.
lead_paragraph: Chapel Hill, N.C. — One Saturday morning this fall, I walked into Chapel Hill Bible Church, an unpretentious complex of brick buildings near the highway. Inside, a conference space bustled with 50 people sitting at round tables. The crowd skewed millennial, mostly (but not entirely) white. I sat next to a hip-looking bearded man wearing a hoodie, who told me he was a nurse at a nearby hospital. My other tablemates included a cybersecurity expert, a doctoral student in speech pathology and an occupational therapist working in public schools.

headline: Elizabeth Warren Is Fighting a Two-Flank War
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: While Ms. Warren remains a leading candidate, her momentum has slowed in part because she faces threats from both the left and the right.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Poll Watch, our weekly look at polling data and survey research on the candidates, voters and issues that will shape the 2020 election.

headline: Ukraine’s Leader, Wiser to Washington, Seeks New Outreach to Trump
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'Trump-Ukraine Whistle-blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Presidential Election of 2020']
abstract: President Volodymyr Zelensky still needs backing from the administration. He is proposing a new ambassador and weighing hiring lobbyists to build better ties.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Eager to repair their country’s fraught relationship with Washington, allies of President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine have met with lobbyists with close ties to the Trump administration, hopeful of creating new channels of communication.

headline: Hallmark and Lifetime Do Hanukkah. Oy.
abstract: And just when you thought made-for-TV Christmas movies couldn’t get any cheesier.
lead_paragraph: My mother adheres to a strict Hallmark movie ritual every December. Five minutes into “The Christmas Club” or “The Christmas Cottage” or “The Christmas Cure” — all very real Hallmark Channel titles — she snatches the remote and hits pause.

headline: Easy Upgrades
abstract: These recipes — for salmon, chicken, noodles and pork chops — all have a genius little twist.
lead_paragraph: Hi and welcome to Five Weeknight Dishes, where the theme today is easy upgrades: Recipes with a genius little twist that pays big dividends, or inspired ideas that struck me like lightning. I love this category of home cooking, as strapped for time as I currently am, but still in want of something good to eat, and as few dishes to do as possible. There’s also the satisfaction that comes from making an easy meal with a brilliant, unexpected maneuver.

headline: How We Made Images of Methane, an Invisible Gas
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Photography', 'Cameras', 'Natural Gas', 'Methane', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: We went to one of the world’s biggest oil fields with an infrared camera to find out what’s leaking into the sky.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: These Stand-Ups Are in an Escapist Mood, Much Like Their Audience
abstract: In several new and recent specials, Seth Meyers, Tiffany Haddish and others largely ignore politics in favor of the personal or just plain silly.
lead_paragraph: In Taylor Mac’s “Gary,” the most ambitious comedy to open on Broadway in years, the title character is a clown who badly wants to upgrade to a fool. What’s the difference? A clown seeks laughs, but a fool also aims to save the world.

headline: 11 of Our Best Weekend Reads
abstract: The year in pictures. This is what racism sounds like in banking. Gretchen Carlson wants her voice back. In praise of public restrooms, and more.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the weekend. If you haven’t started holiday shopping, it might be time. But we’re not here to pressure. Maybe you need some time to relax and take a spin through our gift guide. Or maybe you are all done and just need a dose of amazing journalism. We’ve got you covered there. Read on!

headline: A Seafood Pie for the Feast
abstract: Cooked under buttery puff pastry, seafood mingles in a velvety sauce for a fish pie that doubles as a stunning holiday centerpiece for Christmas Eve.
lead_paragraph: A fish pie, creamy on the bottom, covered in mashed potatoes on top, is a classic cold weather staple across the British Isles. Like its meaty cousin, shepherd’s pie, it has a cozy appeal as inviting as a fluffy rug next to the fire. But filled with seafood rather than lamb, a fish pie makes for a much lighter meal.

headline: The Work Diary of ESPN’s Mina Kimes (and Her Dog, Lenny)
abstract: A pioneer in sports podcasting relies on spinach feta wraps from Starbucks, a Linus blanket and Busta Rhymes on repeat.
lead_paragraph: Mina Kimes watches a lot of sports. A lot. She also reads about sports and thinks about sports and talks about sports and writes about sports. Her workweek is a world away from her previous life as an investigative financial journalist. “I really didn’t think I’d be doing any of this stuff,” Ms. Kimes, 34, said.

headline: Scorched Silence, Fragile Rebirth, Award-Winning Music
abstract: Lei Liang’s “A Thousand Mountains, a Million Streams,” about fragile environments, won the prestigious Grawemeyer Award.
lead_paragraph: The apartment building in which the composer Lei Liang grew up, in Beijing in the 1970s, was a musicological beehive. Its residents worked at the Music Research Institute of the Chinese Academy of Arts, which had an archive of rare historical recordings that had been saved, often at great personal cost, from destruction in the Cultural Revolution.

headline: Nature’s Best Poetry of 2019: Clouds
abstract: Every day, members of the Cloud Appreciation Society post photos of the sky from around the world. This is why they stop to look up.
lead_paragraph: The Cloud Appreciation Society was founded by Gavin Pretor-Pinney in 2005. Its tens of thousands of members around the world communicate online via a  “Cloud Forum,” and they regularly convene at “Sky Gatherings,” which feature group expeditions, lectures on cloud-related art and science and even performances of cloud-themed music. They also submit photographs to the Cloudspotter app to earn stars and badges for properly identifying the clouds they spot.

headline: Sofia Carson and Priyanka Chopra Jonas at Unicef Gala
abstract: Benefits were also held for Alvin Ailey and the New York Harbor Conservancy.
lead_paragraph: Benefits were also held for Alvin Ailey and the New York Harbor Conservancy.

headline: Disney Stars and Dancers
abstract: Benefits were also held for Alvin Ailey and New York Harbor Conservancy.
lead_paragraph: UNICEF held its snowflake ball at Cipriani Wall Street on Dec. 3. The Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater held an opening night gala on Dec. 4 at the New York City Center. And the National Parks of New York Harbor Conservancy held its annual gala at Federal Hall on Dec. 3.

headline: ‘Bombshell’ Raises a Question: What’s Megyn Kelly Up to Anyway?
abstract: A year after the anchor was ousted from NBC, Charlize Theron brings her back as someone who helped take on Fox News from the inside.
lead_paragraph: Megyn Kelly last appeared on NBC more than a year ago, trying to contain an uproar over on-air remarks about blackface that ultimately brought her tenure at the network to an abrupt, unhappy end.

headline: The Year Women Got ‘Horny’
abstract: Women reclaimed a word once the province of crass boys and men who are boys.
lead_paragraph: Coffee, “Star Wars,” turtlenecks, grief: These four seemingly unrelated things are “horny” — or induce horniness — at least according to many young women online, who are openly asserting their desires with a term long thought of as crass and juvenile.

headline: Who Is Jerry Vale and Why Does Martin Scorsese Love Him So?
abstract: The singer’s easy-listening hits were fixtures in the director’s household growing up and have figured in several of his movies, including “The Irishman.”
lead_paragraph: On a typical Sunday afternoon when the director Martin Scorsese was growing up on Elizabeth Street in the Little Italy neighborhood of New York, the family apartment was filled with both the aroma of a simmering sauce and music from the popular Italian-American crooners of the day.

headline: Review: Gandini Juggling’s Drab ‘Spring’ Mixes It Up With Dancers
abstract: The troupe, buzzed about in “Akhnaten” at the Met, delights with its juggling. Too bad about the contemporary dancers.
lead_paragraph: MONTCLAIR, N.J. — The British company Gandini Juggling has been combining its art with others’ for decades. Only recently, though, have those combinations received much attention on this side of the Atlantic, particularly through the group’s contributions to the production of Philip Glass’s opera “Akhnaten” at the Metropolitan Opera this season.

headline: Love Letter: A Forbidden Love, Lost and Found.
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Modern Love (Times Column)', 'Marriages', 'Love (Emotion)', 'Dating and Relationships']
abstract: Plus: Fran Lebowitz made him do it.
lead_paragraph: [This is the Love Letter newsletter. Sign up here to receive it in your inbox. ]

headline: Poems About the Challenges of Life After Prison
abstract: Reginald Dwayne Betts talks about “Felon,” and Jung Chang discusses “Big Sister, Little Sister, Red Sister.”
lead_paragraph: Subscribe: iTunes | Google Play Music | How to Listen

headline: Dancing to (and Around) Bach
abstract: Watch a portion of “New Work for Goldberg Variations,” a collaboration between Pam Tanowitz and Simone Dinnerstein.
lead_paragraph: #SpeakingInDance is a weekly visual exploration of dance on Instagram. Watch the video from our most recent post below, and follow us at @nytimes.

headline: Trump Says of Impeachment: ‘I Wouldn’t Mind a Long Process’
keywords: ['Trump-Ukraine Whistle-blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry', 'Impeachment', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: President Trump, speaking to reporters on Friday, discussed the unfolding impeachment process and said he would like to see the whistle-blower” involved in a lengthy Senate trial.
lead_paragraph: President Trump, speaking to reporters on Friday, discussed the unfolding impeachment process and said he would like to see the whistle-blower” involved in a lengthy Senate trial.

headline: U.S. Places Sanctions on Art Collector Said to Finance Hezbollah
abstract: The Treasury Department said the collector used art to hide assets and a gallery business to launder money.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury Department announced sanctions Friday against a diamond dealer who the government said has used an art gallery in Beirut, Lebanon, and an extensive personal collection, sprinkled with names like Pablo Picasso and Andy Warhol, to shelter and launder money.

headline: 123 Tweets in One Day: A Trump Tsunami
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Impeachment', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'Presidential Election of 2020']
abstract: A reader writes, “This is an amazing and disturbing statistic and a window into the president’s mind and mood.” Also: The British election; advice to the Democrats.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: One More Step Toward Impeachment
keywords: ['Trump-Ukraine Whistle-blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry', 'Impeachment', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Two readers worry that the Democratic strategy may backfire and end up helping President Trump.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Frail Older Patients Struggle After Even Minor Operations
abstract: These patients are not aware of the true risks, and surgeons aren’t telling them, new research suggests.
lead_paragraph: The patient, a man in his 70s, had abdominal pain serious enough to send him to a VA Pittsburgh Healthcare hospital. Doctors there found the culprit: a gallstone had inflamed his pancreas.

headline: ‘We Trusted You’: WeWork’s Chair on Adam Neumann and the Future
keywords: ['Co-Working', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Landlords', 'Initial Public Offerings', 'Real Estate (Commercial)']
abstract: After a bailout by SoftBank, the shared office space company plans to sell customers more services and renegotiate leases with landlords.
lead_paragraph: Marcelo Claure flopped into a chair late this week at WeWork’s headquarters in New York, looking exhausted and exhilarated, his 6-foot-6 frame splayed across the glass meeting room.

headline: New York’s Newest Private Museum Is Tucked Away in Brooklyn
abstract: First he took Copenhagen and Beijing. Now, Danish dealer-turned-philanthropist Jens Faurschou is debuting his blue-chip collection in the borough’s Greenpoint section.
lead_paragraph: Jens Faurschou grew up on the Danish island of Funen, to parents who weren’t big art-buyers but who had a ceramics collection. No, he did not come from money. “Not a dime, unfortunately,” he said.

headline: Jimmy Kimmel Has a New Favorite Crowd: Kids
abstract: The new author has so enjoyed the warm reception to his book, “sometimes I wish I had nothing but children in my audience at the show.”
lead_paragraph: APPLAUSE, PLEASE You know Jimmy Kimmel as a comedian and the longtime host of ABC’s “Jimmy Kimmel Live.” But show business wasn’t part of his grand plan until he got the college radio show that first landed him in front of a microphone. Kimmel says, “I always wanted to be an artist. That was my goal. I’d draw insulting caricatures of my teachers and classmates, or I’d sit in front of the television drawing David Letterman.” This month, his dream came true: Kimmel published “The Serious Goose,” a read-aloud magnet that is now No. 1 on the children’s picture books list. (It should come with a warning: “May rev kids up.”)

headline: Research Nonprofit Shutters TB Vaccine Effort and Lays Off Scientists
keywords: ['Research', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Tuberculosis', 'Nonprofit Organizations', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', "Leprosy (Hansen's Disease)", 'Leishmaniasis', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'your-feed-healthcare']
abstract: A financially troubled Seattle research institute cut back programs, leaving researchers to find new homes for work on infectious diseases like tuberculosis and leprosy.
lead_paragraph: The future of a tuberculosis vaccine and research into other neglected diseases is in limbo after a Seattle institute abruptly laid off about one-third of its researchers, citing a financial crisis.

headline: Mounting Evidence of Abuse by Chile’s Police Leads to Calls for Reform
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Politics and Government', 'Torture', 'Sex Crimes']
abstract: Human rights monitors accuse the police of torture, sexual violence and other abuse, drawing scrutiny to Chile’s scandal-plagued national force.
lead_paragraph: SANTIAGO, Chile — The brutality of the Chilean police’s response to the country’s unrest  is leading to sweeping calls for the force’s reform.

headline: The United Kingdom Has Voted. Will It Remain United?
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Elections', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'Legislatures and Parliaments']
abstract: Boris Johnson’s resounding victory means Britain will almost certainly leave the European Union. But what will become of Scotland and Northern Ireland?
lead_paragraph: Of all the agonizing twists and turns of British politics since the narrow vote on June 23, 2016, in favor of leaving the European Union, the landslide victory of Boris Johnson in Thursday’s election may be the most stunning. It also should have been the most predictable. After three and a half years of debilitating debate, the British had simply had enough and rallied to Mr. Johnson’s unvarnished slogan, “Get Brexit Done.” They are likely to get a very different Britain in the bargain.

headline: In Johnson Victory, Democrats and Republicans See Lessons for 2020
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'Elections']
abstract: The 2016 Brexit vote seemed to be a harbinger of President Trump’s election. But Boris Johnson’s victory may be different.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britain was still counting the final votes in its landmark election early Friday morning when Democrats and Republicans on the other side of the Atlantic began asking what Prime Minister Boris Johnson’s landslide victory meant for them: Was it a good omen for President Trump’s re-election chances in 2020, a cautionary tale for Democrats, or both?

headline: Battered U.K. Labour Party Ponders Next Move, as Corbyn Plans Exit
abstract: Labour’s most left-wing leader in a generation suffered a crushing defeat, leaving his party questioning where it heads next.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — It was supposed to be a new dawn, the moment when Jeremy Corbyn, Britain’s most left-wing political leader in a generation or more, proclaimed the start of the most ambitious economic transformation the nation had seen since the end of World War II.

headline: Military’s Preferred Candidate Named Winner in Algeria Election
abstract: Antigovernment protesters took to the streets to reject the vote as illegitimate. They boycotted the election, which had a record low turnout.

In January, they opened Chanclas Cantina, a sports bar five miles east of the Strip, and some of their first customers were members of the Los Villanos Raiders booster club. The club, which has grown from 10 to 100 members in a year, now calls the bar home.

There were also his accomplishments at home to promote: finishing the first phase of a trade deal with China, averting a government shutdown and moving forward with House Democrats on his signature North American trade pact.

headline: Boris Johnson and the Coming Trump Victory in 2020
keywords: ['Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'Politics and Government', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2020']
abstract: In the postindustrial wasteland, the working class embraced an old Etonian mouthing about unleashed British potential.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump, in his telling, could have shot somebody on Fifth Avenue and won. Boris Johnson could mislead the queen. He could break his promise to get Britain out of Europe by Oct. 31. He could lie about Turks invading Britain and the cost of European Union membership. He could make up stories about building 40 new hospitals. He could double down on the phantom $460 million a week that Brexit would deliver to the National Health Service — and still win a landslide Tory electoral victory not seen since Margaret Thatcher’s triumph in 1987.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday: ‘Black Christmas’ and ‘The Polar Express’
abstract: Stream Bob Clark’s 1974 holiday slasher movie, or catch an animated journey to the North Pole by rail.
lead_paragraph: BLACK CHRISTMAS (1974) Stream on Tubi and Vudu; Rent on Amazon, Google Play, iTunes and YouTube. Before Bob Clark made “A Christmas Story,” the gift of holiday programming that keeps on giving, he directed this slasher film that has a decidedly deadlier take on the holiday. It follows a group of sorority sisters who start to receive disturbing phone calls at their house as they prepare to head home for the Christmas break. The caller then starts to stalk each of the girls, picking them off one by one in a bloody killing spree. Although A.H. Weiler dismissed the film as “a whodunit that begs the question of why it was made” in his New York Times review, the movie went on to become a horror classic. The film became influential in the genre for its use of first-person camera shots and its decision not to unmask the killer, serving as a flash point for other slasher movies like John Carpenter’s “Halloween.” It has also inspired a few remakes, including a version out in theaters now.

headline: The Patriots’ Season of Chaos

headline: ‘Mayors for Mike’: How Bloomberg’s Money Built a 2020 Political Network
abstract: Michael Bloomberg is relying on powerful city leaders as allies in his presidential campaign. Several have received grants, training and support packages totaling millions from his foundation.
lead_paragraph: STOCKTON, Calif. — Michael R. Bloomberg and Mayor Michael Tubbs of Stockton seemed like an improbable political duo on Wednesday as they heaped praise on each other. Mr. Tubbs, a 29-year-old liberal who is Stockton’s first black mayor, hailed Mr. Bloomberg as a leader “with the resources, with the record and with the relationships” to defeat President Trump in 2020. Mr. Bloomberg, a 77-year-old centrist billionaire, called the younger man “my kind of mayor.”

headline: How Do I Decorate for Hanukkah Without Copying Christmas?
abstract: It’s not easy trying to compete with Yuletide bling.
lead_paragraph: Q: We’re a Jewish family living in the New York City suburbs. Every December, our neighborhood is abuzz with lights, wreaths and galloping lawn ornaments. To say that our children notice would be an understatement. They don’t long for Santa — they get their fill of presents at Hanukkah — but they do envy the display. My daughter wants some flair! So what do we do? How do we decorate our home for Hanukkah in a way that doesn’t make it feel like Jewish Christmas? Is this even possible?

headline: Variety: Puns and Anagrams

They are always so witty and inventive (the puzzles and their solvers). It’s especially unfortunate that more people don’t plunge into the “Puns and Anagrams,” or Panda, because this is a gateway drug to more cryptic puzzles.

headline: Gamblers, Wastrels and Lumberjacks: An Old Cemetery Gives Up Its Secret History
abstract: An estimated 72 people died during construction of a rail tunnel through the Montana mountains. After more than 100 years, their final resting place has been found.
lead_paragraph: TAFT, Mont. — More than 110 years ago, as the West finally was being tamed, the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul railroad rushed to build a transcontinental rail line to the Pacific Coast. Standing in the way, though, was a formidable peak in the middle of Montana’s Bitterroot Mountains.

headline: Staring Down Impeachment Vote, Freshman Democrat Seeks Legislative Victories

Bolton, the former national security adviser, was refusing through his lawyer to tell Congress what he knew about “many relevant meetings and conversations” in the matter, Representative Antonio Delgado’s mind was elsewhere.

If the president fully admitted what he had done, he could head off charges of high crimes and misdemeanors. Mr. Graham scribbled on a piece of paper what the president had to say.

She was moving away and I wanted to give her something to commemorate our time together.

headline: I Still Kind of Love the New York Subway
abstract: Sometimes I wonder if I can stand many more years of unreliable service. Then something happens that gets me all mushy again.
lead_paragraph: Like any good New Yorker, I mind my own business on the subway. Unless I’m in a bad mood, like that cold day last week when nobody was emailing me back, and my jeans were too tight, and I was late for a meeting I didn’t want to go to and this kid turned his profane rap music up to full volume on the platform. Black and brown teenagers are often overpoliced in public spaces, but this kid was as white as Post Malone.

headline: How the Superrich Took Over the Museum World
abstract: The wealthy have always influenced the art scene. But in recent years, they’ve dominated it.
lead_paragraph: With the recent opening of its sleek new quarters, the Museum of Modern Art has solidified its position as one of the world’s leading showcases for high culture. Designed by the “starchitect” firm of Diller Scofidio + Renfro, the renovation cost $450 million; that comes on top of the $425 million the museum spent on an earlier makeover, in 2004. That redesign came under sharp criticism, and within a decade a new overhaul was deemed necessary. In less than 20 years, MoMA has spent almost a billion dollars reinventing itself.

headline: What’s on TV Sunday: The Kennedy Center Honors and ‘The Sound of Silence’
abstract: “Sesame Street,” Earth, Wind & Fire and Sally Field are honored for their achievements in the arts, and Peter Sarsgaard is a sound-obsessed house tuner in “The Sound of Silence.”
lead_paragraph: THE KENNEDY CENTER HONORS 8 p.m. on CBS. In addition to celebrating 50 years on television this year, “Sesame Street” became the first TV program to receive a Kennedy Center Honor. The ceremony, which also honored the R&B group Earth, Wind & Fire, the actress Sally Field, the singer Linda Ronstadt and the conductor Michael Tilson Thomas for their lifetime achievements in the arts, took place in Washington  on Dec. 8, and will be broadcast for TV audiences Sunday night. LL Cool J hosted the star-studded event, which featured performances by Carrie Underwood, Thomas Rhett, Yuja Wang and the Jonas Brothers, as well as spoken tributes from Emmylou Harris, Tom Hanks, Joseph Gordon-Levitt and David Foster.

abstract: A key United Nations meeting ended early Sunday  with the United States and other big polluters blocking even a nonbinding effort to enhance their climate targets next year.
lead_paragraph: In what was widely denounced as one of the worst outcomes in a quarter-century of climate negotiations, United Nations talks ended early Sunday morning with the United States and other big polluters blocking even a nonbinding measure that would have encouraged countries to adopt more ambitious targets for reducing greenhouse gas emissions next year.

headline: Tiger Woods Leads by Example in Presidents Cup Comeback Win
abstract: The player-captain set the tone on Sunday by winning the team’s first singles matchup and then guiding the United States team to a come-from-behind victory that left Woods in tears.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — Tiger Woods’s final putt on Sunday was still rolling toward the hole when he started to remove his cap for a postmatch handshake with Mexico’s Abraham Ancer.

headline: The D.N.C. Chairman Knows No One Is Happy. Neither Is He.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Some Democrats say the party’s presidential debate stage is too big.

headline: From Canada’s Legal High, a Business Letdown
abstract: Investors poured money into Canada’s marijuana market, but one year after legalization, the euphoria has evaporated.
lead_paragraph: SMITHS FALLS, Ontario — When Canada became the first major industrialized nation to legalize recreational marijuana, visions of billions of dollars in profits inspired growers, retailers and investors, sending the stock market soaring in a so-called green rush.

headline: Andrew Clements, 70, Dies; Wrote Best-Selling Children’s Books
abstract: His best-known book, “Frindle,” posed a question about the nature of words: What would happen if you called a pen a frindle?
lead_paragraph: Andrew Clements, who mined a brief teaching career in Illinois in writing two dozen books for young readers, most notably “Frindle,” which sold more than eight million copies, died on Nov. 28 at his home in West Baldwin, Maine. He was 70.

headline: Review: A Radiant Revival of ‘Der Rosenkavalier’
abstract: The conductor Simon Rattle, in a rare appearance at the Metropolitan Opera, leads an insightful account of Strauss’s best-known opera, with a winning cast.
lead_paragraph: Richard Strauss’s “Der Rosenkavalier” has several truly sublime and justly beloved scenes and ensembles. With a good cast and conductor, these are almost surefire moments in any performance.

headline: Somebody’s Watching: Hackers Breach Ring Home Security Cameras
keywords: ['Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Security and Warning Systems', 'Cameras', 'Computer Security', 'Mobile Applications', 'Privacy', 'Discrimination', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: Unnerved owners of the devices reported recent hacks in four states. The company reminded customers not to recycle passwords and user names.
lead_paragraph: Ashley LeMay and Dylan Blakeley recently installed a Ring security camera in the bedroom of their three daughters, giving the Mississippi parents an extra set of eyes — but not the ones that they had bargained for.

abstract: The Swedish teenager who inspired a global movement is returning home, as admirers and critics weigh in.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Greta Thunberg says she needs a break.

headline: Goar Vartanyan, Celebrated Soviet Spy, Dies at 93
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations']
abstract: Without her and her husband, also a Soviet spy, “the history of our world could have been different,” the Kremlin said. But her exact role remains a secret.
lead_paragraph: Goar Vartanyan, a Soviet spy who forged a formidable espionage partnership with her husband and helped protect Stalin, Churchill and Roosevelt during their historic meeting in Tehran in 1943, died on Nov. 25 in Moscow. She was 93.

headline: Schumer, Pushing McConnell to Negotiate, Lays Out Plan for Impeachment Trial
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Trump-Ukraine Whistle-blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry', 'Impeachment']
abstract: The Senate Democratic leader wants to seek testimony from Mick Mulvaney, John Bolton and other White House officials, and subpoena documents the White House has withheld.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the House prepared to make President Trump only the third president in American history to be impeached, the Senate’s top Democrat on Sunday laid out a detailed proposal for a Senate trial “in which all of the facts can be considered fully and fairly” — including subpoenas for documents the White House has withheld and witnesses it has prevented from testifying.

headline: Espionage, North Korea, Xinjiang: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Why Twitch Is Still the King of Live Game Streaming
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Computer and Video Games', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: Facebook, Microsoft, Twitter and others are spending millions on video game streaming to compete with Amazon’s Twitch in a fight to court millennials.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft paid millions to lure a top video game streaming star. Facebook signed an exclusive streaming deal with the largest e-sports company in the world. Twitter streamed Fortnite’s collapse into a black hole.

headline: After Volcano Blast, New Zealand Asks if Adventure Tourism Can Last
abstract: The eruption on White Island has set off an intense debate on exploiting nature for thrills.
lead_paragraph: WHAKATANE, New Zealand — When Phil van Dusschoten retired as a police officer and started a diving business 24 years ago, the next chapter of his life seemed set, steering visitors through the stunning Bay of Plenty to frolic with dolphins and swim around the volcanic White Island.

headline: ‘Jumanji: The Next Level’ Unseats ‘Frozen 2’ at the Box Office
abstract: The Dwayne Johnson vehicle opened to about $60.1 million in domestic sales this weekend.
lead_paragraph: For the second time this year, Dwayne Johnson is in the biggest movie in the United States and Canada.

headline: 400 Rounds of Ammunition Found at Pawnshop Connected to N.J. Killings
abstract: The police arrested the owner of the store in Keyport, N.J., on criminal weapons charges.
lead_paragraph: When David N. Anderson carried out a deadly anti-Semitic terror attack with his girlfriend in a kosher deli in New Jersey last week, he had a phone number and an address written on a note tucked into his back pocket.

headline: The Impeachment Process Is Barely Functioning
keywords: ['Trump-Ukraine Whistle-blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Watergate Affair']
abstract: Hyperpartisan politics and an implacable president may break Congress’s ability to check him.
lead_paragraph: When the process of impeachment drove President Richard Nixon from office in 1974, there was widespread celebration that “the system worked.” But the 1974 impeachment process may turn out to have been unique, a model for how it should work that has yet to be replicated — and perhaps never will be.

headline: ‘Uncut Gems’ and Its Exquisitely Harrowing Soundscape
abstract: The Safdie brothers’ movie layers the noise of New York with dialogue and music so effectively, at times you don’t even need the visuals.
lead_paragraph: The best running joke in “Uncut Gems” is the vestibule that serves as the entry to the jewelry shop owned by Howard Ratner (Adam Sandler). It is maybe 15 square feet, with (presumably bulletproof) plexiglass walls — small and transparent and yet completely cut off from the action in the shop. The buzzer that lets people into the store is faulty, and people frequently get stuck.

headline: Anti-Semitism or Free Speech? College Students Cheer and Fear Trump Order
keywords: ['Jews and Judaism', 'ANTI-SEMITISM', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Synagogues', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'Palestinians', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Civil Rights and Liberties']
abstract: Students across America wondered whether an executive order targeting anti-Semitism would “backfire” on Jewish students.
lead_paragraph: CHAPEL HILL, N.C. — Spencer Kaplan, a junior at Duke University, believes Israel has been unfairly targeted on campus, and he felt unsafe as a Jewish student after a swastika was found scrawled on a mural that Duke students had painted to honor the victims of last year’s massacre at a synagogue in Pittsburgh.

headline: Black Women Now Hold Crowns in 5 Major Beauty Pageants
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Women and Girls', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Beauty Contests']
abstract: Toni-Ann Singh of Jamaica won the Miss World pageant on Saturday. Black women also hold the 2019 crowns of Miss Teen USA, Miss America, Miss USA and Miss Universe.
lead_paragraph: Toni-Ann Singh of Jamaica was crowned Miss World on Saturday, marking the first time that black women have simultaneously held the titles of five of the world’s top beauty pageants.

headline: 2020 Campaigns Throw Their Hands Up on Disinformation
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'News and News Media', 'Social Media']
abstract: Few politicians have teams to spot false statements about them online, or to fight back before it spreads.
lead_paragraph: In 2018, Lisa Kaplan assembled a small team inside the re-election campaign for Senator Angus King, an independent from Maine. Wary of how Russia interfered in the 2016 presidential election, it set out to find and respond to political disinformation online.

headline: When the O.K. Sign Is No Longer O.K.
keywords: ['Fringe Groups and Movements', 'Whites', 'Hoaxes and Pranks', 'Discrimination', 'Neo Nazi Groups', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: Here is how a hand gesture long seen as innocuous was appropriated to signify “white power.”
lead_paragraph: Touching the thumb and index finger to make a circle, with the remaining three fingers held outstretched, is a gesture that people around the world have made for centuries, mostly in positive contexts.

headline: Gershon Kingsley, Master of Electronic Sounds, Dies at 97
abstract: One of the first composers to embrace the Moog synthesizer, he gave the world the enduring instrumental hit “Pop Corn,” among many other works.
lead_paragraph: Gershon Kingsley, a composer who brought electronic sounds into popular music and wrote the enduring instrumental hit “Pop Corn,”  died on Dec. 10 at his home in Manhattan. He was 97.

headline: In 2020 Census, Big Efforts in Some States. In Others, Not So Much.
abstract: California is spending $187 million to try to ensure an accurate count of its population. The Texas Legislature decided not to devote any money to the job. Why?
lead_paragraph: EDINBURG, Texas — Next month, California will uncork a $187 million campaign to prod its nearly 40 million residents to participate in the 2020 census. Neighborhoods across the state have been computer-ranked by how likely residents are to fill out census forms. Custom marketing campaigns are being focus-grouped. Nonprofit organizations have been showered with grants to boost response in hard-to-count areas.

headline: What Was Lost in ‘the Last Good War’
abstract: Letters and recordings keep a family connected, 75 years after the Battle of the Bulge.
lead_paragraph: Morey Moseson didn’t know what he wanted to be when he grew up. Not for lack of options — the world seemed impossibly full. He was the class valedictorian, and the class clown. He loved to dance to Benny Goodman and Glenn Miller. His sister, Lee, two years older, taught him how to do the Lindy hop. They’d practice the eight-count step late at night, big band swing notes at 78 r.p.m. filling the rooms of their home in Jamaica, Queens.

headline: Wander About
abstract: Get off the shelf and have some fun with Howard Barkin and Kevin Christian’s Monday puzzle!
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — Aah, a nice new week, a fresh start, a Monday puzzle, something we can actually feel confident about. Two congenial constructors, one a familiar weekender, Howard Barkin, and one a Monday regular, Kevin Christian. Three theme answers, check; some interesting cultural touchpoints, check; a dip into modern vernacular (by way of two debuts), check.

headline: Exposed as Stasi Spy, a Newspaper Owner Tries to Reclaim His Story
abstract: An entrepreneur took over a venerable Berlin daily, saying he wanted a new conversation about East Germany. Then his own past became the news.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — When a wealthy married couple bought the Berliner Zeitung, a distinguished but ailing survivor of the East German press, they timed their newspaper’s big revamp for the 30th anniversary of the fall of the Berlin Wall last month.

headline: France Extradites Argentine Man Suspected of Torture
keywords: ['Extradition', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: Mario Sandoval was sent to his native country to face charges of crimes committed during the dictatorship. In France, many wonder why it took so long.
lead_paragraph: A former police officer from Argentina who has lived for more than 30 years as a university lecturer and security expert in France was extradited and arrived on Monday in his native country, where he is wanted for crimes against humanity, including torture, committed during the country’s dictatorship, the French lawyer representing Argentina said.

headline: Trump Officials Praise Gains From China Deal, but They Come at a Cost
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Customs (Tariff)']
abstract: The economic losses sustained during a bruising 19-month trade war will not be easy to make up.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Trump administration officials predicted big gains for the economy from a newly announced trade deal with China, but the economic losses sustained during a bruising 19-month trade war will not be easy to make up.

headline: In Era of Hardening Identities, Trump Order on Jews Kindles Questions Old and New
abstract: The president said he wanted to target anti-Semitic speech on campuses, but in the time of new nationalism, nothing is really that simple.
lead_paragraph: President Trump’s executive order targeting anti-Semitic and anti-Israel speech on campuses might be framed as a narrow legal matter, but it has touched on a defining issue of our time: Who belongs, and who decides?

headline: At Pulse Shooting Site, a Plan to Remember Renews Pain for Some
abstract: A museum and memorial are intended to honor the victims of the tragic Pulse nightclub killings in Florida, but some families and survivors have objected to the multimillion-dollar projects.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO — The struggle to heal has been palpable here in the years since 2016, when a gunman turned Pulse, a gay nightclub, into what was then the site of the deadliest mass shooting in modern American history.

headline: Soccer Broadcast Pulled After Arsenal Star Mesut Özil Criticized China
abstract: A state-run television network pre-empted an English Premier League match between Manchester City and Arsenal after Mesut Özil denounced the mass detention of Uighurs.
lead_paragraph: A state-run television network in China canceled a live broadcast Sunday of an English Premier League soccer match after the Arsenal star Mesut Özil publicly condemned the country’s treatment of fellow Muslims.

headline: Comey Admits Errors in Surveillance Warrants, but Defends F.B.I.
keywords: ['Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The former bureau director acknowledged “significant mistakes” in warrants to wiretap a former Trump campaign adviser, days after an inspector general’s report was released.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — James B. Comey, the former F.B.I. director, acknowledged on Sunday that he was wrong when he said there were no problems with the warrants used to approve surveillance for an adviser to President Trump’s 2016 campaign.

headline: Why You Shouldn’t Believe Those G.D.P. Numbers
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Gross Domestic Product', 'Economics (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Law and Legislation', 'Income', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Income Inequality']
abstract: The statistics keep on rising, but they don’t track the well-being of most Americans.
lead_paragraph: The Commerce Department will announce the latest G.D.P. numbers on Friday, and they’ll probably be solid. The economy seems to be growing at an annual rate of about 2 percent, which isn’t bad for the 11th year of an expansion.

headline: Trump’s Lasting Legacy
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'News and News Media', 'Impeachment', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Television']
abstract: America has changed under this president.
lead_paragraph: The impending impeachment of Donald Trump will be a rebuke, but it will not be a restraint.

headline: James Kennedy, Who Inspired the Movie ‘Radio,’ Dies at 72
abstract: Cuba Gooding Jr. played Mr. Kennedy in the film, which chronicled his friendship with a high school football coach in South Carolina.
lead_paragraph: James R. Kennedy, a man with developmental disabilities who became a familiar and beloved presence on the sidelines during a South Carolina high school’s football games, inspiring the 2003 film “Radio,” died on Sunday in Anderson, S.C. He was 72.

headline: The Decade Tech Lost Its Way
abstract: An oral history of the 2010s
lead_paragraph: An oral history of the 2010s

headline: ‘Harry Connick, Jr.: A Celebration of Cole Porter’ Review
abstract: With showmanship and childlike wonder, one musical sensation revisits the era of another.
lead_paragraph: Harry Connick Jr. has got Cole Porter under his skin. And he wants the world to know it. Not only did he recently release an album of Porter songs called “True Love,” but he’s also written and directed a show dedicated to the iconic composer. Titled “Harry Connick, Jr.: A Celebration of Cole Porter,” the show, running at the Nederlander Theater, delivers on the promise Connick wrote in the program notes, “fasten your seat belts; it’s going to be a wild ride.”

headline: Review: ‘London Assurance’ Minds Its Manners
abstract: A 19th-century comedy from Dion Boucicault, at the Irish Repertory Theater, showcases some delicious characters in an imperfect vehicle.
lead_paragraph: When Dion Boucicault wrote his 1841 play, “London Assurance,” he called it a “modern comedy.” But its form, which owes a debt to 18th-century comedies of manners, was deliberately regressive, its plot as familiar and creaky as a horse-drawn wagon. Even in the early Victorian era, this mild romp was an antique. The Irish Repertory Theater’s current revival, however deft and cheerful, does not increase its value.

headline: The Right Way to Close Out an Email. (Skip That Inspirational Quote.)
abstract: Signoffs and signatures: Why hitting send can be so fraught.
lead_paragraph: An endless debate rages on across technological society: What are you supposed to say at the end of your email? Is a cheery “Cheers” too affectedly British (unless you’re a Brit)? Is “Best” hopelessly bland? Can you simply end things, gracefully dropping off after your name until the next interaction, or do you have to list your jobs and accomplishments and vital stats after you say “Bye”? What do you really need to know when emailing another person? And, dear God, are people still actually calling one another in today’s world? (And do you have to do that, too?)

headline: ‘Watchmen’ Season 1 Finale Recap: Worthy Adversaries
abstract: Damon Lindelof’s provocative “remix” of the beloved comic finished the season with confidence, completeness and no shortage of stylistic bravado.
lead_paragraph: The first feeling after watching the finale of “Watchmen” is relief. Whew. Damon Lindelof has flown this plane through heavy turbulence — and a hailstorm of frozen squid — and landed it safely, which is no small achievement in itself. It was a crazy idea to riff around the consensus choice for the best graphic novel ever written, and to riff so boldly, too, by rewriting a new racial identity for Hooded Justice and plotting drastically new courses for characters like Silk Spectre II and Dr. Manhattan. (All without Alan Moore’s blessing, which he has given to no adaptation of the book.) It was audacious to shift focus from the Cold War and nuclear arms to white supremacy and racism, inviting intense scrutiny from all comers.

headline: Hallmark Channel Apologizes for Pulling Ads With Brides Kissing
abstract: The company said it was contacting Zola, a wedding website service, to “re-establish our partnership and reinstate the commercials.”
lead_paragraph: Hallmark apologized on Sunday after facing days of backlash for pulling four television ads that featured brides kissing each other.

headline: No Corrections: Dec. 16, 2019

lead_paragraph: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Dec. 16, 2019.
