lead_paragraph: Meet Elliot Alderson. He’s a real go-getter.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Worst Job in Politics? Ask the D.N.C. Chief
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, December 16, 2019.
lead_paragraph: “I will be a one-term D.N.C. chair, O.K.? You can write that one down. Yes, I will be a one-term D.N.C. chair. Ask my wife.”

headline: Deputy Sheriff No Longer With Department After Body-Slamming Student at School
abstract: State investigators in North Carolina are reviewing the case to determine whether criminal charges will be filed against the deputy.
lead_paragraph: A North Carolina sheriff’s deputy who authorities said slammed a student to the ground twice before dragging him through a school hallway — a use of force caught on video — is no longer with the department, according to authorities.

headline: Top U.S. Envoy Warns North Korea Against Weapons Tests
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Nuclear Tests', 'ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT', 'Missiles and Missile Defense Systems']
abstract: Stephen E. Biegun appealed to the North to return to dialogue on denuclearization. “Let’s get this done,” he said.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — The top United States envoy on North Korea warned on Monday that if Pyongyang conducted a major weapons test in the coming days as feared, it would be “most unhelpful,” as Washington tried to de-escalate tensions with the country.

headline: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Brexit, Arsenal, Amazon: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: Delegates at last week’s climate conference in Madrid were supposed to iron out the details of the Paris climate accords’ rules, set provisions for international carbon trading and ramp up climate-action targets.

headline: MoMA PS1 Gears Up for ‘Greater New York,’ With Busier New Director
abstract: The once-every-five-year survey of new art in the city is back.
lead_paragraph: When she was named director of MoMA PS1 this summer, the British curator Kate Fowle said she would still make time to organize exhibitions and work directly with artists. Next year, she will — as one of four curators of Greater New York, the art center’s once-every-five-year survey of contemporary art made in and around the city.

headline: N.F.L. Week 15: What We Learned
abstract: The Falcons stunned the 49ers, the Texans held on to beat the Titans and the Patriots broke out of a scoring funk with (a lot of) help from their defense.
lead_paragraph: In a week that had quite a few blowouts, there were thrillers in Tennessee and San Francisco and there was a scoring resurgence for New England (which came with some caveats). Overall, Week 15 will wrap up with eight of the league’s 12 playoff spots having been secured, giving a fairly clear picture of what we can expect going forward.

headline: In France, Dying at Home Can Mean a Long Wait for a Doctor
keywords: ['Doctors', 'Shortages', 'Death and Dying', 'Politics and Government', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: It is illegal in France to move a body without a death certificate, which only a doctor can sign. But a doctor can be hard to find.
lead_paragraph: DOUAI, France — Her mother’s death had been expected. Terminally ill with breast cancer, she lay in a medical bed in her living room, visited daily by a nurse.

headline: What’s on TV Monday: ‘Hellboy’ and ‘Burlesque’
abstract: Neil Marshall’s comic-book reboot arrives on HBO. And Cher’s glamorous neo-burlesque club comes to Netflix.
lead_paragraph: HELLBOY (2019) Stream on HBO. Rent on Amazon, Vudu and YouTube. Neil Marshall directs this reboot of Guillermo del Toro’s 2004 and 2008 movies about Mike Mignola’s colossal comic book half-demon. David Harbour replaces Ron Perlman for the title role, taking on Hellboy’s red, knob-headed physique to battle an ancient resurrected sorceress played by Milla Jovovich. As Jeannette Catsoulis wrote for The Times, this movie is “exuberantly British and quite possibly off its rocker.” Rated R for “operatic splatter and stewed children,” this “crack pipe of a movie” probably isn’t for the faint of heart.

headline: Word + Quiz: convivial
abstract: This word has appeared in 41 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year.

headline: As Protests Rage on Citizenship Bill, Is India Becoming a Hindu Nation?
keywords: ['Hinduism', 'Discrimination', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Citizenship and Naturalization', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: Several people have been killed as unrest spreads to new corners of the country. Many see the passage of a new law as anti-Muslim.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s government has rounded up thousands of Muslims in Kashmir, revoked the area’s autonomy and enforced a citizenship test in northeastern India that left nearly two million people potentially stateless, many of them Muslim.

headline: This Intersex Runner Had Surgery to Compete. It Has Not Gone Well.
abstract: Annet Negesa, Uganda’s 800-meter Olympic hopeful, says she was advised to undergo an irreversible surgery because of naturally elevated testosterone levels. Her career has never been the same.
lead_paragraph: Annet Negesa had just finished training in Kampala, Uganda, in June 2012 when she received a call from a doctor from track and field’s world governing body. He told her that she would no longer be competing in the London Olympics because her testosterone levels were too high for competition.

headline: N.Y. Lawmakers Passed 935 Bills by June. Many Remain Unsigned.
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'Politics and Government', 'State Legislatures', 'Vetoes (US)', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists']
abstract: A groundbreaking legislative session has hit pause, with a slew of legislation awaiting Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s signature or veto.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY, N.Y. — For six months, Democrats in the State Capitol flexed the power of unbridled one-party rule, ushering in a sweeping overhaul of New York’s housing, environmental, criminal and social justice laws.

headline: Netflix Is Ad Free, but It Isn’t Brand Free
abstract: Tide Pod shout-outs onscreen. Flirtatious exchanges with companies on Twitter. Netflix may not run ads, but it has become a coveted marketing platform.
lead_paragraph: Netflix subscribers like being able to glide through entire seasons of “Stranger Things” and “The Crown” without sitting through commercials for insurance and S.U.V.s with bows on the hood. Subscriptions, rather than advertising, drive its nearly $16 billion in annual revenue, and being commercial-free “remains a deep part of our brand proposition,” Netflix said in a statement.

headline: Beijing Backs Hong Kong Leader Despite Election Setback
abstract: China’s president endorses Hong Kong’s embattled leader, Carrie Lam, despite the rout of her political allies in local elections three weeks ago.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — China’s top leader backed Chief Executive Carrie Lam of Hong Kong on Monday despite the monthslong protests that have rocked the city and the recent landslide defeat in local elections of political parties aligned with her.

headline: Lesson of the Day: ‘The Modern Life of Origami, an Art as Old as Paper’
abstract: In this lesson, students learn about the art of origami and make their own creation as a holiday gift.
lead_paragraph: Featured Article: “The Modern Life of Origami, an Art as Old as Paper”

headline: Searchers Try to Find Earthquake Victims in Philippines
abstract: Two bodies were pulled from the rubble of a collapsed store on Monday, but searchers were looking for more after the powerful quake in the south.
lead_paragraph: Rescuers on Monday raced to reach several people believed trapped inside a supermarket that crumbled as a magnitude-6.9 quake violently shook the southern Philippines this weekend, killing at least five people, officials said.

headline: Afghan Warlord Escapes Arrest as Troops Turn City into War Zone
abstract: Afghan leaders sent combat forces to capture a belligerent warlord, but many critics believed the deadly raid was a political stunt gone awry.
lead_paragraph: MAZAR-I-SHARIF, Afghanistan — For nearly 24 hours, the center of Mazar-i-Sharif, one of Afghanistan’s economic hubs, became a front line for a battle that included machine guns, rocket-propelled grenades and helicopter gunships. And it didn’t even involve the Taliban.

headline: There Are Economic Warning Signs for Trump in the Midwest
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Voting and Voters', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The U.S. economy found its footing after a summer recession scare, but the Midwest is still stumbling.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. economy found its footing after a summer recession scare, but the Midwest is still stumbling.

headline: Moments in Reading That Salvaged an Often Sour Year
abstract: The critic Dwight Garner recalls the scenes, observations and one-liners in books that stuck with him in 2019.
lead_paragraph: A good book can confirm your sanity. A good book can make you feel a bit less alone. In 2019, there was no escaping a sour and scalded national mood, and good books were necessary.

headline: After Her Heart Stops Beating, a Woman Continues to Think
abstract: In “10 Minutes 38 Seconds in This Strange World,” a finalist for the Booker Prize by Elif Shafak, the narrator recalls her life in the minutes before she dies.
lead_paragraph: 10 MINUTES 38 SECONDS IN THIS STRANGE WORLDBy Elif Shafak

headline: Advice for College Students Studying Abroad, and Their Parents
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Americans Abroad', 'Parenting', 'International Study and Teaching']
abstract: Students take challenges along when they spend a semester abroad and need to be prepared to take care of themselves in a new setting and a new language.
lead_paragraph: As our children grow up, we learn the shifting mix of emotions that accompanies sending them off on their own — to camp, to college, on a variety of adventures. Study abroad for American college students has become more common — it’s about one in 10 college students now — and common in Europe as well, where the European Union operates the Erasmus program, which gives many students the chance to study in other countries.

headline: The Hidden Drug Epidemic Among Older People
abstract: People in their 60s take an average of 15 prescription drugs a year. Combined with over-the-counter products, they may do more harm than good.
lead_paragraph: While news reports focus on an epidemic of opioid abuse among young adults, another totally legal and usually hidden drug epidemic is occurring at the other end of the age spectrum: the fistfuls of remedies — both prescription and over-the-counter — taken by older adults.

headline: Punished for Sleeping on the Streets, They Prevailed in Court
abstract: The Supreme Court won’t review a ruling that blocks cities from prosecuting people for sleeping outdoors when no shelter is available. Meet the plaintiffs who started the case.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Being homeless was hard enough for Pamela Hawkes. Her pain was compounded when she found herself a frequent target of the police.

headline: New Kind of Student Loan Gains Major Support. Is There a Downside?
abstract: Income-share agreements, promoted by Betsy DeVos and Silicon Valley, may wind up merely shifting the payment burden from some students to others.
lead_paragraph: Q: When is a student loan not a student loan?

headline: Is Palo Santo Endangered?
keywords: ['Wood and Wood Products', 'Alternative and Complementary Medicine', 'Conservation of Resources', 'Forests and Forestry', 'your-feed-selfcare']
abstract: No, but, you should probably reconsider how you are using it.
lead_paragraph: Palo santo — the aromatic wood that has been used for traditional healing and in spiritual ceremonies in indigenous and mestizo Latin American cultures for centuries — has seen a growth in commercial popularity alongside concerns about its conservation status.

headline: How to Help a Teenager Handle the Death of an Idol
abstract: Social media lets teenagers feel truly connected to celebrities, so the death of a favorite rapper like Juice WRLD can hit them like a personal loss.
lead_paragraph: In June, the YouTube star Etika was found dead in the East River, a suicide. My 15-year-old son was a fan, and I watched him process the loss without saying much. A few weeks later, the Disney Channel actor Cameron Boyce died at age 20. “People can just die so young?” my son asked. I nodded.

headline: Shopping for Serving Dishes
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Design', 'Tableware', 'Home Repairs and Improvements']
abstract: Because when you’re planning a dinner party, you need to think about more than just the food.
lead_paragraph: Plates, bowls and other serving dishes are critical to the success of any dinner party — whether they’re lined up neatly along a buffet or scattered around the dining room.

headline: How to Cook Brisket Like a ‘Jewish Grandma Fashion Designer’
abstract: At Batsheva Hay’s Upper West Side apartment, Fridays are dedicated to serving this simple stovetop supper.
lead_paragraph: In One Good Meal, we ask cooking-inclined creative people to share the story behind a favorite dish they actually make and eat at home on a regular basis — and not just when they’re trying to impress.

headline: A Doctor’s Diary: The Overnight Shift in the E.R.
keywords: ['Hospitals', 'Nursing Homes', 'Skin', 'Doctors', 'Infections', 'Catheters', 'Emergency Medical Treatment', 'your-feed-science', 'Elder Care', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Bed Sores', 'your-feed-health']
abstract: In the typical emergency room, demand far outpaces the care that workers can provide. Can the E.R. be fixed?
lead_paragraph: My choices as a doctor in the emergency room are up or out. Up, for the very sick. I stabilize things that are broken, infected or infarcted, until those patients can be whisked upstairs for their definitive surgeries or stents in the hospital. Out, for everyone else. I stitch up the simple cuts, reassure those with benign viruses, prescribe Tylenol and send home.

headline: Elizabeth Warren and Bernie Sanders Have a Problem: Each Other
abstract: They’ve abided by a de facto nonaggression pact. But to win the Democratic nomination, one must prevail over the other by consolidating the left.
lead_paragraph: FAIRFIELD, Iowa — Diane Chojnowski and Denyce Rusch were among the Iowans who braved light snowfall and temperatures in the teens to see Senator Bernie Sanders on Sunday afternoon, a few hours before Senator Elizabeth Warren was also due in this liberal pillar of eastern Iowa.

headline: Fashion Nova’s Secret: Underpaid Workers in Los Angeles Factories
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Social Media', 'your-feed-fashion', 'your-feed-selfcare']
abstract: The online retailer makes fast fashion for the Instagram elite. The way many of its garments are made is much less glamorous.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Fashion Nova has perfected fast fashion for the Instagram era.

headline: On a Bahamas Sail, 8 Friends Get a Taste of Robinson Crusoe
abstract: A 300-pound sea turtle and a million stars on an unguided journey around the Exuma Islands.
lead_paragraph: Thick emerald waves broke over a quarter-mile-long sandbar, blocking our way. A few hundred yards east, whitecaps crashed across Exuma Sound — a 6,000-foot-deep abyss of rolling swells and powerful trade winds that would likely flip our tiny sailboats. Beyond the sandbar, we could see the tranquil flats of the Exuma Bank and the protected beach where we hoped to camp the first night of the trip. We just had to get around the bar before dark.

headline: Mitch McConnell, India, N.F.L.: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Here's what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Weather N.Y.C.: Flurries, Then Rain, Then Sunshine
abstract: Flurries could complicate the evening commute, with some sleet and showers thrown in.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: When Does Activism Become Powerful?
abstract: It’s about much more than amassing money or people.
lead_paragraph: From Hong Kong to Chile to the United States, people around the world are angry. They don’t have a say in things that matter in their lives. So they protest, sign petitions, call their lawmakers and organize sit-ins. Despite this enormous energy, their actions can often feel futile. How can we make them add up to something more, so people have power over the things they care about?

headline: What Will It Take to Clean Up the Electric Grid?
keywords: ['Solar Energy', 'Wind Power', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Electric Light and Power', 'Global Warming', 'Energy and Power']
abstract: It’s a huge undertaking to slow climate change, but we’ve done big things before.
lead_paragraph: Decades of climate change foot-dragging are finally giving way to public demands for action. Around the world, millions of young people are on the march. Political and business leaders are making pledges and offering plans.

headline: I Headed the F.B.I. and C.I.A. There’s a Dire Threat to the Country I Love.
keywords: ['Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Inspectors General']
abstract: The rule of law is the principle that protects every American from the abuse of monarchs, despots and tyrants.
lead_paragraph: The privilege of being the only American in our history to serve as the director of both the F.B.I. and the C.I.A. gives me a unique perspective and a responsibility to speak out about a dire threat to the rule of law in the country I love. Order protects liberty, and liberty protects order. Today, the integrity of the institutions that protect our civil order is, tragically, under assault from too many people whose job it should be to protect them.

headline: From Zero to 4, Before the End of the Driveway
abstract: Ride-on vehicles like cars, trucks and the occasional front-loader captivate children and offer the big carmakers a marketing opportunity.
lead_paragraph: Imagine it’s Christmas morning. You wake up, and head straight to the living-room tree. Under its green branches is a bright yellow Mercedes-AMG GT sports car, with your name on it.

headline: Young Black People Are Killing Themselves
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Depression (Mental)', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Youth']
abstract: The numbers are shocking.
lead_paragraph: I recently took a panicked call from a friend who’d just received a text from his 22-year-old brother that sounded like a suicide note. “Thank you for all that you’ve done to try to help me,” it read. “Nothing has gone right for me in life. I don’t have a job, any friends or a girlfriend. I hate being alone all the time. I feel like a failure. You and everybody else would be better off without me.”

headline: I Will Visit Your Grave When I Go to Iraq
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Iraq War (2003-11)', 'Poetry and Poets']
abstract: Safa al-Sarray was killed when Iraqi forces fired a tear-gas canister at his head.
lead_paragraph: Iraqis have been protesting since early October against the dysfunctional and corrupt political system installed by the United States after the 2003 occupation. Unlike previous waves of protests that began in 2011, this protest was spontaneous and not organized by any party.

headline: A Secret History of the War in Afghanistan
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The government tried to tell a story of success. Hundreds of classified memos reveal a darker struggle in an “unwinnable” war.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: Via Apple Podcasts | Via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher

headline: Boeing May Suspend 737 Max Production
abstract: The manufacturer could announce its plans today for the troubled plane, which has been out of service since two deadly crashes.

headline: Saudi Arabia Insisted Aramco Was Worth $2 Trillion. Now It Is.
keywords: ['Initial Public Offerings', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Foreign Investments']
abstract: On their fourth trading day, shares closed with a value that eluded the oil company before its initial public offering.
lead_paragraph: Saudi Aramco, the world’s biggest oil company, ended trading on Monday with a market value of over $2 trillion, a worth that had eluded it when it took its shares public.

headline: Are You Good at Giving Gifts?
abstract: How do you decide what to give the people you care about? What about those who tell you they don’t want anything?
lead_paragraph: Are you good at giving gifts to friends and family? How do you decide what to give? Do you ever feel pressure to find the “perfect” gift?

headline: Moderate Democrats Back Impeachment of Trump as House Vote Nears
keywords: ['Trump-Ukraine Whistle-blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Impeachment']
abstract: Several vulnerable freshmen who had expressed reservations about the effort said they would vote to impeach President Trump, despite the political risks.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Democratic lawmakers representing conservative-leaning districts announced one by one on Monday that they would cast votes this week to impeach President Trump, signaling that a critical bloc of the most politically vulnerable Democrats is pulling together behind the party’s effort to seek his removal from office.

headline: He Helps Parents Get a Second Chance at Learning
abstract: An adviser at a Lower East Side center faced setbacks to education in his childhood. Now he motivates parents who want to go back to school.
lead_paragraph: Croilot Semexan grew up struggling to understand his identity. The son of a Haitian mother and a Dominican father, Mr. Semexan moved from Port-au-Prince to Bridgeport, Conn., when he was 9.

headline: What You Get for $850,000 in California
abstract: An 1865 clapboard cottage in Cambria, a converted farmhouse in the Sierra foothills and a 2004 home in Chula Vista.
lead_paragraph: An 1865 clapboard cottage in Cambria, a converted farmhouse in the Sierra foothills and a 2004 home in Chula Vista.

headline: $850,000 Homes in California
abstract: An 1865 clapboard cottage in Cambria, a converted farmhouse in the Sierra foothills and a 2004 home in Chula Vista.
lead_paragraph: Believed to be the oldest continuously inhabited house in San Luis Obispo County, this clapboard cottage is called Music House, after the name of early owners. It is on the east end of Main Street in Cambria, an unincorporated coastal community halfway between Los Angeles and San Francisco (about 230 miles each way), and 10 miles south of Hearst Castle. The area has a large quantity of second homes and a notable dearth of chain stores. You can bicycle to Moonstone Beach in less than 15 minutes.

headline: Protesters in India Challenge Government Over Citizenship Law
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Legislatures and Parliaments', 'Citizenship and Naturalization']
abstract: Protests against a new citizenship law erupted across India in reaction to the Indian Parliament’s decision to give special treatment to Hindu and other non-Muslim migrants in India.
lead_paragraph: Protests against a new citizenship law erupted across India in reaction to the Indian Parliament’s decision to give special treatment to Hindu and other non-Muslim migrants in India.

headline: 12 Stories That Made Us Look at the Art World Anew
abstract: From profiles of Arthur Jafa and Jasper Johns to an exploration of how, and why, artists trade work, some of our favorite pieces from 2019.
lead_paragraph: This year, we visited the famously reclusive Jasper Johns at his barn in the Berkshire Mountains, caught up with Nick Cave and his fanciful Soundsuits on Chicago’s Northwest Side, looked at how and why artists exchange their work and tried to figure out the most important pieces of art made in the last 50 years. Below, a roundup of our favorite art stories of 2019.

headline: The Incredible, Indelible ‘Watchmen’
abstract: The finale, like the whole audacious season, broke a lot of eggs and hatched something astonishing.
lead_paragraph: Spoilers for the full season of HBO’s “Watchmen” follow:

headline: Where Are Portable Toilets on City Streets?
abstract: Monday: The latest in the Your Lead series. Also: Why California’s and Texas’ 2020 census campaigns are so different, and Raider Nation migration.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: The U.K. Election Explained, in One Number
keywords: ['Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'Elections', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: Votes for the pro-Brexit Conservatives had 10 times the effective power of votes for the anti-Brexit Liberal Democrats. Thank the electoral system known as “first past the post.”
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The answer to Brexit, the Conservative Party’s election victory and everything in British politics is (with apologies to Douglas Adams) 336,038.

headline: Praise for Rep. Jeff Van Drew From Trump, Scorn From Those at Home
keywords: ['Elections, House of Representatives', 'Impeachment', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Trump-Ukraine Whistle-blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry']
abstract: The New Jersey Democrat has quickly become anathema to people on both sides of the political divide after news spread he planned to switch parties.
lead_paragraph: TRENTON, N.J. — When Representative Jeff Van Drew, a moderate Democrat who has staunchly opposed impeaching President Trump, decided to jump to the Republican Party, he got Mr. Trump’s encouragement and blessing.

headline: Supreme Court Won’t Revive Law Barring Homeless People From Sleeping Outdoors
abstract: Scores of states, counties and cities had urged the court to hear an appeal over whether such laws are unconstitutional.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court said on Monday that it would not hear a closely watched case on whether cities can make it a crime for homeless people to sleep outdoors.

headline: Boeing to Temporarily Shut Down 737 Max Production
keywords: ['Boeing 737 Max Groundings and Safety Concerns (2019)', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Halting production of the plane will most likely hurt parts suppliers and could have a broader effect on the American economy.
lead_paragraph: Boeing next month will temporarily stop making the 737 Max, its most popular passenger jet, the company said on Monday.

headline: Epilepsy Foundation Was Targeted in Mass Strobe Cyberattack
abstract: Hackers sent images of flashing strobe lights to the foundation’s thousands of Twitter followers in several attacks.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Hackers sent videos and images of flashing strobe lights to thousands of Twitter followers of the Epilepsy Foundation last month in a mass cyberattack that apparently sought to trigger seizures in those with epilepsy, the foundation said on Monday.

headline: Cook for Comfort
abstract: Make someone roast chicken with mashed potatoes, caramelized carrots and pan gravy.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. The news is menacing these days. Irritation and mistrust dog at those who would like nothing more than to be celebrating unreservedly with family and friends this time of year: Christmas, African heritage, the Jewish festival of lights, the end of the year. The front page is scary, though. Social media is a neurotoxin. They are shouting on TV.

headline: Violence in Northern Ireland Rising Amid Political Paralysis
abstract: Paramilitary attacks are increasing again, fueled by economic stagnation, a leadership vacuum and the impact of a looming Brexit.
lead_paragraph: DERRY, Northern Ireland — On a cold, rainy night last January, a group of masked men abducted a 15-year-old boy from his home in Creggan, Northern Ireland, threw him into the back of a van and took him to a dark alleyway. There, they pinned him against a shuttered storefront and shot him in the legs until he collapsed.

headline: The ‘Black Christmas’ Remake Subverts a Complex Horror Trope
abstract: The final girl has been a staple of the genre for decades, but in 2019 female solidarity is how you survive.
lead_paragraph: This essay contains spoilers for the 2019 remake of “Black Christmas.”

headline: The Best Biscuits? There Are a Few Tricks
abstract: J. Kenji López-Alt swaps ingredients, and grates and rolls his way to biscuits that are simultaneously crisp, flaky, soft and light.
lead_paragraph: I did not grow up in biscuit country. The totality of my pre-20s biscuit experience in the Northeast came in the form of Popeyes sides, Pillsbury Grands and McDonald’s breakfast sandwiches. (I still have a soft spot for those odd folded egg patties.)

headline: Visions of Sugar Rum Cherries Tap Dance in Her Head
abstract: Michelle Dorrance makes a tap “Nutcracker” to Duke Ellington’s swinging riffs on Tchaikovsky’s classic score.
lead_paragraph: There are nostalgic “Nutcrackers” and tongue-in-cheek “Nutcrackers” and burlesque “Nutcrackers” and hip-hop Nutcrackers. But the Joyce Theater, one of New York’s busiest dance stages, has never had a “Nutcracker,” or any specifically holiday-themed show, for that matter, in its 38-year history.

headline: She Changed the Way We Eat. She Wants to Fix Our Democracy, Too.
keywords: ['Diet and Nutrition', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Capitalism (Theory and Philosophy)']
abstract: Frances Moore Lappé popularized the idea that plant-based diets were good for the planet. But her focus has been on politics all along.
lead_paragraph: Frances Moore Lappé popularized the idea that plant-based diets were good for the planet. But her focus has been on politics all along.

headline: Snow, Tornadoes and Freezing Rain Are Coming to a Wide Swath of the Country
abstract: More than 60 million people were under winter weather advisories and warnings, according to the National Weather Service. At least seven people died in crashes on icy roads, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: A storm system that was sweeping across the country on Monday left at least seven people dead over the weekend and placed more than 60 million people under winter weather advisories and warnings with threats of continuing snow, freezing rain and other types of severe weather.

headline: Did Schiff Poke a Hole in the First Amendment?
keywords: ['News Sources, Confidential Status of', 'Trump-Ukraine Whistle-blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry', 'News and News Media', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Freedom of the Press']
abstract: We can’t excuse an abuse of power just because it supports our side.
lead_paragraph: Last week, the House Judiciary Committee debated articles of impeachment drawn from a densely argued, sharply worded 300-page report that the Democratic majority on the House Intelligence Committee produced. It is an investigative tour de force, written for posterity. In considerable detail, using interviews and records, it describes, for example, how President Trump’s top personal adviser, Rudolph W. Giuliani, traipsed across Europe, circumventing diplomats as he furthered the president’s direct political interests. It also delves into the circumstances behind Mr. Giuliani’s repeated contacts with a reporter, John Solomon of The Hill, and marshals a case that Mr. Solomon’s reporting helped push a false and damaging narrative about the then-serving American ambassador to Ukraine, Marie Yovanovitch.

headline: Still Stumped on Holiday Gifts for Picky People? We Can Help
abstract: We have gift recommendations for the hardest-to-please family and friends on your list.
lead_paragraph: We asked our readers to tell us about the hardest-to-please person on their holiday gift list. With time to shop running out, we hope these ideas can provide some inspiration. Questions have been edited for length and clarity.

headline: Feral Pigs Roam the South. Now Even Northern States Aren’t Safe.
abstract: The swine have established themselves in Canada and are encroaching on border states like Montana and North Dakota.
lead_paragraph: HELENA, Mont. — Ranchers and government officials here are keeping watch on an enemy army gathering to the north, along the border with Canada. The invaders are big, testy, tenacious — and they’ll eat absolutely anything.

headline: Review: A Conceptual ‘Winterreise’ Puts a Spin on Schubert
abstract: Joyce DiDonato performed the song cycle from the perspective of the protagonist’s love interest, with Yannick Nézet-Séguin at the piano.
lead_paragraph: Joyce DiDonato is far from the first singer to rethink Schubert’s “Winterreise.” This song cycle of spurned love and frosty anguish is by now a well-trod rite of passage for recitalists. But with some regularity, performers offer remixes that look beyond the standard stand-and-deliver for fresh takes.

headline: Slotkin, Backing Impeachment, Draws Instant Protests, and Applause
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Trump-Ukraine Whistle-blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Impeachment']
abstract: Representative Elissa Slotkin, a moderate Democrat from Michigan, announced Monday that she would vote to impeach President Trump — and quickly faced the consequences.
lead_paragraph: HOLLY, Mich. — Impeaching President Trump, Representative Elissa Slotkin said, “was pretty much the last thing I wanted to be working on in my first term as a congressperson.”

headline: Waters Off California Acidifying Faster Than Rest of Oceans, Study Shows
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Oceans and Seas', 'Fish and Other Marine Life']
abstract: The ocean off California is acidifying faster than the rest of the ocean, a new study shows.
lead_paragraph: California’s coastal waters are acidifying twice as fast as the rest of the oceans, a study published Monday shows. And some of California’s most important seafood  — including the spiny lobster, the market squid and the Dungeness crab — are  becoming increasingly vulnerable.

headline: Frederick B. Dent, 97, Commerce Secretary and Nixon Ally, Dies
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Watergate Affair', 'Textiles', 'United States Economy']
abstract: He was a staunch defender of the president amid the administration’s Watergate crisis and later served as Gerald Ford’s trade representative.
lead_paragraph: Frederick B. Dent, a South Carolina textile manufacturer who in the mid-1970s was President Richard M. Nixon’s secretary of commerce and President Gerald R. Ford’s special representative for United States trade negotiations, died on Dec. 10 in Spartanburg, S.C. He was 97.

headline: Hard Times for a Hot Commodity, the Prized New Mexico Chile
abstract: Years of drought, erratic weather and other stresses are taking their toll on the peppers that are central to the state’s economy and identity.
lead_paragraph: HATCH, N.M. — In all her eight decades of farming in southeastern New Mexico, June Rutherford has never seen a chile season this bad.

headline: How Mariah Carey’s ‘All I Want for Christmas Is You’ Finally Hit No. 1
abstract: The modern holiday classic from 1994 completes the longest ever trip to the top of the Billboard singles chart, thanks to a dedicated marketing plan and a surge on streaming services.
lead_paragraph: For Mariah Carey, this year’s Christmas season started promptly on Halloween night, just as the clock struck 12 a.m. and the calendar rolled over into November.

headline: Welcome to Parliament. Now Sit Down and Shut Up.
abstract: New lawmakers may have realized a lifetime ambition. But with a huge Conservative majority, individual members will have little influence.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — There was no hiding the excitement on Monday as new members of Britain’s Parliament descended on the Palace of Westminster for day one of their new lives, most propelled there by the landslide victory of Boris Johnson’s Conservative Party.

headline: Old Mistresses Turn Tables on Old Masters
abstract: The Prado rewrites the male-dominated canon with the celebration of two overlooked female painters of the Renaissance.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — Old Masters have always outnumbered Old Mistresses, especially at the Prado. The museum is chock-a-block with paintings we know from Art History 101, in which female artists seem almost nonexistent. We come to the Prado to admire El Greco’s bony saints and Goya’s strolling majas, to marvel at Velázquez’s “Las Meninas,” that brilliant painting-puzzle in which the artist depicts himself with assorted members of the Spanish court, working on an enormous canvas that we cannot see, leaving us to wonder for eternity what it shows.

headline: Lakers and LeBron James Can Tie Road Wins Record This Week
abstract: Winning at the Indiana Pacers and at the Milwaukee Bucks won’t be easy. But if the Lakers do, they will tie the N.B.A. record of 16 consecutive road wins.
lead_paragraph: On Oct. 22, the Lakers lost their season opener against the Clippers, as the visiting team in the downtown Los Angeles arena they share. LeBron James and the Lakers haven’t lost on the road since.

headline: Navy Ship Named for Harvey Milk, Slain Gay Rights Leader, Takes Shape
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Ships and Shipping', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Awards, Decorations and Honors']
abstract: Construction of the U.S.N.S. Harvey Milk, a fleet oiler, began last week in San Diego.
lead_paragraph: Harvey Milk enlisted in the United States Navy in 1951 and worked as a diving instructor in San Diego.

headline: He Dreamed of Being a Pilot — Until Politics Got in the Way
abstract: Johannes Anyuru’s novel “A Storm Blew In From Paradise” is inspired by his father’s flight from the tensions of East Africa in the era of Idi Amin.
lead_paragraph: A STORM BLEW IN FROM PARADISEBy Johannes Anyuru

headline: Liquor Taxes Could Go Up 400%, Thanks to Congressional Dysfunction
keywords: ['Federal Taxes (US)', 'Liquor', 'ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Politics and Government', 'Tax Cuts and Jobs Act (2017)']
abstract: A temporary cut in federal taxes on alcohol fueled the growth of American distilleries, but its expiration threatens their demise.
lead_paragraph: The last two years have been good ones for Lyon Distilling. At the small rum producer in St. Michaels, Md., a town on the Eastern Shore of Chesapeake Bay, production has jumped from 4,000 bottles a year to 40,000. Four employees have become 15.

headline: On First and First, a Homey Bakery
abstract: Red Gate Bakery features rich desserts like brown-butter blondies and a stout-infused white chocolate cake.
lead_paragraph: In his homey new Red Gate Bakery, opening Thursday, Greg Rales pays homage to a farm on Nantucket where he spent summers as a child. Mr. Rales is a self-taught baker, though he worked at Flour Shop and briefly at Ovenly. His director of operations is Patricia Howard, who was at the Beatrice Inn. Red accents enliven the white subway-tiled shop that has a kitchen on view through a window. The treats on offer include rich brown-butter blondies, banana bread swirled with chocolate and a caramelized white chocolate cake infused with stout. Oreo-style cookies with eggnog filling, a thin oatmeal cookie with a snowflake pattern, and peppermint hot chocolate are available for the holidays.

headline: Long Lines as Undocumented Immigrants in N.Y. Rush to Get Licenses
keywords: ['Drivers Licenses', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Law and Legislation', 'Politics and Government', 'State Legislatures']
abstract: New York’s law allowing undocumented immigrants to obtain licenses went into effect on Monday. The same day, New Jersey passed a similar bill.
lead_paragraph: On the New York side of the Hudson River, lines outside some Department of Motor Vehicles offices stretched for blocks on Monday, as people sought to take advantage of a new state law allowing undocumented immigrants to obtain driver’s licenses.

headline: Roddy Ricch Debuts at No. 1 as Juice WRLD Returns to the Top 10
abstract: Two albums by Juice WRLD jumped up the chart after the singing rapper’s death on Dec. 8.
lead_paragraph: Roddy Ricch, a 21-year-old rapper from Compton, Calif., has topped the latest Billboard album chart, beating out the newest LPs from the Who and Camila Cabello, while news of the death of Juice WRLD sent his two albums back to the Top 10.

headline: College Basketball Is Wide Open, and Could Stay That Way
abstract: Four of the top five top-ranked men’s teams lost last week.
lead_paragraph: This college basketball season has been about much more than just the blue blood programs. The season has been wide open — four of the top five teams in the Associated Press Top 25 lost last week. Similar upsets are allowing several nontraditional names to step into the spotlight.

headline: Italian Soccer’s Anti-Racism Campaign Features Paintings of Monkeys
abstract: Faced with a series of incidents in which black players were racially abused, Italian soccer officials unveiled initiatives to fight the problem. One was immediately labeled racist itself.
lead_paragraph: Four months into the Italian soccer season, the country’s top league is wrestling with a persistent problem: A series of players have again been victims of racist abuse in the country’s stadiums, groups of hard-core fans have defended their right to abuse anyone any way they choose, and certain clubs have denied that racism is even a problem.

headline: An Olive Oil Adventure Awaits
abstract: New tasting kits from Olive Oil Jones offer the chance to explore European oils and vinegars.
lead_paragraph: Olive Oil Jones, which imports oils and vinegars directly from their producers, has introduced tasting kits. Each well-priced box ($65) has four bottles of oil or vinegar, a varied assortment to explore. The oils are Catalan arbequina, Spanish Sierra de Cazorla, Portuguese Cabeço das Nogueiras and Western Sicilian. The vinegar kit has lambrusco, saba, bittersweet riesling and balsamic from Modena. Olive Oil Jones is co-owned by Steven Jenkins, a former partner in the Fairway grocery chain.

headline: This Space Is for the Baristas
abstract: A sprawling Coffee Project NY space in Queens will hold certification classes for coffee lovers.
lead_paragraph: Cafes that are serious about the coffees they prepare have become commonplace. But here’s a new one that’s also a school and a training ground for baristas, with rigorous courses leading to official certification by the Specialty Coffee Association, a global trade group. Chi Sum Ngai and Kaleena Teoh, who own Coffee Project NY cafes in the East Village and Fort Greene, Brooklyn, have opened an ambitious new Queens flagship in part to fill a gap. “The Specialty Coffee Association has labs worldwide but none in New York,” said Ms. Ngai, who said she had to fly to Gainesville, Fla., to earn her certification. Recreational classes are also offered in the lab’s spacious classroom. The huge roaster in the front room is the top of the line; Ms. Ngai likes it because it’s not fully automated so she can control the settings. There is an informal cafe where a wide variety of coffees are brewed in myriad styles. Sandwiches and some pastries are served.

headline: Gift a Brick of Caviar
abstract: Pressed into a block, this new caviar product can be grated to add rich flavor to eggs, warm toast and pasta.
lead_paragraph: Calvisius, the Northern Italian farmed caviar company, sells an innovative and useful type of dried caviar. Made from California white sturgeon roe and shaped like an ingot, the caviar is firm and hard so it can easily be shaved with a grater or potato peeler over scrambled eggs, an omelet, mashed potatoes, pasta, cheese, seafood or buttered toast. A little goes a very long way and the flavor blooms with warm food.

headline: After 6 Murder Trials and 23 Years, Curtis Flowers Is Granted Bail
keywords: ['Discrimination', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Jury System']
abstract: Mr. Flowers was freed for the first time in more than two decades as prosecutors decide whether to try the quadruple-murder case against him for a seventh time.
lead_paragraph: WINONA, Miss. — For more than two decades, Curtis Flowers has returned over and over again to a court in Mississippi to face prosecution for the brutal killings of four people in a small-town furniture store where he once worked.

headline: Review: Fresh Talent Fuels ‘The Magic Flute’ at the Met
abstract: An exceptional cast provides delights in this trimmed-down, family-friendly version of Mozart’s fairy tale opera.
lead_paragraph: There is undeniable magic in the Metropolitan Opera’s family-friendly version of Mozart’s “The Magic Flute”: in its wildly imaginative, puppet-filled staging by Julie Taymor; in its fairy tale of a knight on a quest to win the woman of his dreams while attaining enlightenment; in its snappy and colloquial English adaptation by J.D. McClatchy.

headline: Burgers for a Better Planet
abstract: My 91-year-old father-in-law happily eats plant-based hamburgers. That gives me a little more hope for the environment.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — Here is how my father-in-law now begins every meal at our house: He asks the blessing, unfolds his napkin and prepares to tuck in. Then he pauses, his fork still in the air, and asks, “Is this real meat?”

headline: The Puzzling Decade
abstract: As the 2010s come to an end, we’re interested in your opinions on what, if anything, has changed over the past 10 years in New York Times Crosswords and Games.
lead_paragraph: The world is counting down the days to the end of a decade. For an upcoming column, we are interested in your opinions and impressions about what has changed in New York Times Crosswords and Games over the past 10 years.

headline: With Echoes of Trump, Boris Johnson Scorns the BBC
abstract: The prime minister and his party question the broadcaster’s reliance on fees paid by viewers. They are increasingly at odds with its journalism, too.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The British Broadcasting Corporation has long been one of Britain’s most revered institutions. But after an election campaign in which it faced charges of bias, the media organization finds its future in the hands of some of its biggest critics.

headline: How the Internet Came to Loathe Pete Buttigieg
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Millennial Generation', 'Tuition', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: It’s natural for a rising candidate to get kicked around. But the nature of the backlash says a lot about the past decade of Democratic politics.
lead_paragraph: Last month, after polls showed Pete Buttigieg vaulting unexpectedly to the lead in Iowa’s Democratic caucus, he aired an ad introducing his plan for higher-education reform: a proposal to make public-college tuition free for households earning up to $100,000 a year and reduce it on a sliding scale for those making up to $150,000. “Some voices,” he says in the ad, want to make college “free, even for the kids of millionaires” — a swipe at his rivals to the left, Elizabeth Warren and Bernie Sanders, who had each called for free college for all.

headline: A Climate Disgrace
abstract: Readers react to the end of the United Nations talks, with a poor showing by the United States.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Hummus, the Book
abstract: This coffee-table tome on hummus follows the dish throughout the Middle East.
lead_paragraph: The title of this lavish gift volume on hummus is rendered in Arabic, English and Hebrew. The book tours cities in the Middle East, exploring how they use chickpeas, not just in hummus but also in falafel, stews and other dishes, and even fashioned in gold as a prize embedded in a holiday treat like the bean you might find in a king cake for Epiphany. Different renditions of hummus, appealing preparations like a chicken and chickpea casserole and Yemeni spiced falafel, and a history of the chickpea are strewn throughout as the book explores the hummus route, with contributions from writers like Claudia Roden.

headline: U.K. Plans to Pass Anti-B.D.S. Law
abstract: The new Conservative government plans to pass a law restricting local authorities from participating in the Boycott, Divestment and Sanctions movement.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britain’s newly elected Conservative government plans to ban local authorities from taking part in the boycott-Israel movement, a British official said, following the lead of American officials who have also sought to clamp down on the campaign to pressure Israel to change its policies toward the Palestinians.

headline: Hong Kong, India Protests, British Election: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Instant Fish Stock, the Escoffier Way
abstract: SeaBags is a powdered stock based on a 1921 recipe from the famed French chef.
lead_paragraph: For Feast of the Seven Fishes, you will surely need some fish stock. Here’s the easy answer, a powdered stock base made from fish (like cod or haddock), onions and parsley root. It is said to be based on a recipe from 1921 that was developed by Auguste Escoffier. A chef, Henry M. Summers, was the first to introduce a convenient instant version in 1984, but production lapsed within about 10 years. Mr. Summers has reintroduced it with Paul Nippes, an artist and amateur cook. It’s easy to use: a tablespoon yields a cup of stock. But it’s shy of perfect because it’s salt-free; you’ll need to add some.

headline: Impeachment Week: ‘Maybe Truth Can Still Win’
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Trump-Ukraine Whistle-blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry']
abstract: Readers react to The Times’s editorial calling for the impeachment of President Trump, and to a news article about the likely trial in the Senate.

headline: A Methane Leak, Seen From Space, Proves to Be Far Larger Than Thought
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Environment', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Research', 'Methane', 'Natural Gas']
abstract: The  findings mark a step forward in using space technology to detect leaks of methane, a potent greenhouse gas, from oil and gas sites worldwide.
lead_paragraph: The first satellite designed to continuously monitor the planet for methane leaks made a startling discovery last year: A little known gas-well accident at an Ohio fracking site was in fact one of the largest methane leaks ever recorded in the United States.

headline: Almost Famous: Kim I Am
abstract: Kim Hill was a rising singer. She met a young rapper named will.i.am. The rest is history — or is it?
lead_paragraph: Kim Hill was a rising singer. She met a young rapper named will.i.am. The rest is history — or is it?

headline: I Quit The Black Eyed Peas. Then They Became Famous.
abstract: Kim Hill was a rising singer. She met a young rapper named will.i.am. The rest is history — or is it?
lead_paragraph: In the mid-1990s, the singer and songwriter Kim Hill met a young rapper who suggested they start making music. That rapper’s name was will.i.am, and his group was a rising Los Angeles underground hip-hop crew called The Black Eyed Peas. The rest is history — or is it?

headline: Harvey Weinstein: ‘My Work Has Been Forgotten.’ Accusers Are Livid.
abstract: As his rape trial nears, Mr. Weinstein told The New York Post that he should be remembered for helping women in Hollywood.
lead_paragraph: In his first interview in over a year, the disgraced Hollywood producer Harvey Weinstein called himself a “forgotten man,” saying that he should be remembered for the opportunities he provided to female actors and directors, rather than for the allegations of sexual assault lodged against him.

headline: Heidi Hynes, Transplanted Crusader for the Poor, Dies at 51
abstract: Dismayed by inequality and injustice, a white woman from the Midwest devoted her abbreviated career to helping poor blacks and Latinos in the Bronx.
lead_paragraph: Heidi Hynes grew up in Kansas City, Mo., where both her parents were gregarious volunteers for the Society of St. Vincent de Paul, a Catholic group whose credo is “End Poverty Through Systemic Change.”

headline: Carly Fiorina Says Trump Should Be Impeached (But She May Vote for Him Anyway)
abstract: The former Republican presidential candidate and chairwoman of Hewlett-Packard stopped short of calling for Mr. Trump’s removal from office.
lead_paragraph: Carly Fiorina, the former Republican presidential candidate and chairwoman of Hewlett-Packard, said Monday that she believed it was “vital” that President Trump be impeached, but left open the possibility of voting for him in the fall of 2020.

headline: Woman Charged After Spilling Soda on Reporter’s Head
abstract: A county commissioner in Georgia was hosting a budget meeting when his wife spilled a cup of soda and ice on the reporter’s head. She has been charged with disorderly conduct and simple battery.
lead_paragraph: At a Chattooga County budget meeting in Summerville, Ga., on Friday, a reporter suddenly found herself drenched by someone else’s soft drink.

headline: Oops! Surviving Your Holiday Party Faux Pas
abstract: Parties are supposed to be fun, right? There are loads of opportunities for things to go very wrong. Overtalkers, misspeaks, the awkward hug: with this handy guide, you’ll be able to handle the most awful situations any social event could present.
lead_paragraph: Parties are supposed to be fun, right? There are loads of opportunities for things to go very wrong. Overtalkers, misspeaks, the awkward hug: with this handy guide, you’ll be able to handle the most awful situations any social event could present.

headline: Times Readers on the Rooms That Changed Design
abstract: From Georgia O’Keeffe’s New Mexican retreat to Oscar Niemeyer’s home outside Rio, commenters’ suggestions of the most influential spaces.
lead_paragraph: When T convened a jury of experts to name the 25 Rooms That Influence the Way We Design, we expected that it would strike a nerve: definitive lists of this sort always tend to engender passionate feedback — and who among us hasn’t seen a space that’s remained in our mind’s eye, influencing not only how we see, but how we live (or, at least, would like to live)? With that in mind, we looked through comments on the article and T’s Instagram account to find some more rooms that readers themselves would have included. From Frank Lloyd Wright’s handsome midcentury homes to choices that reflect the paucity of women and non-American designers on our original list, here are some of the most popular selections.

headline: What Does Being Best Dressed Mean?
abstract: And who gets to say? As the latest list of lauded style-setters arrives, it may be time to say goodbye to the whole concept.
lead_paragraph: This weekend, the International Best-Dressed List was released — its 79th iteration, but the first under its new caretaker, Air Mail, the Graydon Carter newsletter/zine. Did you notice?

headline: Peter Snell, Record-Breaking Runner in the 1960s, Dies at 80
abstract: A middle-distance runner from New Zealand, he set world records in five events and won three Olympic gold medals.
lead_paragraph: Peter Snell, a middle-distance runner from New Zealand who set world records in five events and became a three-time Olympic gold medalist in the 1960s, died on Thursday at his home in Dallas. He was 80.

headline: Seahawks’ Josh Gordon Is Suspended Indefinitely
abstract: Gordon, who was released by the Patriots earlier this year, has served four previous suspensions for violations of the N.F.L.’s substance abuse policy.
lead_paragraph: Seattle Seahawks wide receiver Josh Gordon has been suspended indefinitely for violating the N.F.L.’s substance abuse policy, the league confirmed Monday, the latest pitfall in his troubled career. The suspension was first reported by ESPN.

headline: Strict Vaccine Law Stumbles in N.J. Legislature
keywords: ['Vaccination and Immunization', 'Freedom of Religion', 'State Legislatures', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Law and Legislation', 'Measles']
abstract: There were not enough votes in the State Senate to end religious exemptions to vaccine requirements for all students.
lead_paragraph: The New Jersey Legislature, seemingly on the verge of passing one of the strictest vaccine laws in the nation on Monday, postponed a final vote on a bill that would have ended religious exemptions to vaccine requirements for students enrolled in any school or college, public or private.

headline: Want to Gift Someone a Pet? Here’s What to Do First
abstract: Before you put a bow on a puppy or kitten for your family, here’s what to consider when getting a loved one a pet.
lead_paragraph: Every so often, I see a rom-com with a hokey gift-giving scene. An actor giggles in delight as the surprise gift of a puppy plants wet kisses on them. Though this cliché pulls at my heartstrings every time, in the real world, gifting a pet to a friend, lover, or family member can be a bad idea.

headline: Ex-Goldman Sachs Partner Barred by S.E.C. Over 1MDB Scandal
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Bribery and Kickbacks', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Tim Leissner, the husband of Kimora Lee Simmons, will not have to pay anything beyond the $43.7 million he agreed to surrender as part of a guilty plea.
lead_paragraph: Securities regulators have barred a former partner at Goldman Sachs from working in the industry more than a year after he pleaded guilty to helping orchestrate the looting of billions of dollars from a sovereign wealth fund in Malaysia.

headline: Purdue Pharma Payments to Sackler Family Soared Amid Opioid Crisis
keywords: ['Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Bankruptcies', 'Pain-Relieving Drugs', 'Opioids and Opiates', 'Corporate Taxes', 'your-feed-healthcare']
abstract: A new audit finds that the family directed $10.7 billion from the drugmaker to family-controlled trusts and holding companies, as legal pressure tightened around Purdue.
lead_paragraph: As scrutiny of Purdue Pharma’s role in the opioid epidemic intensified during the past dozen years, its owners, members of the Sackler family, withdrew more than $10 billion from the company, distributing it among trusts and overseas holding companies, according to a new audit commissioned by Purdue.

headline: The Tax Break for Children, Except the Ones Who Need It Most
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Poverty', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Tax Cuts and Jobs Act (2017)', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions']
abstract: The child tax credit, begun in 1997 as a tax cut, has become an anti-poverty program. But more than a third of children don’t receive it because their parents earn too little.
lead_paragraph: MONROE, La. — With two children and a third on the way, Ciera Dismuke worked five jobs last year while earning just under $15,000. Although the Trump administration often boasts that it doubled the federal child tax credit to $2,000 per child, Ms. Dismuke, like millions of Americans, earned too little to fully qualify. Instead, she got $934 a child, an increase of just $75.

headline: Uber in Talks to Sell Its Food-Delivery Business in India
keywords: ['Delivery Services', 'Car Services and Livery Cabs', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Start-ups', 'Initial Public Offerings', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Dara Khosrowshahi, Uber’s chief executive, is paring back the company’s money-losing businesses.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Uber is in advanced discussions to sell its food-delivery business in India, according to two people with knowledge of the plans, as the company moves to stem its losses.

headline: China Protests U.S. Expulsion of 2 Diplomats Accused of Spying
keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'United States International Relations', 'Military Bases and Installations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The diplomats were expelled after they drove onto a base that houses the headquarters of the Navy’s SEAL Team 6. China’s denial of the accusations is the first official acknowledgment of the episode.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Chinese government denounced on Monday the United States’ secret expulsion this fall of two Chinese diplomats suspected of espionage, and asked for a reversal of the action. The expulsions appeared to be the first of Chinese diplomats suspected of spying in more than three decades.

headline: Netflix Looks Abroad as Growth Slows in the U.S.
keywords: ['Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Company Reports']
abstract: The streaming giant, which likes to keep its numbers to itself, gave out fresh information on regional subscriptions in an official filing.
lead_paragraph: Netflix is the dominant streaming platform in the United States. More than 60 million people in the country pay a total of $9 billion annually to watch the original series like “The Crown” and Martin Scorsese’s Homeric mob elegy “The Irishman,” which was viewed by 26 million accounts in the first week of release.

headline: How Trump Lost His Trade War
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States Economy', 'Customs (Tariff)']
abstract: On speaking loudly and carrying a small stick.
lead_paragraph: Trade wars rarely have victors. They do, however, sometimes have losers. And Donald Trump has definitely turned out to be a loser.

abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Googled ‘Impeachment’ Lately? First Result Is a Bloomberg Ad
abstract: Michael R. Bloomberg is showing what a virtually bottomless advertising budget can do by buying his way into the hottest political conversations of the moment.
lead_paragraph: Type the word “impeachment” into Google, and odds are the first search result won’t offer a news report on the latest developments in Washington.

headline: Giving Water a Second Life
abstract: In a country where clean water is scarce, India’s textile industry uses countless gallons of it. Learn how DuPont designed a new filter to recover 92 percent of contaminated water.
lead_paragraph: In a country where clean water is scarce, India’s textile industry uses countless gallons of it. Learn how DuPont designed a new filter to recover 92 percent of contaminated water.

headline: ‘Parasite’ Advances as Nine Oscar Shortlists Are Released
abstract: The South Korean sensation made the list of contenders in two categories, while Taylor Swift’s “Cats” song was snubbed.
lead_paragraph: Want to get a jump on next month’s Oscar nominations? You can already begin culling the list of contenders now that the academy has released shortlists for nine categories, including the races for best documentary, international film and original song. Below, your Carpetbagger has analyzed six of those narrowed races. (The three other categories, all for short films, contain entries that have not yet been widely screened.)

headline: There May Be Surprises Yet
keywords: ['Trump-Ukraine Whistle-blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry', 'Presidential Election of 2020']
abstract: A lesson worth remembering: “Don’t predict impeachment politics.”
lead_paragraph: A veteran political reporter who covered the Clinton impeachment offered me some good advice this afternoon: “Don’t predict impeachment politics.”

headline: Judge Rejects Michael Flynn’s Claims in His Attacks on Prosecutors
keywords: ['Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A federal judge rebuffed a series of dubious accusations of prosecutorial misconduct by Mr. Flynn’s lawyer, an outspoken critic of the special counsel’s investigation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A federal judge on Monday rebuffed accusations by President Trump’s first national security adviser, Michael T. Flynn, that F.B.I. agents and federal prosecutors engaged in misconduct in his criminal case, delivering a comprehensive rebuke to his 11th-hour claims.

headline: American Student Freed by Iran Calls for Nations to Release Political Hostages
keywords: ['Political Prisoners', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Xiyue Wang, released in a prisoner exchange between the United States and Iran, and his wife, Hua Qua, said they were thankful for those who had helped with the diplomacy.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An American graduate student from Princeton University who had been imprisoned for three and a half years in Iran called on Monday for all nations to free their political prisoners.

headline: Vox Media to Cut 200 Freelancers, Citing California Gig-Worker Law
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Freelancing, Self-Employment and Independent Contracting', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions']
abstract: A state law meant to target Uber and Lyft has repercussions for contributors to the sports site SB Nation.
lead_paragraph: More than 200 bloggers in California will lose regular writing gigs because of a state law meant to improve working conditions at companies like Uber and Lyft that rely on contractors rather than employees.

headline: Hundreds of Historians Speak Out on Impeachment
abstract: Over 750 historians — including Robert Caro and Ken Burns — signed onto a statement condemning President Trump’s ‘numerous and flagrant abuses of power.’
lead_paragraph: Not long ago, Sean Wilentz, a professor of American history at Princeton, talked to other historians who were frustrated about not having an easy way to voice and organize their concerns over Mr. Trump’s Ukraine pressure campaign.

headline: Spending Deal to Avert Shutdown Carries Key Priorities for Both Parties
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Politics and Government', 'Federal Budget (US)']
abstract: Five days before the government is set to run out of money, lawmakers released the dozen bills needed to keep the government functioning, as well as other provisions.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Lawmakers on Monday unveiled a dozen bills that would allocate $1.4 trillion in federal spending for the remainder of the fiscal year to prevent the government from shutting down at midnight on Friday.

headline: Congress Prepares to Hit Assad With New Sanctions for War Crimes
keywords: ['Embargoes and Sanctions', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: The bipartisan sanctions package, five years in the making and expected to pass the Senate on Tuesday, is set to enact biting punishments on the Syrian government, Russia and Iran.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — More than five years ago, an unusual whistle-blower approached Congress: a Syrian military photographer. Fleeing Damascus, he smuggled out tens of thousands of gruesome photographs documenting evidence of war crimes perpetrated by the Syrian government.

headline: Anti-Trump America, We’re Counting on You
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Trump-Ukraine Whistle-blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry', 'Impeachment', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'News and News Media', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Elections, Senate']
abstract: The anti-Trump majority needs to make itself seen.
lead_paragraph: Brian Kilmeade — the dark-haired guy on “Fox & Friends,” Fox News’s morning show — was surprised. During the program on Monday, a correspondent reported that a Fox News poll showed that 50 percent of voters favored impeaching and removing Donald Trump. (An additional 4 percent favored impeachment alone.) “I was stunned to see that that’s the number, because I thought that things were trending away,” said Kilmeade.

headline: ‘Sing Street’ Review: New Wave Music as Sweet Deliverance
abstract: This tuneful adaptation of John Carney’s movie, about the saving grace of pop music in 1980s Dublin, hasn’t quite found its ideal voice.
lead_paragraph: A boy presses “play,” and the world goes away. That basic, everyday magic act — variations of which have been practiced by restless adolescents since the dawn of recorded sound — takes on fresh, senses-stirring life in the opening moments of “Sing Street,” which opened on Monday night at New York Theater Workshop.

headline: Spanish Beach
abstract: David Levinson Wilk gives us a puzzle, only to take some of it away.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — The last time we encountered David Levinson Wilk, he was asking “Why?,” but in this puzzle, he’s not asking; he’s just taking, taking, taking.

headline: Nearly 40 Years After College Student’s Stabbing Death, Genetic Records Lead to a Suspect
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Forensic Science', 'Genealogy', 'DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid)', 'Kidnapping and Hostages', 'Sex Crimes', 'Domestic Violence']
abstract: A Colorado sheriff announced an arrest in the 1980 homicide of Helene Pruszynski, 21, who had been an intern at a Denver radio station.
lead_paragraph: For nearly 40 years, the murder of a college student, Helene Pruszynski, stumped Colorado detectives. The cold case languished for so long that all but one of her immediate family members had died.

headline: Giuliani Provides Details of What Trump Knew About Ambassador’s Removal
keywords: ['Trump-Ukraine Whistle-blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Impeachment']
abstract: Rudolph Giuliani said in an interview that he briefed the president “a couple of times” about Marie Yovanovitch, the envoy to Ukraine, setting her recall in motion.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Rudolph W. Giuliani said on Monday that he provided President Trump with detailed information this year about how the United States ambassador to Ukraine was, in Mr. Giuliani’s view, impeding investigations that could benefit Mr. Trump, setting in motion the ambassador’s recall from her post.

headline: Quotation of the Day: In a Mighty Conservative Majority, Individual Tories to Wield Little Power
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, December 17, 2019.
lead_paragraph: “You arrive at Westminster and you are the new boy or girl at what turns out to be a rather bigger school than you thought. You suddenly realize that you are a person of the utmost insignificance.”

headline: Corrections: Dec. 17, 2019
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Dec. 17, 2019.
lead_paragraph: Because of an editing error, an article on Sunday about the demand for Danish television misstated the title of a Norwegian television show. It is “Lilyhammer,” not “Lillehammer.”

abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
