headline: Fear and Loyalty: How Donald Trump Took Over the Republican Party
abstract: The president demands complete fealty, and as the impeachment hearings showed, he has largely attained it. To cross him is to risk losing a future in the Republican Party.
lead_paragraph: BIRMINGHAM, Mich. — By the summer of 2017, Dave Trott, a two-term Republican congressman, was worried enough about President Trump’s erratic behavior and his flailing attempts to repeal the Affordable Care Act that he criticized the president in a closed-door meeting with fellow G.O.P. lawmakers.

headline: Trump Backs Down From Threat to Place Tariffs on Brazilian Steel
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Customs (Tariff)', 'Aluminum', 'Steel and Iron', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: President Jair Bolsonaro of Brazil said Mr. Trump decided not to pursue tariffs on Brazilian steel after a phone call on Friday.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump has backed off a threat he made this month to impose tariffs on Brazilian metal, a move that would have broken a previous agreement with the country and risked reigniting trade tensions.

headline: Colleges Agree to Allow Increased Competition for Applicants
keywords: ['ADMISSIONS STANDARDS', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Financial Aid (Education)', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues']
abstract: An agreement between college counselors and the Justice Department should free up colleges to woo early-decision applicants with financial aid.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The financial aid stranglehold on students who commit to colleges may be broken.

headline: ‘Star Wars’ Box Office on Pace for $400 Million Opening Weekend
abstract: The widely mocked “Cats” is unlikely to crack $10 million in its debut.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — “I find your lack of faith disturbing.”

headline: Is Anyone Happy Anymore?
abstract: We’ve lost our ability to take comfort in small things.
lead_paragraph: Recently I have been forced to think a bit about happiness. It’s not something I’ve done before. I have been too busy living. But when an interview with me appeared in The Sunday Times under the headline “Why ‘This Is Happiness’ Author Niall Williams Is Happily Out of Step,” I began to realize that it was not just me but the idea of happiness itself that was out of step with the times, and that it required some mental adjusting, not to say daring, to say aloud the title of my novel.

headline: Was the Virgin Mary a Virgin? Does It Matter?
abstract: Philip Yancey, an evangelical Christian writer, responds to my questions, and my doubts.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the latest in my occasional series of conversations about Christianity. Here’s my interview, edited for space, with Philip Yancey, an evangelical Christian writer who has more than 15 million books in print in more than 50 languages.

headline: Short-Term Thinking Is Poisoning American Business
keywords: ['Income Inequality', 'Private Equity', 'Capitalism (Theory and Philosophy)', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Free-market capitalism won’t survive unless it makes structural changes toward long-term investing.
lead_paragraph: In 2007, James Rogers did the unthinkable. As chief executive of Duke Energy, one of the largest coal-powered utilities in the country, he lobbied for the passage of aggressive cap-and-trade legislation. The bill, if passed, would have imposed billions of dollars in costs on his business, and it was vigorously opposed by the coal industry’s primary lobbyist.

headline: The World Christmas Made
abstract: The Christian past shapes the secular present. Does it matter?
lead_paragraph: In early November, a study published in the journal Science claimed to trace the whole social course of modernity — the decline of clan and tribe, the turn to nuclear families, the rise of individualism — back to Roman Catholicism’s opposition to incest.

headline: China’s New Civil Religion
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Religion and Belief', 'Churches (Buildings)', 'Christians and Christianity', 'Buddhism', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Taoism', 'Atheism', 'Confucianism', 'Superstitions']
abstract: The Communist Party is reviving traditional beliefs for political gain — while cracking down on some faiths.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — In the northern suburbs of this city is a small temple to a Chinese folk deity, Lord Guan, a famous warrior deified more than a millennium ago. Renovated five years ago at the government’s expense, the temple is used by a group of retirees who run pilgrimages to a holy mountain, schoolchildren who come to learn traditional culture and a Taoist priest who preaches to wealthy urbanites about the traditional values of ancient China.

headline: Las Vegas Apartment Fire Kills at Least 6, Officials Say
abstract: The fire, the deadliest in the city’s history, broke out early on Saturday and quickly filled the building with smoke, inundating the upper floors, where several residents jumped from windows, an official said.
lead_paragraph: Authorities said they were investigating whether a stove that was being used for heat ignited an early-morning fire in a Las Vegas apartment building on Saturday, killing six people and injuring 13 in the deadliest blaze in the city’s history.

headline: How to Turn Anger and Fear Into Political Power
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Volunteers and Community Service', 'Political Action Committees']
abstract: Latino organizers have the answers. When will party elites trust them?
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — First there were seven. Then 50. Then thousands of people, mostly Latino and many undocumented, who held a vigil on the lawn outside of the Arizona State Capitol in the spring of 2010, praying that Gov. Jan Brewer would not sign an anti-immigrant bill, the most punitive in generations, which had sailed through the Republican-controlled Legislature.

headline: What Happened to All Those Frozen Eggs?
keywords: ['Egg Donation and Freezing', 'Women and Girls', 'Infertility', 'Babies and Infants', 'Fertility Drugs', 'Reproduction (Biological)']
abstract: Egg freezing was supposed to be as revolutionary as birth control. It hasn’t lived up to the hype — but it has still changed women’s lives.
lead_paragraph: The potential for egg freezing to allow women to pause their biological clocks is one of the most astonishing developments of recent fertility science. The promise was thrilling: Women could enjoy more time to find the right partners, break up with the wrong ones and become emotionally and financially ready to become mothers.

headline: The Poverty and Prosperity of Losing My Husband
abstract: The financial planning he’d done his whole life paid off — to me, not him.
lead_paragraph: Last week I got new checks in the mail. It had been years since I needed any; like most people I find myself writing fewer and fewer checks these days. Cutting open the package, I was struck by the fact that where I used to receive a whole box of checks, I now got a slim envelope with only two books — one more paper item that used to be solid and institutional was now, like so much else, swiftly passing into irrelevance. I couldn’t help feeling a twinge of loss.

headline: How Trump Made a Writer of Thrillers Stick to Facts
keywords: ['Writing and Writers', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Richard North Patterson wrote best-selling novels about presidents, until he decided that the political moment was too strange to make anything up.
lead_paragraph: WEST TISBURY, Mass. — Over four decades and nearly two dozen thrillers, the novelist Richard North Patterson has used current events as scaffolding for his imagination. Late-stage abortion, conflict in the Middle East, genocide in Africa, gun control, the death penalty — the thornier the issue, the better.

headline: What’s Wrong With Manchester City? Nothing
abstract: Pep Guardiola’s City may not be a match for its recent history, but a thrashing of Leicester City shows it is hardly a broken team.
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, England — It has reached the stage, now, when it comes to gauging Pep Guardiola’s mood, his state of mind, where no detail can be overlooked.

headline: Abbey Simon, Masterly Pianist, Dies at 99
abstract: Mr. Simon, light of touch yet breathtakingly pyrotechnic, was known for his interpretations of the Romantic literature.
lead_paragraph: Abbey Simon, an American pianist celebrated for a style that harked back to an earlier, golden age of keyboard prowess, died on Wednesday at his home in Geneva. He was 99.

headline: Down for the Count
abstract: Laura Taylor Kinnel enters the ring an unknown, and leaves victorious.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Sunday constructor debuts are great. Not to detract from weekly constructor debuts, which are also wonderful, but a big grid makes a big splash and enables someone to dramatically unfurl those newly fledged wings (newly fledged to us, anyway). According to Will Shortz’s print intro, Laura Taylor Kinnel teaches math (surprise!) and is the director of studies at a Friends boarding school in Pennsylvania. Ms. Kinnel traces her interest in crosswords to this venue, solving the Sunday puzzle in The Times with her grandmother.

headline: Brendan Dassey of ‘Making a Murderer’ Is Denied Clemency
keywords: ['Amnesties, Commutations and Pardons', 'False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Documentary Films and Programs']

lead_paragraph: Gov. Tony Evers of Wisconsin this week denied a request to grant clemency to Brendan Dassey whose murder conviction was documented in the Netflix documentary series “Making a Murderer.”

headline: Matt Bevin Drew Outrage Over His Pardons. These Governors Have, Too.
abstract: Governors who issue pardons often do so on their way out of office. But the criticism, and court challenges, can endure.
lead_paragraph: When a radio host asked Matt Bevin, the former governor of Kentucky, why he had pardoned a man convicted of raping a child, Mr. Bevin’s first response was, “Which one?”

headline: Trump Largely Ignores Impeachment as He Rallies Young Conservatives
abstract: With a relentless attack on liberalism, the president returned to his greatest hits: attacks on the “fake news,” environmentalists, liberals and immigrants.
lead_paragraph: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. — President Trump on Saturday largely ignored that he had become the third impeached president in history as he rallied young conservative activists with campaign-style attacks on the “far-left ruling class” at the start of a two-week vacation.

headline: Officials Discussed Hold on Ukraine Aid After Trump Spoke With Country’s Leader
keywords: ['Foreign Aid', 'Trump-Ukraine Whistle-blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Emails also suggest President Trump first began asking about $250 million in Pentagon aid after a June 19 article in the Washington Examiner.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — About 90 minutes after President Trump held a controversial telephone call with President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine in July, the White House budget office ordered the Pentagon to suspend all military aid that Congress had allocated to Ukraine, according to emails released by the Pentagon late Friday.

lead_paragraph: You protest, they watch.

headline: West African Countries Take a Step Away From Colonial-Era Currency
abstract: A bloc of eight countries will rename their French-backed currency and France will scrap a contentious requirement for reserve deposits.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — A bloc of West African states took a step away from a French-backed regional currency that dates back to the colonial era, making a significant symbolic break from the past.

headline: The Patriots Beat the Bills (Again) Behind Julian Edelman
abstract: Edelman, the New England wide receiver, missed some game time after faking an injury, but he provided critical playmaking and scoring when it mattered most.
lead_paragraph: FOXBOROUGH, Mass. — An instant after a violent collision on Saturday evening in the pivotal, hard-fought game between New England and Buffalo, Patriots wide receiver Julian Edelman lay motionless on the turf as if unconscious. It was, Edelman said hours later, a ruse. When he slammed into Bills defensive back Jordan Poyer while running a crossing route early in the third quarter, he had committed offensive pass interference — and Edelman knew it.

headline: Diane Hu, Alexander Sappington
abstract: The couple met at Princeton, from which each graduated, the bride cum laude and the groom summa cum laude.
lead_paragraph: Diane Shuyan Hu and Alexander Joseph William Sappington were married Dec. 20 at Villa Serenita, a rental home in St. Thomas, in the United States Virgin Islands. Michael Motylinski, who received an online ordination through the Wanderlust Bay Ministries, officiated.

headline: Meredith Miller, Kimberly Duva
abstract: The couple met in 2004 at a friend’s birthday party in Park Slope, Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Kimberly Ann Duva and Meredith Reade Miller were married Dec. 16 at their apartment in Manhattan. Hilary Gingold, a civil court judge with chambers in Brooklyn, officiated.

headline: Boeing Starliner Lands in New Mexico After Clock Error Prompts Early Return
keywords: ['Space and Astronomy', 'Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'International Space Station', 'Private Spaceflight']
abstract: The new ride to orbit built for NASA and its astronauts returned to Earth after problems during its first trip to space on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Boeing’s new spacecraft, the CST-100 Starliner, safely parachuted to Earth on Sunday, landing atop inflated airbags before dawn at the White Sands Missile Range in New Mexico.

headline: For Women in Kabul, ‘It Is Just Me and the Water’
abstract: Since 2001, 23 public and private pools have appeared in Kabul, but only two allow women. They’re a welcome refuge from suicide bombings and the threat of a Taliban takeover.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — When Fatema Saeedi is in the pool, she cannot hear the crowded, chaotic noise of the city around her. She does not think about suicide bombings or Taliban attacks. She concentrates on her breathing as she moves through the water. One hand in front of the other. Exhale.

headline: In France, Holiday Skating Rinks Are an Unlikely Climate Battleground
abstract: The attractions have prompted environmental concerns, and some cities have canceled them, citing the size of the carbon footprint needed to maintain the sites.
lead_paragraph: ST.-MALO, France — On a recent morning, toddlers and teenagers laughed and shouted as they skated around a rink of shiny ice just outside the walls of St.-Malo, a city on the northern coast of Brittany where winters generally hover above freezing.

headline: How a Poisoning in Bulgaria Exposed Russian Assassins in Europe
keywords: ['Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations', 'Poisoning and Poisons', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Arms Trade']
abstract: For years, members of a secret team, Unit 29155, operated without Western security officials having any idea about their activities. But an attack on an arms dealer in Sofia helped blow their cover.
lead_paragraph: SOFIA, Bulgaria — The Russian assassin used an alias, Sergei Fedotov, and slipped into Bulgaria unnoticed, checking into a hotel in Sofia near the office of a local arms manufacturer who had been selling ammunition to Ukraine.

headline: Deborah Gist, Ronnie Jobe
abstract: The couple met in April at the Summit, a Tulsa social club, where they bonded over the songs of the Bee Gees.
lead_paragraph: Deborah Anne Gist and Ronnie Dale Jobe are to be married Dec. 22 at their home in Tulsa, Okla. The Rev. Courtney Richards, a Disciples of Christ minister, is to officiate, with the Rev. Mark R. Wood, an Episcopal priest, to take part.

headline: Samantha Meyer, Edward McGarrigle
abstract: Her send-off for a new jobs included farewell drinks, a round of karaoke and the start of their relationship.
lead_paragraph: Samantha Hindel Meyer and Edward John McGarrigle were married Dec. 21 at Maritime Parc, an events space in Jersey City, N.J. Brian Pramberger, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, led a ceremony incorporating Jewish traditions.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Republican Party Under Trump Offers 2 Options: All In, or Out
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, December 22, 2019.
lead_paragraph: “He has a complete connection with the average Republican voter and that’s given him political power here. Trump has touched the nerve of my conservative base like no person in my lifetime.”

headline: Corrections: Dec. 22, 2019
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Dec. 22, 2019.
lead_paragraph: The Ask Watching column last Sunday misstated the location where the television show “Claws” is set. It is in Manatee County, Fla., not Miami. The error was repeated in a picture caption.

headline: What’s on TV Sunday: ‘Mr. Robot’ and ‘Noelle’
abstract: After four seasons, USA Network’s cybersecurity thriller comes to an end. And a Christmas movie from Disney+ is available to stream.
lead_paragraph: MR. ROBOT 9 p.m. on USA Network. This month, Rami Malek earned his third Golden Globe nomination for his lead role as the tortured vigilante hacker in this cyberthriller series. Elliot (Malek) and Mr. Robot (Christian Slater) have come a long way. In last week’s episode (spoiler alert!), Elliot and Whiterose (BD Wong) shared their vision for humanity in a tense philosophical debate before the creation of a seemingly parallel universe. And, if that weren’t enough of a cliffhanger, Elliot came face to face with his hooded doppelgänger and asked the burning question: “Who are you?” Catch the reveal in this two-part series finale.

headline: Afghan President Leads in Disputed Vote as Opposition Protests
abstract: Long-delayed initial results of the September election show President Ashraf Ghani leading with a slight majority of the vote.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — President Ashraf Ghani of Afghanistan was on course to win a second five-year term, the country’s election commission announced Sunday, based on long-delayed preliminary results of the September vote, which has faced protests and accusations of fraud.

headline: Ursids Meteor Shower 2019: Watch It Peak in Night Skies
abstract: Meteor showers can light up night skies from dusk to dawn, and if you’re lucky you might be able to catch a glimpse.
lead_paragraph: All year long as Earth revolves around the sun, it passes through streams of cosmic debris. The resulting meteor showers can light up night skies from dusk to dawn, and if you’re lucky you might be able to catch a glimpse.

abstract: Murphy, who helped keep ‘S.N.L.’ alive in the ’80s, hosted for the first time in 35 years, with help from his old characters and a ton of special guests.
lead_paragraph: It took 35 years, but Eddie Murphy came back to host “Saturday Night Live.”

headline: U.K. Honors a Flawed Feminist Trailblazer, Nancy Astor
abstract: The American-born Lady Astor was the first woman to take a seat in the British Parliament. A century later, her legacy is still being debated.
lead_paragraph: PLYMOUTH, England — When women finally won the right in 1918 to enter Britain’s Parliament, many expected the first female lawmaker to sit there to come from the ranks of the suffragists, the activists who had fought, often at huge personal cost, for the vote.

headline: A Holocaust Survivor Now Struggling to Pay Rent
abstract: Zoltan Matyash witnessed “the worst of human agony” at Auschwitz and Buchenwald. Now he and his wife, Mera, are trying to get by on a fixed income in Borough Park, Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Zoltan Matyash grew up in Czechoslovakia, the oldest of two boys and four girls. He was born a Kohen, part of a line of priests who in the Jewish tradition are responsible for transmitting God’s blessing.

headline: Lights. Camera. Senior Center?
keywords: ['Volunteers and Community Service', 'Retirement Communities and Assisted Living', 'Movies', 'ACTORS AND ACTRESSES', 'Elderly']

keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Discrimination', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', '#MeToo Movement', 'Workplace Environment', "Women's Rights"]
abstract: Campaigns promoting female empowerment are all the rage. But women in advertising say they still have to navigate “Mad Men” workplaces.
lead_paragraph: The empowerment of women was a major theme of Advertising Week, a yearly gathering of roughly 100,000 ad-industry people in New York. The female R&B group TLC kicked off the program with a concert called “Future Is Female,” and there were panel discussions with titles like “Mom Bosses,” “#RewriteHerStory” and “Time’s Up, Pay Up: We Will Not Wait 100 Years.”

headline: Chicago House Party Shooting Leaves 13 Wounded, 4 Critically, Police Say
abstract: The party was part of a memorial for a man who was killed in April, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: A house party on the South Side of Chicago was meant to remember a man who was fatally shot during a carjacking in April, the authorities said. But the memorial itself erupted into violence early Sunday after at least two gunmen opened fire, wounding 13 people, four of them critically.

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: Eat deliciously on Christmas — and on the days leading up to it, with sesame-glazed duck legs, baked mushrooms and beans, and a breakfast feed from Melissa Clark.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s been a difficult month for my crowd, and it looked for a time as if we’d lose Christmas entirely. But the tree’s now trimmed with favorite ornaments (A ski-jumping bear from Quebec! A ceramic dolphin from Florida!), and the whole place smells of forest and cinnamon. There’s lots of jing-jing-jingling. The dog’s asleep in front of the fire.

abstract: Choosing a meaningful gift for a child — one they truly connect with and value — can be more challenging than it seems.
lead_paragraph: When my 9-year-old daughter asked for a sewing machine last year, my instinct was to pick up a simple one for kids. It was inexpensive. It was easy. I could check it off my list and be done. But a good friend steered me away.

abstract: To what extent is giving a DNA test also a present for law enforcement?
lead_paragraph: The company GEDmatch, the DNA database that facilitated an arrest in the Golden State Killer case and in dozens of other cases since, emerged from a desire to connect people to their relatives. For the past decade, the site’s co-founder Curtis Rogers has been running the company out of a small yellow house in Lake Worth, Fla.

headline: Mama Cax, Amputee Model and Disability Activist, Dies at 30
abstract: A Haitian-American, she landed fashion campaigns, appeared on the cover of Teen Vogue and walked runways at the White House and at New York Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: Mama Cax, a Brooklyn-born advocate for people with disabilities and a rising model who challenged the fashion industry’s standard of beauty by not shying away from displaying her prosthetic leg on the runway and in fashion campaigns, died on Dec. 16 in London. She was 30.

headline: Jeanne Guillemin, Who Exposed Soviet Anthrax Lab, Dies at 76
abstract: After an outbreak killed scores of people in 1979, she showed how even a tiny amount of a biological warfare agent could threaten a population.
lead_paragraph: Jeanne Guillemin, an eminent medical anthropologist and scientific sleuth who helped expose a secret biological warfare lab in the Soviet Union as the source of a lethal anthrax outbreak, died on Nov. 15 at her home in Cambridge, Mass. She was 76.

headline: Vaping on Campus: No Parents, No Principals, a Big Problem
abstract: Despite a growing health crisis that has killed more than 50 people, vaping has become an irresistible — and addictive — part of life for many college students.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS, Ga. — Gail Moody had her first e-cigarette inhale of the day moments after waking up one recent morning. She took more puffs while showering. Aerosolized nicotine filled her lungs again during a break in her morning run, between mouthfuls of lunch, and as she worked at a tobacco shop near the University of Georgia, where she is a sophomore.

headline: 9 Delightful Tips for Living a Smarter Life in 2020
abstract: Small ideas that have big impacts.

headline: Stranded on Border, This Migrant Became the Camp Doctor

lead_paragraph: MATAMOROS, Mexico — Under a canopy on the edge of a squalid encampment, a young physician named Dairon Elisondo Rojas holds office hours every day from 10 to 4.

headline: ‘Dabangg 3’ Review: A Hero From the School of Knock ’em Hard
abstract: In this Bollywood action flick, Salman Khan is a one-man wrecking crew. When not knocking heads, he dances.
lead_paragraph: The Bollywood movie “Dabangg 3” opens with several bangs: Wedding robbers are doing what wedding robbers do — collecting guests’ gold chunks and cash — when the police arrive on the scene. The officers bumble until their leader, our hero, Inspector Chulbul Pandey, blasts his way onto the scene. He comes flying through a wall, riding what looks to be a giant drill (or is it a modest rocket?) and proceeds to punch, karate chop, kick, toss in the air, and generally drub the miscreants in a way that would be purely cartoonish if not for a dose of mild sadism. (Crotch, meet knife.)

headline: Johanna Lindsey, Best-Selling Romance Novelist, Dies at 67

lead_paragraph: Johanna Lindsey, whose best-selling romance novels told stories of unbridled passion, revenge, submission and abductions among aristocrats, debutantes, pirates and fearless heroines, died on Oct. 27 in Nashua, N.H., her family recently announced. She was 67.

headline: What’s on TV Monday: ‘His Dark Materials’ and a Football Finale
abstract: The fantasy series based on novels by Philip Pullman wraps up its first season. And rivals clash on Monday Night Football.
lead_paragraph: GREEN BAY PACKERS VS. MINNESOTA VIKINGS 8:15 p.m. on ESPN. The two teams at the top of the N.F.C. North meet in Minneapolis in the final Monday Night Football game of the year. The Minnesota Vikings haven’t lost at home all season and have never lost to the Packers at U.S. Bank Stadium but they trail their regional rivals in the standings. They were also defeated in an earlier matchup at Lambeau Field in September. With the regular season just two games away from completion there’s still plenty to fight for. The Vikings have yet to clinch a playoff spot and the Packers are competing for postseason privileges. Minnesota fans may be hoping that the Vikings’s offensive edge and passionate home support will be enough to avoid a regular season series sweep.

headline: A Test for Foreign Teachers in Indonesia: Are You Gay?

Durham, the veteran federal prosecutor named by Attorney General William P. Barr to investigate the origins of the Russia inquiry, burnished his reputation for impartiality over the years by keeping his mouth closed about his work.

lead_paragraph: Baba Ram Dass, who epitomized the 1960s of legend by popularizing psychedelic drugs with Timothy Leary, a fellow Harvard academic, before finding spiritual inspiration in India, died on Sunday at his home on Maui, Hawaii. He was 88.

headline: Inside Christmas Card, Girl Finds Plea From Chinese Prison Laborers
keywords: ['Forced Labor', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Christmas']
abstract: A 6-year-old found the note in London while writing Christmas cards to her classmates. “Forced to work against our will,” the message read.

headline: An Insightful New Translation of the Timeless ‘Art of War’
abstract: Michael Nylan’s translation of the classic book of strategy by Sun Tzu is the first in any modern language by a female scholar.
lead_paragraph: The most electric war plan in semi-recent American literature appears in “A Run Through the Jungle,” a story by the much-missed Thom Jones. Here is that plan in its entirety: “Infiltrate Hanoi, grab Uncle Ho by the goatee, pull off his face and make a clean escape.” Because warfare is rarely so simple, books of strategy are consulted.

headline: Five Tips for Living Longer in 2020
abstract: There are steps you can take to avoid deadly risks like falls, colon cancer and breast cancer, and increase your chances of living longer.
lead_paragraph: Advice from Well on ways to minimize risks and increase your longevity.

headline: 10 Books to Watch For in January
abstract: A collection of long-lost Zora Neale Hurston stories, a heart-stopping novel about a migrant’s journey across Mexico, a look at the crisis facing America’s working class and more.
lead_paragraph: Lydia, a bookstore owner, had a pleasant life in Acapulco before the arrival of a violent cartel called Los Jardineros. After her husband publishes an exposé about the group’s leader in the local newspaper, her family is massacred, and Lydia and her young son must go on the run. This novel is a heart-stopping story of survival, danger and love, as they undertake the grueling journey to the United States.

headline: Why Is There a Coffee Shop in So Many Stores?
abstract: In New York, boutiques of all kinds are beginning to look a lot like cafes.

headline: New York State Moves to Ban Foam Food Containers
keywords: ['Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Foam', 'Recycling of Waste Materials', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: The proposal by Gov. Andrew Cuomo would make New York the second state to approve a ban on containers made of polystyrene.
lead_paragraph: The previously ubiquitous puffy containers began to disappear this year from New York City delis, takeout joints and halal food trucks. They were banished from other pockets of the state as well, and in many cities around the world.

headline: Tackling Inflammation to Fight Age-Related Ailments
abstract: Body-wide inflammation is tied to most chronic diseases, limiting people’s health and longevity.
lead_paragraph: The quest for a fountain of youth is many centuries old and marred by many false starts and unfulfilled promises. But modern medical science is now gradually closing in on what might realistically enable people to live longer, healthier lives — if they are willing to sacrifice some popular hedonistic pleasures.

headline: An Apocryphal Christmas Miracle
keywords: ['Diphtheria', 'Children and Childhood', 'Immune System', 'ANTIBIOTICS', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: An old tale about a children’s ward in 1891 may be a myth, but the diphtheria antitoxin was a real gift.
lead_paragraph: Gather around, children, and let me tell you the — false — legend of the Christmas diphtheria antitoxin miracle. I’ve just finished a book about the end of many kinds of childhood mortality, and got caught up in this tale that is often said to have happened on Christmas 1891, in Berlin.

headline: For the Sydney Hobart, an Indigenous Crew Puts to Sea
abstract: For the first time in the grueling event, Indigenous Australians are officially racing.
lead_paragraph: Some sailors prepare all their lives for an event like the Rolex Sydney Hobart Yacht Race. Then you have Naomi Cain, a 42-year-old upstart who started sailing six weeks ago.

headline: Sharing a Room in Bedford-Stuyvesant and Making New Friends
keywords: ['Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Roommates']

lead_paragraph: Though Craigslist and Facebook have been the go-to places to find a room share for years, Kira Hooks, a 26-year-old musician who moved to the city from Nashville this August, quickly ruled out them out.

headline: Earth Science Has a Whiteness Problem
abstract: Barely 10 percent of doctoral degrees in the geosciences go to recipients of color. The lack of diversity limits the quality of research, many scientists say.
lead_paragraph: When Arianna Varuolo-Clarke was growing up, her favorite evenings were spent watching the Weather Channel with her grandfather. She wanted to “chase thunderstorms” and understand where tornadoes came from, she said. She decided to become an atmospheric scientist. In 2014, she landed an internship at the National Center for Atmospheric Research as a college sophomore, and quickly realized that her path as a woman of color would not be easy.

headline: In Fighting Over the Minors, What Might Baseball Lose?
abstract: M.L.B. says it needs to take a broad look at the structure of the sport, but its proposal to trim the minor leagues risks undercutting part of what makes it special.
lead_paragraph: When the San Francisco Giants chose catcher Joey Bart second over all in the 2018 draft, the fans in Keizer, Ore., knew what that meant. A decade earlier, they had gotten an early glimpse of another first-round catcher, Buster Posey, who went on to lead the Giants to three World Series titles. Now Posey’s likely successor would play in their town, too.

headline: Elizabeth Warren Returns to Oklahoma, Stressing Working-Class Roots
abstract: It was a personal and political homecoming at a key moment in Ms. Warren’s candidacy. Her monthslong rise in national polling has stalled in recent weeks.
lead_paragraph: OKLAHOMA CITY — At the age of 16, an “Okie” known to her friends as Liz Herring and to her family as “Betsy” graduated from Northwest Classen High School, her professional prospects limited by her gender and her politics fairly conservative.

headline: 36 Corvettes, Hidden for Years in a Garage, Will Be Given Away
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Contests and Prizes', 'Collectors and Collections', 'Antique and Classic Cars']
abstract: The set of ’Vettes, one from each production year between 1953 and 1989, will be part of a sweepstakes drawing next year.

The ’89 is so ’80s — it has one of those early digital dashboards, with a big-digit speedometer, that were panned by aficionados. headline: Putin’s Russia, Punching Above Its Weight, Keeps Adversaries Off Balance

headline: L’Express, the Beloved Montreal Bistro Where So Much Began

headline: T’s Best Interiors of 2019
abstract: Take a look inside the most memorable homes featured in T this year, including Tom Dixon’s Brutalist villa in Monaco and the early Modernist abode of Osvaldo Borsani.
lead_paragraph: Take a look inside the most memorable homes featured in T this year, including Tom Dixon’s Brutalist villa in Monaco and the early Modernist abode of Osvaldo Borsani.

headline: The 17 Most Extraordinary Homes Featured in T This Year
abstract: Step inside a Brutalist villa just outside Monte Carlo, a castle in southern Tuscany — and more.
lead_paragraph: With the endless stream of design imagery on social media, it takes a singular aesthetic to elicit a second look. The best homes featured in T this year stand out for their strong points of view — from recent creations such as Tom Dixon’s Brutalist villa in the Monégasque hills and Studio Peregalli’s chalet in Switzerland’s Engadine valley to those that contain a rich and layered past, like the early Modernist home of the architect Osvaldo Borsani and the medieval castle in southern Tuscany revived by the vintner Charlotte Horton. Click through our slide show to see, and read more about, our favorite interiors from 2019.

headline: Quiz: Can You Identify These Politicians, Athletes and Celebrities? Most Americans Can’t.
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Celebrities', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Why recognizability matters, to politicians and celebrities alike.
lead_paragraph: Why recognizability matters, to politicians and celebrities alike.

headline: Growing Death Toll on City Roads
abstract: After six deaths last week, most involving commercial trucks, Mayor de Blasio's safety program seems to be losing ground.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: Saudi Death Sentences in Khashoggi Killing Fail to Dispel Questions
abstract: Saudi Arabia has been accused of shielding Prince Mohammed bin Salman, who foreign experts suspect was behind the killing of Jamal Khashoggi.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Saudi Arabia sentenced five men to death and three to prison terms over the killing of the Saudi dissident writer Jamal Khashoggi in Istanbul, a ruling widely dismissed as punishing low-level agents while protecting their leaders.

headline: North Korea, Jamal Khashoggi, Baba Ram Dass: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Here's what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Year in Sound
keywords: ['Impeachment', 'Christchurch, New Zealand, Attack (March 2019)', 'Uighurs (Chinese Ethnic Group)', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)']
abstract: Our audio time capsule captures the sounds of conflict, color and controversy that defined 2019.
lead_paragraph: Our 2019 “Year in Sound” was produced by Clare Toeniskoetter and edited by Wendy Dorr.

headline: South America Is in a Quandary. Just Like the United States.
abstract: The knowledge economy is today’s road to greater and more inclusive prosperity.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — South America is falling apart. The popular rebellion in Chile — a country often held up as an example of success predicated on good behavior — is only the most extreme instance of a discontent that is either breaking out or simmering in almost every South American nation. The struggle between the right and the left has intensified. But so far nothing that contributes to socially inclusive economic growth has resulted from these protests. What does it all mean? And how do South America’s troubles mirror the United States’ own?

headline: What the Senate Does Now Will Cast a Long Shadow
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Constitution (US)', 'Trump-Ukraine Whistle-blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry', 'Impeachment']
abstract: Mitch McConnell and the other 99 senators must serve the institution and the Constitution that established it, not President Trump.
lead_paragraph: When the Senate ultimately convenes to consider whether to remove the president from office, for just the third time in its history, it will convene not as a legislative body, but as a court of impeachment. And it will not just be President Trump on trial. The Senate — and indeed, truth itself — will stand trial.

headline: An Immigrant’s Christmas Eve
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Asylum, Right of', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Deportation', 'Jews and Judaism']
abstract: We could have been turned away at the border. But a law enforcement officer granted my family a few days of freedom.
lead_paragraph: On the night that we first came to the United States — Christmas Eve, 1979 — my mother, my brother and I were what President Trump would probably call illegal aliens. Like most of the immigrants at America’s borders today, we were fleeing violence and instability in our native home.

headline: Am I Wiser Than My Grandparents?
abstract: Judging the past by the values of today can be its own kind of intolerance.
lead_paragraph: NARA, Japan — In Canada recently, I ran across one of the most anguished mea culpas I’ve encountered in a long time, in a piece prominently displayed in The Toronto Star. Its author, JP Larocque, confessed that in 2008, he foolishly dressed up for Halloween as someone from south of the American border, thus being guilty, all at once, unusually for his considerate homeland, of racial insensitivity, cultural appropriation and a joke in inexcusable taste. That a photo of himself wearing a sign that said, “MEXI-CAN’T” might surface at any moment meant, even more profoundly, that he had “lived with regret ever since.”

headline: China Blocked Her From Freezing Her Eggs. So She Sued.
keywords: ['Egg Donation and Freezing', "Women's Rights", 'Women and Girls', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: The Chinese government prohibits single women from freezing their eggs, forcing many of them to go overseas. “It feels like my right to choose is always controlled by others.”
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Teresa Xu wants to have a baby someday. Like many women around the world, she hopes to freeze her eggs while she works to save money for a future family. The trouble: China bars single women from the procedure.

headline: What Should Europe Do About Viktor Orban and ‘Illiberal Democracy’?
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Debates (Political)']
abstract: Donald Tusk is leaving his job as European Council president, but he still faces the problem presented by his old friend, transformed by power and cynicism.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Donald Tusk grew up inside Poland’s Solidarity movement, the workers’ revolt that combined with intellectuals to bring down the Communist regime in the face of a Soviet threat of invasion and then martial law.

headline: Notre-Dame Will Not Host Christmas Mass, a First in More Than 200 Years
abstract: The Paris cathedral, which suffered a devastating fire this year, is still closed to the public as reconstruction efforts slowly get underway.
lead_paragraph: Notre-Dame cathedral in Paris will not hold Christmas services this week for the first time in over two centuries, as workers continue to shore up the fragile building after a devastating fire.

headline: General Who Was Algeria’s De Facto Ruler Dies, Leaving a Power Vacuum
abstract: Gen. Ahmed Gaïd Salah arranged the ouster of the country’s longtime president this year, while cracking down on a protest movement that demanded broader change.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Algeria’s de facto ruler, Gen. Ahmed Gaïd Salah, who this year managed the ouster of one president and the ascent of another amid deep civil unrest, died on Monday, according to the state news agency and Algerian press reports.

headline: $2 Million Homes in California
abstract: A 1988 clapboard-and-stone house in Sonora, a recently built townhouse in La Jolla and a newly renovated ranch in Sebastopol.
lead_paragraph: Constructed as a family home by a local builder, this house is 10 miles northeast of the Gold Rush town of Sonora and about 45 miles northwest of Yosemite National Park. The area is popular with second-home owners from Silicon Valley, who enjoy the proximity (about 25 miles) to Pinecrest Lake and the Dodge Ridge Ski Resort.

headline: The Artist Renee Cox’s Decade in Images
abstract: The photographer shares a selection of her favorite images from the past 10 years.
lead_paragraph: The photographer shares a selection of her favorite images from the past 10 years.

headline: An Artist Shares Her Most Striking Images of the Decade
abstract: Renee Cox selects her favorite photographs from the past 10 years, including a shot of her and Rick Owens’s likeness and portraits from her ongoing series.
lead_paragraph: On the eve of her 30th birthday, the artist Renee Cox, who at the time was enjoying a successful career as an editorial photographer for Essence magazine, began thinking about her legacy. She was pregnant with her first child, and things that had appeared important to her before now seemed less so. “In my 20s, I could talk about a pair of shoes for an hour,” she says. “As I got older, that got harder to do.” The 28-day cycle of her magazine work, too, was on her mind. Then, in 1990, a decisive moment presented itself. Cox was in New York’s SoHo, having a drink with some industry friends at Jerry’s, a favorite of the ’90s fashion crowd. “I said, ‘It’s amazing, Nelson Mandela has been released from prison after 27 years.’” The group paused and looked blankly at Cox. Then, someone at the table announced that they’d heard Donald and Ivana Trump were getting a divorce. “That’s when I knew it was time for me to get out of fashion,” she says.

headline: Boeing Fires C.E.O. Dennis Muilenburg
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'Boeing 737 Max Groundings and Safety Concerns (2019)']
abstract: Boeing has been mired in crisis since the crashes of two of its 737 Max jets killed 346 people.
lead_paragraph: Boeing said on Monday that it had fired its chief executive, Dennis A. Muilenburg, who was unable to stabilize the company after two crashes involving its best-selling 737 Max plane killed 346 people and set off the worst crisis in the manufacturing giant’s 103-year history.

headline: Making the Front Page: How All the News Fits in Print
keywords: ['Newspapers', 'News and News Media', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Today’s A1 is the result of a far more democratic and organic process than the one in place when I arrived at The Times in 1978.
lead_paragraph: In an effort to shed more light on how we work, The Times is running a series of short posts explaining some of our journalistic practices. Read more from this series here.

headline: Using His Camera as a Witness and Weapon
abstract: Shahidul Alam, the acclaimed Bangladeshi photojournalist and activist, pushes against the limits of his medium to cast light on what is suppressed or has vanished.
lead_paragraph: Like Woody Guthrie, who called his guitar an anti-fascist weapon, the Bangladeshi photographer Shahidul Alam has used his camera for 35 years as a tool to advance social justice. He began by documenting street protests in Dhaka, the capital, in the mid-80s, making pictures in the tradition of the Magnum photographers, especially Henri Cartier-Bresson. But over time, he pushed against the natural constraints of a medium that registers what is seen, so that he might illuminate what is suppressed or has vanished.

headline: Words to Live By: Artists We Lost in 2019
abstract: At their best, the artists who died this year could make us see the world in new ways — even as they made us laugh and cry. Here is a tribute to some of them, in their own words.
lead_paragraph: At their best, the artists who died this year could make us see the world in new ways — even as they made us laugh and cry. Here is a tribute to some of them, in their own words.

headline: Why California Still Doesn’t Have 40 Million People
abstract: Monday: California’s growth rate has hit historic lows. Also: A Yosemite holiday tradition.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Barge With 600 Gallons of Diesel Sinks Off Galápagos Islands
keywords: ['Derricks and Cranes', 'Maritime Accidents and Safety', 'Ships and Shipping', 'World Heritage Sites', 'National Parks, Monuments and Seashores']
abstract: The spill, which occurred after a crane toppled onto a barge, forced an emergency cleanup in one of the world’s most revered natural destinations.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of gallons of diesel fuel sank into the waters off the Galápagos Islands on Sunday after a crane toppled onto a barge and caused it to overturn, the authorities in Ecuador said, prompting an emergency cleanup in one of the world’s most revered natural destinations.

headline: An Unforgettable Holiday Centerpiece
abstract: An end-of-year extravagance, Gabrielle Hamilton’s whole roast suckling pig is an easily prepared, visually stunning project.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Gabrielle Hamilton wrote a lovely piece for The Times this week, about end-of-year extravagances — caviar sandwiches and homemade Boston cream doughnuts and the like — and particularly about the whole roast suckling pig (above) she has at one holiday party a year — “with its crackling skin so crisp it sounds as if you are cutting a loaf of bread, and its profoundly sticky, ribbon-soft, milky meat.”

headline: Wine Lessons From a Master
abstract: “Wine Simple,” from Aldo Sohm, the head sommelier at Le Bernardin, offers practical basics, with step-by-step illustrations.
lead_paragraph: Few of the myriad wine books that fill the shelves give an illustrated, step-by-step guide to opening a bottle of wine with a standard waiter’s corkscrew, showing what to do if the cork breaks. “It happens,” says Aldo Sohm, the wine director at Le Bernardin, in his new, very practical book about wine. There’s information on wine basics, winemaking and natural wines, as well as a guide to grapes, countries and regions, and instructions on how to taste, order, buy and collect wine, and serve it at home. It’s a book that teaches, making it more suitable for a novice than someone with a sophisticated cellar and palate.

headline: A Chocolate Bar With a New Look
abstract: These deconstructed bars from La Maison du Chocolat have two flavors, side by side.
lead_paragraph: The chocolate bar has supplanted the luxury truffle or box of assorted bonbons in the world of chocolate. Bars from companies across the globe are now labeled according to country of origin, percentage of cacao, added ingredients, style and even how they’re supposed to affect your well-being. At La Maison du Chocolat in Paris, the chef and creative director, Nicolas Cloiseau, has come up with a collection of “deconstructed” bars. Each box has a side-by-side panel of dark, milk or white chocolate, with other ingredients like dried fruit, nuts and puffed rice mixed in. In another innovation, the panels are scored for breaking into pieces instead of being molded in segments. There are six 2.75-ounce bars in the collection, each in a bright box.

headline: Fresh Evidence in Hand, Schumer Demands More Emails and Documents
keywords: ['Trump-Ukraine Whistle-blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Impeachment']
abstract: Senator Chuck Schumer, the minority leader, laid out a long list of records Democrats would like to see as the House pressed for testimony from a former White House counsel.
lead_paragraph: Senator Chuck Schumer said on Monday that newly released emails showing that military aid to Ukraine was suspended 90 minutes after President Trump demanded “a favor” from Ukraine’s president were “explosive.” They strengthened, he said, Democratic demands for far more internal administration documents ahead of Mr. Trump’s impeachment trial.

headline: The Ganges Brims With Dangerous Bacteria
keywords: ['ANTIBIOTICS', 'Water Pollution', 'Drug resistance (Microbial)', 'Digestive Tract', 'Bacteria', 'Sewers and Sewage', 'Water', 'DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid)', 'Cremation']
abstract: This sacred river offers clues to the spread of one of the world’s most daunting health problems: germs impervious to common medicines.
lead_paragraph: GANGOTRI, India — High in the Himalayas, it’s easy to see why the Ganges River is considered sacred.

headline: Home Goods From Italy
abstract: The owner of Il Buco has a new space to sell tableware and home accessories from Italy.
lead_paragraph: Since 2013, Donna Lennard, the owner of Il Buco and Il Buco Alimentari & Vineria in NoHo, has been selling country-style Italian tableware and home accessories from a loft near the restaurants. Now, Il Buco Vita has a new permanent home nearby. Earth tones dominate the pottery, glass, dinnerware, pitchers and serving pieces. There are rustic cutting boards, soft linens and throws, small paintings of food and landscapes, some vintage items, cookware and twisted beeswax candles with double wicks. Most of what’s on display is also sold online.

headline: For a Festive Sip, Turn to Blackberry Liqueur
abstract: This liqueur from Westchester County, N.Y., is good in place of cassis for a Kir. Or try it in a trifle.
lead_paragraph: In place of cassis for a kir, turn to a blackberry liqueur from Heimat New York to add sultry richness to a glass of white or sparkling wine. (It’s also good for trifles.) It’s the latest flavor from the year-old company in Mamaroneck, N.Y. Ute Londrigan, who makes the liqueurs, has plumbed her German grandmother’s recipe box for the formula. She obtains the fruit for this liqueur, as well as for the other flavors — Bosc pear, cranberry, white peach, raspberry and rhubarb — from upstate farmers.

headline: Eloise Can Now Take Her Tea Downtown
abstract: Afternoon tea is now available at Augustine, Keith McNally’s restaurant in the Beekman Hotel.
lead_paragraph: Though the restaurateur Keith McNally has tended to look to France and its brasserie style for his greatest hits, he is now taking his cue from his native England with the introduction of a proper afternoon tea at Augustine. Offered daily from 3 to 5 p.m. at his restaurant in the Beekman, a hotel near City Hall, the tea features a multitiered stand holding little sandwiches (ham, roast beef, cucumber and smoked salmon) and pastries like scones. Linzer cookies and mini-Sacher tortes are also included thanks to Markus Glocker, the Austrian chef of Bâtard, who is running the kitchen.

headline: What Happened When My Son Asked Santa for a Golden Trumpet
abstract: The smallest gifts can be the ones that linger in memory.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — It was 1994, a week before Christmas, when my not-quite-3-year-old spied a shopping mall Santa and insisted on paying him another visit. I tried to demur. I tried to deflect. His official Santa visit had taken place weeks earlier. This trip to the mall was just a chance to escape the gloom that is Nashville in December, to wear out those busy toddler legs in a place where it wasn’t raining and cold. We planned to ride a few escalators and throw a few pennies into the fountain: “I wish for a brudder!” my child yelled with every splash of a copper coin, and all the nearby shoppers smiled. I could not smile.

headline: What Billionaires Don’t Understand About College Debt
abstract: Forget big donations. Go for structural reforms.
lead_paragraph: In May, the billionaire Robert Smith was widely lauded when he announced he would pay the student debt of Morehouse College’s graduating class to the tune of $34 million. So were Michael Bloomberg, the former New York mayor and presidential candidate, who gave $1.8 billion to his alma mater, Johns Hopkins University, in 2018, and Steve Tisch, who earmarked $10 million for middle-class students at U.C.L.A. in October. Ken Langone, a founder of Home Depot, appeared on a TV show last year to celebrate his surprise gift of $100 million to help pay the tuition of medical students at New York University.

headline: How to Eat Dinner Like the Last Citizens of Pompeii
abstract: The chef Heston Blumenthal’s latest exploration of historical appetites is a menu inspired by the final meals prepared in the doomed Roman city.
lead_paragraph: In A.D. 79, a baker in the Roman town of Pompeii placed some loaves of bread in his oven. While they were baking, Mount Vesuvius erupted, raining down layers of hot ash and stone that would both extinguish life from the town and enshrine its final moments. In excavations some two millenniums later, the loaves finally came out of the oven — carbonized, but with their shape and texture intact. And on a blustery evening last week, a recreation of those loaves graced a banquet at the Ashmolean Museum in Oxford, England, where the British chef Heston Blumenthal staged a meal inspired by the cuisine of Pompeii.

headline: The Nightjet: A Big Bet on Train Travelers Who Take It Slow
abstract: While other European rail lines have reduced their overnight train services, Austria’s state-owned system is investing in its own.
lead_paragraph: On a recent morning, as Venice awakened to crisp November sunshine, a group of travelers appeared on the steps of Santa Lucia Station. They stood in awe of the Grand Canal just opposite, rummaging for sunglasses in their bags.

headline: Kanye West Gives Lincoln Center an Opera for Christmas
abstract: Fans talk outside “Mary,” West’s version of the Nativity story with his Sunday Service choir.
lead_paragraph: David Geffen Hall was nearly full on Sunday evening for Kanye West’s “Mary,” the hip-hop star’s second venture into what he calls opera. But no one there seemed more enthralled with the performance than West himself.

headline: For Her Children, Seeking the Education She Didn’t Have
abstract: Born in Lebanon to a Palestinian mother and a Syrian father, Iman Chtayoui lacked proof of her identity. She wanted to put her children in school, but she needed extensive legal help.
lead_paragraph: TYRE, Lebanon — When Iman Chtayoui’s husband began courting her, she wasn’t interested.

headline: Add Falling Ice From Glass Towers to a New Yorker’s List of Worries
abstract: Smooth exteriors and sloped surfaces increase the surface area for ice to form.
lead_paragraph: Alongside the year-round fears of pedestrians in New York City — plummeting into a sidewalk cellar or being hit by a car — the winter season ushers in another potentially deadly menace: falling ice.

headline: Blackface at the Ballet Highlights a Global Divide on Race
abstract: A photograph from the Bolshoi stirred a debate on social media that exposes differing attitudes in the United States and Europe.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this month, Misty Copeland posted a photo to her 1.8 million followers on Instagram. “This is the reality of the ballet world,” wrote Ms. Copeland, the first African-American female principal at American Ballet Theater.

headline: The Secret Afterlife of Lost German Luggage
keywords: ['Lost and Found Property', 'Auctions', 'Luggage and Packing', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: Roughly 250,000 items are lost each year on the trains or platforms belonging to Deutsche Bahn. What happens to those items is decidedly German.
lead_paragraph: Roughly 250,000 items are lost each year on the trains or platforms belonging to Deutsche Bahn. What happens to those items is decidedly German.

headline: Bannon’s Work With Wanted Chinese Billionaire Began Shortly After He Left White House
abstract: Stephen K. Bannon, once President Trump’s top political adviser, struck up a business relationship with a mysterious and wanted Chinese billionaire just after his White House job ended.
lead_paragraph: Almost immediately after ending his White House employment, Stephen K. Bannon, the former chief strategist to President Trump, forged a lucrative financial relationship with a mysterious Chinese billionaire who was sought by Beijing for extradition from the United States.

headline: Playwrights Are Finding ‘Television Money’ Helps Pay the Bills
keywords: ['Writing and Writers', 'Television', 'Theater', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Graduate Schools and Students']
abstract: More top playwriting programs are preparing students to write for the small screen. And TV writers’ rooms are scouting those classrooms for new talent.
lead_paragraph: In a bare fluorescent-lit room at The New School in Greenwich Village earlier this month, three writers peered into their laptops as moans wafted in from the acting class next door.

headline: The Sexual Predator’s TV Wife
abstract: Harassment has long been a hurdle on the anchorwoman’s rise to the top. New projects, like “The Morning Show” and “Bombshell,” examine what she has to do to stay there.
lead_paragraph: “The Morning Show” begins with a wake-up call. Mitch Kessler (Steve Carell), the Matt Lauer-ish co-host of a “Today” show-ish program, answers the phone at 3 a.m. to learn that he has been fired over allegations of sexual misconduct. When his co-host, Alex Levy (Jennifer Aniston), reports to a chaotic pre-dawn set, her producer, Chip (Mark Duplass), says something sycophantic about how much America needs her, and she snaps. “Don’t drag America into this,” she says. “This affects me.”

headline: Klobuchar Is Banking on Iowa Moderates. Her Problem: So Is Buttigieg.
abstract: Amy Klobuchar remains in a distant fifth place in Iowa, where her biggest challenge is translating rising curiosity around her candidacy into support on caucus night.
lead_paragraph: DIAGONAL, Iowa — Amy Klobuchar was holding two loaves of bread.

headline: Almost Famous
abstract: An Op-Docs series of short films featuring people who fell just short of making history — and were happy anyway.
lead_paragraph: An Op-Docs series of short films featuring people who fell just short of making history — and were happy anyway.

headline: Harry Styles Hits No. 1 With One of the Year’s Biggest Debuts
abstract: The former One Direction member succeeded thanks to a mix of streaming, digital sales and vinyl.
lead_paragraph: On his way to one of the best weeks for an album this year, the former One Direction member Harry Styles did it the old-fashioned way and the of-the-moment way.

headline: ‘Worthless. Gutless. Loser.’ Online Attacks Escalate When the Mayor Is a Woman.
keywords: ['Mayors', 'Threats and Threatening Messages', 'Sexual Harassment', 'Discrimination', 'Cyberharassment', 'Women and Girls', 'Social Media']
abstract: Female mayors are more than twice as likely as male mayors to experience psychological abuse and almost three times as likely to experience physical violence, a new study found.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Satya Rhodes-Conway’s inbox makes abundantly clear how personally venomous local politics has become.

headline: Cookies for the Sophisticated Set
abstract: Real Treat, a Canadian brand, has four subtle cookie flavors suitable for your next party.
lead_paragraph: These cookies are suited to a cocktail party. Top Shelf, by the Canadian company Real Treat, is a line of four cookies: Salted caramel shorties with fennel would go well with an aperitif; double dark chocolate, with candied lemon peel, is buttery and spiced — suitable for a dunk in milk. There’s also a savory salted lemon with herbes de Provence and dark chocolate chunk with smoked pecan, which, after a few chews, is all barbecue. Limited edition holiday flavors, including gluten-free spiced pecan shortbread, are also available. The ingredients in these small-batch cookies are certified organic.

headline: He Won and Lost the Kentucky Derby. He Can’t Stop Watching the Replay.
abstract: With Maximum Security, Luis Saez had the greatest ride of his life on the first Saturday in May. Until he didn’t.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Sports department is revisiting the subjects of some compelling articles from the last year or so. Here is our May report on the Kentucky Derby disqualification of Maximum Security.

headline: Assembling a New Tradition
abstract: Resurrecting a childhood tradition enables a woman to find her chosen family.
lead_paragraph: In my preteens, I was not yet above going into a toy store. And since these were the days before video games, my eyes were drawn to the puzzles on the shelves: 500 pieces, 1,000 pieces, 1,500 pieces. Mostly beautiful scenery and travel destinations.

headline: What We Learned in 2019: Health and Medicine
abstract: Developments in medicine and health that we’re still thinking about at year’s end.
lead_paragraph: It’s not easy to say that any particular development in health or medicine was the most important in a given year. But if we had to choose some highlights, we would opt for these unforgettable events and findings.

headline: Karl E. Meyer, 91, Reporter, Editorialist and Author, Dies
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'News and News Media', 'Writing and Writers', 'Cold War Era']
abstract: He reported on Castro’s rise and the Bay of Pigs invasion and, as an opinion writer, criticized, in retrospect, a Times reporter’s Stalin-era dispatches.
lead_paragraph: Karl E. Meyer, a third-generation journalist who fortified his reporting as a foreign correspondent and editorial writer for The Washington Post and The New York Times with a scholar’s grasp of historical context, died on Sunday in Manhattan. He was 91.

headline: A $750,000 Taxi Medallion, a Driver’s Suicide and a Brother’s Guilt
keywords: ['Taxicabs and Taxicab Drivers', 'Credit and Debt', 'Depression (Mental)', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts']
abstract: After the cabdriver Kenny Chow died by suicide, his brother carried his legacy — and then, a creeping fear that he was to blame.
lead_paragraph: Richard Chow discovered his younger brother’s taxi abandoned outside Carl Schurz Park, a 15-acre Manhattan oasis overlooking the East River. He began to panic.

headline: Marianne Williamson: Who She Is and What She Stands For
abstract: A self-help author and spiritual leader, wants to “harness love for political purposes.”
lead_paragraph: A self-help author and spiritual leader, wants to “harness love for political purposes.”

headline: Forget Stock Market Forecasts. They’re Less Than Worthless.
abstract: Wall Street strategists are issuing predictions for 2020. Ignore them, our columnist says, and invest with cheap, diversified index funds.
lead_paragraph: It is the time of year for predictions and I’ll make one: You will be better off ignoring the Wall Street stock-market predictions for 2020.

headline: Deval Patrick: Who He Is and What He Stands For
abstract: A late arriver to the White House race, the former Massachusetts governor brings a moderate message and a rags-to-riches biography.
lead_paragraph: A late arriver to the White House race, the former Massachusetts governor brings a moderate message and a rags-to-riches biography.

headline: John Delaney: Who He Is and What He Stands For
abstract: Funding much of his campaign with his own money, Mr. Delaney is running on a platform of bipartisanship and moderation.
lead_paragraph: Funding much of his campaign with his own money, Mr. Delaney is running on a platform of bipartisanship and moderation.

abstract: Here’s what you need to know.

abstract: A former mayor arguing that it takes one superrich New Yorker to defeat another.
lead_paragraph: A former mayor arguing that it takes one superrich New Yorker to defeat another.

abstract: The Colorado senator wants to usher in a new era of trust in government and bipartisan compromise.
lead_paragraph: The Colorado senator wants to usher in a new era of trust in government and bipartisan compromise.

headline: Opportunity, the NASA Rover Who Showed Us Mars
abstract: A NASA rover set the beyond-Earth record for overland exploration, and revealed that the basis of life — water — once existed on the red planet.
lead_paragraph: A NASA rover set the beyond-Earth record for overland exploration, and revealed that the basis of life — water — once existed on the red planet.

headline: Barbara York Main, the Australian Lady of the Spiders
abstract: A literary arachnologist, she identified dozens of new species and shed light on the landscape they crept through.
lead_paragraph: A literary arachnologist, she identified dozens of new species and shed light on the landscape they crept through.

headline: Eddie Hill IV Was Just 10. He Was Supposed to Be the One to Make It.
abstract: He stood out from the start. But the dreams for young Eddie were stopped short.
lead_paragraph: He stood out from the start. But the dreams for young Eddie were stopped short.

headline: Peggy Lipton, the ‘Mod Squad’ Star and ... Singer?
abstract: She gave life to two indelible TV characters. And then there was her album.
lead_paragraph: She gave life to two indelible TV characters. And then there was her album.

headline: Isabel Toledo, a Designer Who Expressed Emotion Through Clothing
abstract: Her style was always her own, from the geometry of the clothing she designed to the elegance of her life.
lead_paragraph: Her style was always her own, from the geometry of the clothing she designed to the elegance of her life.

headline: Jimmy Nelson Made Ventriloquism an Art With His Partner Danny O’Day
abstract: They taught each other how to speak — without moving their lips.
lead_paragraph: They taught each other how to speak — without moving their lips.

headline: Doris Day, the ‘World’s Oldest Virgin,’ Could Have Been So Much More
abstract: She was an actress with subversive potential — who became a symbol of a generation’s sexual hypocrisy.
lead_paragraph: She was an actress with subversive potential — who became a symbol of a generation’s sexual hypocrisy.

headline: Etika, a Charismatic YouTuber Who Struggled Through His Online Fame
abstract: His mental health problems collided tragically with the attention economy.
lead_paragraph: His mental health problems collided tragically with the attention economy.

headline: Toni Morrison, the Titan of Literature
abstract: Her friends recall a woman who was as fun as she was brilliant.

headline: ‘1917’ Was an Impossible Mission. Here’s How Sam Mendes Pulled It Off.
abstract: The World War I drama, seemingly filmed in one bravura take, is a tribute to his grandfather that Mendes never thought he’d make.
lead_paragraph: When the director Sam Mendes was a young boy, he and his father often traveled to the West Indies to visit his grandfather Alfred Mendes, a novelist. Sam, who had been brought up in North London, found his grandfather to be quite exotic: The small and wiry World War I veteran would sing opera in a booming Trinidadian accent, traipse around his creaky Colonial house in shorts and flip-flops and vigorously greet each morning with a pre-dawn plunge into the sea.

headline: The Modern Appeal of Black Lipstick
abstract: Obsidian shades have a romantic, mysterious allure and are a perfect antidote to the ubiquitous reds of the season.
lead_paragraph: As festive as red lipstick is at this time of year, the shade can feel a little predictable at holiday parties. For those willing to break from tradition, the spring 2020 runways offered a bold alternative: a velvety swipe of black across the lips. “It’s striking, strong and feminine,” says Lynsey Alexander, the London-based makeup artist behind the glossy noir mouths at Courrèges. Similarly beautiful midnight shades could be spotted at Jil Sander and Max Mara, where the tones had hints of merlot and violet plum. While these dark shades are surprisingly flattering, and with the right styling look romantic rather than gothic, applying them requires care. Here, five tips for achieving a subversive-yet-chic effect.

headline: Chinese Restaurants Are Closing. That’s a Good Thing, the Owners Say.

headline: Pentagon Eyes Africa Drawdown as First Step in Global Troop Shift
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Terrorism', 'Military Bases and Installations', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The deliberations stem from a push to reduce missions battling distant terrorist groups, and to instead refocus on confronting so-called Great Powers like Russia and China.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Defense Secretary Mark T. Esper is weighing proposals for a major reduction — or even a complete pullout — of American forces from West Africa as the first phase of reviewing global deployments that could reshuffle thousands of troops around the world, according to officials familiar with internal deliberations.

headline: Love Christmas Variety Shows? Go Ahead, Take Another Helping
abstract: In recent years, Kacey Musgraves, John Legend and Gwen Stefani have all paid tribute to classic televised holiday variety shows, banking on baked-in holiday nostalgia.

Musgraves, a Grammy-winning country star, was channeling the pop icon, from her shiny waterfall of black hair down to her many outfits including a feathered sheer bodysuit reminiscent of Cher’s renowned 1974 Bob Mackie number. It was no coincidence.

headline: Confused in California
abstract: Nearing the end of his round-the-world trip, the 52 Places Traveler was confounded by the Golden State cities of Los Angeles and Santa Barbara.
lead_paragraph: The whirlwind pace of my yearlong trip around the world means I never leave a place feeling like an authority on it. At best, I hope to catch a glimpse of its soul — a collage of impressions and interactions that fit neatly into a narrative. With just three stops and two weeks remaining on my journey, I finally encountered a place where I struggled to find that. I like Los Angeles, but I don’t understand Los Angeles.

Yet I have a sinking feeling that, politically, it’s going to cost the Democrats dearly. Where do things go from here?

headline: How to Help Brazilian Farmers Save the Amazon
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Forests and Forestry', 'Carbon Caps and Emissions Trading Programs', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Global Warming', 'Indigenous People']
abstract: A new investment standard would reward efforts to protect tropical forests.
lead_paragraph: When I moved to the Amazon “Wild West” town of Paragominas in northern Brazil in 1984 as a young scientist studying forest recovery on abandoned pastures, I expected a town filled with bandits and land grabbers. Instead, what I mostly found were courageous, hard-working families from across Brazil who had come to the rugged town of sawmills, cattle ranches and smallholder settlements to improve their lot in life.

headline: Saudi Arabia and Kuwait Settle Dispute Over Oil Fields
abstract: The agreement over a shared region could bring more oil to the global market and benefit Chevron.
lead_paragraph: Saudi Arabia and Kuwait said Tuesday that they were ending a long-running dispute over an oil-rich strip of land shared by the two countries, a move that will allow as much as 500,000 barrels of crude per day to return to the world market.

headline: Australia’s Volunteer Firefighters Find It Hard to Pause, Even for Christmas
abstract: Thousands are working extended shifts to battle relentless blazes, raising questions about whether the country can continue to rely on an unpaid force.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — Lucy Baranowski, a volunteer firefighter, has taken time off work over the past three weeks to battle one of the biggest blazes ever recorded in Australia. The smoke has given her a cough. She and her husband, also a firefighter, are tired to the bone.

headline: ‘The Song of Names’ Review: A Prodigy, a War and a Mystery
abstract: A young violinist goes missing in London in 1951. The eventual answer as to why is powerful.
lead_paragraph: “The Song of Names” begins with a disappearance: In 1951, David Eli Rapoport, a violinist of around 21, is set to make a splash on the London stage. Born in Poland as Dovidl, Rapoport was, as a child, left in the care of a gentile London family that respected his Judaism and nurtured his talent. They prepared him for a life as a virtuoso. What could possibly cause him to skip his debut?

headline: ‘Spies in Disguise’ Review: Smug Agent Meets Gadget Geek
abstract: Will Smith and Tom Holland are an action odd couple in this animated comedy.
lead_paragraph: Will Smith voices an “is there anything he can’t do?” secret agent whose massive skills are dwarfed by his humongous ego in “Spies in Disguise,” a colorful but not very eye-opening animated offering from Blue Sky, the studio that brought us the “Ice Age” diversions. The character is an amiable-to-the-point-of-toothless sendup of Smith’s celebrity persona and many of the roles he’s played.

headline: Tiny Love Stories: ‘A Dishonest, Possibly-Cheating-on-Me Boyfriend’
abstract: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
lead_paragraph: I spent the last night of Hanukkah knee-deep in potato peelings with my closest friends. None of them are Jewish, but they were all eager. We ate latkes, passed the Shamash around my dining room table so we could each light a candle on the menorah. Watching my friends take such care with a religion that is not their own evoked an unexpected tenderness. Love is the way my friends laughed as we stood around my kitchen island on my last Hanukkah at home before college, squeezing grated potatoes into patties and sliding them into oiled pans. — Rachel Lynch

headline: How I Found My Voice

headline: Once Upon a Revolution in Iran
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Muslims and Islam', 'War and Revolution']
abstract: Forty years after the Iranian revolution of 1979, the people of Iran are still struggling for their rights.
lead_paragraph: I spent the better part of two months, from Christmas 1978 until late February 1979, covering the Islamic revolution in Iran. There was no internet, no mobile phones, no Twitter. No one wore masks to hide their faces. The anger was immediate and raw. It led to the fall of the Pahlavi dynasty and the founding of the Islamic Republic.

headline: Christmas Turns the World Upside Down
abstract: What does it mean for God’s power to be “made perfect in weakness”?
lead_paragraph: If you were wholly unfamiliar with the life of Jesus and listened only to what many Christians in America say today, you could be forgiven for thinking that the most important thing Christianity values is worldly power — the power to control and compel, to impose one’s will on others, to vanquish one’s enemies. Blessed are the politically powerful and the well connected, you might assume, for theirs is the kingdom of heaven.

headline: In Japanese New Year Dishes, a Family Connects With Its Past

headline: ‘1917’ Review: Paths of Technical Glory
abstract: Sam Mendes directs this visually extravagant drama about young British soldiers on a perilous mission in World War I.
lead_paragraph: On June 28, 1914, a young Serbian nationalist assassinated the presumptive heir to the Austro-Hungarian throne, thus starting World War I. That, at any rate, is the familiar way that the origins for this war have been shaped into a story, even if historians agree the genesis of the conflict is far more complicated. None of those complications and next to no history, though, have made it into “1917,” a carefully organized and sanitized war picture from Sam Mendes that turns one of the most catastrophic episodes in modern times into an exercise in preening showmanship.

headline: Be Paranoid About Privacy
keywords: ['Mobile Applications', 'Maps', 'Privacy', 'Consumer Protection', 'Social Media', 'General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR)']
abstract: We need to take back our privacy from tech companies — even if that means sacrificing convenience.
