headline: ‘The White Sheik’: Fellini’s Charming Farce About Fandom
abstract: The director’s first solo feature pokes fun at the fantasies and obsessions that fuel the entertainment industry.
lead_paragraph: “The White Sheik,” which had its premiere in 1952, was Federico Fellini’s first solo feature, and the essence of his style is present from the moment when a tattered canvas canopy appears on an empty beach, accompanied by Nino Rota’s brassy carnivalesque score.

headline: 8 Ways to Be Kinder to Yourself in 2020
abstract: You deserve it!
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Smarter Living newsletter! Every Monday, S.L. editor Tim Herrera emails readers with tips and advice for living a better, more fulfilling life. Sign up here to get it in your inbox.

headline: ‘Ip Man 4: The Finale’ Review: Head Punches and Heart
abstract: Lessons about intolerance are interwoven with the hand-to-hand skirmishes the series is known for.
lead_paragraph: The modesty that defines good martial arts in the “Ip Man” franchise is also a principal virtue of the films. “Ip Man 4: The Finale,” the concluding chapter of a saga inspired by the life of the famed teacher of the Wing Chun fighting style, closes out the series with body flips, head punches, smashed furniture and heart.

headline: Watching an Interstellar Comet and Hoping for a Bang
keywords: ['Comets', 'Stars and Galaxies', 'Telescopes and Observatories', 'Earth', 'Space and Astronomy', 'Solar System', 'Hubble Space Telescope', 'Christmas']
abstract: Seeing Comet Borisov won’t be easy for the typical sky gazer, but astronomers still have a lot to learn from this extrasolar tourist.
lead_paragraph: After drifting between stars for eons, Comet 2I/Borisov will make its closest approach to Earth on Saturday, Dec. 28. The comet is only the second confirmed interstellar object to be observed in our solar system, after Oumuamua in 2017. During the comet’s close approach, it will be about 180 million miles away from us, which at that point will be farther away than Mars.

headline: Green Bay’s Win Over Minnesota Opens Up the N.F.C. Seeding Race
abstract: The struggling Vikings are locked into the No. 6 playoff seed in the N.F.C. But four teams enter Week 17 with a chance to secure the top seed for the conference.

headline: ‘What She Said’ Review: Pauline Kael, Screen Queen
abstract: Kael’s distinctively passionate voice, competing with movie fragments, is disastrously muffled, as are those of her admirers and detractors.
lead_paragraph: Unlike its subject, the documentary “What She Said: The Art of Pauline Kael” merely feints toward criticism. A numbing torrent of largely unidentified film clips and poorly labeled commentary, Rob Garver’s overstuffed tribute to the life and work of America’s best-known — and most written about — film critic is at times barely coherent.

headline: New Russian Method to Silence Dissent: Military Service in the Arctic
abstract: A key ally of Aleksei A. Navalny, President Vladimir V. Putin’s most prominent opponent, was seized and shipped off to serve at a remote, frigid air defense base.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — After trying a number of methods to silence the dissident Aleksei A. Navalny and his supporters, the Russian authorities tried something new this week: They seized one of his key allies, put him into compulsory military service and sent him to the Arctic.

headline: ‘Love at First Sight’ Inspired This African Art Collection

lead_paragraph: BOWIE, Md. — The white living room in Olusanya Ojikutu’s home, with its soaring cathedral ceiling, is a temple to his traditional and contemporary African art. Sculptures bookend the sofa, paintings and prints decorate the walls and the overall atmosphere is one of beauty, historic grandeur and repose.

headline: $10,000 in a Coffee Cup: 8 Swept Up in N.J. Political Corruption Cases
keywords: ['Corruption (Institutional)', 'Bribery and Kickbacks', 'Money Laundering', 'Campaign Finance', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct']

headline: ‘You’ Review: The Perfect BF Still Has One Little Problem
abstract: The dark comedy about dating, serial murder and the joys of reading, now a Netflix series, returns for a second season on a new coast.
lead_paragraph: “You,” one of television’s more addictive treats, returns for a second season on Thursday. It has moved to a different shelf of the candy store — it’s now a Netflix series, after premiering on Lifetime — but it’s as tasty, and as bad for you, as ever.

headline: ‘Just Mercy’ Review: Echoes of Jim Crow on Alabama’s Death Row
abstract: Jamie Foxx and Michael B. Jordan star in an adaptation of a memoir by the civil rights lawyer Bryan Stevenson.
lead_paragraph: Bryan Stevenson’s “Just Mercy” is a painful, beautiful, revelatory book, the kind of reading experience that can permanently alter your understanding of the world. Partly a memoir of Stevenson’s career as an activist and a lawyer specializing in death-penalty appeals, it is also a meditation on history and political morality, a clearsighted and compassionate reckoning with racism, poverty and their effects on the American criminal justice system.

headline: Marshawn Lynch Arrives to Give Seattle a Playoff Push

headline: Chuck Peddle Dies at 82; His $25 Chip Helped Start the PC Age

lead_paragraph: Chuck Peddle, the engineer and entrepreneur who helped launch the age of the personal computer after designing a microprocessor that sold for a mere $25, died on Dec. 15 at his home in Santa Cruz, Calif. He was 82.

headline: The Meaning and Melodrama of an Italian-American Christmas
abstract: Seven fishes, baby Jesus and the comfort of the familiar.
lead_paragraph: Grandma Bruni lived in a working-class neighborhood in a two-family home that I’d struggle to describe — it was that ordinary, that humble. But it was known for blocks in every direction, at least around this time of year, and not because she went wild with multicolored lights or put one of those sleigh-plus-Santa monstrosities on the roof, the way some Christmas exhibitionists did.

headline: A Final Rhapsody in Blue From Matthew Wong
abstract: A posthumous show by one of the most talented painters of his generation reveals a “visionary fusion of form and feeling,” our critic writes.
lead_paragraph: On Oct. 2, the artist Matthew Wong took his life in Edmonton, Canada, where he lived. He was 35, had Tourette’s syndrome and depression, and was one of the most talented painters of his generation.

headline: Joseph Fallek, Lawyer Who Defended Police Officers, Dies at 93
abstract: A onetime New York officer himself, he made a career of representing former colleagues accused of misconduct and corruption.
lead_paragraph: Joseph Fallek, a former New York City police officer-turned-lawyer who pursued a high-profile career defending officers accused of misconduct, died on Dec. 9 at a hospital in Roslyn, N.Y. He was 93.

headline: In Gory, Majestic Fiction, a Hard Look at the Holocaust’s Stubborn Silences
abstract: The novels of Dasa Drndic, a Croatian writer who died in 2018 at 71, are contraptions that produce panic, pity and exhilaration in her readers.
lead_paragraph: This month, Merriam-Webster named the pronoun “they” its word of the year. Runners-up included “quid pro quo,” “impeach” and, for good measure, “egregious” — as thrifty a description of 2019 as we could hope for.

headline: Japan Shrinks by 500,000 People as Births Fall to Lowest Number Since 1874
keywords: ['Population', 'Birth Rates', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: A widening gap between births and deaths has put Japan in a demographic squeeze, with fewer people to replace retiring workers and support them as they age.
lead_paragraph: Japan has 512,000 fewer people this year than last, according to an estimate released on Tuesday by the country’s welfare ministry. That’s a drop of more than the entire population of the city of Atlanta.

headline: That Goddess Quality? This Ailey Dancer’s Got It
abstract: Jacqueline Green has hit a new level this season, elevating premieres and shining in classic repertory.
lead_paragraph: Jacqueline Green was a shy 13-year-old when her mother, considering possible schools in Baltimore, observed two qualities that her daughter possessed.

headline: Christian Post Editor Resigns Over Editorial Defending Trump

abstract: Yu won the Relentless Award for “Nightwatch,” a story based on his family that he wrote as a student at the University of California, Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: Max Yu is the first to admit: He’s not very good at entering contests. (Or at winning them.)

headline: Hayden Fry, Who Made Iowa a Football Powerhouse, Dies at 90
abstract: The Hawkeyes had foundered for nearly two decades when he took over in 1979. It took him three seasons to turn the team around.
lead_paragraph: Hayden Fry, a hall of fame football coach who revived the University of Iowa’s flagging program, leading the team to three Big Ten championships and three Rose Bowls during his 20-year career there, died on Dec. 17. He was 90.

headline: Bloomberg Drops Vendor Connected to Prison Labor
abstract: Michael R. Bloomberg said that he had not been aware of the practice until he was contacted by a reporter, but that his campaign ended its relationship with the company immediately.
lead_paragraph: Michael R. Bloomberg said on Tuesday that his presidential campaign would no longer work with a vendor after learning of a subcontractor that had been involved in using prison workers to make phone calls on behalf of his candidacy.

headline: Dalton Baldwin, an Eminence Among Accompanists, Dies at 87
abstract: Often described as an equal partner to the singers he performed with, he preferred to be called simply a pianist.
lead_paragraph: Dalton Baldwin, an American pianist and recording artist who was acclaimed for nearly six decades as a recital accompanist to major singers, including Elly Ameling, Jessye Norman and especially the French baritone Gérard Souzay, died on Dec. 12 in Kunming, in the Yunnan Province of China. He was 87.

headline: Santa Hats and Tear Gas: Hong Kong Protests Flare Again
abstract: Christmas took on a new cast in a city pushing back against Beijing. Here are photographs from the scene.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Christmas Eve, ordinarily a night of revelry in Hong Kong, was filled with tear gas and pepper spray as riot police officers clashed with pro-democracy protesters who gathered at malls and shopping districts.

headline: Mexico Calls Amplified Police Presence at Bolivia Embassy a ‘Siege’
abstract: Several high-ranking officials who served with Evo Morales, the former president, have sought refuge in Mexico’s embassy in La Paz. Bolivia’s new government calls them “fugitives.”
lead_paragraph: LA PAZ, Bolivia — Amid a political crisis that has consumed the country for more than two months, the Bolivian police have stepped up their presence around the Mexican Embassy, which has given refuge to allies of the country’s former president, Evo Morales.

headline: Speaking Out on Gay Rights and Corruption Costs Ambassador His Job
abstract: Zambia’s president wanted U.S. Ambassador Daniel Foote gone after he criticized the government for corruption and for sending a gay couple to prison.
lead_paragraph: The United States recalled its ambassador to Zambia on Monday after he criticized the government for sending a gay couple to prison and accused officials of stealing millions of dollars of public funds.

headline: Dellin Betances Joins the Mets on a One-Year Deal
abstract: Betances, who had spent his entire career with the Yankees, is a four-time All-Star but appeared in just one game last season because of injuries.
lead_paragraph: After eight seasons with the Yankees, Dellin Betances is not leaving New York — but he is not returning to the Bronx, either. The Mets on Tuesday signed Betances, a four-time All-Star who had become a free agent, to a one-year deal to bolster a bullpen that woefully underperformed in 2019.

headline: Pentagon Warns Military Personnel Against At-Home DNA Tests
keywords: ['Genetics and Heredity', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid)', 'Discrimination', 'Tests (Medical)']
abstract: The tests, from companies such as 23andMe and Ancestry, have become popular holiday gifts, but the military is warning service members of risks to their careers.
lead_paragraph: In an internal memo, Pentagon leadership has urged military personnel not to take mail-in DNA tests, warning that they create security risks, are unreliable and could negatively affect service members’ careers.

headline: Is This Frog a Hate Symbol or Not?
keywords: ['Social Media', 'Discrimination', 'Computers and the Internet', 'ANTI-SEMITISM', 'Hong Kong Protests (2019)', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: Pepe, Gaysper and other symbols teach us that tech companies need policies that adapt to a changing world.
lead_paragraph: The idea that platforms like Twitter, Facebook and Instagram should remove hate speech is relatively uncontroversial. But doing this isn’t easy. Hate speech is fluid, dependent on cultural context and social meaning. To manage it, platforms must constantly re-evaluate hateful symbols and communicate with users about their decision-making.

headline: Children’s Aid Helped a Young Ghanaian Woman Get to College
abstract: Karen Mills, who came to New York at 13, found a support network through piano lessons.
lead_paragraph: When Karen Mills first met her father, she was 13 and getting off a plane in New York, her first time in America. He came to pick her up at the airport, but she realized right away that he couldn’t see her. He suffered from severe glaucoma. In all the years of their long-distance phone calls, he’d never told her that he was blind.

headline: Nigeria Releases Leading Critic on Bail After a Campaign an Ocean Away
abstract: Omoyele Sowore, a publisher and ex-presidential candidate, was released after months in detention. His New Jersey neighbors had led the effort to free him.
lead_paragraph: A Nigerian publisher and former presidential candidate was released on bail on Tuesday after a monthslong imprisonment that heightened fears of deteriorating protections for free expression in Africa’s most populous nation.

headline: Michigan Attorney General Clarifies Status of Nassar Inquiry, Saying It’s at an Impasse
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Attorneys General', 'Gymnastics', 'Sex Crimes', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Although an inquiry into Michigan State University’s handling of the sexual abuse scandal has stalled over records and other evidence, the attorney general’s office said it had not been suspended.
lead_paragraph: A yearslong criminal investigation that ensnared Michigan State University’s former president over her role in the Larry Nassar sexual abuse scandal, as well as a onetime dean and an ex-gymnastics coach, is at an impasse as prosecutors and the university clash over the release of documents, the state attorney general said on Wednesday.

headline: Iraq’s New Election Law Draws Much Criticism and Few Cheers
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Elections', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'Legislatures and Parliaments']
abstract: Iraq’s Parliament voted to overhaul the country’s election laws in a bid to reduce the power of political parties. But many protesters, who had called for just such a change, were not impressed.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — The Iraqi Parliament made good on its promise to overhaul the country’s election laws, voting on Tuesday to make sweeping changes in how lawmakers are elected, seemingly in response to demands from protesters to give citizens a greater voice.

abstract: Time to focus.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Smarter Living newsletter! Every Monday, S.L. editor Tim Herrera emails readers with tips and advice for living a better, more fulfilling life. Sign up here to get it in your inbox.

headline: What Santa Said
abstract: Bruce Haight dishes on the man in the sleigh.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — If you think you’re exhausted after celebrating Christmas, think about how Santa Claus must feel.

headline: What’s on TV Wednesday: ‘Togo’ and ‘The Witcher’
abstract: Willem Dafoe stars in an adventure movie on Disney Plus. And a PBS program looks at Christmastime in Tudor England.
lead_paragraph: TOGO (2019) Stream on Disney Plus. Willem Dafoe throws on a fur coat and hat and takes to the snow-covered mountains in this adventure film, which has skipped theaters in favor of a debut on Disney’s new streaming service. The movie is based on the 1925 serum run, during which antitoxins were transported hundreds of miles by dog sled to fight a deadly disease outbreak in Nome, Alaska — in the middle of a brutal winter storm. It’s often associated with Balto, the dog that completed the run (and got a 1990s big-screen animated feature out of the deal). The new movie focuses on a different dog, Togo, and his trainer and musher (played by Dafoe). The story creates drama from a classic combination of heroism and harsh conditions. “It’s going to be bad,” Dafoe’s character says early in the film, sizing up the coming storm. How bad? “Memorable, I think.”

headline: Christmas Eve Wildfire in Chile Destroys Dozens of Homes
abstract: Firefighters struggled to control the blaze on a hillside in Valparaíso. The city’s mayor said the fire might have been set intentionally.
lead_paragraph: SANTIAGO, Chile — A wildfire raged through a residential area on the outskirts of the Chilean city of Valparaíso, prompting evacuation orders and destroying more than 200 homes by Wednesday, Chile’s interior minister said.

headline: Serge Ibaka Still Can’t Believe He’s a Champion Now
abstract: The Toronto Raptors star returned home to the Republic of Congo this summer, as always. But this time he did so with a trophy.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — When Serge Ibaka, made his annual summer trip home to the Republic of Congo, his itinerary was similar to his previous visits. He spent time with family members and close friends. He held basketball clinics for local youths, part of the charitable arm of his Serge Ibaka Foundation.

lead_paragraph: A brief kiss between two female characters was removed from screenings of “Star Wars: The Rise of Skywalker” in Singapore, a country with restrictive laws against gay people.

headline: Japanese Lawmaker Is Arrested in Casino Bribery Investigation
abstract: Tsukasa Akimoto, a member of the governing party, is suspected of accepting cash from a company that wanted to build a casino on the island of Hokkaido.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — A member of Japan’s Parliament was arrested Wednesday on suspicion of taking bribes from a company that wanted to build one of the first casinos in Japan, which legalized them just three years ago.

headline: In a Collection of ‘Peanuts’ Tributes, the Gang Is All Here
abstract: “The Peanuts Papers” brings together George Saunders, Ann Patchett, Chris Ware and others to celebrate and analyze Charlie Brown, Snoopy, Linus, Lucy and the rest.
lead_paragraph: “I don’t remember ever thinking they were funny,” Ira Glass writes in a new anthology of writing about the quintessential American comic strip. “Who ever laughed at ‘Peanuts’?”

headline: Killer Slime, Dead Birds, an Expunged Map: The Dirty Secrets of European Farm Subsidies

lead_paragraph: The E.U. has green aspirations. Its signature, $65 billion policy says otherwise.

headline: Taking an Uber? 9 Tips to Ride Safely
keywords: ['Car Services and Livery Cabs', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Mobile Applications', 'Emergency Telephone Numbers', 'Sex Crimes']
abstract: Both Uber and Lyft post advice on their websites and also offer safety features in their apps, but here are a few more suggestions from experts to stay safe while in a ride share.
lead_paragraph: Uber recently revealed that more than 3,000 incidents of sexual assault were reported last year in its vehicles in the United States. While that number represents a small fraction of its total rides, it’s still a scary possibility to customers who want to safely use the service. Both Uber and Lyft, the other leading ride-hailing company, post advice for staying safe in a ride share on their websites, and also offer safety features that allow passengers and drivers to share their location and call 911. New ride-hailing services like Safr are focusing on serving female drivers and female passengers.

headline: A Decade of Fitness
abstract: Dogs and high-intensity exercise in. Barefoot running out.
lead_paragraph: For the past 10 years (and change), I have been covering exercise science in this column. During that time, I have seen interest in high-intensity exercise soar and enthusiasm for barefoot running fizzle. We have learned contracting muscles talk to baby neurons, creativity blooms from walking, a minute of exertion can be ample, aging is elastic and a chubby dog may be our best exercise motivator.

headline: ‘1917’ Isn’t the First (Supposedly) One-Shot Film. Here’s a Timeline.
abstract: Filmmakers have been vying for decades to come up with loooong takes that tell tales great and small.

lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: Nail Clippers, a Parking Meter and a River Barge: This Is N.Y.C.’s Yard Sale
abstract: When the nation’s largest city cleans out its closets, it takes a massive year-round operation, including public auctions, to get rid of it.
lead_paragraph: Think of it as quite possibly the world’s biggest yard sale.

headline: On the Streets of Midtown Manhattan
abstract: The neighborhood is filled with office workers and tourists but in recent years has also become more residential.
lead_paragraph: The neighborhood is filled with office workers and tourists but in recent years has also become more residential.

lead_paragraph: “Where was this product made?”

headline: Midtown South, Manhattan: A Commercial Neighborhood Sees an Influx of Residents
abstract: The area is filled with office workers and tourists, but it’s also becoming more popular with buyers and renters.
lead_paragraph: Marta Wöhrle and her husband, Pascal Volle, were relocating to New York from London in 2001 and mostly looking in Chelsea when they came upon a two-level, “very affordable” apartment that was just what they needed. However, she said, “It was in a strange location,” tucked away on an almost-entirely industrial side street two blocks from Pennsylvania Station.

headline: Saudi Arabia Wants Your Next Vacation
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: The oil-rich kingdom is betting on tourism to broaden its economy, but will visitors come?
lead_paragraph: AL-UYAYNAH, Saudi Arabia — In a makeshift camp under a starry sky, Ghazi Al-Anazi talked about his experience in the fledgling Saudi tourist business. A decade ago, barely in his 20s, he started taking British business associates of his brother to see the wind-carved hills of the Saudi desert.

headline: Crisis Looms in Antibiotics as Drug Makers Go Bankrupt
abstract: First Big Pharma fled the field, and now start-ups are going belly up, threatening to stifle the development of new drugs.
lead_paragraph: At a time when germs are growing more resistant to common antibiotics, many companies that are developing new versions of the drugs are hemorrhaging money and going out of business, gravely undermining efforts to contain the spread of deadly, drug-resistant bacteria.

headline: My Very Marry Christmas
abstract: Why do we love getting engaged around the holidays?
lead_paragraph: I awoke with a stabbing pain in my heart. For a moment I did not know where I was. Then I remembered: I was back in the room I’d grown up in, at my mother’s house in Pennsylvania. It was Christmas morning, 1987. The house was quiet, except for the hissing and clanking of its old steam radiators.

headline: A Century Ago, the Modern Middle East Was Born
abstract: At the end of 1919, Woodrow Wilson still wanted the region to decide its future. Britain and France had other ideas.
lead_paragraph: As 1919 came to a close, people around the world were celebrating the holidays, grateful for the return of peace on earth after the convulsions of the Great War. “Peace on earth” was a relative concept; there was still fighting in Russia. But for the most part, the soldiers were home, and their families were looking forward to a new decade, free of conflict.

headline: The Forgotten Story of Christmas 1918
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Christmas', 'Civilian Casualties', 'World War I (1914-18)']
abstract: We remember the 1914 Christmas Truce as a moment of humanity amid war. Four years later, a darker tale unfolded.
lead_paragraph: It’s a famous tale, and largely a true one: On Christmas 1914, five months into the First World War, groups of German and British troops along the Belgian and French border put down their weapons of war and held unofficial cease-fires. Men sang Christmas carols across the trenches on Christmas Eve, and on Christmas Day, some were brave enough to rise out of their trenches and walk into no man’s land to meet their enemies in person.

headline: The Decade Parents Couldn’t Win
abstract: 90 percent of American moms and 85 percent of American dads feel judged.
lead_paragraph: As the decade draws to a close, NYT Parenting is reflecting on the experience of American parenthood in the 2010s. I have been turning it over in my head and, for me, this decade in parenting is embodied in a single indelible image: a parent awake in the middle of the night, pinched face illuminated by the glow of her phone, flagellating herself with the judgment of other moms and dads.

headline: Pope Francis, in Christmas Speech, Urges Nations to Tend to Refugees
keywords: ['Speeches and Statements', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Freedom of Religion']
abstract: In his traditional holiday benediction, Francis renewed his call to resolve conflicts and to help those who have fled them.
lead_paragraph: ROME — As Christians around the world celebrated Christmas, Pope Francis called on Wednesday for a softening of “stony and self-centered hearts,” once again directing the world’s attention to the plight of migrants and people living in areas plagued by conflict, social and political upheaval, injustice, or natural disasters.

headline: Merry Christmas
abstract: And happy ma la!
lead_paragraph: This article is part of David Leonhardt’s newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it each weekday.

headline: ‘One Cut of the Dead’ Review: A Fresh Take on the Zombie Flick
abstract: A one-take movie stunt is justified in the Japanese director Shinichiro Ueda’s fast and furious backstage comedy.
lead_paragraph: The crew of a low-budget zombie flick is getting antsy: They’re shooting at an abandoned water plant that once hosted military experiments, and the spooky location is a little too on the nose. Lo and behold, real zombies pop up and chomp their way through cast and technicians. Suddenly, the fake blood turns real.

headline: Get Those Records, Tapes and CDs Onto Your Smartphone
keywords: ['Music', 'Audio Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Digital Audio Players', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Smartphones']
abstract: Ready to convert your older analog audio to more portable digital formats? Here’s how to make it happen.
lead_paragraph: A huge amount of the world’s audio has been digitized, but many veterans of the Analog Age still have out-of-print albums, lectures and other content locked on vinyl records, cassettes and CDs. Converting the audio to digital formats for personal use is much simpler than it used to be, though, thanks in part to gadgets that connect to a computer’s USB port.

headline: What You Get for $799,000
abstract: An 1880 brick rowhouse in Baltimore, a modern townhouse in Houston and a 1985 ranch house in Sarasota, Fla.
lead_paragraph: An 1880 brick rowhouse in Baltimore, a modern townhouse in Houston and a 1985 ranch house in Sarasota, Fla.

headline: $799,000 Homes in Maryland, Texas and Florida
abstract: An 1880 brick rowhouse in Baltimore, a modern townhouse in Houston and a 1985 ranch house in Sarasota, Fla.
lead_paragraph: This four-story building is in the historic downtown Bolton Hill neighborhood, facing a narrow two-block-long park with a fountain. It is less than a mile northwest of the Amtrak train station and a mile southeast of the 745-acre Druid Hill Park, which has a zoo, reservoir, community pool and farmer’s market. Maryland Institute College of Art is a half-mile east, and the Johns Hopkins University medical campus is two miles southeast. It is also near the Joseph Meyerhoff Symphony Hall, the Patricia & Arthur Modell Performing Arts Center at the Lyric and the University of Baltimore.

headline: House Hunting in India: Portuguese Influence Survives on the Coast
abstract: Tourists from home and abroad have long flocked to the coastal state of Goa, where the market is currently rising as a result of restrictions on foreign buyers.
lead_paragraph: This three-bedroom, Portuguese-style villa is in Goa, a small, tourist-friendly state in southwestern India known for its colorful architecture, historic houses of worship and white-sand beaches on the Arabian Sea.

headline: Lashes, Lashes, Lashes: What It Took to Give the ‘Bombshell’ Women the Fox Look
keywords: ['Movies', 'Prostheses', 'Cosmetics and Toiletries', 'News and News Media', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations']
abstract: The makeup artists behind the film used prosthetics, base color, eyeliner, pounds of lash glue and lots of lip gloss to get the Fox look.
lead_paragraph: They were Roger’s angels. Megyn Kelly, Gretchen Carlson and the other women at Fox all had a specific look that was intended to please him. New York Magazine once described it as “pert noses, bronze skin, blonde hair”; they showed lots of leg, were almost always white and, in the end, appeared “conspicuously unnatural.”

headline: Allee Willis, 72, Dies; ‘Friends’ Theme and ‘September’ Songwriter
abstract: She also wrote or co-wrote “Neutron Dance” for the Pointer Sisters, “What Have I Done to Deserve This?” for the Pet Shop Boys and Dusty Springfield, and other hits.
lead_paragraph: Allee Willis, one of the music industry’s most colorful figures, whose eclectic credits as a writer and co-writer included Earth, Wind & Fire’s “September” and the “Friends” theme song, died on Tuesday at a hospital in Los Angeles. She was 72.

headline: 3 Family Members Drown in Swimming Pool Accident in Spain
abstract: A father and his 9-year-old daughter, both British, and another relative, an American teenager, died after getting trapped at a resort near Malaga. A faulty drainage pump was suspected.
lead_paragraph: Three members of a family vacationing in southern Spain drowned after becoming trapped in a swimming pool, prompting an investigation into a potential malfunction with a drainage mechanism that may have sucked them underwater, the authorities said on Wednesday.

headline: Merry Christmas
abstract: Make the holiday even brighter with waffles, pancakes and some mulled wine.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Merry Christmas even if all that means to you is that the streets are empty and you got to work in record time. Go see “Little Women” in the afternoon and hit up the Chinese restaurant after: beef and broccoli, moo shu pork, dumplings, green beans with ginger and garlic. Ho ho ho!

headline: ‘We’d Prefer the Food’: Zimbabwe Fears a Famine Is in Its Future
abstract: Government dysfunction, an economic meltdown, drought and a calamitous flood have plunged Zimbabwe into a hunger crisis.
lead_paragraph: HARARE, Zimbabwe — The people lined up early for a chance to buy subsidized maize meal from the government-run Grain Marketing Board depot in Harare, at prices they could afford. After three hours, a guard emerged to announce that the depot’s supply was rotten so there would be none for sale that day.

lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: From Homelessness to a Life of Giving Back
abstract: Rosella Tedesco left the shelter system thanks in part to a support program. Now she raises awareness and helps others find hope.
lead_paragraph: Rosella Tedesco is one of millions of Americans whose life was upended by the Great Recession.

headline: G.O.P. Senator ‘Disturbed’ by McConnell’s ‘Total Coordination’ with White House
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Impeachment', 'Trump-Ukraine Whistle-blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry']
abstract: Senator Lisa Murkowski of Alaska revealed the first public qualms with Mitch McConnell’s vow to coordinate with the White House on a quick impeachment trial for President Trump.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Lisa Murkowski of Alaska expressed unease in an interview broadcast on Tuesday with the Senate majority leader’s vow of “total coordination” with the White House on impeachment proceedings against President Trump, a potentially significant crack in Republican unity.

headline: Paying Too Much for That College Textbook
abstract: Publishers, an author and a student offer their perspectives.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: ‘Clemency’ Review: No Place for Mercy
abstract: A tremendous Alfre Woodard plays a warden at a prison whose world is upended by the fate of death-row inmates.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes acting seems like possession. That’s how Alfre Woodard’s performance in “Clemency” feels as she violently sweeps you up with the force of her talent. It takes a while before you grasp how deep she’s gone. As Bernadine Williams, a warden at a men’s prison, Woodard enters with a stealthy lack of showiness. She’s playing the very model of a dispassionate overlord whether Bernadine is managing employees or asking a death-row inmate about his last meal, giving everyone the same exacting courtesy even if that semblance of composure has started to quietly crumble.

headline: Black Rhino Born at Michigan Zoo on Christmas Eve
abstract: Doppsee, a 12-year-old black rhino, gave birth to her first calf, a rare delivery in captivity for the critically endangered species.
lead_paragraph: Doppsee, a 12-year-old black rhino, presented a Michigan zoo and conservationists with an early holiday gift on Christmas Eve, delivering a newborn calf in a rare zoo birth for the endangered species.

headline: Not Just Propaganda: A New View of Soviet Artists
abstract: An exhibition in St. Petersburg, Russia, takes a fresh look at two painters whose works were once dismissed as instruments of state control.
lead_paragraph: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia — Figures stare boldly from the canvas, exuding youth and health. Athletes conquer their opponents, factory workers strive proudly for excellence, and soldiers stride off to war, confident of victory.

headline: The Best Bras Might Be Made in Poland
abstract: A reporter’s pilgrimage to the land of meticulous sizing and pretty embroidery.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, I stumbled upon the subreddit ABraThatFits, where people share their struggle to find a bra and pass along what they have learned. While scrolling through the forum, I often came across a specific piece of advice: go Polish.

headline: Traffic Circles Are Everywhere in France. Not Everyone Is Happy.
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Roads and Traffic', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Politics and Government', 'Yellow Vests Movement']
abstract: Traffic circles are ubiquitous in France, accepted as safer than traditional intersections. But they have also become an emblem of the country’s ailments, from urban sprawl to inequality.
lead_paragraph: ABBEVILLE, France — Every day, about 65,000 vehicles cruise through the center of Abbeville, passing by its Gothic church, City Hall and rows of red brick houses, with many drivers on their way to the English Channel about a dozen miles away.

headline: Pop Music in 2019: An Escape From Isolation?
keywords: ['Rap and Hip-Hop', 'Pop and Rock Music', 'Two Thousand Nineteen']
abstract: Over the last decade, pop’s sonic spaces grew isolated and claustrophobic. But this year the pendulum started to swing back toward solidarity, and even a glimpse of optimism.
lead_paragraph: Music conjures spaces: churches, theaters, roadhouses, arenas, pubs, dance halls, living rooms, festival tents, and all sorts of clubs, from tenement basements to cabarets to giant warehouses. Those are social spaces, where musicians perform together and audiences gather to share the sounds — and to flirt, dance, get high, sing along. To somehow connect.

headline: Your Morning Briefing: Standouts
abstract: Highlights from a year in Briefings world
lead_paragraph: One of our goals is to get you up to speed quickly, recapping the biggest headlines and offering a look ahead to the major stories that we’re covering that day.

headline: 30 Prosecutors Say Lamar Johnson Deserves a New Trial. Why Won’t He Get One?
keywords: ['Criminal Justice', 'False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', 'District Attorneys']
abstract: Prosecutors nationwide say there is evidence of innocence for Lamar Johnson, who was convicted of murder. But Missouri’s attorney general said a new trial would violate state law.
lead_paragraph: More than 30 elected prosecutors around the country have signed legal papers supporting a new trial for a Missouri man who has been in prison since his 1995 conviction for first-degree murder.

headline: Think Alexa Is Too Creepy For Your Kitchen? Don’t Give It to Aunty Mary.
keywords: ['Privacy', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Christmas', 'Smartphones', 'Home Automation and Smart Homes']
abstract: As 2019 comes to a close, millions of new spying devices are headed for American homes.
lead_paragraph: The grass-roots surveillance network in the United States is poised for yet another major expansion this Christmas season. Think of each new Ring video doorbell, discount DNA test, WiFi-equipped clothes dryer, smart speaker and mobile phone as a new node on the world’s most advanced and pervasive effort at human monitoring. All that data is collected by someone, somewhere.

headline: Her Children Found Her Body. Now a Parolee Is Accused of Murder.
abstract: Luz Perez, whose 5-year-old son and 2-year-old daughter found her dead on her bedroom floor, was strangled, officials said.
lead_paragraph: A 5-year-old boy was at the window of his Bronx apartment, screaming frantically for help. He and his 2-year-old sister had been alone in the apartment for hours after finding their mother lifeless on the bedroom floor.

headline: For Trump Organization, Office Skyscrapers Make Up for Lagging Hotels
abstract: Office towers in New York and San Francisco — centers of political resistance — are offsetting revenue downturns in the president’s glitzier Trump-branded hotels.
lead_paragraph: DORAL, Fla. — It is happy hour at Trump National Doral Miami, the sprawling resort that is the biggest cash generator in President Trump’s business portfolio. But on a weekday evening in November, only a few sprinklings of patrons grace the resort’s bar and high-end steak house. Tables with lit candles sit empty through the night.

headline: The ‘But I Would Vote for Joe Biden’ Republicans
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Voting and Voters', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: For some Democrats, a key part of the former vice president’s pitch is that their moderate friends and relatives like him, too.
lead_paragraph: CRESTON, Iowa — The voters at campaign events for Joseph R. Biden Jr. here in Iowa and across the country aren’t just shopping for a candidate for themselves.

headline: Joseph Segel, Founder of the QVC Shopping Network, Dies at 88
abstract: The chief executive of QVC’s parent company said it “changed the way the world shops.” Mr. Segel’s many other ventures included the Franklin Mint.
lead_paragraph: Back in the Dark Ages — before the internet, before Amazon — there were other ways to satisfy your craving for impulse buying from the comfort of your home.

headline: Edward Aschoff, ESPN College Football Reporter, Dies at 34
abstract: Mr. Aschoff had contracted pneumonia, according to his social media posts, and died after a “brief illness,” the network reported.
lead_paragraph: Edward Aschoff, an ESPN college football reporter known for his lively blog posts and thoughtfully reported features, died on Tuesday after a brief illness, the network reported. It was his 34th birthday.

headline: Why Stephen Curry (Not LeBron) Is the N.B.A. Player of the Decade
abstract: It had to be one or the other. But as great as LeBron James has been, Curry had the edge in one major way: He changed the game.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times is reflecting on the past decade in the N.B.A., which has evolved perhaps more than any other major sports league.

headline: Did de Blasio Put Politics Ahead of Yeshiva Students?
abstract: New York City stalled the release of a report critical of the schools as the mayor sought the political support of Orthodox Jewish leaders, city investigators found.
lead_paragraph: Four and a half years ago, Mayor Bill de Blasio’s administration received a complaint that thousands of children at Orthodox Jewish yeshivas across New York City were being denied a basic education, including instruction in reading and writing English.

headline: He Vowed to Revitalize Italy’s Schools. After a Budget Loss, He’s Out.
abstract: Education Minister Lorenzo Fioramonti promised to raise performance and introduce lessons on climate change, but Parliament’s budget left him a billion euros short.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Italy’s education minister, who had vowed to revitalize the country’s schools and introduce lessons on climate change in every grade nationwide, has resigned, citing a lack of funding.

headline: No Corrections: Dec. 26, 2019
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Thursday, Dec. 26, 2019.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Saudis Bet on New Commodity: Tourism
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, December 26, 2019.
lead_paragraph: “This planet is running out of places to go.”

headline: Often Played by Ice Cream Trucks
abstract: Trenton Charlson scores with this Thursday puzzle.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY PUZZLE — This kind of theme, as fun as it is, has a tendency to bamboozle online solvers, mainly because it’s hard to tell whether it’s a rebus.

headline: Your Morning Briefing: Standouts
abstract: Highlights from a year in Briefings world
lead_paragraph: One of our goals is to get you up to speed quickly, recapping the biggest headlines and offering a look ahead to the major stories that we’re covering that day.

headline: What’s on TV Thursday: ‘You’ and ‘Girlhood’
abstract: The soapy serial-killer series “You” returns on Netflix. And Céline Sciamma’s “Girlhood” is streaming on Criterion Channel.
lead_paragraph: YOU Stream on Netflix. “Love has taken me to dark places,” the charming serial killer Joe Goldberg (Penn Badgley) says early in the new season of this series. “But Los Angeles has got to be as dark as it gets.” Originally a Lifetime series, “You” picked up steam near the beginning of the year after its first season became available on Netflix. That season played something like “Dexter” crossed with a soap opera: It followed Joe, a killer, as he pursued a romantic obsession in New York City (the relationship didn’t pan out). The new, second season moves the action to the West Coast. It gives Joe a job at a gourmet market and a fresh fixation: a co-worker played by Victoria Pedretti. “The new location allows the showrunner, Sera Gamble, and her staff to add Southern California stereotypes to the generational and class formulas that draw Joe’s scorn,” Mike Hale wrote in his review of the second season for The New York Times, “and to throw the Hollywood melodrama into the genre blender along with the rom-com.” He called the show “one of television’s more addictive treats.”

headline: A Country Where Driving Makes You a Target
abstract: Afghanistan’s highways are prime killing fields, with travelers dying in roadside bombings, ambushes and airstrikes.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — After Shir Mohammad Panjshiri shoveled a final spadeful of dirt onto his brother’s grave, he left the cemetery burdened with questions.

headline: The Whistle-Blowers Next Door
abstract: Yuliya Stepanova and her husband, Vitaly, fled Russia with their son and a secret. Now they live a quiet life in America while the doping scandal they disclosed rages on.
lead_paragraph: The boy and his parents blended in.

headline: Behind a U.A.W. Crisis: Lavish Meals and Luxury Villas
abstract: A federal investigation has led to accusations that union leaders diverted funds to perks like a $6,500 steak dinner and golf outings and gear costing $80,000.
lead_paragraph: On a single day in December 2015, Gary Jones, who resigned last month as president of the United Automobile Workers, spent more than $13,000 of the union’s money at a cigar store in Arizona. His purchases included a dozen $268 boxes of Ashton Double Magnums and a dozen boxes of Ashton Monarchs at $274.50 each. “Hi Gary, Thank you & Happy New Year,” read a handwritten note from the store.

headline: Where Rent Is $13,500, She Lives Off What’s Left at the Curb
keywords: ['Recycling of Waste Materials', 'Income Inequality', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Freelancing, Self-Employment and Independent Contracting', 'Plastic Bottles', 'Aluminum', 'Waste Materials and Disposal']
abstract: Canners and trucks converge in a shadow economy of the streets.
lead_paragraph: At 3 o’clock one recent Friday afternoon on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, three blocks from the mayor’s residence at Gracie Mansion, a woman named Rosa approached an elegant prewar building where apartments rent for $13,500 per month.

headline: Christmas Typhoon Batters Central Philippines
abstract: Thousands traveling home for the holiday were stranded as flights and ferries were canceled. At least 16 deaths were reported.
lead_paragraph: Typhoon Phanfone ravaged three provinces in the central Philippines over the Christmas holiday, with at least 16 people reported to have been killed.

headline: Sex Sells. It’s True Now and It Was True 100 Years Ago.
abstract: In 1920, a publisher told The Times, “It is my firm conviction that any book that deals sincerely with real life, that is a first-rate book, is bound to succeed.”
lead_paragraph: BLAST FROM THE PAST We don’t have a crystal ball so we can’t look into the future to see what will be on the best-seller list in 2020. What we do have at the Book Review is the ability to look back — either in our library of bound issues dating back to 1930 or in TimesPast, a handy digital tool that takes us back to the eras when O. Henry was carousing at Pete’s Tavern and Dorothy Parker was holding court at the Algonquin.

headline: The Turkish Novelist Elif Shafak Wants You to Read More Women
abstract: “Read women writers, women journalists, women poets, women academics.”
lead_paragraph: “Read women writers, women journalists, women poets, women academics,” says Shafak, whose novel “10 Minutes 38 Seconds in This Strange World” was a finalist for the 2019 Booker Prize. “And when I say women, I mean women of all ethnic and cultural backgrounds.”

headline: How to Communicate Better With Your Children in the New Year
abstract: Be a sportscaster. Make a glitter jar. Get a pet. Whether or not you rely on strategies like these, the central advice is to listen more.
lead_paragraph: Often, the central message in experts’ advice to parents is find ways to pay attention to what is going on in your kids’ lives, to be present with them and to listen.

headline: Living as Myself, at Last
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Transgender and Transsexuals']
abstract: This airman could not be Alexandria Holder and still serve. Then came a change in regulations — and in Technical Sergeant Holder’s life.
lead_paragraph: “I don’t believe that transgender people should be in the military.” In 2015, when I heard those words from my supervisor, I was a young technical sergeant in the United States Air Force, and a closeted transgender person. My boss, a master sergeant, went on to explain to me and a couple of other airmen in the office that transgender people had too many problems, that they had mental health issues, that there were too many logistical problems with dorms and open-bay showers and not being deployable.

headline: Three New Books Will Take You to Places You’ve Never Gone Before
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Ships and Shipping', 'Sewers and Sewage', 'Exploration and Explorers']
abstract: From the high seas to the deepest sewers to the South Pole, these books let you live vicariously through the world’s most intrepid explorers.
lead_paragraph: THE SEA JOURNALSeafarer’s SketchbooksBy Huw Lewis-JonesIllustrated. 304 pp. Chronicle. $40.

headline: The Watch Is Smart, but It Can’t Replace Your Doctor
abstract: Apple has been advertising its watch’s ability to detect atrial fibrillation. The reality doesn’t quite live up to the promise.
lead_paragraph: The Apple Watch has been quite successful as a smart watch. The company would also like it to succeed as a medical device. The recently published results of the Apple Heart Study in the New England Journal of Medicine show there’s still a long way to go.

headline: They Wanted a Two-Bedroom on the Upper West Side, but How Many Stairs Are Too Many?
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)']
abstract: Two college friends combine their budgets to find a rental in their favorite New York neighborhood. Which of these options would you choose?
lead_paragraph: Two college friends combine their budgets to find a rental in their favorite New York neighborhood. Which of these options would you choose?

keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Conservatism (US Politics)', 'Liberalism (US Politics)', 'New Year', 'Global Warming', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: And resolutions for the coming election year.

headline: They Said #MeToo. Now They Are Being Sued.
keywords: ['Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Libel and Slander', '#MeToo Movement', 'Sexual Harassment', 'Sex Crimes', "Women's Rights"]
abstract: A growing number of men in China are using defamation lawsuits to counter claims of sexual harassment. Women are thinking twice about speaking out.
lead_paragraph: In a small courtroom in Beijing, supporters of Wang Qi huddled together, awaiting the start of China’s first #MeToo trial. Ms. Wang had accused her former boss of sexually harassing her.

headline: Why Is New York City’s Skyline Always Lit Up?
abstract: The lights are dazzling. But there are several other practical reasons that they stay on all night long.
lead_paragraph: Manhattan’s glittering skyline makes Aja Corliss feel proud to live in New York City, and its soaring buildings represent her ambition to move upward in life.

headline: Is a 63-Year-Old Seaplane With an Electric Engine the Future of Air Travel?
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Electric and Hybrid Vehicles', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: This month, a Vancouver-based airline tested a vintage plane retrofitted with a battery-powered engine. The goal is an all-electric fleet, the first in the world.
lead_paragraph: When Harbour Air’s de Havilland Beaver seaplane first lumbered into the skies in 1956, Elvis’s “Heartbreak Hotel” topped the charts, President Dwight D. Eisenhower was in the White House, and flying icons like the Boeing 747 hadn’t yet been invented.

headline: How The Learning Network Transforms Classrooms Across America
abstract: Meet the team dedicated to helping schools and students teach and learn with The Times, using the news of the day to create a safe and welcoming space to develop critical-thinking skills.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: Scrunchies for Your Crush
abstract: This was the 2019 equivalent of getting pinned.
lead_paragraph: Here’s the news from winter break: Scrunchies have become a desired item for junior-high schoolboys.

headline: 36 Hours in Recife (and Environs)
abstract: A different kind of Brazil is waiting in the country’s lively northeast corner, where musical, culinary and architectural marvels await.
lead_paragraph: Many people visiting Brazil make a beeline for the beaches of Rio de Janeiro. In doing so, they fly over Brazil’s fourth largest city, and one of the most culturally fascinating regions in the country. Recife and the northeastern corner of Brazil are a world apart from Rio, São Paulo and the rest of southern Brazil. The climate is hotter, and much of the food and music can only be authentically consumed in the region itself. It is also a hub of Brazilian political agitation (the northeast, of which Recife is a de facto capital, was the only region to vote against the right-wing president, Jair Bolsonaro, in the last election). Visitors today will find a city that seems at first glance unlovable: One of the most famous songs about the city — and an example of a Recife music genre called manguebeat, or mangrove beat — is called “Rivers, Bridges and Overpasses” (“Rios, Pontes e Overdrives”), and that’s what Recife’s center looks like, to a large extent. But farther south are the teal waters of Boa Viagem beach, and north is the charmingly colorful pocket community of Olinda. Just a few days in the area will have visitors appreciating a different kind of Brazil.

headline: The Year Women Over 50 Reclaimed Their Right to Be Seen
abstract: Rather than ignore such characters as the film industry has often done in the past, mainstream and indie directors alike explored their lives, and sometimes the results were astonishing.
lead_paragraph: The actress Patricia Arquette began her Emmy acceptance speech in September this way: “I am grateful at 50 to be getting the best parts of my life.”

headline: A Barrier to Trump’s Border Wall: Landowners in Texas
keywords: ['Border Barriers', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Land Use Policies', 'Eminent Domain', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Construction of President Trump’s border wall has been slow going, in part because the Texans who own the land have to be coaxed or coerced to sell it, whether they want to or not.
lead_paragraph: PROGRESO, Texas — Two days after giving the federal government his signature, Richard Drawe paused with his wife and mother on a levee that his family has owned for nearly a century to watch the cranes and roseate spoonbills.

headline: How Cruise Ships Bring 1,200 Tons of Toxic Fumes to Brooklyn a Year
abstract: Many ports — all along the coast of California, in parts of Europe, even in China — have found a solution to idling luxury liners. In New York, they’re still a problem.
lead_paragraph: On a chilly fall morning in Red Hook, Brooklyn, the Queen Mary 2, the luxury liner known for its opulent black-tie dinners and ballroom dances, docked under blue skies while a fleet of 50 or so taxis jostled for position on the wharf.

headline: ‘Everyday Supercar’: A New Corvette Puts a Target on Ferrari’s Back
abstract: The $60,000 Stingray pushes its engine to the middle and expectations through the roof.
lead_paragraph: From its dream-car debut in 1953 at the Motorama show at the Waldorf-Astoria hotel, the Chevrolet Corvette has kept its engine up front, where sports-car tradition says it belongs.

headline: ‘They’re My Safe Place’: Children of Addicted Parents, Raised by Relatives
keywords: ['Foster Care', 'Children and Childhood', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Addiction (Psychology)', 'Opioids and Opiates', 'Families and Family Life']
abstract: Nearly 27,000 children in Ohio were removed from their homes last year, many because of the opioid crisis. More than a quarter were placed in the care of relatives.
lead_paragraph: PORTSMOUTH, Ohio — Hannah Thurman’s new life began with her father’s murder.

headline: Nicaragua Has a Simple Message for Protesters: Don’t
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Hunger Strikes', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Political Prisoners']
abstract: For nearly two years, Nicaraguans have been rising up against their government. It has cost some dearly.
lead_paragraph: MASAYA, Nicaragua — Diana Lacayo never imagined that a hunger strike held in a church would turn into a nine-day siege, with the police outside and the electricity and water cut off inside.

headline: Our Favorite Arts Photos of 2019
abstract: Phoebe Waller-Bridge. DaBaby. Slime. Tom Hanks. Amy Schumer (naked). The Times’s culture photographs revealed striking truths about art and the people who make it.
lead_paragraph: The jittery energy backstage at a Broadway theater 30 minutes before showtime, or in the seconds before the curtain rises at the Metropolitan Opera. Björk and Erykah Badu in all their regalia, and the happily-ever-after Swiss life of Tina Turner in retirement, but hardly retiring. Two lions in winter, Robert De Niro and Al Pacino, remembering when they were cubs.

headline: Our Readers Made Our Journalism Better in 2019. Here Are 8 Ways.
abstract: Listening to your comments, letters and feedback and incorporating your thoughts made our coverage stronger.
lead_paragraph: “Never read the comments.” It’s an internet cliché. But here at The New York Times, we do read your comments — and your emails, tweets and letters, too.

lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — This year has been marked by widespread social convulsion in Latin America.

headline: Impeachment Through the Eyes of a Child
abstract: In one of our favorite episodes of the year, we spoke with Leo, a third grader, who answered all the questions about the inquiry that you might have been too afraid to ask.

headline: Patriarchy Is Just a Spell
keywords: ['Movies', 'Women and Girls', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Sexual Harassment', '#MeToo Movement']
abstract: I’m outing Alfred Hitchcock’s 1945 thriller ‘Spellbound’ as a #MeToo film.
lead_paragraph: I was in line at a cheese shop, contemplating our dependence throughout life on milk, mothers’ milk (even if we move quickly on to the milk of other species’ mothers, like cow, goat, sheep, buffalo or vegan substitutes, which emerge from mother earth), when it occurred to me that the Alfred Hitchcock movie “Spellbound” is really about sexual harassment. It’s not about Gregory Peck’s goofy psychological problems; it’s an elucidation of women’s problems — with men. Hitch was way ahead of his time: It’s a #MeToo movie released 74 years ago.

headline: What Will It Take to Beat Donald Trump?
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: It’s not what the progressive left is talking about.
lead_paragraph: Bill Clinton and Barack Obama both campaigned for, and won, the White House on the watchword “hope.” What watchword will it take for a Democrat to win this time?

headline: A Football Player’s Mental Health Struggle Led Him Toward New Ambitions
abstract: “I love playing the game of football, but not the other stuff that goes with it,” said Isaiah Woods, now considering a career in design. “I stress myself out way too much.”
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Sports department is revisiting the subjects of some compelling articles from the last year or so. Here is our November 2018 report on a college football player’s battle with depression.

headline: Netanyahu’s Survival Is Tested as Likud Party Holds Leadership Vote
abstract: Israel’s prime minister declares victory over a challenger from within his own party. An exit poll gives him a wide lead.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — With Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s political future on the line — and possibly Israel’s — members of his conservative Likud party voted Thursday on whether to stick with their scandal-scarred leader or replace him ahead of a general election in March.

headline: Reliving the Completely Wild and Totally Surreal 2000 Oscars
abstract: The first Oscars of the new millennium shocked with crime, scandal and Robin Williams dancing in a “South Park” chorus line
lead_paragraph: It started with hysteria. As the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences planned the 72nd Oscars, a growing panic seized the nation: What if all the computers suddenly self-destruct on Jan. 1, 2000, crippling life as we know it?

headline: Self-Checkout in France Sets Off Battle Over a Day of Rest
keywords: ['Shopping and Retail', 'Labor and Jobs', 'E-Commerce', 'Supermarkets and Grocery Stores', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: Besieged by online rivals, retailers are staying open Sunday afternoons with automated cashiers. Critics see an invasion of American-style consumerism.
lead_paragraph: ANGERS, France — On a Sunday afternoon, customers at a Géant Casino supermarket browsed the aisles and lined up to buy meat, fish and other groceries. It was a typical shopping experience except for one thing: All the cashiers had gone home. Customers scanned items at automated checkout stations as security guards hovered nearby.

headline: Male Ally or Apologist?
abstract: My co-worker was eager to talk about women’s issues, until our other colleague started harassing me.
lead_paragraph: I am a woman, and I have worked with two men for a couple of years. One of them has become a good friend and confidant to me. He and I have had numerous conversations about gender issues. So, when our other co-worker began to sexually harass me, I thought I could turn to him for support. Instead, he told me: “I don’t like to get involved in office drama.” He also told me that he still thinks our co-worker is a “really cool guy” and I should give him a second chance. Do I have the right to feel hurt?

abstract: It’s been a wide-open college basketball season and now the pace picks up for the six power conferences.
lead_paragraph: Since the start of the season, the hierarchy of men’s college basketball has been constantly changing.

headline: The Most Popular Properties of 2019
abstract: We tracked your interest, and these are the year’s most-viewed listings.
lead_paragraph: Every week, we track the most-viewed listings on The New York Times’s Find a Home site and report back to our readers. Now, with 2019 nearly behind us, we’ve tabulated the most popular listings of the year. With an average list price of more than $16 million, a strong curiosity for lavish lifestyles is clearly on display. Only one property, a West Village one-bedroom, was listed under $1 million.

headline: What’s Happening to Us? A Visual History of 2019
abstract: America is lonely, unequal and worried. Also maybe needs a snack and a nap. Styles photographers went out to identify magic, anxiety and transformation in 2019.
lead_paragraph: It’s very nearly 2020, an election year in the United States, and by the look of the country on TV and in the newspapers, you’d think every day was spent in bitter acrimony over health care and environmental catastrophe, financial inequality and discussing if we all work for Mark Zuckerberg and Jeff Bezos.

headline: Americans Keep Spending: Holiday Sales Grew 3.4%
abstract: A retail survey showed an 18.8 percent rise in online shopping. Consumer confidence has been bolstered this year by a low unemployment rate.
lead_paragraph: Americans keep spending, driving the economy at a time when unemployment is at a half-century low point despite headwinds from the trade war.

headline: William Kentridge Brings ‘Wozzeck’ Into the Trenches
abstract: The artist’s production of Berg’s brutal opera, updated to World War I, has come to the Metropolitan Opera.
lead_paragraph: Three years ago, on a trip to Johannesburg, I had the chance to watch the artist William Kentridge working on a new production of Alban Berg’s knifelike opera “Wozzeck.” With a troupe of South African performers, Mr. Kentridge blocked out scenes from this bleak tale of a soldier driven to madness and murder — whose setting he was updating to the years around World War I, when it was written, through the hand-drawn animations and low-tech costumes that Metropolitan Opera audiences have seen in his stagings of Berg’s “Lulu” and Shostakovich’s “The Nose.”

headline: Turkey Is Close to Sending Troops to Libya, Erdogan Says
abstract: The Turkish president said his country’s Parliament would soon vote on a deployment, adding to an escalating proxy battle among regional powers.
lead_paragraph: Turkey moved closer to a major military intervention in Libya’s escalating civil war on Thursday, when President Recep Tayyip Erdogan announced a parliamentary vote that could send troops in a matter of weeks to support the embattled government of the North African country.

headline: 5,000 Years of Asian Art in 1 Single, Thrilling Conversation
abstract: The Brooklyn Museum has reinstalled its virtuosic collection of Chinese and Japanese works, stretching from ancient stoneware to contemporary paintings.
lead_paragraph: Redesigning an American museum’s Asian wing is no mean feat. How to convey the very real throughlines that make terms as broad as “Chinese art” and “Japanese art” meaningful, while also doing justice to the staggering variety of these ancient, and hugely populous, cultures? And what if you are also, like every other museum, under pressure to demonstrate the relevance of your antique artifacts to the present moment?

headline: 14-Year-Old Is Released Without Charges in Tessa Majors Case
abstract: He is believed to have wielded the knife that killed her, the police said.
lead_paragraph: [Update: The focus in the Tessa Majors case turned to DNA evidence.]

headline: ‘You Are Killing Us? We Will Make You a Joke.’ Meet Ahmed Albasheer.
abstract: The Iraqi comedian’s TV show is fueling demonstrations in his home country.
lead_paragraph: Last week in the studio where he tapes the “Albasheer Show,” Ahmed Albasheer put on a dark presidential hat and a jacket covered in an absurd amount of medals and gold braid, and sat at his desk in an office adorned with the seal of the president of the Republic of Albasheer.

headline: New Year’s Eve: A Procrastinator’s Guide to Music and Comedy Shows
keywords: ['Pop and Rock Music', 'Comedy and Humor', 'Jazz', 'New Year']
abstract: You can still grab tickets for the Strokes at Barclays Center, jazz in the Village or comedy in Brooklyn. Here’s where to groove, laugh and ring in 2020.
lead_paragraph: ANNALEIGH ASHFORD AND SETH SIKES Known for paying ebullient homage to timeless luminaries including Judy, Liza and Bernadette, Sikes will hail the new decade with nearly century-old tunes in “Twenty ’20s Songs for 2020,” set for 7 p.m. and featuring a seven-piece band. At 11 p.m., stargazers can catch latter-day dynamo Ashford, who has twinkled brightly in Broadway roles ranging from Lauren in “Kinky Boots” to Dot in “Sunday in the Park with George” to Sylvia, a dog (with Matthew Broderick playing her human), in “Sylvia.” Ashford, who will be joined by Will Van Dyke and the Whiskey 5, promises “a little glam rock, glitter, gay magic and some singalongs.” All tickets to her show include a two-course meal, open bar and dessert buffet, with an after-show dance party. Ringside and premium seats entitle each party of two to a half-bottle of champagne and individual dessert platters during the dance party. At Feinstein’s/54 Below, Manhattan; 646-476-3551, 54below.com. (Elysa Gardner)

headline: 8 Ways to Better Navigate the Internet in 2020
abstract: Mind your manners — and your data.
lead_paragraph: If you’re not scared about the personal data you leave behind you as you travel the internet, you haven’t been paying attention.

headline: May Stevens, Who Turned Activism Into Art, Is Dead at 95
abstract: “The reason I’m an artist,” she once said, “is because it’s a place where you can be totally free.”
lead_paragraph: May Stevens, a painter who for more than 60 years devoted her art to political causes like the civil rights, antiwar and feminist movements, died on Dec. 9 in Santa Fe, N.M. She was 95.

headline: Peter Navarro, Trump’s Trade Warrior, Has Not Made His Peace With China
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Customs (Tariff)', 'Protectionism (Trade)', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Mr. Navarro is still looking for ways to punish China even as President Trump has embraced a deal that his top trade adviser lobbied against.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When President Trump gathered his top economic advisers at the White House to decide whether to make a deal with China, Peter Navarro, his hawkish trade adviser, was ready with a flurry of arguments against the move.

headline: Helping Children Understand Death
abstract: There’s no easy way to have those hard conversations about mortality, but these picture books keep the tone calm, peaceful and approachable.
lead_paragraph: At the end of a long day when I was nine months pregnant, my 4-year-old, Winter, asked, “Is Daddy going to die?”

headline: Kate Figes, Feminist Author on Family Life, Dies at 62
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Books and Literature', 'Women and Girls', "Women's Rights", 'Families and Family Life', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth']
abstract: She explored life after childbirth, marriage, infidelity and other topics, and recalled a difficult relationship with her mother, also a feminist author.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Kate Figes, a feminist writer known for her shrewd, sisterly books about family life, among them a primer on the turmoil of new motherhood and investigations into long-term relationships and infidelity, died on Dec. 7 at her home in London. She was 62.

headline: For a Sweet 2020, Look to the Bitter in Wine
abstract: In a balanced wine, bitterness can play a defining role, underlining other flavors while remaining refreshing.
lead_paragraph: Many good wines have a built-in defense against being consumed by children: They are inherently bitter, a flavor that children seem genetically hard-wired to abhor.

headline: Instead of a Merry Christmas, Maybe LeBron Will Have a Happy Birthday
abstract: James turns 35 on Monday and should celebrate, even if his Lakers have lost two games in a row to the rival Clippers.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Witnessing the sight of Patrick Beverley strutting around with a finger aloft and letting the Los Angeles Clippers’ team owner, Steve Ballmer, wrap him up in a triumphant hug is not how LeBron James intended to celebrate Christmas.

headline: Mastering the Mexican Sandwich
abstract: Even the basic tortas are hardly basic at Tortas Morelos in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Even the basic tortas are hardly basic at Tortas Morelos in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn.

headline: Tortas, Comforting and Carefully Considered, in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn
abstract: Yearning for the tortas of Mexico, Juan Velasco pledged to perfect his own. At his restaurant, Tortas Morelos, every detail of the sandwich has been deliberated.
lead_paragraph: An implicit rule in the art of sandwich-making is that texture — lots of it — is good. A handful of chips pressed into soft bread have the power to transform a humdrum sandwich into something infinitely more engaging. With that imperative in mind, the tecolota torta at Tortas Morelos in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, is the epitome of a great sandwich.

headline: What’s the Worst That Could Happen With My Phone Data? Our Journalists Answer Your Questions
keywords: ['Privacy', 'Mobile Applications', 'Smartphones', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Wireless Communications', 'Bluetooth Wireless Technology', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Online Advertising', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Two Times Opinion writers answer readers’ questions on their investigation into how companies track smartphone users and profit off their data.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Opinion desk published an investigation last week into the location data industry, showing how companies quietly collect and profit off the precise movements of smartphone users. The investigation, One Nation, Tracked, explored the dangers that location tracking poses and argued for more regulation around these modern technologies.

headline: Why Bernie Sanders Is Tough to Beat
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: His supporters are loyal, and in Iowa they don’t really have eyes for anyone else.
lead_paragraph: [Read more: Bernie Sanders drops out of 2020 democratic presidential race.]

headline: Finding Joy in the Unknown
abstract: For Jennifer and Charanpaul Singh Gill, chance, luck, and an acceptance of strangers characterized their 20-year marriage.
lead_paragraph: The way you meet your future spouse sets the tone for everything to come, some people believe, much like the opening music in a movie. This has definitely been true for Jennifer and Charanpaul Singh Gill who recently celebrated their 20th wedding anniversary (and appeared in the Vows column on Oct. 31, 1999).

headline: With U.S. Help No Longer Assured, Saudis Try a New Strategy: Talks
keywords: ['International Relations', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Worried that they can no longer count on American defense, the Saudis have begun talking to their enemies to cool conflicts in the region.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — In the months since a missile and drone attack widely seen as the work of Iran left two Saudi oil facilities smoldering, the Saudi crown prince has taken an uncharacteristic turn to diplomacy to cool tensions with his regional enemies.

headline: Review: In ‘Dare Me,’ Cheerleading Is Murder
abstract: A new series on USA combines dreamlike teenage drama and Rust Belt noir while spending a lot of its time in the gym.
lead_paragraph: Do teenage American girls see their lives as dark fever dreams of yearning and danger? I couldn’t say, but television would have you think so. It’s the vision offered by HBO’s popular series “Euphoria,” and also by the show “Euphoria” reportedly beat out for a spot on HBO’s roster. That show, “Dare Me,” ended up at USA, and the 10-episode season that begins Sunday — sexier and more mysterious than the sometimes glibly nihilistic “Euphoria” — shows that first choice isn’t always best.

headline: For Some Jews, a Menorah and a Christmas Tree
abstract: Readers discuss an Op-Ed article about a Jewish mother’s qualms over having a Christmas tree in her home. Also: A slight to Native Americans; good riddance to landlines.

headline: Certain Foods May Help Postmenopausal Women Sleep Better
abstract: Eating foods like vegetables and nuts with a low glycemic index were tied to sounder sleep.
lead_paragraph: The right diet might help you sleep better.

abstract: Readers discuss how today’s audiences should view classic operas from another era that have offensive stereotypes.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: ‘Not My Fault’: Women in Mexico Fight Back Against Violence
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Sexual Harassment', 'Sex Crimes', 'Domestic Violence', "Women's Rights", 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: A new generation is demanding change, casting off the entrenched notion that women somehow provoke attacks against them.
lead_paragraph: ECATEPEC, Mexico — Itan Flores was a young teenager when her first boyfriend imprisoned her for six weeks in a room furnished with just a mattress and a radio. He returned only to rape her, she said, often withholding food and water.

headline: He is Trying to Get Fire Victims Paid. He Has to Find Them First.
abstract: With days left to seek damages from a giant utility, a team fans out in a hard-hit area to get the word to those eligible.
lead_paragraph: PARADISE, Calif. — Unlike a typical holiday food giveaway, the ham, mashed potatoes and green beans packed in bags at Paradise Alliance Church came with a grim reminder of an even deeper need.

headline: Turkey’s Ban on Wikipedia Is Unconstitutional, Court Says
abstract: The country blocked the site in 2017 after Wikipedia refused to remove pages that the government found offensive, including references to its relationship with terrorists and Syrian militants.
lead_paragraph: A high court in Turkey ruled on Thursday that the country’s ban on Wikipedia was unconstitutional, dealing a victory to free speech advocates more than two and a half years after the ban was imposed amid a crackdown on access to information.

headline: Evictions Are Down in New York. Thank the Voters.
keywords: ['Evictions', 'Landlords', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Rent Control and Stabilization', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Law and Legislation', 'State Legislatures']

lead_paragraph: This spring, New York State enacted the strongest tenant protections in a quarter-century. Already, they have made a difference in the lives of thousands of New York City residents.

abstract: There was the 1619 Project, of course, but so much more. Here are a few recommendations from around The New York Times newsroom.
